description:
If you love Science,Nature, and Art. This is a very HOT attraction in SF. 

So many cool science experiments. Great for kids! Every time I come here I leave learning something new about our world and the many elements of art and nature. This is just one of those places that you can't take for granted it really offers so much knowledge and a new way of exploration.  To be alive is to be here to feel the energy of how impactful science and nature is to our world! and the many new ways of thinking when you step outside the box and try new things.. I'm still amazed by all the beautiful artwork and great talent right here in the Bay Area.
author: Liberty D.

description:
Took my 4 year old here and 90% of the stuff was a complete mystery to them. Then there are the kids whom grew up with iPads and iPhones who got bored quickly. 

It is a great place, just depending on age and the mentality of the child or person on hand. When I was young, I enjoyed going to the previous location.
author: M C.

description:
This is a fun place for both kids and adults. It's filled with interactive exhibits that are great for learning some cool science stuff. My toddler had a blast touching and playing with everything, but it may be some time before he'll really start appreciating the learning side of it all.

Note that it gets very crowded here and everyone is touching everything, so you're likely to catch some germs, but I think it's worth the experience.
author: Janet M.

description:
We took our 5 and 6 year old to the Exploratorium and they had a great time!  We all did.  As family-friendly as it gets!  We parked across the street in their dedicated parking lot.  It was mid-week (Thursday) so it wasn't too busy and even though there were a few Jr High school classes in attendance, there was plenty of space for all of us.  Of the hundreds of exhibits there were only a handful of times that one of our kids wanted to see something that was occupied.  

So much to see here!  And when the crew gets hungry there are plenty of food options available.  If you bring your own food there are places to sit around the building or even inside.

We enjoyed stopping in at the gift shop on our way out.  There were items of all prices (high and low) so we all left there happy.  Highly recommend.
author: Ana F.

description: We just so happened to be in the city walking the pier on community day! What a pleasant surprise considering community is pay whatever you want to pay! We donated graciously because tickets aren't inexpensive here although totally worth it! I would suggest this place for children at least 8+younger kids usually have fun but if you're a parent with more then 1 under 6 good luck! They will run around all over the place and try to make things work, they might have a temper tantrum or 2 because they don't really grasp the concept of "science" and how everything works. I love how they have different areas but it's open and you can see from one side to the other. There were plenty of things here to keep the kids busy. It was even fun for he adults! I would imagine that on a weekday in the morning it's really nice to be able to take your time on certain things here but on the weekends when they are packed you have to wait your turn a little bit more. We will definitely be back here!
author: Jade D.

description:
It's amazing! There are so many things to explore, observe, touch and play with. It's perfect for families with kids who can walk. We took our 13 month old and she loved it! Maximum time spent was an hour before the novelty wore off. 

The best value is to get the family ticket for $99 unlimited visits for the year for two adults. Kids under 2 are free.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
This place was so much fun and a huge highlight of my SF trip! 

LOCATION //
It is located right next to Ferry Building, a huge tourist spot. I recommend hitting up both of these areas on the same day! Parking can be tricky but I got dropped off so I can't say much about that.

AMBIANCE //
This museum is for those of all ages. If you are someone who does not want an experience that has a bunch of kids, this is not the place for you. There are a wide variety of people that come here, including families​ with kids, couples, teenagers, and adults! It's extremely loud and there are a LOT of people. 

EXHIBITS //
Overall, there are 6 major exhibits. Honestly, when you walk in, it's almost overwhelming with the amount of stuff to see and experience. Everything was so interesting and interactive to see. I was here for about 3 hours and I was not able to fully experience it all. Exhibits range from color and light, biology, physics, and more! 

OVERALL // 5 stars
I love this place. I'm so glad that my friend took me here for my trip. Even though it was about $25, I would pay it again to come back!
author: Vy P.

description:
How can you not love hands on science experiments and interactive exhibits that teach you about science, nature, and art. My kids especially loved it. The science teacher husband of mine was also very happy and we spent about 3 hours but could easily have spent more.

Of note that my kids especially loved was the exhibit where you make a parachute item and fly it out of a wind tube. They loved the interactive games that you play against each other and the magnetics. They also loved the art area where you do things like see yourself flying, cut in half, lit up.

All of it was quite fun.  There were a few activities that were broken or not functioning, but there was so much that it didn't bother me too much.

It's a little pricey to get in but if you are a teacher you get in free...just sign up on their website.
author: Maureen W.

description:
All i gotta say is I'm thankful for these engineers and the people that passionately keep up with this place. Big or small!

Really really interactive exhibits, lots of things you can learn and enjoy...both as an adult or as a kid. Its like an awesome science class/lab. You just tinker with things and learn tons of cool things.

I was in there for 3-4 hrs because i like to take museums in and spend time with the pieces. So you should definitely have a small snack in your bag cause you'll get hungry fosho if youre anything like me. (Although there is a small food place inside also)

Super kid friendly. Totes cool for dates. Better to come with some folks rather than just yourself. They even have appointments for you to make this cool drawing with marker! Its first come first serve though. Bring a hand sanitizer if youre a germaphobe bc people touch everything (esp kids!) in this museum.
author: Tia M.

description:
Get the kids off the tablets and into this fidget world!

Little brother decided to visit me so this was one of the things on our itinerary. He's 10 years old and loves playing with things, so his mind is growing like crazy. The place has all kinds of the different types of gadgets to play with. Some required some thinking (complete electrical circuits) and most others involved moving things around which really gets the brain thinkin. My favorite was seeing how nature takes over in a time lapse which included beetles and a rat.... (crickets) Yeah, I'm a weirdo.  My brother was very inspired by the visual effects some of the stationed had to offer. 

Unfortunately, some stations were broken or not functioning correctly which I'm sure happens more often than we think.

Other than that, it was a big hit for both of us. Highly recommend taking kids from ages 5 and up here for a visit. I'm 27 and still had fun... guess I'm a kid at heart some days.
author: Lawrence M.

description:
The Exploratorium is a museum that allows visitors to "explore the world through science, art, and human perception". The entire museum is basically exhibit after exhibit that is all very hands-on and offers a very interactive experience.

We came in on a Tuesday afternoon, around 12pm, and it was mildly full. There is A LOT to do and explore. They even do dissections during various set times during the day. I think my favorite exhibit was a series of matching games you do with a buddy. It was hard, but also super thought provoking.

I think there is definitely a lot to do for adults at the Exploratorium - it's not just for little kids. My two big kids had a lot of fun - and I did too.

My friend mentioned that like the California Academy of Sciences, they also do a Thursday After Dark event for adults only. He had gone previously during an After Dark event and really enjoyed it. It's a little less enjoyable when there's a ton of little kids running around, not really understanding the exhibits.

Buy your tickets in advance if you can, because there is a line to buy them on site.
author: Michelle T.

description:
Visited first-time at the Makers Faire edition of Afterdark (Thursday night series). Came 2nd time for the Opening Preview of Inflatable (Friday night). Absolutely loved it!!!!!!!

Afterdark: 

- Interactive facilities: Changing perception, changing the way you experience 5 senses. Unique & unforgettable (Tactile Dome details below). 

- Ambiance: Fun, exciting, playful, chill, people-oriented. Many come to hang out and grab a drink. 

-IG-worthy photo spots, visually stimulating & science-inspired artworks that are both fun & educational. 

- The best thing about Afterdark is that it's of a different theme each time. There is always something new & refreshing to experience. Also, the way they introduce independent artists behind each piece help encourage the community to support the talent. I've become fan to the artists whose works they've brought to the exhibit. 

-First-time trying the Tactile Dome. Had to say, it was a bit scary in an all-dark environment while having to figure your way out. No spoiler. Just tests the way you face the unseen & unknown. Also increases awareness of the 4 other senses, especially touch and sound. 

- Overall a very happy place!
author: Jess W.

description:
Finally the BF and I made our way to this museum. Compared to most museums in the city, so far this one is definitely my favorite. I tend to gravitate over STEM things so naturally this museum with all of its great exhibits were good fun for kids of all ages! Of course, I'm including myself but it's definitely fun for the whole family. We easily spent about 2-3 hours there, but honestly had we had been with others, we could have added an extra hour. Also a must see- the "inflatable" exhibit which showed cool inflatable art. 

They do events in the evening too which I'd love to check out one of these days (those are 21+ events)

Pro tip for out of area visitors: You should definitely plan where you will park ahead of time. Not that it's always expensive, but sometimes it can get crowded at the lots if you don't do the exploratorium's parking.
author: Kimberly B.

description:
This is the first time I've been to the Exploratorium at its new location.  I had a great time.  The museum was not too crowded even though there were a lot of people there.  There were lots of really cool science exhibits that trick your senses and also teach you about how your eyes and ears and different parts work.

It is a great place for kids, but also a cool place for adults who are into this sort of thing.

You can easily spend 3 hours here if you really look at things and engage with the highly interactive exhibits.

I'm not sure people are really reading yelp to help decide if they want to go here or not, but if they are, then I recommend that you check it out!
author: Ty C.

description:
Got the nieces or nephews over? Grand kids visiting your small SF apartment and driving you to the scotch? Give them and yourself a break by taking them to an indoor and outdoor structured place of play and learning. Thousands of hours have gone into planing, devising, and scheming ways to make science and physics learning fun. Plus there are hundreds of other little monsters--ahem children to interact with, which is brilliant! Why, dear mature adult, should you be saddled with socialization when there are other little monsters--ahem children to do that for you?

You're welcome!
author: Lancer K.

description:
I like the Exploratorium! I had not been to this location so it was so fun to explore. I used to love going as a kid. It is a BIG location and I enjoy that they provide a variety of things to explore - electricity, biology, climate, genetics, light, soundwaves, fossils, etc. For kids and adults, this is a great way to explore and play with some interactive things.

It can be quite crowded on the weekends! Prices are $29.95 for general admission. They have discounts for students, etc.

This is a convenient location and I loved how they did the layout of the exhibits. Such a fun time! You can spend maybe 2-4 hours here, depending how much time you want to spend reading/doing the activities.

You may get tired, so there are some places you can sit or there's some food options instead or nearby at the Ferry Building.
author: Natalie M.

description: The exploratorium was so much fun!! I was here on a non free day and everything was open. No lines and no waiting. There's a ton of interesting hands on activites as well as numerous picture opportunities. I enjoyed it because most of the exhibits are interactive and I got to touch everything. We learned a lot about lighting and magnatism. We also tried the tactile room... no pix.. because there was no light! The tactile room was definitly an experience because your basically trying to navigate through a Macdonalds play place in complete darkness. I would like to note someone is watching you stumble through the dark there is no chance of getting lost. Over all would go again and would pay the ticket price to get in on an off day.
author: Alex T.

description:
This "museum" was pretty cool. I liked that there were so many different sections to check out and a lot of gadgets for everyone to use. This place is kid friendly and it was nice to go somewhere where the kids can touch everything! I do have to say you probably need to have a very high interest in science because although I though it was neat I think kids might find it a little boring. 

But overall this was a good trip if you're coming to SF and need something to do with the family.
author: Aliya T.

description:
A lot of fun experiments for kids to experience! 
My 2 years old have so much fun here! 
All the kids don't wanna leave u til they cut the electricity at 5 when they close. XD
author: Ashley G.

description:
It's wonderful and there is tons and tons to see and do, both inside and outside. I think the best strategy is to hone in on one area to explore and just focus there, otherwise it can be overwhelming. I began bringing my son here when he was three, but I think he only started to really enjoy and appreciate it once he was five or six.

Docking one store for lack of staff/support presence.

The little café on the corner by the north entrance has amazing "cowboy bars". Really yummy! Lots of healthy kid options for food.

Some pics from a recent field trip.
author: Camille L.

description: Went with my kids and ended up spending the whole day.  Amazing variety of variety of hands on science.  Pro tip: bring a picnic lunch and your are encouraged to sit and eat anywhere you like.  Admission price is high, so spend the whole day.
author: Helene W.

description:
So much fun! My bf and I spent the entire day there. The new location is huge. There's so much things to look at and do. You can learn about light, sound, animals, etc.My favorite section is the biology section which will be completed in 2019. There is $20 all day parking right across from the exploratorium.

I'd recommend going later in the day or going thursday night for the after dark hrs to avoid the children. I'd also give yourself at least 4-5 hrs minimum to spend there.
author: Sebo W.

description:
I finally made it out to Exploratoriurm After Dark!  The event is on Thursday evenings and is open to adults 21+.  I loved the concept of having the space and time to enjoy this hands on museum and not feel bad for taking up an exhibit over a kid, like during regular hours.  They also have cocktails, beer, and wine for purchase inside.  

The Exploratorium is huge!  It is a place you can come back time and time again to see your favorite exhibits or check out new ones.  It was pretty crowded when we went and the lines for drinks was pretty long.  They also didn't have that many bars so that probably didn't help.  It resulted in us only getting one beer since we didn't want to waste our entire time in line.   

The hands on exhibits is what makes this place.  Many have been around since I was a child, but they are still engaging to play with.  I personally loved the light wall and the mono color room.  I also enjoyed the walk inside pinhole camera outside where you can see the bay bridge on the table.  

Considering it's a quick walk from Embarcadero BART, it is a must see for children and adults alike.
author: Stacey C.

description: Lots of exhibits to play with but gets crowded on weekends.  Take BART and walk a few blocks, very convenient.
author: J W.

description: Amazing, amazing, amazing. Genius idea, fun execution, and so much fun for people of all ages! I can't believe that I haven't been here multiple times yet. During the day, understandably, it's overrun with little kids. Once you figure out how to maneuver around them, it's pretty enjoyable as there's so many different stations to use, words to read, and knowledge to gain. My favorite had to be the visual section where there's a bunch of mirrors that warp your vision in various ways. Spent quite a time over there freaking myself out. I also enjoyed the random art that was featured, especially this octopus looking thing that moved and lit up when you did. Great afternoon spent with the coworkers. I will definitely be going back, possibly to try the Exploratorium after dark for adults. I've heard booze is involved.
author: Liz B.

description: LOVE this place! Everything is hands on and so interactive for kids. I think my kid is a tiny bit young for it though, he's 16 months old so he can't really interact with all the stuff and comprehend everything that's going on. Regardless, he still had a blast with all the areas that had lights and stuff he could run around. I can't wait to bring him back when he's a little bit older!
author: Lisa D.

description:
Looking for something to do w/ the toddler, so we went here during our stay in SF on 12/23 Saturday morning. Spent $15 for parking at nearby Pier 19 (indoor parking in a large warehouse), it's discounted if you tell them you are visiting the Exploratorium. Beats having to find street parking!

We got tickets for 2 adults and our toddler was free. Thinking we could spend at least 3+ hours here, we ended up only staying 1 hour since the husband had food poisoning from lunch, and we had to leave quickly. 

We will be back again to explore the rest of the exhibits! :)
author: Yonnie C.

description:
This is an awesome museum, and I definitely recommend checking it out. It's super hands on and you get to see amazing sculptures and experience weird things. 

When coming here, you should drink from the toilet. No really! You will see! There is also a really cool wall which you can write anything on with your phone flashlight. In gallery 3, there are really cool lights projecting rainbow in the whole room, super cool. 

Buying food here might be a bit expensive, but that's the same case in every museum. Compared to other museums, this is definitely on the cheaper side. There are also a lot of options.
 
Overall, my experience here was pretty cool and I would come here again.
author: Felicia C.

description: A nice place to reconnect yourself with the scientific phenomenas and a cool place to hangout with some science enthusiasts.
author: Sharad B.

description: This place is cool and definitely meant for kids. However my husband and I had heard about it and wanted to check it out. We can be kids too right? Lol my main complaint with this place is the price of admission. $30 a head is a lot, especially if you don't plan on being there for hours. Otherwise, the exhibits were cool and interesting and when you can get on one (bc it's non stop busy) they're fun.
author: Heather W.

description:
If someone asked me on a first date and suggested we go to the Exploratorium I tell you what I may have found the one. In fact, I would go on dates 1-10 to the Exploratorium because there's just so much to do here. Checked it out on a Sunday afternoon with a group of friends (we're all in our late 20s mind you) and thought we would only spend an hour tops here. Three hours later, we had only explored two of the seven (?) galleries. 

The highlight was the tactile room* where you're immersed in total darkness and have to find your way to the end. DO YOU LIKE SCARY MOVIES?! I don't but this was really fun and freaky. 

*Note: you have to buy separate tickets to the tactile room
author: Nancy L.

description: My favorite museum in the city, have never been able to feel I come close to finish it.
author: Natali M.

description: The best museum for kid in the Bay Area. Lots of interactive exhibits and a great, friendly staff. Young kids will want to spend 3+ hours here to try all the experiments. The museum is definitely worth the entrance fee. The only draw back is high to find parking in the area.
author: Mark H.

description: Exploratorium is the best place to visit for tourists. Having a good location, Exploratorium could be visited by thousands of people every day. I brought my friends to visit Exporatorium and they were impressed by the beauty inside. It is a lot of things to do inside, a lot to explore and to share the opinions.  It is a great place to learn something new and to have fun. I recommend bringing your children to the Exploratorium as they have different activities for them.
author: Elena L.

description:
Come here yearly with the class for a field trip, the kids love it. There is so much to see that we are never able to fit it all in with one visit. Each time we come back we see things that we never saw before but yet we thought we saw it all last time.
Weekdays do get crazy packed with kids on field trips so if your coming for a trip with family or solo I would avoid early hours on weekdays or you will be knocked over by excited kids.
author: BRANDI P.

description:
I haven't been here in years up until two days ago. Let's start off with parking. There is no specific parking lot/garage for this facility. So, being in San Fran, good luck. It took me about 10 min to find a parking garage with open spaces available and another 10-12 min to walk to the Exploratorium. I'd like to point out it was a Friday so I'm sure it was busier than during then Mon -Thur. Also, try to find the closest possible parking because after a very fun and tiring day here, the kids did not want to walk a good 10+ min when we left left. 

So, for the Exploratorium itself. It is a little pricey but worth it! 30 for adults and 20 for kids. I paid 10 dollars more and got a season pass. It made sense for the amount of people I had with me. 3 and under are free!! The kids were so excited. The kids ages ranged from 2 to 11. There is SO... much to see and do there. We got there at 12ish and stayed until 5 and we didn't even finish the whole thing. (Good thing i got the season pass) it's even fun for adults. A great learning and hands on experience for all ages! We even got to see a cow eye ball Dissection. The facility is clean, and everything is kept up well. Also, make sure to go outside, there some fun stuff out there too! 

The only bad thing I didn't like was the sea glass restaurant. All the staff there were not friendly especially the guy at the register! He didn't greet me, I asked where can I find a fork he pointed to the table to his left and then when he rang everything up he didn't even tell me my total! LEGIT didn't say one word to me! So rude! I later seen another staff member ask him if he was ok, like maybe he was having a bad day. BUT I'm sorry, that behavior was unacceptable! I watched him do it the almost 45min-to a hour that I was there to every customer! I paid almost 60.00 in food!! So overpriced, for blah food, and it's not even kid friendly! $9.00 for one hotdog! Next time, I'm bring lunch and eating outside! 

Overall, we had a good time! We intended on going to pier 39 after but honestly, we were all drained and didn't have the energy. It's a all day trip. And they close at 5 so, get there early so you can take your time and not feel rushed to finish everything. 

P.S. they have lockers you can rent for 50 cents inside and HUGE lockers outside for the same price.
author: Suzy R.

description:
I've seen social media posts about this place but never really explored to see where it really was. Little did I know it was on the pier. Here was my experience on a Sunday morning (Free Museum day)

AMBIANCE:
Parking: There's street parking and plaza parking, it is SF so the best recommendation is to come early and plan your trip accordingly.

Feels: It's freakin SF! You're close to the pier and a lot of spots are a fair reasonable walking distance (Fairie, Pier 39, etc). You get a gorgeous view of SF and the Bay Bridge. The museum itself is amazing. As a hands on type of person, I enjoyed all the activities here. It made me think, be creative, and have fun. Great place for all ages and types of vibes whether it may be just touristing or datenighting it up.

CUSTOMER SERVICE: 
The people there were knowledgeable, friendly, and patient. Vibes that make SF, SF.

TL; DR OVERALL:
5 Stars. Love, love, love. From the proximity, the views, to the exhibits. It's a great place to learn or take good photo ops. I would love to come back here again. 

TIPS:
* Look into their website for free admission days
author: Leland S.

description:
I visited the Exploratorium on a recent visit to San Fran, and it was soooo awesome!  I did go in the midafternoon, and there were about 7 million children there, literally 7 million.  But by 5 pm-ish it definitely slowed down and was more chill.  Next time I visit I will definitely be doing the adults only after hours version of the museum.  

The exhibits were SO cool, museum was huge and had several main areas.  I learned a ton as I went through each area, and it was so cool to be able to participate directly in the exhibits.  I ended up spending about 3 hours wandering around and exploring.  My favorites were definitely the animal area with the fish, gerbils, etc, as well as the light and illusion exhibits.  Super cool place, will definitely visit again.

The store was also awesome, tons of science-y stuff to take home.
author: Laura G.

description:
This was my second time coming here. There was so much to do. We didn't even go through all of the exhibits. The first time I came here we didn't go through all of the exhibits. 

If you come here, here are my tips: wear comfortable shoes, bring snacks and water for your kids and yourself, make sure before you eat you wash your hands (mostly all of the exhibits are hands on), bring your patience cap (it can get real busy on weekends and during the summer), take time to sit (most exhibits are standing).

Enjoy!
author: Dorothy B.

description:
How have I not reviewed this yet?! 

Not much left to say, really. It's one of my favorite places to take out of towners and people of all ages come out of there having learned something and exhausted from having so much fun. No matter how many times I've been there, I never get tired of it. 

If you have the extra money to try the Tectile Dome, I recommend it! You go into a pitch black room and you basically have to feel your way out of there! 

I recently attended an After Dark event, and it was a lot more fun than I expected. Seeds were the topic of discussion and they created samples, drinks and a mini dissection to keep you entertained and educated. 

Highly recommend the Explortorium.
author: Michelle C.

description: Came here with my friends and I was really looking forward on going to this museum since its an interactive one. We came on a Saturday afternoon so it was pretty busy filled with kids but my friends and I still had a good time. We took our time going through each room and we really enjoyed this photo booth looking one and also this mirror one. I would def recommend going to this museum because it was really fun and I think anyone of any age will enjoy!
author: Alexa-Ferl S.

description:
Spyglass restaurant 

Observation deck

$3.25/hour 9-12.

$4/ 12-3pm.

Front and Green Street
author: Jboogie L.

description:
I have always loved the Exploratorium since going to the old location every year as a kid.
My first time to the new site was a bit of a disappointment. It was for the Thursday night "After Dark" evening for adults. It was a bit frustrating as so many people were there...not one exhibit was free to play with, the lines for the bars were long. It felt like everyone there was using it as their Happy Hour option (average age was maybe 26).
author: Amy O.

description:
I've been to many different types of science centers and Exploratorium and this one by far is one of the best ones with lots of interactive things for both children and adults. 

We didn't do the food restaurants here but it's nice because you can come and go with the stamp throughout the course of the day. The staff was pretty helpful in terms of pointing out things when needed and they have lots of lab displays going on throughout the day in each of the six different areas. Going on 4+ hours of being here and we still haven't really covered everything but ideally you could probably do it all in about 3 hours and then head out. Expect field trip groups from the YMCA or schools to be here but don't worry plenty of activities to keep everybody's hands full.

The one thing I'm not a fan of is the $30 price ticket for an adult!! Trust me I get it but I'm not doing much of anything but wandering and reading.Tthe $20 price tag for the kids is pretty pricey too. Hence that's why we stayed 4+ hours as I wanted my money's worth!!! It is the Bay Area and things are pricy, but was expecting a lot more bang for our buck!
author: Omari D.

description:
There should be more places like the Exploratorium...hands on science that engage, fascinate and educate minds both young and old. The level of creativity in this place never ceases to amaze me and I'm just about as interested in the displays as I am about the people who create them and set-up these displays. Who are they? What informs their ideas? What is the mojo that leads them to come up with these creative works? It's down-right fantastic. It's like sunshine on a cloudy day!

And the new location works too, a great addition to the pier...and it makes sense too with the ocean being right there!

Better still, I was here because I was chaperoning children from a poorer section of the Bay area. The Exploratorium provided both the BART tickets and entry to this place. Talk about good! The impact will be felt beyond typical measurement!

Thanks Exploratorium!
author: Ron C.

description: I haven't been here in years, like since it was at it's old location. I remembered having so much fun as a child, cow eyeball dissections and crazy hands on creations. I wasn't sure how it would be coming as an adult, I definitely was pleasantly surprised. Different location, same amazing layout, cow eyeball dissections still happening. This is a place for young and old, those who are deep thinkers and those who just go with the flow. Whether you're in awe of seeing a project function, or in awe as you read the details of how it works, this is a place that has something for everyone.
author: Kailee L.

description:
Fun, FUn, FUN!!! This new site of the Exploratorium is at Pier 15. I chaperoned 4 boys for my son's second grade field trip and we all had a blast. Upwards of 100 new or updated exhibits was a definite plus. My personal favorite was the "How quiet can you walk" (we are louder than we think!). The kids even enjoyed the cow eye ball (ewww) interactive session. There is a small gift shop and cafe onsite. Reading the exhibit descriptions not only helps understanding but makes each one most entertaining. 

Parking can be pricey. Plan to spend at least $15 if you don't find street parking for less.

I'll definitely return with the fambam.
author: Nydia S.

description:
Exploratorium, wait a minute didn't you used to live by the Palace of Fine Arts? I could've have sworn you did! When, I was a younger version of myself, I dreamed of being a scientist. Places like the Exploratorium kept the inner child in me always craving to learn. So now that I am an adult and not a scientist it's nice to know that I left my inner little child that I left child in the walls of these museums.

The place is not just a museum, it is an Interactive Art and Science imagination feeding, curiosity sparking, propelled perception of experiences that make you realize how little in life you actually know. 

The Exploratorium now caters to everyone. On certain nights they have the Exploratorium after Dark, sometimes they show presentations and documentaries and also a older crowd is here just in case you're the type of person who does not really like children.... (yeah, there are evil people like that).

Everything in this place is completely Hands-On which will keep you engaged. It's one of the best interactive museums for family or as a single person, or maybe even a date night.

You can get parking across the street I'm not too sure but maybe they do validate, if you visit the museum. At times the place can be overcrowded so plan accordingly to when you want to go. 

If you are a teacher you can sign online and GET FREE entrance admission. Another thing that's very popular here is something called the tactile Dome, you know what you have to pay separately for... but if you want to experience something truly unique. I say go for it! 

This is definitely not the last time I come to visit this place.
author: Michael R.

description:
$25 for students ABSOLUTELY worth it! This place is fun, informative, and interactive. There were 6 exhibits, some more fun than others. I came here with my boyfriend and we spent over 4 hours here. We did come on a weekend so there were a LOT of people, but if you pass the big crowds in the first exhibit it gets less crowded.  

I would recommend here for any age.
author: T V.

description: I have been coming here since I was a kid and take my kids here.  Amazing experience and something gained every time we visit.  Not only for kids.  Something for everybody!  On the Embarcadero, easy to do with Pier 39 or whatever to fill your day.
author: Chris G.

description:
Located on Pier 15, the Exploratorium is a large, interactive museum with exhibits combining science, art, and fun in the fields of biology, physics, chemistry, and even sociology/psychology.  Its easy to spend a few hours here and get a decent walking workout.  Be warned that the place is overwhelmed with kids.  I'm all for encouraging young ones to get interested in STEM, especially if the parents spend time explaining the science to them.  Along with teaching manners and discipline as well!

Still, its a nice museum that has lots of cool things to see and do.  It just takes some patience to wait your turn on some of the exhibits.  I spent my entire academic and professional career in the sciences, yet I still found plenty of things to learn in the Exploratorium!
author: Daniel C.

description: An incredible place for children and adults alike! I took my fiance here for his 26th birthday. It was so much fun, we were there from the time it opened until it closed. We went during the day on Friday so it was not crowded and we could explore the exhibits. It was fun experimenting with science and also very educational. We spent all day there and only made it through 2 areas of the Exploratorium. There is so much to explore and learn from at this museum, its amazing. If i visited SF more often I would surely get a season pass. An overall engaging, educational, and fun museum! 10/10 will visit again!
author: Erin L.

description:
This is one of two go-to places with my little one on a rainy day in SF, it's a feast for the mind and the senses!

Really well run and thoughtfully laid out, it's designed for family-friendly exploration. You do need to keep an eye on the little ones, though, it's quite possible to have some harm done without monitoring some of the interaction with the exhibits.  That said, you can still relax and have fun.

Pro tip: We have an annual family membership and it paid for itself after 2-3 visits, and I think that was within 2 months.
author: Saminda W.

description: This place is awesome.  We spent like 4 hours here but could have easily spent twice as long.  Enough to keep you amused for days.  If you are visiting San Francisco with kids this place is a must.  If you are visiting without kids, its still a must.
author: Zen D.

description:
Though there were kids running everywhere, if I was single, and a guy takes me here for a date, I'd be very impressed. That being said, when I have kids, I will definitely get a membership and just send my kids here all the time. Exploratorium manager, if you are reading this, I hope you develop a daycare program, sometimes in the next 5 years. 

This is an interactive science museum, with some cool art, all aiming to teach you physics, math, biology, chemistry, psychology, etc. The exhibits' "pre-requisite" various greatly, so all ages will enjoy them. 

Tips:
1. Rest well the night before and come early, there is SO much stuff to look at! We were there for 4 hours and saw maybe 1/3. 
2. Wear comfortable clothes and shoes.
3. Do not wear rings. Most of the stuff are interactive and you will want to touch everything. I wore rings and they were inconvenient. 
3. Don't try to coordinate with friends. There are too many interesting things for you to worry about keeping a big group together. People will get distracted by different things, let them, and enjoy being a kid again.
author: Tata X.

description:
We went there with our 5.5 year old son. The line for ticket is long so see if you can buy the tickets in advance to avoid standing in line for 10-15 Min

All exhibits are interesting and fun for kids, our son enjoyed many of them.
You can easily spend 2-3 hours here. You will find frequent bench for tired feet in case you have older party with you.

About the cafe:
The hamburger and fries was good. It's a quick grab and go, it has a few tables outside.

We will probably return.
author: Afshan L.

description:
We were here from open to close, that's how AMAZING it is! Since it was a Friday at 10 am when we arrived, there were A LOT of kiddos on field trips running around. It didn't bother me at all, it was really cute to see them exploring. But, I think it's worth mentioning because if you're looking to explore without children in the mix I recommend checking out the adult night. 

We played in the Tinker Lab for about an hour and had way too much fun making our own little sound making trinkets with Legos. The folks that were working that part of the museum were also so engaged in their work and enthusiastic about teaching us what to do that the experience felt even more special. 

Highly recommend this place for kids and adults!
author: Erika M.

description:
We came there while visiting in SF, had lots of fun (even thogh we are 35+ But better for kids  ) 
It is very big, so come with the right shoes...
author: Nicole H.

description:
Currently, they have the wild card exhibit. It's a small walk through of things made from cardboard.

My kids enjoyed all the cool hands on activities. It's dark inside. 

There is also an outdoor exhibit. Check out the distorted house. 

Teachers get in free. Just fill out the form on the website and you will receive an email immediately.

We found meter parking. 

Restrooms were decent.
author: Jenny L.

description: Throwback to the 'Science Station' from my hometown. An excellent place for adults as well as children. We went there for the afternoon and had a great time. A huge array of science based displays that encourage learning and/or refreshing ourselves on basic scientific principles, etc. An inquisitive mind can get lost here for hours of entertainment and come out having learned something.
author: Christopher Y A.

description: Very fun experience for all ages! We were there for 3.5 hours & still weren't able to see everything.
author: Erin H.

description:
You know that someone is a dedicated Yelper - or at least a Yelp Elite - when he/she tries to put a significant review on a number that's evenly divisible by 100.  (There, that should secure my Elite status for next year, right Steph?)  My significant review is the most unusual major museum in San Francisco.

The Exploratorium is a "please touch me" museum, geared especially for upper elementary kids and suitable for all.  The ticket prices are in line with other museums in The City, and there are free days throughout the year.  Located a half mile up the waterfront from the Ferry Building.  Parking is a major issue, as is typical in SF.  It is absolutely fitting for an entire morning, afternoon, or even day, to center around a visit to the Exploratorium.

Science is king here, and the Exploratorium shows the practical & fun side of science.  Kids see physics in action, natural demonstrations, psychological experiments, and musical interludes.  But no boring lectures, nosirree.  Here's a very small sample, based on what my daughter did:
* Felt five different kinds of rain, from a light drizzle in San Francisco to a heavy downpour in Durban
* Saw why you shouldn't always trust your feelings as we played a "Let's Make A Deal" game of which door the prize is behind
* Learned exactly where to place the beach ball so that the air current keeps it in the air all the time
* Heard how a musical score can tell a completely different story to a movie depending on its style
* Created her own tornado
* Shared an echo chamber with her dad;  she tweeted like a bird while I shouted Scripture
* Laughed when (and because) she saw a video of other people laughing
* Got a video of her expression when she was startled by a puff of air in her face
* Stuck her finger in a machine that told of her emotional state when different questions were read
But wait, there's more - so much more!

She had been to the Exploratorium on a school field trip.  I last went to the Exploratorium when it was at the Palace of Fine Arts.  It was worth a second visit.  And would also be worth many more visits.  If you're visiting San Francisco, this is a must-see attraction.
author: Ron L.

description:
Holy cow.

Wow!

This place.

This place.

I genuinely don't have words to describe how much fun I had! I didn't really think it would be particularly exciting to be honest. Some cool science things, maybe a couple of neat exhibits... probably something to run through in maybe 45-60minutes tops.

What ensued was over three hours of fun, an unwillingness to leave, and an urge to go back again. This interactive museum, is it really a museum though?, provides for fun of all ages with really cool interactive ...well... everything. Learn about weather systems, learn about death, learn about lighting, learn about sound, learn how to walk quietly, learn about kinetic movement. Everywhere you go is an interactive learning experience that really immerses you in the entire experience.

The one complaint I had was that the kids would often just run over to a cool exhibit and just start to play around with it - the concept of lines seemed to escape many of them. And I get it, at the end of the day the museum is probably geared more towards kids but there were some really cool things that I wanted to try and do but so did a lot of kids and they kept rushing to the exhibit and pushing me out. It would not be becoming to push the kids out of the way in situations like this. So, if you're an adult, and going only with adults, I would recommend going on an "Adult's Night" or whatever equivalent event they may have (and if they don't have one, they need one!).

Otherwise, I was seriously blown away and even though I spent several hours in the museum I feel like it was totally worth my time. Even if you're just visiting SF, for the first time or the one hundredth time, this is totally worth the stop, especially since it's right along the pier and you can get a great view of the city.

Everything about this place is perfect and - if you're into Instagram or cool social media photos - you'll definitely manage to get many good ones here.
author: John T.

description:
What an amazing museum! We came here right after 10AM with an intention of leaving around lunch time, but ended up staying the entire day, with  a leisurely lunch break at the Seaglass restaurant. 
The place is huge, with a ton of hands-on exhibits, all grouped by themes - magnets, properties of light, properties of sound etc, most of the displays are appropriate for all ages. 
My husband and the 8yo gravitated towards more complex displays. They are both very technical and inquisitive, and had a great time.
I explored with our 6yo, and not being of much technical acumen, I had an absolute blast as well.

A few things to note:
Weekday Mornings are busy with school groups. Weekday evenings are not crowded at all.

The admission is pricy, and the place is huge. Come here prepared to spend the day and make it worth it.

The Tactile Experience is best to be explored together (it's more fun and more interactive that way). No kids younger than 7yo are allowed. If it's not crowded, they will let you go through a couple of times.

A few exhibits are outside, bring a hoodie, as it gets a bit breezy

Sea-glass restaurant is not cheap, but is incredibly convenient AND has a full bar. The food is healthy, and delicious. The drinks are mixed the right way and from good ingredients, not from store bought mixes. 

Gift shop is amazing. 

Enjoy being a kid again!
author: Katherine G.

description:
Yeah, science!

I would recommend this museum for anyone who both loves and hates science. Obviously for science fans, this is an awesome place to reengage with astronomy, colors, chemistry, oceans, the atmosphere, electricity, food, geology, etc. And for those who don't like science, I think this is a fantastic place to truly learn and explore. It's very hands-on, interactive, but not pretentious or even super hi-tech. 

There are so many different and unique activities to see, touch, smell, and hear. Since it's mostly geared for kids, this museum is like a lab and scientific amusement park rolled in one. There are over 600 participatory exhibits, and the exhibits rotate. I got through a decent number of the exhibits, but it definitely took several hours. I was there until they closed.

The museum itself, located at Pier 15, has a net-zero energy goal. As a result, the museum has several sustainability efforts such as an array of PV and an HVAC system that takes advantage of the bay water underneath the piers. Science for the win!

It takes awhile to get through all the exhibits, both because there are so many and also because there's a lot of people at any one exhibit. Adult tickets are $29.95 and youth (4-12) tickets are $19.95. There are five annual free days.
author: Alice W.

description:
Great place for kids AND adults. Could easily spend three hours with the kids. So many things to do and explore. Well worth it. 

Parking is available at Pier 19 1/2 for $20 (enter Exploratorium discount code posted at the lot and on the Exploratorium website. Take note, make sure you do not leave anything in your car. Two cars were broken into (smashed rear windows) while we were there. Be very cautious.
author: Falcon J.

description:
A great hands on exploration for children and adults alike.  They encourage you to touch the exhibits and be curious.  What a wonderful place to make connection for a curious mind.  

There's outdoors exhibits too.  About a 15-20 min walk from the Embarcadero muni, right by the waterfront. Everyone should go there at least once, more so if you have children.
author: Elaine Y.

description: it's ok... but WAY overpriced for what you get.  I'll pack a lunch next time for sure.
author: John C.

description:
It's the very place for family explore the science, amazing experience. 
It's easy to find and you can enjoy it for a whole daytime. The outdoor exhibition is also very interesting. I like the movie in Cinema a lot.
author: Tong Z.

description:
I visited the Exploratorium on one of their free dates that was sponsored. The line ups even though were massive, didn't take us a long time to go inside the Exploratorium.

This place is like a centre for exploration and discovery with tons of interactive things to do with different focuses in each interactive activity! We went when it was free, so it was a little more packed than I had hoped it would be!

One of the things I really appreciated was the wood sculpture that keeps adding on every year! The Exploratorium is a place for people of all ages - definitely a great place to go with your family!
author: Kristy N.

description:
MAN I wish I lived in San Francisco because I'd have an annual pass to the Exploratorium and go weekly! This is one of those awesome places where fun, curiosity, and learning come together into an awesome experience!  

The interactive attractions are divided into areas and most are easy to accommodate to a variety of ages. For example, the photo-sensitive shadow room: Toddlers can stand and create a shadow, kids can countdown and then jump and make crazy shadows, tweens and teens can "draw" using the lights from their mobile phones and parents can do all of the above and take super fun photos that make great memories!

There are also 2 super cool gift shops that I'd buy EVERY gift for future birthday party invites from because they're so unique and amazing!

We didn't totally love the food at the Seismic Joint Cafe. Everything was expensive and 2 drastically different pasta dishes both tasted like lemon (see my review on the restaurant separately). We'd bring our own snack bars next time.

Our Three-Thumb Review is 3 Thumbs way up!  My teen son really loved the challenge of doing the Morse Code correctly.  My tween daughter loved the machine that made ice instantly! I loved the Tactile Dome (check out my full review separately)! Truthfully though, we couldn't get enough of the whole place! Plus they loved the many spots that offered unique selfie and Instagrammable moments! The only challenge is - it's huge!  Not a problem for residents, just means tourists better plan a return trip or consider setting aside almost a whole day. This place appeals to all ages from toddler to vintage!   

#ThreeThumbReviews #Maze #Touch #Museum #Tactile #Dome #FamilyFun #Adventure #vacation #Family #getaway #Children #KidFriendly #SanFrancisco #Roadtrip #Exploratorium #Pier15 #blogger #makesmewander
author: Sarah H.

description:
Wonderful museum!

So much to see and do to please all ages and diverse group, probably why the prices are high and they don't feel the need to do have reciprocity w/other aquariums, museums, and zoos across the country
author: Melissa K.

description:
I can't add more to any of the good things that have been said about this place - this museum is fun for kids AND adults... there's a lot of interactive exhibits and cool things to see.  In my mind, the Exploratorium is the perfect example of art + technology. A lot of the exhibits, while scientific, also have an artistic element to them. Plus there's something for everyone (assuming you like some form of science) - their exhibits cover topics from light, sound, social science, mechanics, physics, electronics, biology and geology.

Some memorable exhibits (there's a ton of them) are the toilet fountain, the toothpick sculpture held together by glue, the monochromatic room, and the dry ice comets. One example of a great interactive exhibit is this booth where you have to step over gravel but make the least amount of noise (super hard). Another one has you play with an infared camera and a shadow box camera. It's all good, creative fun.

The location is also convenient. It's super easy to get to via public transportation - you can take the F line from Market St to get here. Or if you plan on parking, the Golden Gateway garage has a good rate of $8 for a whole weekend day (it's within walking distance). If you're looking for food, just walk along the pier towards the Ferry Plaza Market for lunch/dinner before or after!

Sure you may think admission is pricey, but I think you get your money's worth as there's more to do and it's (IMO) better than the California Academy of Sciences, the Tech Museum in San Jose, and the Pacific Science Center in Seattle (I'm a science museum nut). They have free days that are posted on their website as well as discounted Thursday nights for adults only. I can give a quick review on each of those visits:

- After Dark (Thursday in August): For $15 on Thursday Evenings the Exploratorium is only open to adults - it's a hip and relaxing atmosphere. No kids to hog the exhibits and crowds of people to weave through. Literally got to spend some time playing with some of my fav exhibits. It's a great place to bring a date to, since there's a lot to see or do. Even if the date sucks you can at least have fun looking at things. They even serve alcohol, which in some cases makes the exhibits more entertaining.

- Free Community Day (Sat in September): The weather was super nice, but there was a long line to get in. They limit the number of people in the building at once and would let people in as people left - luckily my sis and I only ended up standing outside for ~15-20 min, and this was when Pokemon Go was popular so we had something to do while waiting. =P The inside was REALLY crowded... it was little hard to get to play with any of the exhibits because the children took priority. Walking through the hall with all the electrical activities was difficult. Hell a fight almost broke out between a mom and a guy who pushed her kid off an exhibit.

- Free Community Day (Sun in January): Weather was cold and rainy... unlike the last free day I went to, there was hardly a line to get in and it was much less crowded than the Sept visit. Guess Bay Area folks are afraid from the rain (but not this couple from Seattle!). Still a lot of people compared to the After Dark visit, but more manageable. I got to play with more of the exhibits too, though the kids were still obnoxious at times.

If you want to come here an have to the capability of going on a Thursday... do it. Great way to meet people. If you're a cheap ass like me and want to go on their Free Days, just be mentally prepared for the crowds. Otherwise I highly recommend people visit this museum - it's great.
author: Alyanna C.

description:
Id definitely recommend going to the after dark sessions if you are an adult because during the day this place is overrun with kids. There are school groups in every section which makes it hard to really interact with each of the exhibits. 

Having said that, this is a cool museum. Lots of things to do and learn about. The shop is also great for interesting and educational gifts.
author: Christie W.

description:
We brought our 9, 7 and 5 year old here today, it was a fantastic experience! There's so much to see, touch and play with. 
You may not be able to see everything in one visit. 

What I great memory for our family
author: Amy C.

description:
Wonderful way to spend some time with kids that are allowed to touch and explore anything! Age range from 1 to 28, and this place kept everyone entertained. Caught more of the adults hogging up the stations than kids :)

Not too crowded on a Saturday afternoon, so many stations that kept everyone's attention while most were still open.
author: Dina Y.

description:
I really enjoy interactive museums, and this place is no exception. This was by far the best museum I've ever been too - it is completely different from a traditional museum, in that every exhibit has an interactive educational experience. This place is good for all ages. I could come here every week just to show different friends this cool experience. 

This is also a great place for a date! You won't have awkward silences or get bored because of all the activities and people around you. This shoukd not only be a tourist spot, but also a local favorite. We are so lucky to have such a unique museum in the bay area!
author: Darrell T.

description:
Love this museum! It's perfect for all ages, even younger kids. You can play and interact with all of the exhibits because there's no tape on the floor telling you to stay three feet away. Summers are always packed with people lining up to play with the exhibits. During the school day, classrooms from around the bay usually visit in groups. If you're looking to play with each of the exhibits, go on a weekday to avoid the crowd. 

The museum is divided into different subjects, including a psychology, physics, art, vision, biology, and an observatory section. The view is amazing, especially from the observatory located in the back. There's a great view of the Bay bridge and downtown San Francisco. Watch the ocean for a bit and you will likely see some sea otters frolicking in the Bay. 

My favorite part of the museum is the tinkering studio. I was able to make a toy and take it home. The explainers in the area walked me through how to make the toy. 

The restaurant in the museum has good food, especially the ramen. It's pricey, but it's better than your average museum food. If you're looking to explore more of San Francisco, Pier 39 is a fifteen minute walk away along the pier or Embarcadero which is a ten minute walk. 

This is also a great museum for adults, especially on Thursday nights where entrance is 18+, and drinks for 21+. The first Thursday of each month is also themed. 

They also offer some free days throughout the year, so look out for those.

TLDR; Go the Exploratorium, you won't regret it!!
author: Sophia L.

description:
Situated on Piers 15 and 17 in San Francisco's Embarcadero, the Exploratorium allows visitors to explore the world via science, art, and human perception.  The mission of the museum is to produce inquiry-based experiences to transform learning worldwide.
This museum is divided into six exhibits (of which one is outdoors), each with numerous exhilarating interactive displays for experiments to keep everyone engaged.  Plenty to see, to do, and to learn!  Plus, the not-too-expensive general admission fee is worth the price to spend several hours wandering around the museum.
author: Akisato S.

description: Exploratorium cafe ..... The worst over priced food, wasn't worth the money... the food was cold and the sizing wasn't enough to match the price.. the salad platter that includes string beans was disgusting no flavor never getting it ever again... Also the miso soup was super salty , tofu tasted bad and overall the soup was just not good for $8. The sushi is wayyyyyy to expensive with u get just a  little.
author: The T.

description: My 5 year old was a little too young to enjoy a lot of the exhibits but we still had a great time. The staff was very very young and might have even just been high school volunteers so it didn't feel very professional. The cafe burgers were great but expensive, just like everything else in San Francisco.
author: Logan P.

description:
I came here for an After Dark event (adults only, every Thursday) and couldn't believe how much there was to see and do here. And better yet how much fun I had! 

Not only can you take advantage of all the cool attractions/exhibits they have on a regular visit but for half the price. And really interesting guest speakers on whatever topic for the chosen night. This night's happened to be all about space with special guest Adam Savage. 

They have bars (and some food) set up through out that take cash and card plus the Sea Glass restaurant in the back. We happened to be here on a night that had fantastic weather so we were able to enjoy the upstairs outside balcony with views of the Bay Bridge before listening to a presentation on robots in space. 

I'll definitely be back!
author: Tarah P.

description:
This is a great place to go for the whole family!

The interactive museum has something for all ages! I would highly recommend this for grade school children to learn and explore more through an interactive way. 

There isn't a TON to do, and this is not an all day activity.
author: Maya A.

description:
This place brings out your inner child, and it's always a joy to come to. 

First off, yes this place is pretty much for children, but if you like interactive museums and super basic sciency type stuff, you'll likely love this place. Also, if you hate kids (like I do) try the Thursday night visit time, it's adult only and a great date idea! 

I personally think the Exploratorium is a very special place, there's nothing quite like it in the Bay/California. I've been to similar museums in other parts of the country but none nearby. It's basically a collection of really interesting machines/art/build/play exhibits that try to teach you something about science. You really get to see a lot of these interesting facts in play, and it's just so much fun to experience. 

Everyone who worked here was super helpful and nice, and the museum itself was generally clean. I will say you should probably bring a bottle of hand sanitizer. This place has a lot of hands on activities and the kids touch everything! 

Overall, I'll be back very soon. It's a great way to spend a day!
author: Sophie W.

description:
Being here is like I've died and gone to science heaven. Yes, I'm a science dork and the two times I've gone here, it's one of the most fun experiences I've had. Everything is so interesting and there's six different galleries to go to. From testing your seeing & hearing to learning about electricity to playing co-operative games; there's just so much to do. The whole museum has mostly all hands-on activities which is my favorite because you'll never get bored. You can drink out of a toilet! (Go and you'll see what I mean)

This is the best place to go with friends or a date night. I've gone to the Exploratorium during the day and After Dark. If you're over 18, I highly recommend going to the After Dark at least once. It's less crowded (kids) so you can try the experiments more. Plus, it's $15 for After Dark which is cheaper and worth it in comparison to a day pass of around $30 (adult). Food & drinks here is pricey but that's to be expected. 

I can easily spend the whole day here but I believe on average, people spend around 2-3 hours here. 

Go explore! SCIENCE IS AWESOME.
author: Tiffany H.

description: My sons favorite spot on this trip.  Get the City Pass to save some money, and plan on spending 3+ hours here for the kids to see everything.
author: Matt T.

description: *****READ****** These guys sell tickets online for dates they aren't open. Spent $60 not refundable. So many business now a days aren't keeping up with their online reputation. Either update your website or don't sell tickets on dates your closed. Google and your website said you open. This place is a scam don't buy your tickets online. I guess you can't rely on the website to tell you if they are open or not.
author: Sean H.

description: This place is amazing. There's a lot of hands-on activities. My children loved it! I really liked it because I used my teacher passed and I came in for free.
author: Sonia C.

description:
Our kids (age 6 & 11) loved this place! So much to do, see & explore. Everything was hands on, spent over 3hrs here. Highly recommend!

Tip- we got the SF city pass ($89 adult, $69 kids), which included admission to the Exploritorium, Alcatraz, Aquarium, Academy of Science, free cable car & bus rides. Super good deal!
author: Victoria S.

description:
Haven't been since they moved to the Embarcadero and we finally went to check out on a Friday. Since it is summer, we were picturing masses of kids but there were a ton of people of all ages and once you got past the initial exhibits in the entry way, it wasn't too crowded. 

Would allot 3-4 hours. There's plenty more to see but we were getting a little overwhelmed by the end. If you plan on going more than once a year, the membership is worth it (and you can apply your days' admission towards it). Make sure to check when the free days are and AVOID. The free community night was starting as we were leaving and it was a total zoo.

You also get free passes via the Discover & Go program with your library card but you have to reserve in advance as they do have a limited quantity and will run out.
author: Sarina Y.

description: We took our kids and they loved it. They have observatory area, my daughter enjoyed examining the rocks and sands, watching the boats from the big windows, experimenting different objects. Although the entrance fee is expensive but it's worth getting the membership. There are so many things to see and try out. I loved this place and we'll be coming back soon.
author: Ashi C.

description:
This place is so much fun! I love inter active museums! It is a wonderful way pass the time on the Pier. They have exhibits such as physics, chemistry, biology, and other wonderful math and science categories. The man at the front desk was very helpful, he asked me what my favorite subject was, and showed me the displays on the map that interested me so I could head there first. 
There is also some sort of behind the scenes open air workshop in the middle of the museum which is nice to look at.
A cafe is located on the property, but I didn't get a chance to grab anything. There are also outdoor exhibits too. Paid lockers are also available (I think they might be 50 cents) so you don't have to lug your personal belongings around. I would return if I were in the area!
author: Virginia M.

description:
This place is a ton of fun for kids.
We brought the entire family including my sister's children and we had a rockin good time. Education and fun in one package. We recommend this to anyone with kids. Thank you!
author: Katie E.

description: One of those places you simply can't miss. I come here with my family and friends yearly and we always have a great time. There are six exhibits and trust me - you won't have time for all of them unless you have multiple eyeballs that can pop out and stroll outside your body. Too much to see man. My little brother just loves this place too. 10 stars
author: Christian S.

description: This place is fantastic! I cant believe how big it was. There is so much to do and learn. We went to the adult only event from 6-10p. I highly recommend going here if your in the area for hours of entertainment.
author: Selena V.

description: I've been going here since I was a little kid. It's one of my all time favorite places. The new location is great. What a perfect place to take people who love learning.
author: Dave B.

description: I was late to this amazing museum, but in an hour was amazed at the million things to do here! I caught a geocash and had time to have an awesome dinner at all their local eateries!
author: Manny C.

description:
My boyfriend went here as a child and for six years he's been making noises about going back.  We finally had a free Saturday and it seemed like the right day! 

I was initially pretty unimpressed with the prices..... 30 for adults/20 for children. (I have this whole problem with museums charging that much money. If we are trying to educate children and discourage so much screen time, than maybe learning opportunities should not be so expensive...  PLUS two waters and a carrot juice in their cafeteria cost $18) 

The museum really is vey big though. If you experience everything in there and have a (brown bag!!) lunch, it will take you at least 3.5 house and up to 5 hours with young kids. 

You can touch and interact with everything. Remember though, this is a children's museum so be ready to give them the right of way and come armed with your patience.
author: Sashy M.

description: This is one of the best museum in the world. Very educational and experimental for kids and teens. The theory of learning  through playing is truly executed.
author: Gina W.

description:
There's a so many things to involve your kids with while at the same time obtaining knowledge from everything! 

This is definitely a place to make science fun for those who aren't so fond of it. The best part about this place is the endless things you can be hands on with or amusing artwork or experiments worth looking at! 

I've been here two times only and I've noticed that they change it up a bit which is nice to see new content! I'm also glad that it's on the Pier which makes it accessible to many restaurants and different shops! Definitely a family friendly place. 

OVERALL I would comeback of I had time because this place needs a almost a full day dedicated to cover everything!
author: Finau F.

description: The best thing about a visit to the Exploratorium is that you can make the visit whatever you want it to be. Every visit is different because things are constantly changing. You can spend hours playing and watching. As we entered there was a group of middle schoolers having fun daring each other to drink from the toilet drinking fountain. We played with the magnetics experiments. Enjoyed watching students experiment with light. We did not watch it this time; but, the dissection of a cow's eye is very educational. The tide columns were fascinating. Next to the columns was a geyser demonstration. We sat and watched them for maybe a half an hour. If you get hungry, there is a restaurant. Next time you are near the San Francisco waterfront, spend at least an hour exploring the Exploratorium. Be careful, you might find yourself there longer than you anticipated.
author: Gregory S.

description: Good date spot and an even better place to geek out. My girlfriend and I are both huge STEM nerds and love going to these sorts of spots. There is a lot to explore and will most likely take at least 3 hours to explore entirely. Some exhibits are very hot or miss but it was overall enjoyable with many excellent spots for picture opportunities.
author: Riley M.

description: Great place to take the kids. We spent 3 hours here & it didn't even feel like it. If you're an educator, sign up for a discount online... you get in FOR FREE!!! And if you don't sign up to get in free, just tell them you're an educator & they take $5 off general admission which is $29.95. Our group included 2 adults, an 11 year old & a 3 year old. We spent almost $50 to get in & it was money well spent! Good times with the family!  Recommend coming here to anyone & everyone!
author: Cyd C.

description: LOVED our time here! So worth your money because you could spend forever and a day learning without feeling like you're learning. Great for little ones to get interested in the beauty of math and science, even greater for adults who once hated both subjects.
author: Alyssa O.

description: This place is SO fun! My husband and I spent hours exploring the museum. We felt like kids again. Everything is hands on and interactive. The Infinity Room was awesome.
author: Katie H.

description: Such a fun place! There are hundreds of mini-experiments demonstrating a countless number of scientific concepts throughout the museum, mostly focused on mathematics and physics, but some chemistry and biology thrown in too. I loved how hands-on the museum was and how it brought back many concepts I haven't thought about since my college physics class. Definitely check out the adults-only evening hours, because it's even more fun (sorry kids)!
author: Nate C.

description: My boyfriend and I took my daughter and twin niece & nephew this past Martin Luther King Jr Day,  They all had a great experience. We enjoyed the upside down mirror reflection the most, It was pretty cool! Definitely recommend to take your kids on a day out!
author: K L.

description:
Being a science major I always love seeing experiments, hands on activities, and everything science. The exploratorium is like a giant science museum except a hundred times better!

I went during their after dark night and the theme for the night was glow, having different types of lights glow and Tesla cool related experiments. 

This science museum has every type of science, biology, physics, engineering, chemistry, and much more!  You don't need to be into science to enjoy this amazing place!
author: Jonathan B.

description: Very interesting museum but super super expensive with no discount at $30... but so nice of the clerk to let us know we can make volunteer donation of $5 or more to get in. Whew! Favorite part was the 3D mirror. The kids would love it. Age 3 or under is free.
author: Peggy F.

description: This was the first time we visited the Exploratorium since they moved to a new location. I went to the Exploratorium many times as a kid and have now brought both of my kids. It is just as interesting and amusing now as it was when I was a kid. Kids loved it
author: Christie C.

description:
A must see if you are in San Francisco and if you love museums like my kids and I do. My kids and I love this place!  There are so many awesome exhibits to explore that are science & Art focused , which are the best kinds for kids!  My 9 & 10 year old girls were engaged and interested in all of the exhibits right away, especially after the long walks we had in SF the night before & that morning!  If you know SF, you know how much you have to walk around everywhere!  

One of our favorite sections of the museum were the lighted/colored areas to explore like the mood hat, & the color screens & rooms (see my pics)!  Our other favorite part of the museum was the awesome mirrors & gadgets you get to tinker with which blows your mind about the Science behind the visual & tactful items you engage with!
author: Michelle A.

description:
Took my 9 year old daughter here for a couple hours of fun since we were in the city early for a play that evening. 

I am not sure what I expected - but we did not expect to have near as much fun as we had. We were there on a Tuesday during the day and even with it being near the end of the school year, it was surprisingly not crowded. 
The place was AWESOME and we only had time to explore a very small portion of the museum.  I am shocked I have not taken my daughter there before now and immediately turned our day passes into annual passes. Too great not to go back over and over and over!
author: Dayna B.

description: This museum is HUGE. I went for the first time i think in 2012, and I went again pretty recently for after dark. I expected after dark to be special somehow but turns out it just means no kids. It was fun though; there are a lot of interactive science-y things to do, and each station has an interactive part as well as a board that explains the science behind the interactions. It's a really awesome museum and I definitely recommend it. I also highly recommend coming on Thursdays after dark because it's cheaper and there's no kids! Probably less people too.
author: Andrea W.

description: We bought the City Pass and this place is one of the spots available as part of the program.  We ventured here one day and came away very impressed.  This place is HUGE and has tons and I means tons of hands on things to do mixing fun and science all together for the kids to enjoy, as well as the adults.  You can easily spend four to five hours in here if you're not careful, and it some cases, could take you a day or two to complete given your schedule.  I feel that on our trip, we probably saw everything, but it was in a bit of a rush.  Take your time when you come here, enjoy and see everything you can, because it can be overwhelming due to the size and wide array of things to see and do inside AND outside.  Recommend this spot for anyone with children from 3 to early teens.
author: Herb D.

description:
Exploratorium is fantastic for all ages and regardless the level of your interest in science.  It is not a huge space to be honest but it has a lot of interesting stuff packed in there.  We came for 2 times this year when my kid is older and every time the kiddo didn't want to leave.

For kids like mine who can't read yet, they have a lot of interesting gadgets or exhibits to play for a bit or even a long while.  For grown folks like us, there are still plenty to learn and explore.

Of course it is also located on the beautiful Embarcadero and just a few blocks away from other attractions like the Fisherman's Wharf or the Ferry Building.  It is a perfect place for both the tourists or locals, and also to spend for just a few hours or a full day.

Highly recommended!!!
author: Michael L.

description: The Exploratorium is a wonderful place for a field trip, afternoon adventure, or museum trip. It has so many fun and interactive activities and exhibits. It is so much fun to visit and very educational, and I would definitely go again. 5/5 would go again.
author: Felipe Q.

description:
I was concerned that my son (13) and I would be bored. We hadn't been in so long and I thought we would probably just walk through because it'd be geared to a younger crowd. Man, was I wrong! We stayed for hours and only left because we were hungry and it was fleet week (planes flying overhead were too cool to pass up).

I have been coming to the Exploratorium since I was a kid. The old location will always have a piece of my heart. I remember going there at such a young age with family, friends, and on field trips. 

This is my first time at the "new" location. I have walked by it tons of times and always wondered what it looked like inside. Well, I found out and I  absolutely love it! 

The "old" location ALWAYS felt packed. Not a bad thing, a great place for people to be, but it always felt a bit like a battle getting through. This location felt much bigger and more spread out. It is HUGE! 

All of the old classic exhibits that have been around for 20 years seem to still be there plus some newer ones. I believe the woman at the desk said there were 600 new exhibits or somethint. 

 It's broken up into different types of science relatively well. I don't recall there being a big biology section before, but that exhibit impressed me quite a bit. There is an outdoor area and cafe as well. The store is huge and full of fun souvenirs or even quirky gift ideas. 

Absolutely love it. Definitely will be back. Doesn't hurt that I get in for free because of the company I work for either. :-)
author: Sean M.

description:
I came here because of the San Francisco CityPASS. It looked like fun and a friend said I would enjoy it. I didn't know what to really expect from this place, but what I got was hours of fun--even for an adult!

-- GETTING THERE --
The easiest way to get here is to catch the F bus to Pier 15, at the Ferry Station stop. Or you could walk 15-20 minutes from there to Pier 15.

-- TIME NEEDED TO EXPLORE --
