I came around 4 pm on a Thursday. I was warned by the ticketing guy that they were closing at 5 for one hour and I should come back at 6 pm for the 18+ crowd which opens until 10 pm, because as he said, "there is no way you will have time to do everything in one hour."

I came back the next day instead around 5 pm, which would've given me at least five hours. The ticketing guy was right, you need at least, *at least*, three to four hours here to truly enjoy everything the Exploratorium has to offer.

-- EXPLORING --
I first walked in expecting museum exhibits of sorts. What this place is is a large collection of mini interactive exhibits that teaches you something about the world: about physics, science, art, math, nature, and other things. They teach you in a way that feels fresh, fun, and interactive. The exhibits themselves are created by hand in their workshop at the location.

It wasn't too crowded when I went so everyone was able to individually explore each piece until they were done; there was hardly any waiting as you could go interact with another exhibit while waiting on another.
Their special exhibit during this time was the "Strandbeest." You may have seen these skeletal-like "creatures" moving on their own along the beach while being powered by the wind. Check out YouTube for videos. They had a large creature on display which moved around; this one was powered by pressured air.

-- GIFT SHOP --
The gift shop has a large selection of toys, games, books, and other things to inspire art and science in a young or older mind. I got myself some lenticular postcards and some Bornite "peacock" rocks that give off an iridescent shimmer.

-- SUMMARY --
I think I went through and explored about 90% of the exhibits that interested me--and there are *a lot*. You will need time to explore all these things. You don't want to feel rushed so plan the time for it. I certainly took my time and thoroughly enjoyed experiencing all the wonders of the Exploratorium. Recommended for kids and adults.
author: Benjamin B.

description:
I took my 4 year old and 8 month old. I was a little worried that everything would be over their heads, but I was wrong! This is a great place for people of all different ages. 
My 8 month old liked looking at all of the lights and colors.
My 4 year old was interested and engaged through the exhibits that we saw. Actually, there was so much to see and do that we didn't have a chance to see everything. There was so much mental stimulation going on in a hands-on and very fun way.
We live in the East Bay and I appreciated that I could hop on Bart then walk for this adventure.
We will be back for sure!
author: Lourdes U.

description:
The name "Exploratorium" is very suiting. This place isn't quite a museum, and you really have to experience it for yourself to fully grasp its beauty.

Don't let the hoards of children fool you, guys, the Exploratorium isn't just for kids. And the price might seem high, but believe me, it's more than worth it; you'll be amazed by the things you learn.

There are countless exhibits, to the point where it's almost overwhelming. No way you can get through this place in one day, so don't even try. Time flies by quicker than you can imagine, before you know it 4 hours will have gone by in a flash.

I can't imagine what this place is like on a weekend. My sister, dad and I went on a Monday afternoon and it was already pretty packed. Thankfully there's both a grab and go cafe and a sit-down restaurant if you get hungry or need a break from all that learning.

So what are you waiting for? Get your exploring pants on, open your eyes and prepare your brain to absorb loads of information all while having a blast.
author: Rebecca S.

description: It's a nice science museum, it's huge. Came in with a friend and enjoyed it a lot. I think we spend about 2 hours to go around almost everything.   It's a good place for kids and definitely they can learn about sciences.
author: Mary W.

description:
This is a VERY interactive museum, mainly geared towards kids.  It was pretty fun to explore and check out the different things it has to offer.  

FYI, if you're a teacher, this place is free admission for you! Great deal cause I basically saved about 30 bucks to come in for free!  It is located a couple blocks by the Ferry Building and totally walkable to it.  Make sure to sign up if you're a teacher before showing up!
author: Danny N.

description: My kids enjoyed the different stations around facility. It's just that there was really no supervision with kids and so many kids running around wild. No staff presence really only in the restaurant and front desk. But again most visitors are there on a field trip so I can see how that can be difficult for parent volunteers. It was pretty wild and no one seem to speak up and tell kids to stop running or climbing on things.
author: K P.

description:
This is a hands-on museum, where you can play/try/test just about any item inside of it. The museum is pretty much a science museum that answers so many of our curious questions and expands our knowledge in the most practical way. 

Outside looks are deceiving, as the place inside is much bigger than what it looks from outside. 

Great for all ages, but will be a great hit for young ones. Expect to spend hours there if you want. 

Admission fees are reasonable and they have many packages.
author: Mike S.

description:
Wow, let just start by saying this place is a great day out for people of ALL ages.  It is very difficult to believe that a person can come here and not enjoy themselves.

The tickets are priced very fairly and honestly I am surprised they don't cost more.  The science experiments are factually and accurately supported (to the best my scientific knowledge), there is a huge variety of things such as visual displays, light wave machines, old school radios, I mean I can go all day really.  

There are obviously are fair amount of children although it was difficult to decide who was having more fun out of the children or adults!  


There is also a sort of gift store to the left of the main entrance.  This store has some really cool, fun interactive toys and games!  Be prepared to spend a little at this store, not extremely expensive but remember it's a gift shop for a science museum. 

I would absolute recommend this place to ANYONE.
author: Jon C.

description:
Came here after work and Finally got to go to the new location. Went to the old location when it used to be at the palace of fine art...of course the new location looks more spacious and have more stuff than the old location...

Anyways, the day that i came, the general admission was $29.95. It may be pricy...but if you love science or play their stuffs, this place is to go...they have a lot of stuffs to check out and things you can play with which can make you stay there for hours especially its quite big... even if you're not a science person...that is why its call exploratorium since it allows to explore your mind with all the things this pace provides
So its good for all ages
author: Julie N.

description: Went here today for the first time. Very cool place! Totally worth checking out especially if you have children.
author: Coleman T.

description:
This place is packed full of hands-on science experiments! There is something- many things- for every age! More than enough to fill an entire day. The majority of the exhibits were too advanced for my little people, but kids aged 6 all the way to adults can spend hours upon hours here exploring and learning all kids of interesting things. We still enjoyed a few hours before everyone needed a nap.

Our favorites (good for little people)- the stage with disco lights and music, the stop motion shadow camera, and the xylophone area. 

Be prepared for crowds- this museum fills up early. We were there before opening on a weekday and the field trip lines were huge! Although my kids were little (2 & 3), we still enjoyed a few hours, but I would suggest one adult per child with this age due to the crowds. It was definitely chaotic in there.
author: Christianna S.

description: Great experience for young children. They are able to interact with exhibits and learning stations. They are applying concepts and lessons. All taking place in an inviting and safe environment. Best part is that they are having fun!
author: Luis L.

description: This is a great place to spend the whole day. I have the annual pass for my family. We go to San Francisco to have dinner with family very often. In the day time, I will bring my kids here. The environment is nice, clean and safe. Even the toilet drinking fountain is clean. After three visits, we still haven't seen the entire museum. Majority of the workers or volunteers are students/teenagers. Majority of them are really great with kids. The others are there to hang out with their friends. But over all it has been a great experience every time we went there.
author: Tony Y.

description:
This is hands down one of the best museums I've ever visited.  I only wish there was more hours in a day to spend here...

We brought our children under 7 here which frankly wasn't the most productive.  Most of the hands-on experiments were too complex for preschoolers, and they simply couldn't comprehend the theories.  I, on the other hand, was very excited to try every one of the stations.  

The museum is organized by theme, and the vast number of themes / subjects covered is truly what makes this an incredible experience.  It's not just a science museum, its exhibits cover a wide spectrum of topics ranging from human behavior to astronomy to languages to human anatomy...  Don't forget to get out onto the patio to tinker with more unusual musical instruments or go to the rooftop and look through the live camera of the harbor.  The breathtaking view of the harbor is enough to waste an afternoon on.  To truly digest every exhibit thoroughly, one should plan to spend at least an entire day here. 

I plan to come back, when my children are a little older...  Then we can all get excited about learning our world!
author: Linda M.

description: Wonderful location right on Embarcadero near Ferry Building. The Observatory Gallery (upstairs) has a  beautiful view of bay bridge on one side, and then of financial district and coit tower on the other. Lots of cool exhibits for children and adults; good date spot!
author: Natasha K.

description:
This place is for KIDS! Don't come here if you are not a child you will be disappointed...If it wasnt for the day pass I wouldn't recommend any grown person to come here....

for 30$ a person/adult. Id say have one parent go with the kids if you have any its a great place to spend a few hours while they play and explore here.
author: Cameron L.

description:
Overall excellent experience. What can I say that hasn't already been said? The TP is ridiculously thin. I get you're trying to be environmentally conscious, but half of it ends up torn into small shreds on the floor because you can barely get it off the roll. Anyway, that was way more than I was planning on saying about TP. 

Good day, sir/madam!
author: P. C.

description:
The Exploratorium is definitely geared towards middle school kids and younger. They have interactive stations everywhere that explore different topics. Although you could check out the stations as an adult, you have to keep in mind that the seats and stations are at a kid's eye-level and you'll have to crouch down for many of the activities. The topics are also fairly basic, but some are interesting!

The special exhibit, Strandbeest, was surprisingly really cool. I walked around the huge structures and read about how these "animals" move. There was also a live demonstration of one of the Strandbeests walking! Super cool!

I came here because I got free admission, but I would say that it is overall not worth it for adults if you have to pay the $30 admission. I suggest the museum having some sort of discount for adults if they're just bringing in kids. Otherwise, if you're 18+ and want a chance to check out the stations without having kids swarming everywhere and cutting you in line, go to the Exploratorium After Dark on Thursday evenings instead.
author: Winnie Y.

description:
Just a short walk from the ferry building, this new location of the Exploratorium is in a convenient area! All of us out-of-towners can just take BART to Embaradero and walk a few blocks. 

I came during the daytime - loads of kids! And so much to do! I actually never had the opportunity to go to the exploratorium when it was in its old location, so it was all new to me. I love the interaction of exhibits in the museum. You could get lost in it for hours making the admittance fee not even an issue. (Btw, there is a resident discount and student discount!) 

My favorite part was the area where you could see how high tides are and the geysers!
author: Melanie B.

description:
If you are into science and interactive exhibits, the Exploratorium will absolutely be HEAVEN for you. 

I've had the opportunity of visiting this SF museum twice during the past few years on their quarterly free days (they generally have 4 free days a year, including one that's always on pie day). Note that there's always going to be heavy traffic on such days and it will be slightly slower on normal days. 

When coming to the Exploratorium, I recommend coming on Sundays because meters do NOT charge you for parking on church days (lol). Though there's going to be more cars around, not paying anything beats paying like $5 an hour for parking right? 

In normal museums, you can probably see every attraction and get tired within 2-3 hours. But here at the Exploratorium, you can literally spend the WHOLE DAY exploring (no pun intended) everything that this place has to offer. That's because each exhibit is 100% hands on and you will probably take 5 minutes at each place to 1. wait in line for your turn 2. experience the exhibit and 3. wrap your head around what's going on. That's like what, 12 exhibits in one section of the museum, multiplied by at least 5 or 6 different sections at Exploratorium. And that doesnt include the time you are going to spend playing snake for hours!

Some of the really popular places at the Exploratrium in my opinion that you must see before its early closing time (5pm) include the tactile dome, optical allusion area, the stop motion section, as well as the "sharing" area. The last one in particular is pretty cool because there's this famous contraption where you get to explore the Prisoner's Dilemma.

Overall, I guarantee that the Exploratorium is going to be a boatload of fun if you like touching things and learning about science. The price is $30 a person and I personally believe that's more than worth the experience you get here. In comparison, tickets for attractions such as the Monterey Aquarium can be $50 for an adult and I believe the experience is nothing like what you'd get at the Exploratorium. Also, if you are 21+, tickets are $15 for the After Dark exhibits.

tl;dr If you are in SF, you must explore Exploratorium.
author: Bryan W.

description:
This place definitely needs to be on the places to see if you have kids.  The wait to get tickets was kind of long and could use some better automation.

This place is a ton of interactive fun.  There are some science museums that have similar experiences, but this place is remarkable for the depth of experiences and the clear explanations.

The time just flew by--5pm came really quickly.  It was kind of busy, but most of the exhibits are designed to be covered quickly.

This was fun and educational for kids and adults.
author: Edward S.

description:
Such fun in here for both adults and kids. We've come for the after dark events (which were great) but didn't realize how much we didn't get to see. We thought 3 hours would have been enough but ended up wishing we had some more time. 

The gift shop has a lot of really neat gifts if you need a souvenir for friends or family and want something aside from the SF trinkets in Union Square or at Fisherman's Wharf. 

Last tip is to bring lunch and snacks in or eat at the Ferry Building. The cafeteria here is beautiful but pretty pricey.
author: Susan G.

description:
I haven't been here in years.  The last time I was here, the place was in the Palace of Fine arts, but I guess they needed a location that was in more of a prime real estate location as well as being larger. 

This place is great for kids and adults alike. There are not enough hours in the day to fully explore this place and enjoy all the little mini adventures you will have. Plus, if you spend a few seconds at one of the attractions a line will form and sometimes your space will be invaded who don't care about the rules of space. 

Still, this is an amazing place to visit as there is so much to do. It reminded me of Studio Ghibli at times, as it's a museum for kids and adults alike, and you will actually learn a lot from your experience. A great time.
author: Benny H.

description:
For a couple in their early 20's, my boyfriend and I had the best time here! I read other reviews who said that they could easily spend the whole day here, but I didn't find that to be true for us. We spent about 3 hours here and we were done, but all the exhibits were great!

Everything is very interactive, and there are sections for everything. My favorite definitely had to be the social experiment area! I feel like everything else is pretty much catered for younger kids, but the social experiment area was so much fun for us.

There's a student discount, so both of our admissions came out to be less than $40! Although you might not spend the WHOLE day here, it's conveniently located near so many other attractions, and is walking distance from Bart.
author: Kathy K.

description:
Yes, it's terrific.  It's the best place to whittle away a couple of hours, with or without kids.  
I'm just sorry that only rich people can afford to take their kids here.  

I understand economics and I get how it costs a lot of money to build and maintain a facility like this.  But here is my problem.  Most of the reviewers here (and many people I know) get in here for free or reduced cost because of where they work.  Read the other reviews.  Sure, anyone would love it when they don't have to pay the exorbitant cost of entry.

Is that fair?  Shouldn't a cutting edge science museum be available to everyone?

I can afford to bring my kids to the Exploratorium.  It's such an amazing place that I wish they could find a way to make it more affordable for everyone.
author: Karen r.

description:
I hate to use stars on things like this - I would rate this as a prom date - it didn't deliver on the promises in my mind based on what I had heard.  It cost a lot more than it should have.  But it was still a good time.  

My kids seem to have liked it.  There are so many exhibits and things to do that it all gets a bit muddled.  I think imagination is sparked a thousand times in a child here but it is so busy that it is hard to get into even cursory details of science.  Entrance expensive,  Food expensive, nothing really close by - if you have kids bring and eat.  It is also hard to park (SF of course).  Enjoy once.
author: Tim B.

description: When I was gettin the tickets I decided not to get the after hours ones because I didn't think there would be that many kids. I would recommend after hours tickets. But it was so much fun! There was a lot to do inside & out. Would go again
author: Alexis A.

description:
This is a fantastic museum! And one that will typically cost you $30 a head. However, if you have a library card, and can plan a few months in advance...you can reserve a pass for each member of your family with a Discover & Go Pass...all for FREE! So that's exactly what we did. 

We began our day with a boat ride to the Ferry Building...a wonderful, relaxing way to travel! About a mile's walk (if even that), and we reached the Exploratorium. Although this museum is truly fun for ALL ages - I think my husband and I would have enjoyed it a tad more without a 1 year old in tow! The museum itself is quite large, and VERY hands on - so give yourself a minimum of 2-3 hours for exploring. When you're finished, it's an easy walk to Fisherman's Wharf and Ghirardelli Square, if you don't mind being a tourist for the day. 

Despite having comped tickets (yay!), the Exploratorium really is worth the $30 admission fee...so cool!
author: Amber L.

description:
Amazing! I can't believe it took us so long to make it to this location. It is really fabulous. We had 5 kids with us ranging in ages from 3-11 and they all had a great time and found things that they had fun playing with and exploring. 

The only bummer is that the tactile dome was sold out. So it were going to try to buy those tickets online next time. I have memories of losing my mind in the old tactile dome because I was a total wuss as kid and afraid of the dark. It's only fair to inflict the same type of memory on my children.
author: Alexis M.

description: 2 families of 3.  Fun kinda, til you need to get a meal or park or pay for entry. Terrible service times infinity. Never coming back. After parking+overpriced food which ran out of food an hour into serving actual food. You should be ashamed!!!!!! Tourist trap plus 150 bucks for a family of 3 for nothing!!!!
author: Brian R.

description:
There's a lot of things to be seen here but for $30pp for an adult and $25pp for a child, a big family should really consider getting a family pass for a better deal. This is not a Pier 39 arcade with pinball machines and skiball but lots can be enjoyed here if you dig science.

The Exploratorium really should consider placing hand sanitizer stations throughout. I saw children sticking their hands in dirty places and then into their mouths and god know what other grimy places while also playing with the interactive displays. If you are afraid of germs, this might not be the place for you. If your children are immune-compromised, steer clear or don't touch any of the displays without gloves. 

There's two cafes, one in the front and one in the back. Although I didn't try the food, the prices were very on par and reasonable with nearby eateries. Street parking is free on Sunday but ou can always opt to pay $40 to park in the lot for tourists which is across the street.
author: W A.

description: Second trip to the Exploratorium and my family of four just can't get enough of it! My boys are 9 and 7 and this had TONS of hands on fun for their very energetic curiosity. We came at lunch time and decided that the little cafe wasn't kid friendly so we went across the street and grabbed food truck lunch and then came back. My husband and I took one kid each and spent the rest of the afternoon exploring and experimenting. My younger son LOVED an exhibit where he could make a hands on electric circuit powered card that would light up. He also loved the huge wall that had tons of pipes, wooden pegs, and marbles that you could make your own track. The sand tables than would spin and you could experiment with design was fun for me too! My older one wants to be a marine biologist one day and he loved the exhibit that was all about nature. This place is great for hands on tinkering for the young and the young at heart. I highly recommend it. It was full but not to full when we went on a Friday --  a MUST go to when you are in the area!
author: Cristina P.

description: If you have time for only one museum in San Francisco, this is the one! This a great museum for all ages and even better when you go with a group. Nearly all the exhibits are interactive and there are also quite a few that require a partner and are much more fun with 2 or more people. We only spent about 2.5 hours here (and rushed through several galleries), but felt that you could easily spend a whole day here. While the Exploratorium validates parking at a couple of nearby garages, we were able to find some street parking (meter enforcement ending at 6pm) a few blocks nearby.
author: Yvonne K.

description:
This place is awesome-!! Kids definitely have fun being here also adults-! 

It is very educational and great way to interact with kids-!My family and I have such great time together here-!
author: Jang R.

description: If this isn't 5 stars, then I am not sure what would be.   Great for kids of all ages, but also entertaining for adults.   The exhibits are always changing so it is worth checking out even if you have been there before.   It might not be cheap but it is a high quality product, so it is worth it in my book.
author: Matthew J.

description:
This place has a lot to offer in terms of cool things to come see and do in the city of San Francisco.  I know there's a lot of reviews already on this place so instead of telling you exactly what's inside let me summarize the parts I liked and didn't like and leave it up to you if you want to come explore.

In the plus column: 
-Not far of a walk from Ferry Bldg. If you can make your way to the Embarcadero Center, then your within walking distance of the Pier 15. It goes by fairly fast, but with little ones you might want to pay for bicycle taxi. Bring cash for that. Problem is they only seem to be around on weekends only. Bring snacks! If the kitchen is down at Exploratorium no food places until your back near Ferry Bldg.  Or your kid might not like what's offered at Exploratorium then that short walk back to Ferry Bldg. feels enormous with younger ones in tow.

-Lots of interactive displays. Interesting for all ages. Maybe best 5+ years of age. Noise level high in the front, gets quieter the deeper into the museum you go.

-You could spend a whole afternoon here. There is almost too much information to take in, in one trip. Membership is worth it if you plan to go 2-3 a year. Otherwise, once a year is enough for me, but there's also other cool museums to visit, so I don't know how often we'll be coming back. 

In the negative column:

-Extremely popular place. They seem to have no limit on how many people they let in. Try to not get offended when some rude kid hijacks your kids spot in front of a display. Parents these days seem to like to let there kids go free range, and not willing to teach their kids to wait their turn. Can be aggravating at times.  

-It's kind of dark in certain spots in the museum to see certain displays better. However, the net effect is I felt very tired after 2 hours of straining my eyes. I was ready for a nap. 

Overall, cool place to come to visit. I got some fantastic pics of the family. Worth it just to check it off the bucket list of places to explore in SF.
author: Svetlana S.

description: Really love this place! Everything is fascinating, since science is my favorite subject. At first I thought it was for kids, but turns out, it's great for all ages (especially students like me). It's also large and took 2+ hours to walk half of it. Most of the stations were fun and hands on. They also have exhibits outdoors, so make sure to check those out too. There's also two levels to explore. I'd come back and finish the rest of the exhibits when I'm in the area.
author: Amy L.

description: This is something i really wanted to explore in the city and yes it has amazing stuff. The mood lightning ball, the intense eye connect, art, body shadow, diff pendulums and what not. Would go again...!
author: Namisha G.

description:
Came here with the girlfriend to check out one of the after hours events, and it was pretty lit!  There's a lot of parking across the street, and they even serve alcohol!  They have a few libation stations placed throughout the hall, so you can refuel as you desire.  Pretty fun being able to nerd out once in a while, and there's even an outdoor area if you want to get some fresh air real quick.  

After exploring the area, I started to get hungry, and luckily there's a dinning common area where someone makes fresh sushi rolls for you!  I got the spicy tuna roll; it was kind of pricey but totally worth it!
author: Eric L.

description: Not worth 30 dollars. We decided to go here to wait for traffic to die down and it was so short. We finished everything within 20 minutes. I recommend this place if you have kids. But for my boyfriend and I it was a waste.
author: Tram T.

description: My eight year old and I are enjoying the day racing our way from exhibit to exhibit.  Trying to Be scientific tourists.  We came when he was nearly 2 & the trip was a total bust for him but we loved It.  This trip is MUCH better and he is going nuts for all the interesting things to see and do.
author: Sarena B.

description: Went at night during the adult time. Very impressive displays and interactive entertainment. I've been to numerous science museums around the country, but the Exploratorium is by far the best!
author: Dan S.

description: I cannot say enough good things about this museum.  It is so much more than a museum.  It is a fantastic educational opportunity for kids of all ages, from 3 years old through college.  It is a science workshop where the visitor is actually provided the materials to create the exhibits, all with guidance and tools to observe the results of the experiments.  I have seen nothing else like it!  Try to get your kids there at least once.  Worth a trip to SF for this alone.
author: Colleen H.

description:
We arrived shortly before it opened and enjoyed walking around the building to check out the interesting interpretive stations and enjoy the great city and bay views.  

The Exploratorium itself is a must experience for all ages but especially children.  Getting in the door right when it opened made it easier to navigate the activities before it got more crowded. 

Easily accessible via multiple forms of frequent public transit.
author: R S.

description:
The Exploratorium has plenty to see and learn, and you don't have to be a kid to have a good time!

Compared with the California Academy of Sciences, the Exploratorium has more hands-on exhibits and a larger focus on scientific phenomenon. There are six galleries here:

Gallery 1 - Human Phenomena:
Play co-operative games demonstrating the Prisoner's Dilemma. Try some games to see how alike you and your partner are - physically and mentally. Think you have good attention to detail? Find out with a game that tests the phenomenon known as change blindness!

Gallery 2 - Tinkering:
Learn about electricity and magnetism, and see how fast you can pedal a machine that powers various devices. Watch water freeze in a vacuum, and even float atop a column of air! Check out Rolling Through the Bay, a huge toothpick sculpture of many Bay Area landmarks.

Gallery 3 - Seeing and Listening:
Fool your sense of perception with the Ames Room. Try shooting hoops while wearing funky glasses that distort your vision. Hear sound through vibrations in a metal rod. Step into a room where everything appears monochromatic because certain wavelengths of light have been removed. Seeing is believing, but don't believe everything you see!

Gallery 4 - Living Systems:
Watch as man-made geysers erupt, play a shell guessing game with a friend, watch a talk at the Explainer Station, and learn about plants and insects with natural exhibits.

Gallery 5 - Outdoor Exhibits:
It's easy to miss this gallery since it's outside. See models of Bay Area bridges, learn about tides, listen to a 27-foot harp strummed by wind, climb into a rickshaw camera obscura, and more.

Gallery 6 - Observing Landscapes:
Watch as miniature sand dunes are shaped by wind in an aeolian landscape. Look at digital information including historic earthquake activity and population growth projected onto a relief map of the Bay Area. See a live view of the Bay Bridge projected onto a table via a camera obscura. The Fisher Bay Observatory on this level has a lot to offer for those interested in geology and ecology.

Here are some logistics to help you plan your visit:
* The Exploratorium website lists parking options, including validated parking
* The closest BART station is Embarcadero, a 0.6 mile walk away
* Lockers on site cost 50 cents to use, and are large enough to store a backpack
* If you want a preview/reminder of what all the exhibits look like, the entire Exploratorium is viewable on Google Street View!

You can easily spend a whole day here and still not have time to interact with every exhibit. Best to come early, because the place gets way crowded in the afternoon. Have fun!
author: Anson W.

description:
The Exploratorium is located at Pier 15.  When visiting, I recommend taking public transportation, biking, or uber.  Parking around this area is extremely hard to find and can be expensive.

There are lots of exhibits here that fits all ages.  One can be overwhelmed.  Most stimulated the mind.  These exhibits are all interactive and self explanatory. You can easily spend three hours here so plan accordingly.

Pro tip: Get tickets to the drawing board first. There are a limited number of tickets given out. The drawing board is a pendulum the draws an unique design.
author: Peter C.

description: The place is great, my daughter enjoyed it. However, there are so many unruly teen to pre-teen children running around, shouting, and not respecting the exhibits and cutting in line! The worst part was when we were at the landscape area where a bunch of these big, unattended kids ran up from the stairs shouting and even the people who work there didn't do anything! I saw this group several times being obnoxious at different exhibit areas, I'm giving my review two stars because the bad and disruptive behavior was obviously tolerated by staff.
author: Mum K.

description:
Probably the best hands-on science museum I've ever been to.  SO MANY different stations, it's unbelievable.  And it's not only for children.  We had zero kids in our group, and we were still entertained for the full 7 hours.

- Get there as soon as it opens.  We were able to breeze through many exhibits before the large groups of summer camps came in.
- They have places to eat if you pack your own lunch.  If not, their cafeteria looked surprisingly good.
- Don't be dissuaded by the steep entrance fee.  Again, we were there for the WHOLE DAY.
author: T D.

description: This museum is seriously a place you must go to! It's filled with a bunch of cool science and art things that'll definitely keep you saying, "Oh, I didn't know that" or "Oh wow, that's so cool!" They have different exhibits geared towards age and you can spend a good two to three hours My most favorite "OMG this is cool" moment was the big chair, and little chair. I will never forget that moment, the little kid in me came out super excited! We went early which is a good advantage so that you're ahead of the big chaos of when groups come in. This place is definitely on my to-do list when I'm in SF again. My son will love it.
author: Ashley P.

description: I took my 4 & 3 year old sons here & we had a phenomenal time!! It was crowded but there is so much to do!! We were able to stay busy until stations cleared up. I felt my boys would probably have more fun as they get older and can read on their own what each station requires you to do. Overall though, it was a great experience.
author: Seekah B.

description:
Crappy user experience buying a ticket online to an event at the Exploratorium.
Shopping cart does not show me what I bought, just what I spent which is similar to prices of other events. This does not instill confidence. 
Hope they accept it when I show up.

Have loved this place since i was a kid, so it still get 4 stars for the important stuff.
author: Brian C.

description:
Review #900 is going to The Exploratorium.  I have very clouded memories of the original location when it was at the Palace of Fine Arts.  I was still in grade school, but I do remember having a blast and being so fascinated with all the exhibits.  Fast forward many years later to its move to Pier 15 which is a much larger venue and more easily accessible to reach since it's right on the Embarcadero.  When it finally re-opened, my inner-grade school-self really got excited about it.  Probably because I haven't gone back since that time.  Well, after being a member for the last few years since it reopened, it's become quite an interesting hangout for me.

Because I haven't visited the Exploratorium since I was back in grade school a lot of the exhibits all seemed brand new to me.  There's so much ground to cover!

Here's a brief gallery of some of my favorite exhibits:

The Fog Bridge -- http://bit.ly/1KmyjFo

The Tinkering Clock -- http://bit.ly/1gqodvi

Illuminated Fog -- http://bit.ly/1OXnQEw

The Kaleidescope -- http://bit.ly/1MbfOHD (photo credit to Danah W.)

The Concave Mirror -- http://bit.ly/1KpxgZB (photo credit to Danah W.)

The Toothpick Exhibit -- http://bit.ly/1igDobC

Other cool exhibits to check out that I don't have pics of are the Tactile Dome, the Shadow Box, the Pressure Geysers, and Fog Ring Maker.  Of course, all of these are just a mini sample of exhibits that The Exploratorium.  

Because I'm a member, I like how I can always just drop by whenever and move at a slow pace with each exhibit.  There is definitely no possible way you'll be able to cover all the exhibits in one day, unless you're The Flash.  And Member Nights are awesome!  They're the least crowded of times and they have a lot of live exhibits, speakers, and sometimes they even have free food.  Another cool thing to note is that my membership is a Dual Explorer, so I can always bring a guest with me for free. It's been a great perk for me to bring people who've never experienced it before.  And they always seem to have great responses.

The Exploratorium is definitely a place you want to check out if whether you're visiting SF or even if for locals like me.  There are plenty of things to see and do here and you can spend a lot of time here.  And trust on this when I say that you'll feel like a kid again when tinkering with the exhibits.
author: Rodney H.

description: Just, Love, love, Love coming here!! Wish I can come often.. but, whenever I do I sure do take advantage.. to read, get my hands on, learning more things and so much more.. I'm hoping, I can come soon again... since the last time I've been here was 2years ago...
author: LeAza D.

description: Had way too much fun! Haven't visited them in their new location so it has been awhile since I have been here. They still had some of the same fun stuff since I was a kid like the drawing thing and the house thing that makes you look taller when you are short (you know what I'm talking about lol) and the bubble thing and other stuff. There was a pretty cool new section called "Science of Sharing" that dealt with a few things including social interaction. I wanted to spend more time there but my kids wanted to explore. Since we are a family of 5, I got the family membership for just $25ish more. I'm glad I did! We were there for about 3.5 hours and there was still so much to look at and do! Definitely recommend the museum - had a lot to keep kids of all ages and their parents busy! My kids are 9, 11, and 14 and all were engaged. Hubs and I had lots to check out too. Wear good walking shoes, bring water and snacks, and don't forget your curiosity and imagination!
author: Enrica S.

description: This place is fantastic!!! It was raining today so we decided to check it out! We were not disappointed. There is something for every age. What makes this place different from other science museums is the large amount of interactive activities and the great use of space. I learned so many new things that hadn't  experienced before. The price is extremely reasonable for the experience. Great time!
author: Alexis D.

description: THE BEST PLACE EVER! Absolutely fun for all ages. I wish they promoted this more since I feel as though this is a wonderful place to learn and explore through science no matter how old you are. You could literally spend a whole day here with all of the interactive exhibits that they have. They need to make an exploratorium in San Diego so I can go and experience all of the exhibits over a lengthy amount of time.
author: Ally L.

description:
Decided to come here on a rainy Tuesday afternoon with a couple of friends. Parked in Levi's Plaza Garage since it was listed on the website, after validation at the Exploratorium info desk, it was $10 for 4 hours of parking. 

Locals get a nice $5 discount. The guy at the booth didn't ask for my ID.

There was a lot to see inside, organized by the type of exhibit: sound, visual, physics, etc. I find some games enjoyable even as an adult, but most exhibits are more for inspiring the younger children. 

Some stations definitely need their materials either cleaned or need new props all together. 

One place that sounded interesting that I would've liked to try is the Tactile Dome, which looked like it required additional reservation.
author: Amy T.

description:
This place is SOOOOO COOOOL!

However, if you are a childless adult, consider attending their Thursday night event, Exploratorium After Dark. We went on a Saturday afternoon and the place was bustling full of families with young kids. I don't mind kids so much, but since almost everything here is hands-on, just think about all those hands touching literally everything... Yeah. And it was really crowded.

Anyway. The Exploratorium is delightful and bound to make you smile. Nearly everything is interactive, which makes it much more engaging and playful than the typical museum experience. Highly recommend!
author: Fiona F.

description: So much to do here! Didn't even get to try everything in the many hours we spent here! Fun place for family time!
author: Heather W.

description: The exploratorium is now in an incredible space and inviting to both children and adults alike. With a view of the bay and endless experiments and demonstrations to explore - the Exploratorium is a must for both visitors and locals.
author: Mara H.

description: I haven't been here in years and had the opportunity to go this week. I love the new location on Pier 15. It is so neat to be able to be right on the edge of the Bay. I enjoyed the room where you could view the outline of the City and learn more about the Bay. The layout of the whole place is very easy to navigate and allows for pretty easy people traffic flow. The Seascape restaurant is good, but would be nice to have a little simpler food - sandwiches would be nice. Still a great place for all ages.
author: Cheryl H.

description:
Wow.  This isn't your father's Exploratorium!  

Moving from the long time home and previous digs near the Palace of Fine Arts, the Exploratorium has settled in an expansive and brand spanking new space on Pier 15, just a short walking distance from the Ferry Building and the waterfront.  The gorgeous views of the Bay, the multi-level floors of activities and exhibits, and even the cafeteria represent an updated and modern museum experience that is probably unmatched elsewhere in the Bay Area.  

While admissions prices are on the higher side and you would also have to compare with the also excellent Academy of Sciences, I'm not sure the two are even the same as I found the Exploratorium to be much more massive and to almost have an endless amount of exhibits.  The fact that each exhibit is based upon science is perhaps icing on the cake and the large space makes it seem that even on weekends there are definitely outdoor areas or upper floor areas that still don't feel that crowded especially compared to all the other Bay Area alternatives that most have gone too.  

I'd say the perfect audience is probably for school age kids, but there's plenty of activities for those young at heart as well.  

Perhaps the best part was after a busy morning and a plan to walk to the very crowded Ferry Building for lunch on a sunny weekend day, we stumbled upon the Exploratorium Cafe.  Yes, prices are a bit high.  But the variety of food (Humphry Slocombe!  Sashimi!  Mary's Chicken!  Udon!  Fish and Chips!) they served as well as the quality and convenience were all up there that I think it was the perfect match for the museum.  I like the Academy of Sciences but I think I was overall more impressed with the space and food here than I was over there.  Consider me a fan.  

Exploratorium accepts credit cards including American Express.  Better yet, have a friend with an annual membership.
author: Randy F.

description: This place is awesome for the events hosted Thursday at night. There are plenty of attractions here to easily spend 2+ hours. The admittance fee is around $15 and they serve drinks inside as well if you want to feel classy and get your Bill Nye on.
author: Jordan W.

description:
GEEK/ARTISTIC/PHOTOGRAPHY CENTRAL~

PRICE:
$29.95 for adults
$24.95 for students with ID

Shoutout to the cashier who helped me in the front when I already purchased the adult ticket and showed her my school email for me to get my refund!

This place is huge! 6 different areas of things to try and look at. I was stuck in the simon says, Morse code, balancing blocks and photography sections for a good hour or so. There are so many different things to do here. Definitely kid and adult friendly. To be honest, I felt like most of it was adult friendly because a lot of the things to do were pretty difficult and I'm sure most kids under 13 wouldn't understand what they're looking at.

There's also an outside gallery with a distorted room and a seating area for adults to watch their kids play on the playground. A little pricey but you can easily spend 2+ hours here. I probably spent about 2 hours and didn't even get to see everything.
author: Nikki B.

description: So much fun for kids and adults alike! You can't get through it all in one day, but we didn't mind. We have 4 kids age range from 5-12 and they all loved it! You can also leave to grab lunch and head back over which is wonderful, highly recommend to anyone visiting SF for any period of time with kids.
author: Sarah R.

description:
A cool thing to do in San Fran either on a rainy day or short day (waiting on airport) when when visiting. Down on waterfront so views are gorgeous. 
Definitely makes you explore and learn some new things. For those without kids, be prepared :) 
Also maybe pre-medicate with some ibuprofen, as light and noises can be a little much.
author: Cynthia S.

description:
Due to time constraints (such a big city, so many places to eat!), we popped in only to explore the museum store since it was on our walk down to the Ferry Building. All I can say is this is the kind of place where you will find yourself drooling over a felted dissection kit for a vampire bat. That's right, folks. Oh, and it was funny to see the little kids fascinated by the old school typewriter - you'd think it was an antique or something.

Great, friendly staff and they allow you to drag suitcases in.
author: Allie A.

description:
It brings out the kid in you! 
Very beautifully located on the pier, this place amazes people of all ages! Soo many scientific principals explained in such simple ways, childs and adults both have a great time here. 

One of my favorite places in SF!
author: Crystal P.

description:
Awesome! 

The Exploratorium was an amazing time on my most recent visit this Sunday. Most exhibits and machines were fully functional. Although busy, there is plenty to do and at most you might wait a minute or two to try out a exhibit. There are so many of them so unless you plan on spending the entire day there, I would pick and choose which ones to participate in. This place is fun for adults as well.

Employees were friendly and the outside exhibits are super fun. We took plenty of pictures there!

One star off because of the pricing. It can get pricey real quick when taking your entire family. I would have expected more reasonable pricing for a place that is meant for families and the community.
author: Bashir A.

description: Don't let the thousand people in line already scare you away. We went on the Sunday free day and it was worth every cent we didn't pay, however we did donate some money, AnyWho. I love the new location and we stumbled upon free parking less than a block away, exhibits were great and my daughter enjoyed interacting with all the exhibits she could get her hands on literally. A large percentage of the things are interactive and you could see people old and young giving everything from the symmetric art computer to the shadow box a go. Although it took us nine months to get to the free entry day now I know that I'll make it a point to make it to another again! As I said by the muscles from Brussels, I'll be back!
author: Theresa L.

description: Overall the Exploratorium was cool. It can get crowded quick. It is a little hard sometimes to do the different activities because it can be filled with tons of people. For the most part people are nice and will move after trying something once or twice to give other people a turn. It was neat to test and see how our different senses work. However, I would say this is a place more for kids. I went with my husband and we still made a good time out of it. I just think kids will get more from it.
author: Tiffany D.

description: What a great experience for kids and the adults that accompany them!!  This is all about hands-on science!  The signs explaining the activities are not only well written but the love that they give the science behind the activity!  We were there for 2 hours and didn't come close to trying all the activities!  I highly recommend this place!
author: Cristi S.

description:
The Exploratorium is a hands-on learning museum where every exhibit reinforces science principles in some way.  It's a 330,000 sq ft. center located at Pier 15 at The Embarcadero.  

We got there two hours before closing time on Sunday and that wasn't nearly enough time to discover all the place had to offer.  We probably made it 1/4 of the way through. 
 
The place is filled with science experiments.  As you walk through the space you can try, touch and fiddle with everything.  Most of the exhibits I saw were related to physics and kinematics.  There were toddlers, elementary aged children and teens; all of them were engaged in play...a lot of the parents were too.  

I didn't see any information with the exhibits to explain how/why they worked.  The children were too busy exhibit hopping to read anyway.  A place like this sparks their curiosity about why things work instead of giving them textbook information.  If they think something is cool enough they'll probably be inspired to figure out the science behind it later.  
  
One of the most popular displays was the water fountain near the entrance.  Yes, a water fountain.  It looked like a functioning commode.  You had to lean into the toilet bowl to take a drink.  Needless to say this was the big photo op.  

My favorite exhibit was the millisecond photography booth.  It let you photograph the moment when a drop of water fell into a puddle of water.  Setting and resetting the timer (in milliseconds) produced unique water splashes that looked like art.  You could see the resulting images on a TV screen and they were just beautiful!

I didn't love everything.  I saw lots of hand to mouth coughing and nose wiping followed by exhibit play.  Naturally the youngest children have no concept of germs but it's still gross.  It would be great to see a few hand sanitizer stations set up throughout the space like they have on cruise ships since everyone touches the same exhibits.  

This would be the ultimate science field trip destination.  If I'd visited a place like this at an early age I might have gone the STEM route because I would have thought science was interesting and fun instead of a complete bore.  

I would recommend this unique experience to anyone.  Just make sure to budget at least half a day to get the most out of your trip to the Exploratorium.
author: Andrea T.

description:
Oh My GOSH! If I could give this place 20 stars I would. I came in with my 8 year old not sure what expect, and was blown away! Every display is hands-on. We took micro-second photos of water dropping into a cup, played with light, sound, moving things, electricity, and visual effects. We spent the entire day loving every moment. We both even learned a few things in the process. The Exploratorium is a wonderland of physics in action. 

If you have kids, you simply have to take them and experience it for yourself. 

On a side note, we came here from Vacaville on the BART, and the Embarcadero station is a quick 5 minute walk.
author: Julie T.

description:
Straight up, no bs, I like the place:

+1 Plenty of exhibits for anyone to learn about various science concepts.
+1 Good for adults and kids; kids seem to adore this place and get inspired.
+1 Friendly atmosphere and adequately open space.
+1 Most exhibits well positioned for your to access or see, as well as great customer service.
-1 Food is food, but for the crap you served me at that price, it wasn't worth two cents; I'm serious about what I put in my body, and that was garbage.  Maybe I should try a different day or something.

Great place to go to be introduced and get some exposure to science.  I recommend a visit if you are interested in STEM or studying STEM.
author: Sheane C.

description:
This place is AMAZING - for young and older. We showed up 45 mins before closing and my 2.5 yr old had the time of his life. 

Love that they close for a bit and open up again in the evening for adult entry only. Makes so much sense! The outdoor area allowed for a nice break for him to just run in the sun in an enclosed space.
author: Lauren C.

description: This place is amazing! Science fun for everyone! My 17 year old enjoyed it as much as the toddlers and older folks did. In fact, he liked it so much that we went back the next day! So many things to touch and try! It's like a science playground! Oh...we learned a lot too! Great, great, great!
author: Kim W.

description:
I LOVED my experience here! You can easily spend hours here without even realizing it, it's just that much fun. 

HIGHLIGHTS: 
- The museum is sort of broken down by disciplines - biology, physics, etc. A tip I got from another review was to start at the back of the museum and work your way forward. There are a ton of children and families when you first enter the museum so you have to constantly wait to see a display. If you start at the back, there are less people. 
- Almost every display is interactive in some way and it's just so much fun to actually do something hands-on in a museum. There's also an outdoor portion with equally fantastic and interactive displays! 
- The signs that explain the exhibits are very good at breaking down scientific concepts and walking you through how to work with said exhibit/display. Really great for kids! 
- The museum is so large with a seemingly endless amount of exhibits - really worth the price of admission! 

I cannot recommend the Exploratorium enough. It's definitely the coolest museum I've been to!
author: Tiffany L.

description:
Do you trust me?

Well, if we're talking about the Exploratorium and its games, maybe you shouldn't.

Met up with my friends here, and after braving the long lines, we finally ran in and tackled some of their exhibits.

So, back to the issue of trust. They had a social experiment where you can choose to offer your friend a "sip" of water, or "squirt" them.

C'mon guys, you know better than to trust me at this game!

In case you couldn't spot my friends after this game, they were the soaking wet ones!

And, no, I don't discriminate. Both my female and male friends all got squirted. I like to be fair, you know.

The same went for the game where you sat in a chair to be startled. Which would scare you if you were like 9 years old, and were afraid of a balloon that inflates and deflates in the corner.

Not very scary.

Much like most of the exhibits here, I felt that they were geared more towards little kids.

We couldn't imagine spending more than an hour here.

Yes, there's a coloring station, a place to watch magic tricks, or converse with a computer, but honestly, it was like being in a poor mad scientist's cheap garage.

Though, they had one cool invention where you could talk to a person in a British Telephone booth, and at the other end, unlock a safe. You need two people for that game. One to give you the code (which was in the Telephone Booth) and the other person to stand at the safe and open it.

That was coolest exhibit/game there, in my opinion.

Venturing out to their outside exhibits were a bore. They had a bridge that hummed, a tube where you could shout messages, and a bike that when you spun it threw rope into the air. Big whoopee, not.

Once again, I'm not sure how adults, or tweens could even find this remotely worth the money to "play" in here.

Also, given all the kids touching everything, make sure you bring lots of antibacterial.

My friend got sick the day after from this place.

I'm thankful to live in a city which has so many choices. If I had never ventured out of say, my house, or lived in a super small town, maybe this would cut it for me. But, I don't.

Had it not been for the free admission, I'd honestly have to give this place 2 stars if I paid $30 for this boring experience.
author: Jack R.

description:
So much to do here for all ages. My son, 3, and I played here for 6 plus hours. Best museum in the Bay for the whole family. There is something for everyone here. Educational, fun, and engaging: you can't get any better than this place! 

I have a full review here with pictures and videos: 
http://theeverydaymomma.blogspot.com/2016/06/bay-area-kids-fun-exploratorium.html
author: Julia C.

description:
Science science science & learn learn learn!

Located between the Wharf and Ferry Building the Exploratorium is very easy to find. The museum gets busy and packed during the day, but it slowly empties around 2pm when the field trip ends. Once you walk in, you feel and see the excitement from the kids running around. Every thing is touchable so encourage your kid to try everything. 

Plan to spend at least 2-3 hours there, but you can easily spend more time there.
author: Roll N.

description:
This was my first time visiting the Exploratorium, Night Life.  I'm not really sure what the difference between coming during the day and night other than serving alcoholic drinks inside.  The ticket's cost $15, but my friend and I got in for free through her work. Total Savings $30.00.  

The place is actually pretty big and you can spend a few good hours experimenting different things inside the exhibit. The location was an easy walk from the Ferry Building or downtown SF.  However, I'm not sure if I'll want to come back after this visit.  

The experiments inside the venue was kind of dirty.  You can tell things are old or just plain dirty. I believe they can do a better job keeping the place up and tidy.  Since we were there for night life, there was just a lot of empty bottles, plastic cups, and garbage laying around.   

Try it yourself and explore the Exploratorium for $15.00.
author: Stephanie Y.

description: I love this new location. I miss the smell of chocolate in the air but it's great to have an exploratorium right by drinking establishments. I like to have a few drinks and walk around this place for fun, talk about eye opening. This places really gets your senses going. Shakes, rattles, stirs, this place then gets your brain back in focus, ha. I think all my curiosities were reached here and I"ve come sober here many times also.
author: Luke S.

description:
We were excited to come and play here at the Exploratorium. We came with cousins kids and nieces and nephews, so that it would a fun filled family event. 

Parked kinda far at Pier 29. It was nice morning walk though in the breeze to Pier 15. 
Admission is $22 if you're a Bay area resident. 

This place might not look big, but with the amount of activities for you to do, it's pretty big. It's mostly science and engineering related activities that are placed in hands on fun activity style. It's even entertaining for adults as well. They can test your intelligence too! 

We went on a Sunday, so it was pretty crowded. Might be quieter on the weekdays. 
Had lunch at the café. Everything is overpriced as expected. However I had the galette or something like that. It's the only pastry there with bacon and potatoes. Make sure you ask them to heat it up for you. That thing was delicious, filling, and cheaper than a lot of the other things on the menu.
author: Gloria C.

description:
If you're into teasing your brain and exploring science, this is the place for you!  A fun place to enjoy for both kids and adults alike! There's just so many experiments everywhere that it's near impossible to see it all in one visit. 

We came here on 10/30/16 for it's free admission promotion (this happens about 4 times a year). Google their free days to learn about future free dates. Woot to free things!

My favorite part was probably drinking out of a toilet. :P
author: Cindy M.

description:
The Exploratorium in San Francisco should be one of the stops for anyone with children who are visiting the Bay Area, especially if you're already planning to be near the Fisherman's Wharf or Pier 39. 

Watch a demonstration of a contraption known as the "Strandbeest," a giant PVC pipe "animal," walk on its own using only the air of 12 water bottles. 

Most exhibits are interactive, engaging both children and parents. You see some people spinning in chairs in one area, blowing bubbles in another, and then playing with magnetic black sand in another. 

There is a gift shop, an indoor eating area, and a couple  of floors of exhibits that are easy enough to navigate. The location of the Exploratorium is convenient; just outside the building, you get a nice view of the Bay Bridge or you can take a walk over to Pier 39 to eat and shop.

There will be a big crowd on Saturdays, so if possible, visit on a week day so you don't have a long wait for the more popular exhibits. 

It's a bit pricey and the exhibits don't change often so it may not be a place you visit frequently.  But if you're looking for an educational attraction on a day trip to the city, I think it's a good place to visit. Your children will definitely enjoy themselves and you'll be guaranteed to learn a thing or two yourself!  

As is in most sections of San Francisco, free parking is impossible and parking lots and garages are very expensive.
author: Mark D.

description:
WANT TO FEEL LIKE A BIG KID AGAIN!? 
Well if so, I have the RIGHT place for you!

Located between San Francisco Ferry Building and Pier 39 you will find the beautiful new Exploratorium along the Embarcadero Waterfront which is a PERFECT location (Valet parking is right across the street)

I remember the Exploratorium when it was located next to Palace of Fine Arts but I must say that I enjoy this location WAY better.

No matter what time of the day you come its going to be full of people (Children, youth and adults) and its SO nice to see everyone having a great time. No matter what age you are this place is guaranteed to WOW you.

This museum has over 600+ exhibits, an outside park for children and six galleries. All the exhibits are made onsite and range from all different subject areas including: Human behavior, human perception, life science and local environment.

They also have tons of beautiful art pieces in the new location as well!

The Exploratorium is open from:
Tuesday through Sunday from 10am-5pm & adults-only evening hours from 6pm-10pm on Thursdays. 

Quick tip- You can find cheap deals on Groupon and Livingsocial

**The entire museum is wheelchair-accessible** So bring your family and come have an amazing time!
author: Porsche C.

description: We loved this museum.  Our kids are 9 and 12 and we all had such a great time.  I feel like it is not necessarily toddler friendly - it seems that the elementary and middle school age is their sweet spot.  So much to do and see.  They layout was great, and very very hands on.  The cafe was pricey but one of the nicest museum restaurants I've ever been to.  (we went in for a drink)  We packed lunch and sat outside and ate a picnic before we went in.  I think you could spend several days in that museum and still not see everything.  Also, I definitely learned some things while there.  I am so impressed and would love to come back!
author: Anne G.

description: This is an awesome museum, and I definitely recommend checking it out. It's super hands on and you get to see amazing sculptures and experience weird things. It's one of my favorite places to go with family for people of all ages. Highly recommend the Explortorium.
author: Vivian T.

description: As a person who teaches science, this is one of the best museums I have ever been to for kids and adults. You are hard pressed to find a museum that is educational and hands on at the same time. The Exploratorium knocked it out of the park! There was so muc for kids of all ages to do and to play with. For example, do you want to learn how the wheel and axle work on a car? They had an exhibit where you can manipulate different variables to see what would happen if you stopped one wheel or try and stop both wheels. All of their exhibits allow people to manipulate different variables to learn what would happen. I wish we had the museum in Chicago because I would plan field trips to this museum every year.
author: Terence W.

description: It was pretty interesting, but the adult only night felt a bit tacked on. There was a few on going presentations, but they didn't feel super entertaining or informative. Outside of serving alcohol, nothing else felt too out of the ordinary.
author: Raj P.

description:
I was a little sad that this moved from the Palace of Fine Arts to the Pier to begin with. It was a great location before so I was really impressed with what they did at the pier.  It's HUUUGGGEEEE. They have new exhibits mixed with old exhibits (you can see hand typed descriptions) and it's your brain thinking in ways that you have long ignored.

It was much too big to see at one time. Kids were running and laughing everywhere. For me personally, I love to see that. It makes me feel like their is a future for our young scientist and to at least get them interested in science as a jumping off point makes me very happy.

I haven't been to an Exploratorium After Dark since it's moved but I'm willing to go now that I've seen it.
author: Ashley I.

description: Fun with science! My friends and I came on a Saturday afternoon and had a blast. Felt like kids again. There were a few things that I didn't quite understand and I wish they had more workers at these spots to help explain or guide us. But I guess we wouldn't be really be exploring, amiright hah. Bad joke aside, I was pretty bummed that this place closes so early, we didn't get to finish the place. And when they were kicking us all out, I saw the amount of workers or volunteers there and really though how could there be no one there to teach us how some things worked. Like where were these people all hiding when I needed them.
author: Vence M.

description:
Meh. It's a place with a lot of activity and things to look at, but nothing was thaaaaaaaat super cool. We explored the left wing and had an 18-month toddler with us, who really enjoyed himself. And an even smaller baby. So it's definitely good for the kids, but it is really exhausting because there are a ton of people and so much stimuli.

I wasn't super blown away by anything.

Funny story, we were messing with this exhibit where you have half your body hidden, and the mirror creates a mirror image. My friend was doing it and we were telling her to move here, then there, and she looks up and asks, "Where's the baby?" We fucking lost her kid!!!! So then she and her husband ran one way and I went another. I found him dancing in front of some big light display. But I will say this gave me pause because there were a CAJILLION kids which made it hard to spot him quickly.

You could spend a whole day here. But really why?? By the last hour when we were in the right wing I just sat on the couch and spaced next to a random dad napping with his child. We all pooped.
author: Christina K.

description:
One of the must sees in the bay area! The Exploratorium is located at Pier 7, the Embarcadero. It reminded me a lot of the museum of science and industry in Chicago, but an enhanced experience as almost everything here was interactive. Not only was it very interactive, but also the technology driving some of these things were really neat! The venue was packed with people of all ages, we were able to forego the entry fee since I had purchased GoPasses for our group to span multiple tours at a flat rate. The Embarcadero is a beautiful area for a night stroll, and as long as you're already in the area, you should definitley make a stop at the Explorium for a few hours of learning and fun. 

Best,
Charlie
author: Charlie K.

description:
My goodness.. your inner kid is gonna LOVE YOU! 

Such a hands-on and informative museum. I like to think that I live a bougie lifestyle and go to educational museums & fancy restaurants, so I decided to go check this out. Trust me, you won't be counting sheep here. The Exploratorium is gonna keep you on your toes! 

PARKING: It's San Francisco, and unfortunately, you will be forking up some cash. I suggest looking at the museum's website because they have partnerships with several parking garage & validation. It won't be free, but a lot cheaper. I found one that was all day for $15 dollars, so drive around and see what they offer! 

PRICE: Just like parking, the pricing is on the website as well. Adults are $29 and I know it sounds like a lot, but you are really helping to support the museum. They have discounts for students ($5 dollars off) & also local ($7 dollars off). My friend was a student and from the area, so the cashier was nice enough to use both discounts. If it's too expensive, they have a lot of free days as well. Just a warning that those days will be super crowded. Do a bit of research and plan ahead to save some money. 

OVERALL: I am definitely coming back! I want to check out their After Dark event for adults (21+) because a little alcohol makes EVERYTHING better. With how hands-on the museum is, I can see myself bringing some friends and enjoy a great time there.
author: Matthew D.

description:
Really cool sciencey exhibits. Wide array: optics, thermodynamics,  geology, oceanography, etc. Lots of hands-on opportunities that allow you to have fun and learn.

Really geared towards pre-teens. Came for a company event with families, and the kids were the ones who had the most fun.
author: Abhi M.

description:
I feel like a little kid every time I go here! Great for people of all ages and there's so much to do and most especially learn! Definitely come early so you'll have the whole day to enjoy! You'll definitely be occupied for hours! 

Check their website for free days! You'll save yourself $30
author: Rachel E.

description:
I've got fond memories of the original Exploratorium from many years ago as a San Francisco visitor-back when it was located at the Palace of Fine Arts. It had been fun checking out all the hands on exhibits and invoked a certain nostalgia of school trips and a simpler time. Fast forward to the present day and it's new location at Pier 15 and not only are the tried and true original exhibits in play but there are also newer and more modern wonders to have fun with!
The new location is impressive and the spirit of learning and fun remains intact. Every little corner features a new hands-on discovery that both kids & adults will learn from and enjoy. One caveat to that is that it does get pretty crowded and some of the more popular exhibits have queues forming. The interactive nature of the Exploratorium requires patience as others are having their fun and some overall common courtesy to others around you. 
At $30 a person it's an investment,  but worth visiting every few years to see what's new & have fun with old faves. If you don't mind walking, it's very easy to walk here from the BART Embarcardero station (20 minutes or less) and a scenic walk past the Ferry Building and waterfront. 
I'd like to check out the Exploratorium after Dark event where it is adults only-more play time for me! Next time I want to check it out I will plan on doing that rather than a day time excursion.
author: Jennifer N.

description: Awesome place to visit, bring your family, kids, and dates (to the Thursday night after dark).  So many cool and fun things to check out! A great hands on, learning museum!Make sure you check out the cafe in the back, they have the best food! You can even stop by there for lunch one day without going to be museum, the food is always delicious!
author: Mandy B.

description: Went here for a field trip with a homeschool group. The large school groups were obnoxious, with kids who repeatedly chased and tried to kick the pigeons outside. Inside was very loud. My kids and I didn't like seeing the fish tanks and especially the mouse in a cage with kids tapping on it and shouting. Come on, do they really think unsupervised kids are going to be quiet and not tap the glass? I would've enjoyed the museum much more if captive animals hadn't been part of it. My 16 and 13 year old were underwhelmed by the exhibits, although the toilet drinking fountain and magnet station were pretty fun. We had a discounted admission but I wouldn't go again.
author: Christie P.

description:
The Exploratorium is one of those places you visit in the Bay for the experience of a hands-on museum filled with cool science experiments ranging from physics to psychology. I would say that visiting is one of those you do maybe a few times a year unless you have kids who love science museums. 

I went for a special exhibit, which is the biggest driver for me to visit again. A lot of the exhibits do not change often, so if you visit too much, then it is pretty much the same. 

Overall, it appealed to the engineer in me and encourages kids (and adults alike) to know that science isn't for nerds, but cool for everybody! 

TIP: If you are a Bay Area resident, tell the person that the register so! Show your Driver's License and get a discount. 

TIP 2: Come on a Thursday night if you want to avoid kids and get a drink. You end up not waiting as long for the exhibits to play with and less children running around.
author: Albert H.

description: If your around the area with children this place is a good place to go to kill time and learn something new! A lot of reading and walking. This is not recommended if you have a group of adults!
author: Bobby L.

description:
Great for kids and adults alike! 

A little less than 1/2 mile from the Ferry Building so I can hit two spots with one stone (one Bart ride from Fremont to Embarcadero haha). 

I wasn't sure what to expect but I enjoyed it as much as my daughter did. Right when you enter into the "Exploratorium" area, you're surrounded by all these gizmos and gadgets that teach you how things worked. Everything is very hands on and there are instructions on how and what to do. 

There's literally something in every nook and cranny of this place. Everywhere you turn, there's something different to look at, touch, or tinker with. I was learning about things I didn't know about too lol 

It was a little dark inside but it made everything that lit up look even more amazing! At one area of the Exploratorium, you can get a nice view of the pier and ocean. They set up wooden rocking chairs for you to sit and enjoy the view. 

It really is almost a whole day's worth of exploring because there's so much to look at. I recommend coming early when they open to make sure you get to check everything out. Don't forget to go upstairs too! 

Also..they have these little lockers right at the beginning that can play musical notes when you touch the handles. It's 50cents to open and store your belongings and 50cents to open again to retrieve it. Pretty cool.
author: Truc T.

description:
I still miss the old Exploratorium by the Palace of Fine Arts. Maybe because I grew up in San Francisco and went there as a kid, or maybe it's from the sentimental memories of having my high school prom at the old Exploratorium, this one didn't feel the same to me. 

Came here on a Saturday, it was packed with way too many kids. All of the exhibits cater to kids, or maybe I simply grew out of them. Haha!! My boyfriend and I decided to check it out since we haven't visited after it relocated. Boy, we picked the wrong day to come! Not that we hate kids, we love kids, but it's hard to fight over the exhibits with children! LOL! I didn't get to play with anything because all the kids hogged up all the space. My advice is come on a Thursday night for After Dark Adult Night Hours - adults only and cocktails available, sounds amazing! 

The new venue is very spacious with many newly added exhibits to include physics, chemistry, robotics, biology, art, and much more.
author: Janny S.

description: I wasn't sure what to expect but this place turned out to be really cool. It's gets your mind ticking and everything is hands on.
author: Dani M.

description:
Interesting museum with tons of hands on exhibits.

The Exploratorium is very much so a play-as-you-go type of museum. Every exhibit here is educational yet entertaining at the same time. There are so many little contraptions and gadgets to check out, you'll need a whole day to get through them all.

It's a visit once and get it out of your system type of place, but definitely a great place to bring kids.

We happened to venture here on the first Tuesday of the month so entrance was free (I highly recommend you do this to avoid large weekend crowds and save on some costs - especially if you're going as a large group).
author: Claudia C.

description: Bf and I were visiting SF and wanted something fun to do. We decided on this and were NOT disappointed! Most amazing museum. We were there for hours and didn't even cover half of it but were never bored! So many exciting exhibits. Yes, kids jump in front of you and sometimes you have to wait to see something but that comes with the territory. I­t was super fun, and even as adults we learned new cool science things!
author: Samantha S.

description: Exploratorium is one of the finest science museums in all of the U.S. and the entire world. Don't leave San Francisco without stopping at Exploratorium at least once!
author: Leo T.

description: Raising few kids with a good age gap and even going to museums while growing up ourselves, we have been to many science museums all over. The SF Exploratorium wins all hands down. By far, the best science exploration museum.
author: Amr A.

description: Unfortunately our visit was cut short due to a fire alarm! But from what I saw I enjoyed. There is a TON of stuff in here, although a lot of it isn't very intriguing (again didn't see it all) but the amount of stuff definitely helps as this place was pretty packed so the crowds of people was pretty evenly distributed among the different exhibits.
author: Chase H.

description: Fun place for my 4 year old and her friend to play for many hours.  The cafeteria food was good too.
author: Mike P.
