description: They close at 5 pm and reopen at 6, because...They will allow you in for FREE at 4:50 to enjoy the museum for TEN WHOLE MINUTES. No
author: Jim S.

description: We came to SF for a week. We toured some museums, did a winery tour, bikes the bridge, but this was the highlight. If you are a twenty or 30 something you will love the Thursday night beer and adventure night. It was a blast. Of all the things we did this week, this was our highlight. Make sure you get there at 6. We didn't have enough time to do everything in just two hours since we got there at 8.
author: Andrew D.

description:
I love this place. Touch everything! 

This place holds a special place in my heart because it was a place that my family and I used to go to when I was very little growing up in the bay area. The building is different now, but the fun is the same!

They have adult nights too, just like any of the other museums in the city, but I feel like this one is a little less crowded than the Cal Academy of Sciences. They have fun themes too (just like the rest of them) but I always seem to miss them, so I've only ever seen the light one, which isn't as impressive. 

I can't wait to go see Strandbeest!
author: Lai-Nin W.

description:
This place is amazing!! I don't know why I never came here before.

1) It's HUUUUUGEEE. I arrived at 715pm and barely finished 1/3rd of it by close time 10pm.
2) Tickets are normally $29, but I got mine for $10 on UpOut Insider (subscribe) for Exploratorium after Dark Thursdays.
3) They have food and drinks and it's 18+ Thurs nights only, but it's great for kids, adults, anyone!
4) The wings all vary in science theme, but everything is amazing and fun to experiment is.
5) I learned so much
6) The decaying rats was cool, the color theme arousal, music wings, tons of mind illusions, just wow.
7) Lots of art photo ops too.

Find a way to get here (5 min walk from Embarcadero Bart), it's awesome. I'll be back on another Thurs soon.
author: Chuck N.

description: Such a fun museum. I recommend every new couple to go here. You'll learn a lot about your partner through their exhibits as a some of them require a partner. I appreciated that they showed you how to explore math and science in a fun way even if you are a right-brained thinker. The bathrooms are clean and the workers are super nice. If you go on a weekend, be prepared for lots of kids (who are loving life!) It's also pricey for a museum, but maybe I'm bias for being from DC.
author: Laurisha C.

description:
I was not expecting this new location to be so awesome! I've visited the old one a few times so I was skeptical. But I was totally impressed and awed by the size of the place, the new exhibits were fun, amusing, mind blowing etc. Also, a couple of my favorites from the previous building were there as well! 

The restaurant.....DELICIOUS food. I had the clam chowder, potato salad with asparagus and green juice. Lovely employees very helpful and friendly.  

Such a wonderful day the kids loved it. Get there early so you can spend the entire day there. We already want to go back.
author: ShonQ F.

description:
5 hours was not even close to being long enough to enjoy all of the things that the Exploratorium had to offer. I absolutely loved seeing my kids' minds turn with each exhibit! Although there were a bunch of people at the time, this place is enormous with many things to see and explore, so it doesn't feel too crowded. The restaurant inside the Exploratorium was nice although it is quite small. I do enjoy the "healthier" choices they have to offer like a variety of salads, whole wheat spaghetti, grass-fed burgers on a whole wheat bun, fruits, etc. The desserts looked scrumptious, but I opted to not have one this trip.. next time I think I'll try something cause they had so many different things! We absolutely loved this place and will be back whenever we get the chance to visit San Francisco again. Anyone of all ages will love coming here.. you will get lost in all of the excitement! 

My pieces of advice to anyone planning a trip to the Exploratorium: arrive early, plan to spend some money for tickets and if you're eating at the restaurant located inside, be patient and kind, allow everyone to have a turn, and please watch your kids!!!! I don't know how many parents lost track of their kids on the day we went.
author: Kaila L.

description: Kids can't get enough. It's worth getting a family membership when you have 2 kids or more. :). You can take up to 4 kids with you. At regular pricing , two adults and two kids would be around $100. The full family membership is tax deductible (149?). You can also get discounts at the souvenir shops inside.  And... I just learned today that you can get discounted ticket for your friends too! So a bunch of savings...  not to mention you skip the ticket buying line. :)
author: Gaia W.

description: You could stay here forever there is so much to see and do. The only thing I don't like is that it's so fun, like an enormous cave.
author: M K.

description:
Parking: find any spot and just park there as it's The City, and you're going to struggle with parking! My friends and I parked at the Public Parking on the Greenwish street near R&J Market-- with your admission ticket, the first 4 hours is only a total of $10.

Refreshment: We didn't eat in the cafe, but The Exploritorium had offered us Hot Cider! Thanks!

WiFi: NONE

Side Note: be prepared to be pushed out of the way by not only rambunctious children, but adults on dates! I'm next in line to try this art sketch thing and a girl sends her guy to shove me out of the way. Wow, if that's the girl you're looking for, you guys are a perfect match to be paired up as the grouchy couple!


$29:
Adults (18-64)  
 
$24:
Seniors
People with disabilities
Teachers
Students
Youth (13-17) 

$19:
Youth (4-12) 

FREE 
Children (3 & under) 
Members (Join us!)  
California Public School Teachers (Teachers: Apply for free admission)
author: Dany B.

description: Has a nice time at Exploratorium however when we arrived back at our car which was parked at the recommended Pier 19 1/2 lot, someone smashed in the back window and took some belongings. This happened on Easter so maybe it's reason why there was no security personnel or lot employees. The lot is dark and easy for a smash and go break in. Just a disappointment to a wonderful time at Exploratorium.
author: mn n.

description:
Great place to spend an afternoon with the kids!   Lots of experiments and exhibits for them to tinker with. And for me, there is a nice cafe in the back with sashimi and beer. 

Park at Embarcadero 4, and bring the ticket to the Exploratorium for validation.  With validation parking only costs $10, which makes parking the only item that is cheap for the entire excursion. 

I wish there were some hand sanitizing stations throughout.  Hands-on experiments + sick kids that should stay home instead = germs for all. 

Family membership is a good deal if you plan on multiple visits during the year.
author: Jack L.

description:
The only museum I've been to so far that definitely was worth my time! Very hands-on museum!

I took my friend here since I was given two free tickets. Admission usually would be $15. I parked across the building and came here After Dark hours which was after 6 pm. Luckily, I found a parking spot which offered only 25 cents / hour! It was near the news station building.

If you have any bags or items that you don't want to carry, the Exploratorium has lockers which you could rent out. The lockers are pretty big so don't worry about it.

What's really cool with the Exploratorium is that you could drink while you go around the museum! The bartender makes some really good margaritas!

My favorite activity in this museum was the activity where you have to walk across pebbles and you have to do it as quiet as possible. Another notable activity was when you get to choose up to four colors and you move this table back and forth and it creates some really cool pictures.

This is a great place to take friends who don't live around the area and I highly suggest going!
author: Aj C.

description: Amazing place, loads to do. All interactive and informative. Would say you need to set aside most of a day to get the maximum out of it. Area one was by far the best was good fun doing various challenges with my husband. Would love to go back next time we are in the city.
author: Rebeca J.

description:
I was able to check out this fun place with my boyfriend's sister.  While you may think this is a place just for kids, we had a blast there, and we were so disappointed when they shut down the lights and all the exhibits at 5:00...we wanted to stay there longer!  

Initially, we were a bit hesitant to go inside because it's $29.00/adult, which we thought was expensive at the moment.  We weren't sure if it was just for kids, especially with elementary school students stampeding out of the museum around 2:00.  However, we briefly looked at the yelp reviews and decided to just go for it.  We were both so glad we took a chance with this place!  

TIP: If you're a student, it'll be $24/person.  If you can make it on a Thursday night, they have an awesome Night at the Exploratorium for $15/person from 6-10pm.  If I stayed on a Thursday, I would definitely go here at this time because it's such a great deal!

First off, this place is hands-on for every exhibit.  While we felt like we had to wash our hands every few exhibits, this place is well-kept and very clean for the most part.  

The Exploratorium has six sections: (1) Human Phenomena (social behavior/psychology), (2) Tinkering (building things with your hands, (3) Seeing & Listening (light, vision, sound, and hearing), (4) Living Systems (organisms and ecosystems), (5) Outdoor Exhibits (winds, tides, and natural phenomena, and (6) Observing Landscapes.      

If you go with one other person, you can do activities with each other.  We did one where one person reads a card, and the other person has his/her hand in clip that detects if you're excited or not.  Our favorite room was in the human phenomena section where you go in a room and there's different changing lights that trace your body.  Definitely stayed in there for a long time acting silly lol.  We also enjoyed an exhibit where you try to walk across gravel and stay the quietest among your friends.  

If you want to take your time, go from open to close (10am-5pm), but I think we had more space and ability to play with the exhibits because we went on a weekday in the late afternoon so that the school children had already left at that point.  I would love to go back to this place.  I highly recommend spending an afternoon here with anyone of all ages!  I saw a cute family where a dad was teaching his daughter about science.  What a fun way to teach/learn and bond as a parent-child :)
author: Catherine K.

description:
One of the coolest places to visit in the city! This place is awesome, especially if you're a big kid at heart and wanting to go and play with other big kids (cue after hour nights). There's always a new exhibit or something going on that can pique your interest. The adult after hour events are awesome to attend, because they offer not only beer and wine, but also food to keep your energy levels up while running through this place. 

You could visit this place many times and never get through it completely because there is always something new being offered. 

Definitely a place to check out if you're visiting for vacation, with friends, or on a date. 

Likes:
-great place to visit with friends or on a date (check out their adult-only events)

Dislikes:
-I wish they offered more adult nights
-parking can be crazy expensive (take public transit if you can and save your parking money for the beer instead)
author: Tracy T.

description: Extremely big museum. Probably not the best place for teens especially if you've took a lot of math and physics classes in college and you pretty much know how most things works. But none the less, if I were younger, this would have been a better experience especially with your kids. You can easily spend an entire day here without realizing it. Try to go in the morning because on the weekend in the afternoon, it gets pretty crowded and it'll be harder to enjoy everything without waiting.
author: Lawrence C.

description:
There is no doubt that the exploratorium is the coolest, most interactive museum I've ever visited. So many things to see/do. So worth the ticket price. 

Plan to spend a whole day here, because most everything requires reading instructions and follow, takes a lot of brain power!

It would also be nice if there are at least two adults because there is a lot of activities that requires a partner. 

We parked at front street parking, just across the street, for $20 for weekend days. At 11am there are barely any cars there. 
 
The museum is definitely crowded with families. However I so look forward to visit again!
author: Rong Y.

description:
This place is amazing! I went in here on one of their random free days (10/11/15), so everyone who went here that day was so lucky. It was so unexpected, too. My mom and my sister were walking the piers the day prior and planned to visit Exploratorium the following day without knowing it be free. That being said, I don't think this place advertises free days, for obvious reasons. I'd like to thank UNIQLO for sponsoring this free event. They really made my vacation to San Fran much better!

Due to the fact that it was a free event, the place was so packed! I hardly was able to tinker with the little activities spread throughout the building because so many people were using them. Despite that, I still had a great time. 

This was a place where adults, such as myself, are excused to act like little kids again. There were quite a few interesting things here that I learned or refreshed my memory on from my college days. You should really check out the Social Psychology section. There's a lot about us, humans, that you don't know -- or probably already do.

The attached store is full of interesting gadgets targeted toward children. Adults would find it cool, too, but can wind up as junk in the long haul. They do have some books there I wanted to purchase, but I knew I would not read them when I got home. If you have kids, you should definitely invest in some of their books here. I mean, you're kids will learn a lot if they're open to science. Nerds in the making. You gotta love that!
author: Renee C.

description:
I went here a few times when I was younger during field trips and always remember having a good time. The last few times that I have been here was during their Nightlife events. It is great for an older age group since there are no children at the event. I even came here for my 22nd birthday two years ago during Nightlife and it was great.

The drink selection is good, it is overpriced however. I always have a fun and educational experience when I go here. I cannot wait to go back to Nightlife again.
author: Christina S.

description:
One of my friends is an Exploratorium member.  He invited me to the Exploratorium's Member Holiday Party, and I jumped at the chance to see it at night.

The Exploratorium has a different vibe for nighttime activities.  First of all, there are generally more adults and fewer kids around.  That makes it a little quieter inside.  It's also much darker of course, but that makes any illumination really stand out.  There were two huge rhombus-shaped LED displays overhead which put on a colorful and festive show.

I loved every moment of the party.  We grabbed some pretzel snacks and Clif bars on our way to a delicious chicken tinga bowl served with salad, rice, beans, and tortilla chips. Needless to say, the dining area was packed with guests.  My friends had been to member events before so they knew to make a beeline for the food.  I just followed their lead.

If you are at the back and head upstairs, you can see the lights of the Bay Bridge from the outside viewing platform.  That area was covered over with clear plastic tarps, so it's not as cold out there as you might think.  There was a nice woman softly playing the ukulele in the shadows.  I thought it made for excellent mood music.

I like how restrooms are always nearby.  They are located at the front, middle and back of the Exploratorium, and there is one upstairs as well.  Remember to wash your hands frequently.  Everything you touch has been touched numerous times by little hands!
author: The Bottomless Pi T.

description: What a great museum for both kids and adults! I was seriously learning and fascinated with all the hands-on exhibits along with my five year-old daughter. Definitely worth spending the day here if you are visiting SF. The restaurant there is pretty good. I don't think I ordered the right thing. I would suggest getting the sushi, but I was so cold I wanted something hot/warm so I got the vegetarian pozole, which ended up just being a bean soup. Overall, it was a lot of fun spending the day at the Exploratorium! Will definitely be back again next time!
author: Debbie C.

description:
This is one of those San Francisco hot spots you always avoid going to because of the crowds - and rightly so, it gets pretty busy.  In fact, for any spots on the water front, I'd come early and leave by early afternoon if at all possible, and the Exploratorium is no exception.  

It's a bit pricey, but not unusual for SF tourist spots, and if you stay all day, easily worthwhile.  Unfortunately, I wasn't feeling that great, and we were on a schedule, so my son and I only stayed a couple of hours, and got to interact with maybe only 1/3 of the exhibits.  His favorite was the marble run, but sheer range of demonstrations of science is amazing. 

I didn't check out the menu at the cafe, so I don't know what the vegan options looked like (what I did see is some highly questionable hotdogs), but there's a great area outside with some exhibits and picnic benches if you bring your own lunch, which is probably recommended due to the likely food prices.  

You definitely need to go once, and go early.
author: Peter N.

description: This is one of the best places in all of San Francisco to fill your need for kinesthetic learning. Everything here is hands on, so it's appealing to both children and adults of all ages. Some of the exhibits may be too advanced for the younger children, but that's the great thing about coming here, you have plenty of tools to help make learning more fun and less strenuous. All of the exhibits are awesome here, but I think that the shadow room, Lego Batman symphony, and see through pinball machine should be at the top of your list if you stop by for a visit.
author: Joseph A.

description:
Love science and love this place!

I'm a very hands on person when it comes to learning, so this was my candy store. If you're 21+, I suggest going to After Dark (no children so less crowded). There's so much to do here, and I suggest taking your time with each station. It took me 2 different nights (about 1.5-2 hours each time) to finish the entire place. 

Purchase tickets in advance. The line for tickets was pretty long both times I've been there. Plenty of parking if you're going to After Dark.
author: Denise L.

description:
Front desk - wonderful!  They took me at my word that I was a teacher because there was a $5 difference in price.  That is most appreciated.

Exhibits - great!  Everything seemed to be in working order, no trash on the floor, even though place was crowded, you could get to stuff.  I would have loved to know ahead of time that there were things that required advance tickets and reserved times.  

"Explainers" (student volunteer staff): I found this to be the weakest point at this great museum.  The kids looked bored, tired and disinterested in engaging with anyone except each other.  This is so unfortunate because younger kids look up to older kids who know about science as if they are rock stars.  This is not the case here.  The explainers do not live up to their purported name and seem like all they want to do is stand against the wall until they go home.
author: Kathy A.

description: I came here the day before on October 30 for free Halloween weekend day! It was so crowded, but really fun. Great place for young kids to enjoy as well as adults. My favorite part was all the sensory exhibits. Science is COOL.
author: Priti K.

description:
I'm really surprised this has an average 4.5 stars on Yelp. Like most museums, the Exploratorium is underwhelming. Especially the reimagined version. The old museum had its retro charm. But this newer one just feels icky and gimmicky. Museum admission is very high and not worth it. 

The newer museum has the geek chic feel that's rampant around SF. It's like Mythbusters meets data geek and Tech Shop SF or something. It's a really annoying vibe. 

The museum has some occasional lectures. The topics all sound really interesting, but they tend to be ho-hum when you actually go there. 

Like so much of SF, this place just feels foreign, in a way, and fake and shallow. Coming here is okay if you have nothing better to do, but it's really not the most enjoyable experience.
author: Alecia K.

description:
Feel like a kid again! The Exploratorium lies on the pier of San Francisco. The exploratorium carries a hefty admission price. About $22 a person. It seems like a lot, I know but this is one admission I don't mind paying! 
It opens at 10AM until 5PM. I highly suggest coming here when the doors open because this will be a full day trip! Now since this place is really popular, expect many many kids to be here as well as kids on a field trip also.
Now the cool thing about this place is you CAN bring your own lunch so pack some goodies!
This place is divided in so many parts that you might get really overwhelmed with it!
Before you enter, to your right will be the gift shop and cafe. Gift shop is huge and full of cool things you can buy so perhaps it might be best to stop by that prior to going in the museum.
Now as you enter you will see numerous interactive science exhibitions! Go ahead and play with them to your heart's content! The different areas they have here is science, sound, lights, sea, nature, illusions, mechanical exhibition.
The first area you see is where most of the people hang around and as you venture in further, the people seem to weed out.
The reason I say head in at 10AM because the hours seem to whizz by as you are trying different science projects! Be mindful though people, don't be a douche. There are people waiting to try exhibition so don't try and jump ahead of the line. ESPECIALLY you parents that let their kids run at the project when there are other people clearly waiting. So don't be THAT parent with THAT kid.
Anyways the most popular exhibitions are the toilet water fountain, the tornado fog, the vapor , the upside down mirror, the small/large room, the two seat communicators, monochrome room, the light section, the metal needles, the whale tube, the color room, the engine starter. 
Those are just a few to name. There are much more exhibitions to see that it will be impossible to name all of them.
It's an amazing place to spend the day in. Just be weary that cool spherical exhibition where you can enter, charges about $10, so that will be an additional charge.
This is only good for a one time visit to be honest. Once you visit the whole place and do everything, most of it will stay the same throughout couple months. They do switch out exhibitions from time to time.
author: Jason H.

description:
You can spend several fun filled hours in this place.  There's lots of mind opening - brain engaging - very interesting exhibits to explore.

When your down by the piers, put this on your list to do.

It's like a hands on science museum for all ages. Kids like it - but I don't like the kids... but I digress.
author: Jonah O.

description:
Having heard about the Exploratorium for a while, I was excited to check it out during our visit to the Bay Area. 

Knowing full well that most of the experiments are geared towards the kiddos, it certainly didn't stop my fella and I from enjoying ourselves. There are so many interactive items to enjoy, make sure you have plenty of time so as not to limit your experience. 

We spent about three hours here and there was still plenty more to do. I definitely recommend the Exploratorium for anyone looking for something out of the norm, especially if you have kids.
author: Emily R.

description:
Pros:
-Free every Pi Day (3/14)
-Tons of interactive exhibits. It would take a long time to go through everything!

Cons:
-Gets pretty crowded. Beware of stepping on kids.
author: Laura D.

description:
The Exploratorium is a great place to go if you want to feel like a kid again.

There are so many interactive exhibits - this place is huge! Lots of cool stuff to see, though it does get crowded. Little kids were everywhere hogging up the cool experiments, but there's always a few exhibits open while you wait your turn. 

Since this place is so big, you'll probably have to make multiple trips to see everything. I was there for 4 hours and didn't get see half of the exhibits, not because there was a wait, but because there are hundreds of them.

I had an awesome time and would definitely go again. :)
author: Stephanie G.

description:
Haven't been to this location ever since it has opened but finally got a chance to for the Thursday Late night 6-10pm for 18+. It was $15 which is pretty affordable and luckily found parking right across the street for free. Got there relatively late but it is okay....Was still able to breeze through the different cool activities.

I won't highlight all the cool activities/showcase but i will go over some of the more noticeable ones.

-Giant house : a mini house that slants upwards that u can crawl in to distort the size of yourself. Kind of like a playhouse... Very coool and interesting 

- Distorted giant mirror: it reflects you in all sorts of distorted angles

- illuminated fog machine-  on the second floor where u can create and bend fog to your liking

- Giant Chair to tiny Chair - Cool set up for pictures 

-Noise detection chamber - try to walk as quietly as possible... get a score and try to beat your friends



Love how the center is separated into different genres. Definitely a cool place to bring the kids or even a date. Bravo!
author: Auden W.

description: This is an awesome interactive science museum.  It's really big and hard to take it all in in a single visit. They do a great job of having exhibits that children and adults can learn from.  They cover a huge range of topics including social sciences, electricity, physics, weather, mechanics... The tickets are sort of expensive. We bought a Go Card that included admission on two days to a number of SF attractions including the Exploratorium.  The explainers did a great job too for the most part.
author: Brian R.

description: This really is a great place to take the kids!  We took our teenagers, though I think the younger ages are a better target.  Best ages prob 12 and younger.  There seems to be things to do that will keep the little ones busy for a good while.  If able to get the membership that would most likely be the way to go.   Finding discounts was not happening for us, so the cost seemed a bit steep.    Again there is lots and lots to do... they also have a fairly decent cafeteria, I won't rate hoe the food was, as it was cafeteria food.
author: tim d.

description: It's been years since my first visit to the Exploratorium and decided to bring my family on our recent trip to San Francisco. We conveniently parked across the street and enjoyed our 3 hours there. My young sons and husband absolutely loved the exhibits and I instantly regretted not allotting enough time for us to spend there.  We were intrigued but the cow eye dissection but was a little disappointed in the presentation in that it was difficult to hear. Overall, it was a great time and well worth the money spent. Will definitely go again to enjoy the exhibits in its entirety.
author: Irene G.

description:
***************************** 1357 ***************************

  If you are into history and want to dig deep about this vibrant town San Francisco, check out the Exploratorium. It will be worth it, not only for younger kids but adults as well. There's a lot of activities for you to do here and social experiments. 

   You can have the amazing view of the City from here to the bay, the Coit tower and Bay Bridge. 

   They do open on Thursdays from 6-10 pm for 18 and over adults. Discount for seniors, students, and military.
author: Manda Bear B.

description:
"TURN THE PAGE, WASH YOUR HANDS. TURN THE PAGE, WASH YOUR HANDS" - Filburt (Rocko's Modern Life)

Museum is pretty big, and has a lot of interactive activities... thus, tons of dirty hands touching everything! Kids are pretty unsanitary, and unfortunately some adults are too - people picking their noses, unprotected coughs/sneezes, scratching of the butts/balls. Just, gross. If you can't wash your hands in between activities, bring some hand sanitizer. In fact, just drench your entire body in hand sanitizer ya filthy bastard. lol. jk. ;)

My most memorable activity was the cow eye dissection presentation. The volunteers conducting the demonstration were high schoolers, and I was quite impressed. They were very good -- informative, engaging, and even offered hands on activities to the younger spectators. I wish I had the opportunity to play and learn, or even teach eyeballs when I was at that age. I learned about the anatomy of the eye when I was in my twenties, and dissection of (animal) body parts slowly followed. I am a current healthcare provider, so I enjoyed watching "future" healthcare providers taking charge of their future -- or so I thought. Those teenie boopers, aren't even interested in the health field! Upon further discussion, I learned that they (yes, both of them) want to go into engineering! Bastards! lol. jk. It's okay though. Everyone goes into the health care, eventually. It's better to figure it out early on, but oh well. It will happen, and they will just have to learn the hard way. ;)

One thing I do want to note is the expensive entrance fee, and standard museum hours. If you plan to visit, plan accordingly. You don't want to pay a pretty penny, and not have enough time to thoroughly enjoy the museum. Considering the amount of activities provided, and the size of the place, you need at least +2 hours.

Monday: Closed. 
Tuesday - Sunday 10-5pm.

Adults: $29..... Locals: $22
Seniors, students, disabilities, youth (13-17): $24..... Locals: $19
Youth (4-12): $19..... Locals: $17

Every Thursday evening for $15 from 6pm-10pm, they offer a weekly "After Dark" presentation for adults. Now, if you pick your nose, have unprotected coughs/sneezes, scratch your butt/balls but with a cocktail in your hand, at least you have an excuse. jk. Certain Thursdays they offer After Dark: Pairings. I think that is just another name for specialized yet limited h'orderves to coincide with the event planned for the week. In my opinion, they should offer it weekly and make it a Happy Hour thing. Us nerds also like snacks too, you know. We just never had the opportunity to enjoy it safely, or simply enjoy it at all. At least now, we can experience it within the haven of The Exploratorium. lol.
author: A E.

description: C and I was able to get in for free from his work perks. So we decided to BART into SF and go off at Embarcadero and walked to Pier 15/17 where it's located. It was a really nice during and forgot it was also Fleet Week! So there were a lot of people, but it was fine once inside. They have indoor and some outdoor exhibits and everything was interactive. Great place for kids, for sure!
author: Winnie T.

description: This placed is packed with so many different things to do. My kids and I enjoyed it very much. It was fun and educational.
author: Lupe T.

description:
Fun and play with science!

Great for kids, and they reopen Thursday evenings for adults only.

Every Thursday evening they open for adults only. It's less crowded and noisy than during the day, and they open several bars with beer, cider and cocktails.
author: Menlo K.

description:
I love this new location.  I had visited before but not since they opened their doors here.  So much to do and touch.  I visited with my kids and from the minute we walked in until we left they were engaged in  something.  Tons of information and ways to prove the information via interaction.  

I LOVED the shadow room.  Actually my favorite although when I first walked in there I had no idea what it was about.  All of a sudden I see a timer counting down so I am looking at it to see what's going to happen and FLASH!! I'M BLIND FOREVER!! My goodness that was like the flash a camera taking a night picture of earth from out of space (outer space?) would need.  I responded with what I assume was a ridiculously funny face because everyone including my children were hysterically laughing at my reaction.  Well after that first introduction to this outer space flash I realized that you stand against the wall in whatever pose you want and wait for the flash.  Then you move out of the way to see your shadow on the wall.  Pretty darn cool and we spent some time in there making all kinds of interesting poses.  Many other rooms that worked with body movement and those were cool to me too.

They had a few things I never saw at the other place and one of the things I saw as we were ending our day there was this area with information about "mental illness".  Some of it was creepy as hell and made me wish I could travel back in time and slap some people real hard for their ignorant way of thinking and then others - like the message wall made me cry because so many people today really get it.  So I ended a spectacular time there in tears but not all bad.

We also visited their little restaurant and I was really surprised because it was all gourmet food and everything was fresh and delicious.  Some of the staff there wasn't very friendly (that cashier) but the woman behind the salad counter (I believe she was a chef) was an absolute pleasure.  The one behind the pasta area was ok and so was the guy in the sushi area.  The food was not cheap but... when visiting these places I am way too familiar with getting a thing or two and paying big bucks.  The difference here was that it was quality food and so it was worth it.  

I believe every child should experience this place at least once.  Every adult should too.  There is so much to learn but because of the way it's set up children just see the fun part without feeling they are being schooled.

**FANTASTIC place for a child in the Autism spectrum that likes to touch things or see how things respond.  My son liked it a lot and played with many things.

**Wash hands or use sanitizer upon exit.
author: Betty R.

description: Pretty good experience.  Tons of hands on exhibits.  If you have a scientific, inquiring mind, you can spend hours here!  New exhibits being made here all the time.
author: David H.

description: Definitely the best museum I have ever been too. I realize that's a pretty broad statement but once you visit, you are sure to agree. The place is humongous, and really entertaining- so plan on spending a good chunk of time here. Tickets aren't cheap, but it's one of the only places we went to in SF that I can really say we felt was worth the price! All the exhibits are really cool and completely interactive- a lot of them were really neat and my husband and I messed with just as many as our 9 yr old did. This was my favorite thing we did all week!
author: Tiffany P.

description:
Omg this place is bigger! New location which, personally, I find to be more suitable. However, they sacrificed their own parking lot. Highly suggest to visit the website to check for their suggested parking lots. Don't forget to ask for a validation!! If you're from the Bay, you get a local discount which is $5 off from the ticket price! 

This museum has always been my favorite. It's all hands-on and with so many different exhibits. With the new location and new building, their exhibits are perfectly spread out. There was never a time that I had to crowd around an exhibit I wanted to see. You often feel mind blown afterwards. 

This place gets busy and crowded, no doubt about that. But if you come here before noon, you'll be alright. If you plan on seeing EVERYTHING then I would say plan on staying for about 3 hours? Lol. I came here on a Sunday and spent about the same  amount of time AND I didn't even go to every single exhibit. I'm telling you, there is so much to see!! However, with so much to do, it won't even feel like you've been there for so long. 

I will forever recommend this place to people. The staff is friendly and the patronage is diverse -- kids, teens, young adults, and elderly. It comes to
show you that The Exploratorium is something like Disneyland in the Bay. You'll never be too old for it.
author: Jenna T.

description: An interactive museum that will entertain all ages.  The exhibits range from math, science, physics, to biology.  It's easy to spend 3-4 hours in here in a flash.  They even have a few outdoor exhibits also.  The toilet drinking fountain was hilarious to me, cause I'm not drinking out of a toilet no matter what, lol!!  I think everyone should come here at least once and check this place out, it's well worth it!!
author: Phil A.

description:
Having a tech-based exploratorium in San Francisco that showcases innovation, experimenting around with new ideas, learning about formations of the biological Earth and being by the Pier, you can't ask for anything better to explore!

It's a great spot for an activity and an interactive outing - especially with friends, families or colleagues!  You can spend a good 2 or more hours, here, exploring the unique stuff that they have!

They serve up drinks if you need one and an oyster bar!

It is a big exploratorium, indeed, that boggles your mind, while making it entertaining as well!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
The Exploratorium is a very thought-provoking museum, with much to see, three cafes, and a store or two. If you want to get your money's worth and see most of the exhibits, arrive before 1, and avoid weekends. 
It's a large warehouse that spans over three acres, full of machines and contraptions. Practically every piece is interactive with your hands, so it's probably best to bring hand sanitizer along if you have small children (or are afraid of germs). 
The one exhibit that I have heard about but wasn't able to find was the optical illusion section, where apparently they have a room made to look very small, and chairs of all different sizes.
I wish tickets weren't so expensive so I could come back and see everything I missed! I also really don't like their hours...
author: Colby D.

description: So freaking cool! We took our youngest (13yrs) & nephew (14yrs) they had an absolute fantastic time! So many things to look at. We all had a great time! The place is huge! Very cool spot for all ages.
author: Elvira A.

description: They have an abundance of little experiments for the kids. My son is 13 now, and he quite enjoyed reading the explanations at each station and doing the activity. I don't feel like it's any fun for any child under the age of like 8, my daughter is one and a half and she pretty much only enjoyed the screen with the color shadows and the area with the fish. Other than than she just wanted to bang on everything. I was disappointed that this place doesn't have a designated nursing area, I was lucky I asked and they allowed me to use the first aid area. My daughter needs to nurse to reset when she becomes overwhelmed with crowds, with so many families with small children visiting, please think about providing a privacy room for breastfeeding.
author: Lee J.

description:
I call it play place for adults. Maybe it's because we came in during their night time at Exploratorium, similar to Thursdays at the Academy of Science when it's adults only. Spent so much time exploring and playing that we lost track of time. We had to be kicked out at 10pm and I was truly sad.  Give yourself enough time to explore, especially if your going to see an exhibition or show. 
Can't wait to go back!
author: Naty D.

description: Excellent science exhibits to entertain and educate both adults and toddlers. It's a large place, so cater at least a few hours to go through all the zones. Very kid-friendly and has sufficient toilets, water coolers etc for children. The top floor is an open area that overlooks the bay.
author: Lindt C.

description: Recommended amount of time to visit and touch everything- 2 hours. Very large open exhibit with plenty to see, touch and smell. Great for kids and playful adults, theres lots of neat interactive pieces or elaborate displays. I got a chance to see a beach monster in motion and it blew my mind! The gift show has lots of really neat gift ideas for just about anyone (me)
author: Raquel C.

description: This place is definitely worth a visit. My cousin and I (both in our 20s) went on a Thursday night and it was lots of fun! It wasn't overly crowded at all. We were there for 2.5 hours and could've easily stayed longer if it didn't close at 10. There's so much to see, including a beautiful view of the sunset over the bay. I'd suggest purchasing your ticket online if you're going at night. We avoided a very long line that way.
author: Erin V.

description:
So so fun!! My friends and I were so surprised that there was so much to do. We were there for a little over 2 hours, but it could have easily been 3. Some people have said that this is more for children, but we are all in our mid-20s and had a ton of fun. 

Totally worth the money spent! Kind of wish we had more time to finish all the exhibits.
author: Amy K.

description: Lots of kids with boundary, personal space issues.  I got to drink from a toilet!  Wish they served beer, I could throw a couple back while the kids manage their curiosity, I feel totally safe here.  I enjoyed the group games, especially the cattle death.
author: Defn N.

description: This place is awesome!! My kinda thing! I love tinkering and all of this science/engineering type of stuff. Really interesting place for having a different learning experience!! LOVE IT!
author: Tiffany S.

description:
This is definitely one of the coolest museum ever!

It has lots of interactive parts and it teaches you a lot about about several parts of Science like behavior, mathematics, geology, biology, and more.

It's a must-go for anyone who is curious about life and how the World works.
author: Andréia S.

description: Here on vacation and went to their Thursday night half price event.  So far it's been our favorite evening spent in San Francisco.  Wish we had spent more than two hours time there though, so get there early for time to see everything.
author: Tesha D.

description:
Having been to several other science museums in SoCal and New York, I'd say this is my favorite one. It goes beyond kiddie stuff like "what are waves" and "how do solar panels work"; plenty of the material requires advanced understanding to fully appreciate, yet can nonetheless be enjoyed by young kids.

For example, one of the exhibits involves an inverted pendulum. At the right is an inverted pendulum which challenges the visitor to move it left and right, trying to keep it up. However, this is a very difficult task for a human to do. At the left, there is an inverted pendulum controlled by a robotic arm driven an AI algorithm. It is so good at what is does that even if the pendulum is allowed to fall (e.g. by a human pushing over the pendulum), it is able to swing it back into position. To a child, this is a cool robot trick. To someone who studied CS in college, this is an example of reinforcement learning. Actually, when taking CS 229 at Stanford, we wrote a Matlab program to solve this exact problem. Of course, we were only running it on a simulator and our algorithm did a lot worse than the one in the museum, but it's nice to see something you've learned put into practice.

Another example (albeit more high-school level) is a ramp where you can launch balls from various heights, and the distance traveled by the balls is the square root of the height from which they were launched. From high-school physics, we know that the trajectory of a ball in the air is a parabola, so the maximum height attained (which is equal to the height from which it was launched, minus negligible effects of friction and air resistance) is proportional to the square of the horizontal distance traveled.

Other cool exhibits include a picture on a screen that changes in a subtle way every few seconds. Normally, our eyes detect such changes very easily, but when you insert a blank frame in between, it's hard to notice the difference unless you happened to be staring at the right spot at the right moment. There is also a station where you can listen to multiple recorded conversations at the same time, and most people realize that they can only pay attention to one conversation at a time. There is also an outside area with a rain generator.

Despite its relatively small size, this museum has lots of things to do. (It's also surprisingly hard to navigate, even with a map.) Come with the whole family or solo or with friends. It'll be a blast.

89/100
author: Tony J.

description:
Came here on Memorial Day, Monday. 

Let me tell you right now, don't go on a major holiday. It's super crowded and  it's almost like a zoo. 

Overall I found my visit to the exploratorium to be really exciting. The staff at the front were really nice and welcoming. The exhibits are extremely hands on and interactive ( so make sure you wash your hands frequently.lol) I have to say my favorite exhibits would have to be the monochromatic room, How to Walk Like a Fox and the tidal memory station. It's a great place for all ages. Like all museums and fun places; wear comfy shoes, there's a ton of walking and lots of exhibits you can't really try in heels.lol (fox walking. Haha)
author: Luisa P.

description:
Cool little interactive science exhibits that explores the realms of psychology, science, math, and other subjects. Went to an after dark event which was adults only. Member at the ticket kiosk said it would take around 2.5 hours to see everything but we only saw two of the six areas in that amount of time. Very interactive exhibits, would be a great place for a date with great sight lines into the bay.
The exploratorium is located close the the BART, and short walks away from union square and China town. Need Togo again just to see the rest.
author: Christopher P.

description:
What a great place. There are a lot of kids, but what do you expect? I'm not a fan of children, but It was actually so great seeing kids get interested in all these science concepts. Such a great way to get kids excited about STEM. 

There are sooooo many exhibits!! You cannot get through all of them in one day. I just wish they closed the place a bit later. Overall, I really loved this place.
author: Lyra P.

description:
A day at the new Exploritorium at pier 15/17. It had been over 20 years since I had been in the Exploritorium and we were all looking forward to seeing the new space which opened last winter. 

Opens at 10am and there was a line out the door at 9:45 - best advice, pre buy your tickets online. My wife bought ours the week or so before and we did not stand in line. Actually saved a minimum of half an hour standing in line - getting our tickets in advance. 

The place fills up quickly and parking becomes a premium by noon time. There are so many different things to do and play with its almost overwhelming. Our teenager spent over an hour in the first 50' of this enormous building. We took a short walk, 10 minutes and returned and he was still playing on the same display in the tinkering workshop. This is an all day event. 

Plan to have lunch, lots of places to sit and enjoy the view. Two restaurants, one up front and one in the back. As well you may bring food. There are lots of hands on things for young and old alike. Watched people from toddlers to grand parents interacting with the same projects, displays and experiments it is a great place for the family to spend an awesome day.
 
For the $29 admission it seems more than fair for the amount of activities and things to do and experience there that are available, by comparison to an amusement park setting where admission is often double. 

This this a great addition to the city and the fisherman's wharf. Visit the new Exploritorium you will be glad you did. 

A 5 Star attraction in the city.

00049
author: Ray F.

description:
What a great place for all ages! Those of you who are into science and engineering... This is the place to go! A bit pricey but it's well worth it! $30 for adults and $20 for kids. 
It's by the water too, so, it's great. It has a good view outside of the bay bridge so, come on over when your in San Fran! 
You can spend hours here. There are lots to touch and see. Summer hours is until 9 pm. 
My girls and I had a blast here!
author: Christina S.

description: Super fun place to spend the day at. You could honestly spend all month in here! By far the most interactive museum I have ever been to. A great place for kids, tourists, adults, or anyone feeling a little creative. Definitely recommend!
author: Ross S.

description:
Wow!  I finally got the chance to go to the Exploratorium since it moved into Fisherman's Wharf!  When it was at the Palace of Fine Arts, I remember my family taking me there often and it hardly ever changed- it was one of those - I been there, done that - kind of things.  But now in the new location, the museum seems even better.  

I recognized some of the old exhibits but most of the exhibits were new and very innovative.  I especially liked the goldfish displays, the light experimental exhibits and the pinball machine. Also, loved the artistic toothpick sculptures, just wish I remember the name of the artist who did them.   The location is breathtaking as it is right on its own pier.  It is two story and has lots of sitting areas though out the building.  

On the second floor, there is a classroom/lecture forum.  On every second Thursday of the month, this room is open for a food pairing/lecture event.  My boyfriend and I had the opportunity to go to the last one which was all about seaweed.  The food was delicious which included a seaweed pasta, mashed potatoes in a seaweed bowl, seaweed jello and more.  It made me crave for more seaweed!  Yummy!!! 

Next month, the topic will be on artichokes and I really would love to go to that one.  I live in the artichoke capital of the world- Castroville!   Then in July, the topic will be bugs....hmmm..  I am not that daring...no I cannot consider trying bug dishes.  Sorry.  

Pros:
-a fun and engaging way to learn about science
-great Thursday night events including once a month food pairings/lecture
-attractive and spacious museum
-many exhibit combine science and art 
-free play pinball machine (but is very popular)
-much of the exhibits are interactive 
-innovative restaurant on site
-classes offered for teachers and students 
-located conveniently on Fisherman's Wharf
-great views of the bay from this place

Cons:
-admission can be expensive if you do not have coupons or go through an event service like Up & Out
-most items at the gift shop are way overpriced 
-gets very crowded here so best to come early
-most parking around the building is pricey
author: Irene S.

description:
The Exploratorium FINALLY lives up to the hype.

I first visited twenty years ago (as a young-ish person), and I've been back twice in the past decade (this time with my kids). All three visits were enjoyable, but none of them were the awesome and amazing hands-on encounter with science that I'd somehow been led to expect. The Exploratorium felt a lot like any other science museum -- maybe a little more hands-on, but not mind-blowing.

In its new space on the Embarcadero, the Exploratorium really is mind-blowing. We were there for several hours with our two kids (ages 9 & 11) and I felt like we only did justice to a quarter of it. I loved the social science exhibit (finally! we social scientists get our due in a science museum) and the kids enjoyed their return to the Tactile Dome (a.k.a. my personal version of hell -- but I figured that out the last time we were here).

If you've visited the Exploratorium before and been underwhelmed, give it a try in its new home. If you haven't visited, you're in for a real treat. And if you're in the Bay Area and you have kids, join -- I could take my kids here every month, and I wouldn't run out of new stuff to explore.
author: Alexandra S.

description: We had a phenomenal time here at the Exploratorium . We took five children and five adults  yet ten children left the Exploratorium . I saw the glow and excitement in all our eyes . We enjoyed all the exhibits so much and learned all sorts of new things . Can not wait to bring the family back. It was a great way to celebrate this monumental Birthday celebration
author: Antonio D.

description:
If you're an adult without kids, try to come on a weekday when it's less busy.  The thought of touching the same exhibits that other kids touched grosses me out.  Everything was so greasy.

Also, I imagine it to be a mental overload if you try to interact with EVERY exhibit.  It's a lot.  If that's your goal, I'd recommend you start early in the day, take a lunch break nearby, then finish it up in the afternoon.  It will take some resolve.

Needless to say, this is an amazing place.  There is so much to learn even as an adult.
author: Shannon L.

description:
What a fun day trip, a visit to the Exploritorium.  It's an easy walk from the Ferry building, the 9:30 a.m. ferry from Vallejo gets you there at around 10:45 a.m., after the mad rush for tickets when the Exploritorium opens at 10:00 a.m.  Only one family was ahead of us to purchase tickets.  The building was already pretty crowded but we were able to get our hands on most of the exhibits without waiting.  We spent about 6 hours there and missed a few sections of exhibits but had a grand time.  

If you go, make sure to go up to the upper level and go outside to the Bay Observatory Terrace.  Go inside the white canvas structure on the terrace.  It is a camera obscura. Not to be missed.  Give your eyes time to adjust to the dark and you will be treated to a bay view on the table in the structure.

We brought our own food along for lunch and ate it in the outdoor exhibit area.  There seemed to be no problem with us doing so.
author: Jacquelin S.

description:
What person, man, woman, or child comes here without a sparkle in their eye?

With the Exploratorium drawing in nearly 550,000 people annually, it's amazing to see how adults have just as much fun as kids when visiting through the exhibits. 

My first time coming here was actually at their prior location next to Palace of Fine Arts. The Exploratorium is now housed among the Piers along the Embarcadero Waterfront. Not only is this location in such a prime SF area with views casting out into the bay, parallel to the skyscrapers in the Financial District, but it's what's inside that truly is a marvel!

The scientific discoveries of the centuries have fascinated scientists and nerdlings alike, bringing together the most creative mindsets and sparking the scientific revolution. This has shaped our present and is rapidly taking us into the unknown and vast, cosmic future. 

There have been so many interesting scientists and fictional characters that we associate with invention and revolution. Nikola Tesla, Albert Einstein, Thomas Edison, even Dr. Jekyll & Mr. Hyde or the mad scientist who created Frankenstein. This allows a spark for curiosity and paves the way for great inventions. 

Here at the Exploratorium, you can view scientific accomplishments in action, you can test drive experiments for yourself, and you can also learn how these different scientific principles apply to our day to day lives. 

For those of you still awake at this point, I shall continue. 

The father of AC electricity, Nikola Tesla, was a Croatian inventor who moved to America in the late 19th century. He showed the world how AC electricity was the way of the future. The exhibit, "The Electric Flame," here at the Exploratorium, demonstrates how electricity can jump from one electrical node to another, creating a bluish colored flame. This verrrry same style of flame was used when Frankenstein was created. 

ZAAAP! It's ALIVE!!!

You are able to generate this flame for yourself at "The Electric Flame" exhibit. Fun tidbit: AC electricity also powers every house in America and worldwide. Think of all your electronic gizmos. 

Another cool exhibit demonstrated how Aurora Borealis aka Northern Lights came to be. Definition: Auroras are created by charged particles, mainly electrons and protons, entering the atmosphere from above causing ionization and excitation of atmospheric constituents, and consequent optical emissions. 

For those of you who understood as much of that as I did, then a simpler definition is greatly needed. I shall attempt it. Soooo... small electrically charged thingys go high into the sky and collide with other electrically charged thingys and then KABLAM! Ooooh Ahhhh. Beautiful colors of green, blue, and sometimes red, light up the Alaskan skies. Thus, Aurora Borealis is born. 

If that isn't cool, I don't know what is.

So yeah, the Exploratorium is such an uberly awesome possum place to be! You get to learn and discover so much!

Have fun and get your nerd on.
author: Ann S.

description:
If you've ever watched Mr. Wizard or Bill Nye the Science Guy, you've probably been to the new Exploratorium a dozen times already. Am I right? A $300 million makeover on a previously dilapidated pier didn't sound all that promising to me since I was not a great student in Miss Bigelow's science class, especially when I had to dissect a frog or present a dead bug collection when half my bugs were still alive but comatose. Now it's over three times larger than the original location (photo: http://bit.ly/13IXQD1), and since the Exploratorium's big move from the Palace of Fine Arts in April, it has really turned the museum into quite the "It" spot.

The Embarcadero setting has a lot to do it, and it's certainly more convenient to take the F-line to get here. Regardless, I was amazed at how packed it was a couple of weeks ago when Jamie W. and I were swimming upstream against the crowds going the other way (photo: http://bit.ly/155V0vT). We were able to enjoy it much more back at the end of March when the museum had a series of members-only nights, and only a handful of people were roaming the cavernous place that stretched for over 330,000 square feet. Over 600 exhibits are on display at any given time, a full quarter of which were built specifically for the new location.

Clearly the most engaging ones are interactive but in ways that feel retro and wizardly rather than technological. That's really a huge part of the funky charm of this place, isn't it? I played with the slinky (photo: http://bit.ly/15SRqEq). I shape-shifted my face in the camera (photo: http://bit.ly/198WBFr). I made my own light show (photo: http://bit.ly/15TpPoD). You don't have to be a kid to enjoy these exhibits, you just have to remember you were one some time back. The Seaglass Restaurant is a bit of a botch offering pricey choices in a cafeteria setting (review: http://bit.ly/1by4fdn). The view's great though (photo: http://bit.ly/18qj2TT).
author: Ed U.

description:
There is a wealth of learning and knowledge to be had here, but you've got to be in the learning mood to take advantage.

There are so many displays/activities/exhibits to check out, you really do probably need a whole day to take it in.  The problem is, even if you have the whole day, can you focus yourself on learning for all of it?

We couldn't.  Not saying it's anyone's fault but our own, but for two working adults I guess it was a little too much thinking for a Saturday.

Having said that, there's probably enough somewhat mindless quick things you can do that it may still be fun.  I will say we enjoyed trying to make our own marble obstacle course that actually worked, which took us longer than we thought it would.

So my tip would be just know that you will need to be in a learning mood in order to really get the full benefit of the Exploratorium.
author: Brent T.

description:
I was able to attend the Tactile Dome Opening Reception and loved it!
My first time back since the move to the Pier and it is spacious and well designed.
The tactile dome was scarier than I remembered but still a lot of fun. It is worth the extra $$ if you haven't gone through the maze before.
The area is great for lots of photo ops and the Ferry Building is a stones throw away. Great place to be a kid again :)
author: Angela D.

description:
This building is huge to begin with.  It is filled with all those experiments you wanted to try but for one reason or other didn't.  Hands on for 5 to 50 year olds.  You will spend at least 3 hrs to start with and thats only the first visit.  It will take many more visits to appreciate and capture the learning experience this establishment provided!

Didn't get 5 stars because there wasn't any sitting area other than the restaurant at the end and outside quarters weather permitting.
author: Marlyn M.

description:
Hands down one of the best museums i have ever visited. I was excited to be there during a weekday while school was in session, however, once the school groups started showing up, it got pretty busy and crowded. 

But the whole museum is interactive and if you or your kid loves science this is a MUST visit. So glad we made it. so worth the money.

we spent about 2.5 hours here, but you can seriously spend all day if you really wanted to!
author: Erica B.

description:
Definitely a stop for the young and the young at heart!! Make a day of it because you can't see it all. You just have to be selective about what section you want to spend the most time at. A must do, if you're into cool, neat gadgets and love learning about things.
Food choices are slim so bring snacks to eat outside or step out to eat and then come back. Eaterie in the front and a restaurant in the back. Interesting​ selection, just way over priced. Who serves miss soup without rice as a side anyways. Side of rice (2 scoops) - $5. Clam chowder was okay... wish I could have tasted the clams. Everything else was okay.
So come for the experience but make sure you plan the meals.
author: James A.

description:
Tickets and yearly memberships are tax deductible. This alone is worth it.

I love the new location. Amazing views. Cool new exhibits. Parking is $$$ so carpool or plan ahead. 

We spent 1.5 hours here and barely covered the first floor.
author: Helen F.

description:
HANDS ON EVERYTHING

Located at Pier 15 (we walked from the Ferry Bldg!), this was our 2nd attraction using our City Pass. I thought this place would be like a Discovery Center for kids but this place was a bit overwhelming for my little kids. There are SOOOOOOOO many things to touch, feel, hear, see, smell, and did I mention you can touch almost everything?

Of course it would be my kids to immediately find the ONE THING YOU CAN NOT TOUCH, which took over 37 years and more than 105,000 toothpicks to make:
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/exploratorium-san-francisco-2?selected=o9dVNKdoTcaikuj35qxDbw#Rpzi2KNHjqpHp7Cc9VgZ5g
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/exploratorium-san-francisco-2?selected=o9dVNKdoTcaikuj35qxDbw#-q2n83euieVEhwK2NEVSCw  

They have a lot of physics and science concepts that are more appropriate for older children (in middle to high school) like electricity, center of gravity, perpetual motion, light spectrum, and other things I either didn't feel like explaining or couldn't figure out how to explain to my little kids.  How do you explain what an ion is to a preschool kid?  Or what a sound wave or Hertz is? 

My kids were able to participate in a few workshops and thought this place was cool but they have no idea just how cool it is.  I bet in 5 years they will totally get it.
author: Lori I.

description:
This place is huge! We could only see about half of it in two hours. I took my 12 year old brother and we both had a great time. Educational in a fun and entertaining way. Would definitely recommend if you have kids and are looking for a full afternoon of activities!

I did not eat here, so please disregard the crab picture.
author: Jillian M.

description: It was super awesome!!!! They had simple demos of popular scientific principles. It was super cool to see all of the exhibits.
author: Wyatt S.

description:
Although the website says they have stuff for toddlers it is all really geared towards older kids (5+ I would say). I brought my two toddlers and spent $50 to enter and there were few things they could understand or were interested in. It was also really crowded on a Thursday morning because there were a few school trips. That said, seems like it would be a blast for them if they were older. And it probably would have been a better experience had it not been so crowded.

We brought them to the California Academy of Sciences and they enjoyed that much more. I would recommend for younger kids.
author: danielle m.

description:
Great exhibits for kids of all ages. You learn about science and other things that teach you about cause and effect. 
 
I  came here when it was at the Palace of Fine Arts and now I get to take my kid here.  
Just a 1/4 mile down is the ferry building where you stock up on gourmet treats.
author: James H.

description:
This was straight up AWESOME. 

It was a museum full of fun, hands on activities and learning experiences. If you don't love walking around with sticky, slimy, children who like to touch everything and sneeze on your kneecaps, then this is not the place for you. However, we all must live our lives and not be complete germ-a-phobes, so I'd say suck it up, bring some hand sanitizer, and giggle along with the kids. 

It's slightly hard to navigate, and there is a lot going on, so plan on being there for a solid 3 hours if you want to get the full experience. Grab a map and read the signs, you'll make it out alive if you just follow your inner compass--unless your inner polarity is jacked, then I got nothing for you except a solid "good luck". 

You're going to leave with all of your senses being completely stimulated, not remembering how you ended up where you did--so take photos and VIDEOS. It'll be worth going back through and watching them again. And if you're with "that guy" who was so overwhelmed that you found him huddled in the fetal position on your way out, you can go through your photos with him later so he doesn't miss out entirely. 

TIPS & TRICKS: 
* If you want your children to know you're the cool parent, bring them along. They will be in heaven, and the best part is that they'll ask you questions like, "Why is it doing this? How does the sand move? Why is your face large in that mirror?" And you'll quickly read the explanation (because let's face it, you really didn't know what the heck was happening either) and tell them in your own words. It is at this time that they'll leave thinking you are all-knowing, and will never question you, ever again. 
* Drink from the toilet drinking fountain. It's weird.
author: Haley N.

description: We usually sign up for one or a couple of annual memberships somewhere and this time we thought we would try the Exploratorium, it was our first time there....was a little reluctant as it seemed they didn't have much for toddlers but they had plenty for all ages.  We took the ferry boat there and hung out at the farmers market and walked over.  Our 5 year old has a blast, we were so surprised how much was condensed into this place....and by the way, this place is HUGE!  We didn't even finish exploring the entire museum...maybe 75% of it?  We were exhausted but our little one could have gone allll day.   We were pleasantly surprised and love our decision to be members.  Looking forward to the summer days when the weather is amazing and we can do this more often!  I would highly recommend for all ages!  Learned a lot too :)
author: Angie I.

description:
The Exploratorium is good for:

1) Gorgeous views of the bay

2) Thoughtfully curated hands on science-y exhibits 

3) Hand sanitizer manufacturers 

4) Fun potential stocking stuffers like crayon puzzles, slinkys and temporary tats

5) Pricey admission tickets ($29 per adult, $22 for Bay Area peeps)

6) Long lines, extreme overcrowding and general kiddie chaos

7) Paying more $ if you would like to see the Tactile Dome. (Meh!)

8) Checking out a cool spirograph drawing thing, gross termites, making mini rainbows, topsy turvey mirrors and watching kids make it rain.

9) Happy nephews 

10) Proof positive that being an auntie rather than a parent is totally working for you.
http://goo.gl/IGVifZ
author: Amy C.

description: Such a neat place with so many things to do and try that you can easily spend an entire day here! It was also neat to see the research lab & workshop where they come up with ideas and make the exhibits. Definitely a must see for people of all ages, though when we went this place felt like a kid's paradise- there were children everywhere! The admission was a bit costly but expected with all the repairs the museum must go through for its machines. Make sure you ask for student/teacher discounts! Cuts the price down significantly :) also, admission is free 15 minutes before the museum closes!
author: Johnny Z.

description: i took my 2 young kids to this place (5 and 2 yrs old). this place have many science related hands on activities. it's current location on pier 15 is very scenic. it's also close to tourist attractions; fisherman warf and ferry building. very educational. it's a bit costly for their entrance fee but still worth it to check out.
author: Jack W.

description:
This museum is quite expensive, but it is worth it. There are so many wonderful interactive exhibits, displays and machines, that hours go by in no time. The Exploratorium is certainly also entertaining for adults (luckily for us there were not so many children when we visited).

Closing time came too soon, although your mind is "full" after some hours of learning, getting constant impressions and being active in discovering the world of science :-) Maybe a ticket which is valid for more than 1 day would be a good thing!  Note: Free Wi-Fi is available in the museum!
author: Annelies B.

description:
Thank you Exploratorium for giving a discount to Bay Area residents & students - you can get a student ticket for just $15 by showing them your student ID (even if you've graduated...but don't tell them that!). 

The new location offers a great view of the Bay. Just walk out onto the patio on the 2nd floor and soak up the view of the Bay Bridge, sailboats, and beautiful water. It's also a lot bigger than the old location and you can seriously devote about 3 hours here to fully experience everything - definitely bring your walking shoes! 

The info desk did not provide much help on the best exhibits to check out but here are some of my favorites:

+ Bio section - you can see a real live chicken embryo
+ Upside down mirror where you can reach out and almost touch yourself, ET style. 
+ Electric/mechanic section - get on a bike to see how you can generate energy for light bulbs, radio, and/or a fan. 
+ 2nd floor drawing room - draw your interpretation of The Bay
+ Walk across gravel and see how much "noise" you really make
+ Sit out in the gazebo and watch little kids play if you're tired of being indoors.

There are abundant interactive exhibits - rehash your knowledge about physics, biology, etc.  Learning is FUN! I brought an out of town visitor here and won't hesitate to bring my nieces and nephews back too. Kids under 5 get in for free. 

I also love the new location's proximity to public transportation - get off at Embarcadero BART and it's only a 10 min. walk away. You can easily get lunch in the Ferry Building or Little Italy beforehand.
author: Bonnie Z.

description:
I grew up going on field trips to the Exploratorium at the old location in the Palace of Fine Arts. I was sad they moved but embraced the change.  The new location has given them much more room to spread out and evolve.  Now that it's on the Embarcadero you can group your visit with other things like the Ferry Plaza, Pier 39 and Fisherman's Wharf.  

It's the one museum where you are allowed to touch almost everything.
Kids and grownups alike are entertained by seeing how and why things work the way they do. That being said, the excitement can turn into kids being very pushy, not waiting their turn or not allowing others to have a turn because their parents are distracted.  To lessen your exposure to kids running amok, go to an After Dark event on Thursdays where it's adults only.  Not to say you won't run into an adult that has the same behavior.  On other days, since there are field trips, a week day is not necessarily your saving grace.  Show up early or after 3 and crowds typically thin out.  Saturdays and holidays are the most packed.  Being a member also pays off as the member only events are also less crowded.  

Step out on the top level deck, there's a nice view of the Bay Bridge and Treasure Island.  There's also a camera obscura there right now (for fellow photo geeks).  Plan for at least 2-3 hours if you're going to go through the whole place and not tinker with everything.  

Don't forget to drink from the toilet before you leave ;)
author: Kristi G.

description: Our family trip was built around going to the Exploratorium. We are a homeschooling family and after seeing a video online of a cows eye being dissected, we were fascinated. And we now have our own personal video of it because we caught the presentation right after it began. The Museum is HUGE. I can't say that I was interested in EVERYTHING we saw, but feel there is something there for everyone, and many other things that may spark your interests. We visited only one day and weren't able to see each exhibit, but were very pleased that there were many cool things to actually interact with and learn from.
author: Litameadows ..

description:
Fun place!! Lots of cool and interesting exhibits.  Make sure to come early, like first thing when they open, like we did, around 10am, in order to avoid the masses, it'll give you more time to understand and test each exhibit.  Also, its a great place to take a date, especially on adult night (which I was told is on Thursday).  Definitely coming back again!

Note: To avoid the crazy long ticket lines (like we did), buy your tickets online in advance.  It'll save you at least an hour.
author: Mike M.

description:
Went to the new Exploratorium location on Pier 15/17, it's only 10 minutes from Embarcadero Bart Station so most everyone can do the walk.

It's $25 adults, but for locals in the Nine SF Bay Area Counties only $20!  Kid regular price is $19, local $15.  Discounts help.

There's 2 places to eat there without Museum Admission: Seismic Joint Cafe - small cafe with ready-to-eat food, pretty quick.  $6 chowder is not very good & boiling hot, not filled up to the brim either only 12 oz!  Seaglass Restaurant - there's a sushi bar, black beans - by the time we got it was cold, polenta fries that were fried fresh - B. said hot & fresh, really good.  Wraps, cookies, local honey, etc.

6 galleries - I didn't see them all.  
600+ exhibits, I didn't see even half!  Must go back!

Bay Observatory Terrace- you don't need Museum Ticket to see!

You can drink out of a "toilet" - funny photo op.

Lots of things to take pics of!

Many bathrooms.

Gift shop next to the Cafe.  Worth some photos!

Worth a visit, glad it's closer to Downtown SF!

Hrs:
Mon: Closed, except select Holidays
Tues: 10-5
Wed 10-10
Th 10-5 &
Th 6-10pm for Adults Only!!  18+, $15
F-Sun 10-5

PS: There are Five FREE Days if u don't mind waiting a while!
Sun 9/29/13 - Engineering Day
Sun 10/13/13 - Founder's Day
Sun 2/2/14 - Groundhog Day
Fri 3/14/14 - Pi Day
Sun 5/11/14 Mother's Day
http://www.exploratorium.edu/visit/faq
author: Ann L.

description:
1. Sunday is a pretty darn good time to go. We were able to get FREE parking, right across the street from the museum. Street parking, Sunday was free. Crossed the crosswalk and we were right there. 

2. It's a large enough space to take up about 2 hours of your time. The displays/exhibits were definitely interesting enough if you take the time to really read into the science. But if you are just into looking without interacting, you may not get much out of the place.

3. If you are tired walking all the way to Exhibit 6, there is a great large window that has nice open ocean views. 

4. Sunday was again probably a great day to go since the museum was not terribly over run with kids. They definitely occupied a lot of the exhibits, but not all.

5. The staff was generally very friendly and helpful.
author: Kelly G.

description: I took my four kids today and they absolutely loved it! I have 3 children under three and they were free. We came on a weekday so it won't be so crowded and it worked out perfectly. There were still some schools visiting but they mostly left about 1:30 and it was pretty easy to do anything we wanted. There is a restaurant all the way in the back , a bit pricey but that's expected. Parking right across the street and don't forget to get your hand stamped so you can leave for lunch and then go back.
author: Inez E.

description:
This is a fun museum, even the adults are engaged.  It was fun to play with our children, even though they're a "tween" and a teen, they still loved it.  We didn't see any exhibits that were broken or missing items, they all were functional and I'm sure that's no small feat!  

My only advice is to bring your own food.  The food is not overly kid-friendly and is very expensive.
author: Vickie S.

description:
I have been to a couple of science museums and this one was just alright in my opinion. I had high expectations after reading all these 5 star reviews and 4.5 overall rating. I got here around 12pm on a Friday and there was a line to get in! I waited about 15 minutes to get in. I didn't know what was taking so long. I paid my admission and went on my way within 30 seconds when it was my turn. 

This place has hundreds and hundreds of interactive activities. A couple were not working that day but it was not a big deal. The museum was separated into 6 areas/galleries according to a theme. It was neat to see most of them and interact with a few since this place was packed with kids. I had to skip a few activities since you would need a partner and I came by myself. I walked though the entire place within an hour. I noticed it became a little less crowded so I hit up the other activities that I missed. All in all I spend about 1.5 hours there. (Compared to the 5 hours at the OSMI in Portland, Oregon. I also spent about 3 hours at the Denver science museum which would have been longer if I didn't have a flight to catch).
