Was this place worth $29 admission fee? In my opinion, no. 
Would I come back here? Maybe, if the price was lowered to around $20
author: Jimmy P.

description:
Great informal education for the kids.

Came here shortly after it's grand opening and this place was packed with people lining up before the doors had opened. Admission fee for an adult is $25. This place is great for children for some hands on education. It's neat they have little class sessions for children to attend for more of an in-depth learning. 

The black room with the ghost was pretty scary. After reading the description of the purpose for the black room, I still had a hard time figuring out the "educational" part to it. I think it freaked some little kids out. 

Great location on the pier with a great view of the bay bridge in the back.
author: Mei W.

description: Had such a blast here with my friends on a Saturday after checking out the farmers market and restaurants at the ferry building. You definitely need more than one day to experience all the exhibits. They have food offerings inside, so it might be worth it to just eat inside and stay from open to close to maximize your coverage of the museum and get most value for your ticket if you don't plan on a return trip.
author: Phillip P.

description:
We haven't been able to go to the actual exploratorium yet.. But the book store was -awesome-! This is still on the to do list. 

But I did want to leave a compliment for Skorpio, who was in the gift shop ,he's personable and warm and quite ready to answer any questions you might have. And if you're at the artmatic machine, be sure to put $5 in and see what art you get. I enjoyed my $15 purchases.
author: Dianna B.

description:
I went here last weekend for the second time. Even though I have been here before, I still spent about 4 hours exploring all of the exhibits. This place is great for all ages. I'm 23, and I think that I had just as much fun as the kids who were visiting. I think this is a great place to take your kids for the day and even to take a date. I in particular enjoyed gallery 1, which was based on social behavior. Most of the exhibits are interactive. Be prepared to walk around a lot and get your hands a little dirty.

The ferry building is also nearby. Which is a nice place to get lunch before or dinner after.

If you are a local or a student, be sure to ask about special pricing!
author: Cynthia M.

description:
When I saw the exploratorium was moving from its old location, I was worried they would reduce the exhibits and just make it a showcase for big donors. In my opinion, the California Academy of Sciences did that when it used to be a really nice museum with many exhibits but when they renovated it, the place turned out to be a mess. I was scared the same would happen to the exploratorium, one of my favorite museums in the Bay Area. 

I turned out to be 100% wrong. 

I visited the exploratorium for the first time since it reopened and I absolutely loved it. First off, they had more exhibits. I loved the observatory. Also, they expanded that bio science area. While I loved the first one, the new one was even better. Also, I liked their outside exhibits with the mist and the rain (although no one will be out there when it actually rains). But overall, what I liked the most was that they kept all exhibits from the old location. 

Now onto my favorite (or should I say most distracting) exhibits. 

2nd best kept secret: this exhibit showing overfishing had you text "fish" to a number so your boat would survive but not texting "fish" too much or the fish would go extinct. I still have fun texting that (including while writing this review).

Best kept secret: Daisy, an AI computer program like siri that you can type conversations with, the program mixes up the words you type and creates new sentences. I love getting her to talk about certain topics and seeing how she responds. For example, I talked about how much I love USC sports and she kept saying "Go USC!" I even put in some mean girls quotes to see what she would do. She took the bait and kept saying fetch, even after I told her at least ten times to stop trying to make fetch happen. 

Overall, it was such an amazing visit. They kept the integrity of it, did not turn it into a showcase for large donors but at the same time made some important updates. I'm going back for sure!
author: Alec W.

description:
I went to the Exploratorium back when it was at the Palace of Fine Arts. I thought the exhibits were great and fun even for adults. Now, fast forward a few years later, and the Exploratorium is now at the pier. It's a big space and you can spend a few hours going through all the exhibits.

As fun as the exhibits are, you do have to touch a lot of things and it starts to feel really gross really fast. Maybe I missed them but I didn't see any hand sanitizing stations. They should really have them at like every third exhibit or something.

There are a lot of kids on the weekend so if you don't like kids, don't go on the weekend.
author: Danielle C.

description:
This place is fantastic - this was one of my favorite places to go as a child, and still remains one of my favorite places to go even as an adult. The new space is spacious and almost perfect for the exploratorium, and there's even a nice patio on the top where you can stand and look towards the ocean.

The exhibits are extremely fun and almost everything is tactile and fun to play with. The exhibits, while some have been around for over a decade, are generally well-maintained as well.

TIP: If you're 18+ and want to go (and not bring children), definitely go during the "After Dark" series they have on Thursday Nights. It's half price ($15 instead of $30), and there will be no kids running around. Great date night for any couple.

TIP: The tactile dome is really fun and worth the $10.
author: William C.

description:
I went for the Sexplorations after hours on a Thursday night. It was awesome. I never knew I could be entertained watching live sea urchin insemination! I recommend checking out a special after hours event to avoid kids taking over everything and get some special exhibits.

The tactile dome is a must! It costs extra and doesn't take that long, but its a super cool experience. 

All of the different sections are super cool and very diverse. You could easily spend a couple hours just going through the standard attractions, so don't expect to see everything if you go for after hours. The living section with plants and animals was from favorite part, but I spent maybe the most time in the sound section, just listening to everything.

The restaurant is worth it too. Not too expensive and a lot of options. I got spicy carnitas fries and a stevia soda. Other options were sushi, mussels, and mixed sandwiches.
author: Ryan H.

description:
I finally was able to pay this place a visit! I must say, it was everything I hoped it would be and more.

This place is a wonderful science hub. There are over 600 interactive exhibits, and I don't think I even made it to half of them in a 3 or 4 hour time span. There are exhibits dedicated to engineering, math, color, optical illusions, design, sound, emotions, and so much more. 

I had heard the Exploratorium was a better Tech Museum, but this place blows the Tech Museum out of the water. I guess it's like comparing Great America to Disneyland... they're just on entirely different levels.

If anyone has a curiosity or love for science, they'll be right at home here. The museum is perfect for children, as the exhibits have easy-to-follow instructions and are full of interaction. I also thought it was a great date idea, and if it wasn't such a pain to get into the city on weekday nights, I would love to give the after-hour Thursday events a try. Booze + science = good times, I imagine.

The only downside to this place is I wish there were some hand sanitizing stations around. I didn't see any while walking around the museum, and for the amount of people touching everything -- especially during cold and flu season -- I won't be surprised if I end up coming down with something.
author: Alyssa B.

description:
A few weeks ago, I went to the Exploratorium for the first time in years! (Last time was during an elementary school field trip) I love the new location right by the bay and the piers. We went on a Saturday afternoon. It wasn't as crowded as I thought it would be for a beautiful Saturday afternoon but there was still a good crowd, especially families with children. I didn't have to fight off any kids though haha. We didn't buy tickets ahead of time but there wasn't a line to get in. 

I loved all the interactive exhibits. One of my favorites was the group snake game which is a giant version of the snake game that came on old cell phone. The "shadow room" (I don't know what it's actually called) was really cool too. We came back to it on the way out as well. You can use your cell phone flashlight to write/draw things on the wall. Every minute or so there's a flash and the room takes a picture of your shadows on the wall. Overall we spent about 2 hours playing and exploring but you can easily spend way more time here. We came later and stayed till closing. The Exploratorium is definitely a good date idea! Have fun, play, explore, and be a kid again!
author: Miko I.

description: Super cool new place but every time I've gone it's SO crowded with all the school field trips.
author: Christine R.

description: I've been to the night event several times, but haven't gotten around to writing a review. Always a good time, despite it being on the Embarcadero, parking is not an issue. Drinks are average priced for SF. Like the fact that lockers are only 50cent's... being that I went there straight after work, and didn't want to drag around a heavy backpack and jacket. And as always lots of cool exhibits, and interactive science stuff! Would highly recommend if you've never been. If you want to take kids go during the day, and if you want just an adult night out, go at night. It's a Win-Winn for everyone!
author: J C.

description: Great full day activity for both adults and children. Every exhibit is hands on displaying concepts relating to perception, psychology, biology, physics and more. I'm not sure it's even possible to try all of the demonstrations in one day! If you would like to avoid all the children running around, certainly go on a weekday during school hours. However, there's so many exhibits to try out there's always something available to inspect. Tickets are only $30 for adults which is a great price to pay for a full-day activity. You can leave and come back for no re-entry fee and there is food inside as well.
author: April P.

description: Every child must make a trip up to the Exploratorium. It is an amazing place that is bound to spark creativity and curiosity amongst children and adults alike.
author: Sachin C.

description:
I came here for my company's post-holiday party.  We had two wings of the museum for us, the wings that were near the water.  Although with company parties, food and booze all around, I still could not resist seeing the different exhibits during the night.  Of course, my patience and understanding of learning and reading the exhibits went down as the evening wore on!

I have to come back here during a regular museum day so that I can actually focus on the exhibits or one of those Thursday night after hours things.  Probably the only bummer factor is where you park and how much you could pay depending on where you park.  I parked about 10 minutes away on the street just to get a few extra steps underneath my belt and enjoyed a nice scenic walk among the tourist folks!
author: Ben H L.

description:
This place is AWESOME!!!! I can spend a whole two days here and still not see everything at the extent I'd want to see it. There are so many interactive exhibits that are fun and educational at the same time. It's definitely a place to take your child or even an adult that doesn't like science, but likes to play around. I learned so many things when I went, but don't ask me what I learned! 

I would love to go to this place again when I visit just because I didn't get a chance to really fully explore. I can spend hours on one exhibit. 

You will not be disappointed. As long as you don't mind kids running around your ankles, then you're good.
author: Grace A.

description: Such a fun place to play and feel like a kid (even if you're pushing 30) Loved every gallery, well worth the $30.
author: Sarita P.

description:
Lots to Do

This place was fun, but it would likely be a lot more fun with young children.  We chose to go on a Thursday evening, because the adult-only feature sounded nice.  It was indeed nice, to a point.  Instead of lots of little children running around having fun, there were lots of older children trying to balance being as drunk as they could be with trying to manage fairly simple tasks.  There was a certain entertainment value in all of that, but it wore thin pretty quickly.
author: Ted Q.

description: Very fun way to explore about science and learning. There's hands on things you can touch and experiment with. If you're so worry about germs then just bring hand sanitizer or wipes because a lot things are touch from all sorts of people even kids. Great place for children to have sensory play.
author: Anonymous U.

description:
This place is a MUST GO if you are in the SF area!!! I will be sure to visit every time I travel to SF. 

Unlike other museums or exhibits this place is completely interactive. There are hundreds (okay, this may be an exaggeration but there is a whole lot!) of things to do here!! 

You do not have to be a child to enjoy this place. Although it is a perfect place to keep kids entertained for hours, I think this would make an amazing activity for a date!

Suggestion: If you are a germaphobe, bring some hand sanitizer. :)
author: Alyssa K.

description:
I LOVE THIS PLACE!

We came to SF a few months ago and had seen the outdoor exhibits (serious fun, totally for free, I already liked their style), and vowed to actually go in the museum next time we were in the area.

Cue a few weeks ago when we were in SF again- first thing on the list is the Exploratorium. It was amazing, completely reasonably priced, and we honestly could've spent the entire day there. There are so many different exhibits, and it hits interests on so many different levels- you've got the super science-based stuff for your engineer types (my husband) and the general knowledge "Wow! I see ____ every day and never knew it worked that way!" based stuff (me). 

Just talking about it makes me want to go back. I would recommend this museum to anyone, any age, with any type of interests/ hobbies. The only thing I would suggest to bring is patience. People will mob certain exhibits and take quite a long time to clear out; if you really are interested, either take a deep breath and wait or circle back. It'll be worth it, I promise.
author: Kirsten S.

description:
The Exploratorium is fantastic. We left our toddlers at home and took our 6 year old on his birthday and it was really fun. He was engaged and fascinated the entire time. I would not have wanted to take toddler age but older is awesome. Everything was interesting and there is A LOT to see. We got there three hours before close and barely got to the last exhibit. And the people that work there are awesome!

FYI - do not park across the street at the parking lot that says exploratorium - they do not validate and use the name illegally. Park at the public parking at the Levi Strauss center a few blocks back.
author: Adrienne S.

description: Wow, what a great place.  My 3.5 year old was hands on with everything and it was not only okay, but encouraged.  There is a lot to see and do, so plan accordingly.  We started at the back because it was so crowded, but those exhibits seemed to be a bit old for my kid.  Once we got to the exhibits towards the front, she spent more time on the individual exhibits. We will go back and start front to back next time
author: Heather S.

description: Came here for a company event, the space is massive and there is cool things to see and interact with. They had a good setup of drinks, bars, food, bands, and DJs.
author: Jonah K.

description: Awesome place! It used to be more for younger kids but now it seems like it's more for the 10 year olds and older... there were. A few things to entice the younger set but there is much to read...
author: Kim H.

description:
I have so many fond memories of visiting the Exploratorium when I was in elementary, it was always such an interesting places filled with electricity, water, sand, optics and a lot of other things to fill my young self with excitement curiosity.

Twenty years later I visited again but with my twin 18 month old children. I was very curious to see how things have changed in the new space and whether there would be anything age appropriate for my kids,

Location:
Very Easy to get to from the Bay Bridge, past the ferry building and before Pier 39.

Parking:
Lots of lots in the are, I parked right across the street where it was $5 each hour.

Food:
Nice cafe inside, had a nice Mac and cheese, the wife and chowder. They also have some sushi and i think a bar on the other side of the sushi. They had some interesting drink selections including a specialty root beer and a few varieties of jarritos. The view was really amazing  near the windows, with views of the bay bridge and other parts of the bay.


The exhibits:
The exhibits are way more spaced out now than the old location. Wide aisles made it easy to push our side by side stroller around. We just parked our stroller in the middle of the place and started to go around. I also liked that there were plenty of benches inside. The exhibits themselves were a little old for my kids. They enjoyed some of the tactics ones, the bubbles, some of the different lights and a few of the sound ones. I think they are way to young. A lot of exhibits have instructions that help you to understand what's going on. At a minimum maybe first grade so that a kid could read the instructions and then work the apparatus. Pre-k/k may like to push some of the buttons but you don't get enough instant satisfaction from simple button mashing.

Overall:
Very high quality place and worth the visit young or old, just not too young.
author: Chris C.

description:
Great place to spend a day.  Waaaaay more exhibits than the former location at the Palace of Fine Arts.  All hands on, and quite overwhelming to be honest.  The space is huge, and seems to go on and on.  Outdoor exhibits as well.

Big props to the cafeteria for a an extensive and healthy variety of food, from quinoa salads to sushi to roast chicken.  Some of the dishes we ordered for the kids were a miss (mac n cheese, fish n chips).  

Didn't hit the gift shop this time but will definitely be back.  Especially since we didn't get to see everything.  Expect to pay more than before, but you'll see why.
author: Kristin U.

description:
This museum has so many educational and fun exhibits, it'll be impossible to get through them all in one visit, unless you're prepared to spend an entire day there.  The location is great and I like how they have some exhibits outside on the pier that take advantage of the museum's proximity to the water.  I definitely recommend visiting to anyone who enjoys museums, especially those who like physics, nature, science, and math.  

I docked a point -- and was very tempted to dock 2 -- because they sell way too many tickets.  We went last Thursday night and it was mayhem.  Almost all of the exhibits (which all require interaction in order to be understood) were already occupied or had a line of people waiting.  So we only got to "interact" with 5-10 exhibits.  And during that time, we were so aware of how much time we were taking (b/c a line quickly formed) that we couldn't fully enjoy ourselves.  On top of that, all of the lockers were full so we couldn't check our bags and coats and the lines for drinks were at least 20 minutes long.  I expect to be shoulder-shoulder and have to wait for a long time for a drink at a club or bar, not a museum.
author: Negar A.

description: Seems like a great museum, but it would be even better if there were more things younger kids could enjoy.
author: Abraham G.

description:
We came here on free founders day so you can imagine how crowded it was. But even with that this place is a 5/5.

It's huge!!! Even with us rushing through everything it still took us 2 hours and on top of that we did not see everything! Don't think it's a kiddie place too, a lot of the activities they have here can be suited for adults. I also like that for each activity they have a "Why does this happen?" It explains the science of things. 

If you're thinking about coming here just come. It won't be time wasted. They have tons of things here that definitely piques curiosity and interest. I know I'll be back later to go through all of the exhibits :)
author: Mcfrancis S.

description:
Worth the cost! Lots of cause and effect activities for kids and adults to experience.
Because all activities require reading to varying degrees (and possible explanation, parents) I would recommend this place for kids over 10 who can read and interpret explanation instead of just pushing and pulling on any lever they see. Many displays require patience and understanding. All displays worked but I noticed many kids did not have the patience to watch if they did not see an immediate result.
With kids below 10, I would recommend a different attraction. Plan on a minimum of 90 minutes here to experience kinetic, mechanical, electrical, and biological exhibits/activities.
author: five star T.

description: The Exploratorium is a fun get away for a few hours on the weekend. I only wish that you could get to their gift shop from the entrance and not have to buy a ticket. They have numerous fun educational toys that you can buy. There are several different areas to explore. For me I did not care for the sound area and some of the light exhibits, they made me nauseous (especially the sound area). This is a great spot for kids to have hands on fun with learning. If you have a library card you can get a Discover and Go pass from your library. This allows you one free entrance for a family per year. You can also use it for free access for all sorts of other Museums in the area as well.
author: Lacy C.

description:
It's so much better at Pier 15 than it was in the Presidio.  Nightlife on Thursdays is definitely worth a visit to avoid a bunch of rascals running around.  It's just as fun as it was when I was little.  Such a cool sensory experience.  You'll learn something new with each visit!

The restaurant is good too--some of the best views you'll find on the Embarcadero.  The foods pretty typically priced for a museum, but it's actually pretty good and there are a ton of options.
author: Olivia D.

description:
+ fun
+ educational 
+ hands-on activities 
+ informative 

I love enriching my mind w/ information I don't know and having fun whilst leaning. I had a great time w/ my family that day. I actually let loose for a moment there. 

My dad treated us to a day filled w/ laughter. I think my favorite parts of the exhibits was the slow motion video camera, the black screen freeze thing, and the gigantic Pac Man game. My dad, sister, and I all yelled and cheered so the blinkies would not get to Pac Man. Stupid kid that controlled the down arrow got us killed. 

I think a full day is not enough to take advantage of this place and the plethora of things it has to offer. We spent the entire day there w/ the exception of going out for lunch but the memories: priceless. 

Thanks for a great time, Dad. Love you!
author: Tram N.

description:
What a change from the old exploratorium! When I found out the exploratorium was moving, I was sooo sad. I remember the field trips and the birthdays I spent there. 

I finally decided to check out the new location at Pier 15. It sure has changed! It's HUUUUUUUUGE. I can definitely spend a few hours there. There are tons of exhibits and even some seminars/discussions you can attend. My friend and I had a great time with all the experiments.

The only thing is that it's WAAAAAAAAAY crowded. Too many kids running freely and tons of tourists. I would go on a weekday to avoid the rush.
author: Jessica Y.

description:
This place will be fun if you know what to expect. I loved the exhibits - they were all very educational and so interactive. However, I'm leaving a low rating because of my experience here. 

This place is PACKED with screaming, yelling, crying, misbehaved kids running all around you. It completely ruined my visit. I would say the ratio of kids and their parents to lone adults here would be 80% to 20%. The kids here were so rowdy and loud and didn't seem like their parents were really watching them or cared what they did - even if they disturbed other patrons. The kids swarm all of the interactive exhibits and while you patiently wait your turn to use a display, 10 additional kids jump in when its your turn and their parents don't seem to care that you're waiting. You can wait all you want, you're never going to be able to see that exhibit you've been patiently waiting to use. Once you actually find an open exhibit, it won't stay that way for long. A wandering child will come up to that same exhibit and start touching all the pieces and pestering you while you're still finishing up and their parents won't come collect them.

I think part of the onus is on the museum to inform potential patrons what to expect. If I had known the atmosphere would be so hectic and that it would be impossible to see any of the exhibits, I wouldn't have come. The other part of the weight falls on the parents that visit here. Parents didn't seem to care at all if their kids disturbed other patrons or cut in line. I've never seen such a huge amount of misbehaved kids in one space. All I know is that my mother would never have let me get away with that behavior when I was a kid. 

Considering admission is $30 for one adult to get in, it kind of sucks when you can't use or see any of the exhibits. I really felt like I was in a daycare center or one of those play places in the mall. Additionally the exhibits didn't seem to be properly maintained given that children manhandle them all day. For example, some exhibits used sand and there was maybe a couple tablespoons of sand left by the time I passed by, and I got here at 11 or 12 in the morning. 

I regret not coming during the nighttime, adult only admissions.
author: Johanna H.

description:
We used to take our kids to the old building and it was a great fun. Now at a new building its even more fun and more things to do. The kids are older but we still have a lot of things to do every time we come here. And we find something new every time as well. 

I also like the nice cafeteria/restaurant that they have here, the food here is pretty tasty. We also like little structures and attractions outside of the building, those are fun. Our every visit here we end with a nice stroll along the water enjoying the nice view of the Bay and the city skyline.
author: Mark C.

description: Back then, the exploratorium was located within the Palace of Fine Arts. It was later moved to this location. This location also hosts a Thursday night event where people can come in to purchase drinks and explore the area. I have to argue that given the choice of the Academy of Sciences vs. this place, this place is a lot more hands on, but targets a younger demographic. I feel like the experiments within this location is for kids in middle school and high school. If you're looking for a romantic high school date this is probably the place. If you are looking for something more mature, I suggest the Academy of Sciences. This place seems to be way overcrowded. I also came here on a pokemon night, so there were loads of people. Instead of looking at the experiments people were trying to go around and capture all sorts of pokemons. There is hard to find parking at this location because its close to embarcadero.
author: Amy Y.

description: I can't believe how many awesome gadgets there are to play with, and unlike the interactive exhibits at the MoMath in NYC, not a single one was broken! I don't know how they manage to pull that off.
author: Jonathan S.

description:
The Exploratorium is a magical place! Though they moved out of the gorgeous Palace of Fine Arts, their new space allows more people to engage with the exhibits at once. There's kids everywhere of course, but this makes the exhibits more lively even if you're older. Being closer to the Bay at their new location, they have new areas that focus on creatures and the history of the ecosystem. They even have a neat timeline simulation of the seismic activity in San Francisco and the fish in the little aquarium are enthralling. 

The Exploratorium is a must visit for anyone at least once; its rich history (founded by Dr. Frank Oppenheimer), artists' created exhibits, and exploration in design and tinkering is unfounded. If you cannot stand the kids, go for their After Dark Thursday nights. With so much to see and learn here you're sure to have a memorable time; it even makes for a sweet date spot.
author: Thom And Vicky H.

description:
I do miss their previous location at the Palace of Fine Arts, but the space they have now on Pier 17 is exactly what they needed.  It's spacious for all their exhibits and has great views of the Bay Bridge.  Though it does get crowded, it only feels cramped in a few places.

It can get overwhelming, especially if it's your first time.  There's so much to see and do.  I don't think you can cover it in one day, especially if you have small children.  You should come in with a game plan to cover what you want to see.

Oh, if germs aren't your thing, then bring hand sanitizer.  This museum is a hands-on experience, and you paid good money to get inside.

And if you're local, remember to tell them to get a discount!  And check out their website for their free days.
author: Vira P.

description: My husband and I hadn't been to the Exploratorium since we were kids, we both loved it then. Their new space is quite nice. We didn't arrive terribly early on a summer Saturday, but when we looked in, there wasn't a line so we decided to give it a go. And yes, the admission is a bit pricey, but we figured that was par for the course in San Francisco, so we didn't mind at all. I was worried our two toddlers weren't going to have anything to do...5 hours later we had to practically drag them out of the place and we didn't get to explore all of the exhibits. Yes, there were a lot of kids and some were misbehavimg and unconstrained, but for the most part, the experience was wonderful. My husband and I had a blast playing with the different exhibits and even though our kids may not have understood what they were doing or witnessing, they had fun. It was a great experience and it was so amazing to experience the Exploratorium through our kids' eyes and excitement. We'll be back.
author: Katie R.

description:
I remember having so much fun on a field trip when I was like 10 but it's just so much different when you're an adult. I thought I would come and relive my childhood memory but I just wasn't in the right mind set or I'm just not a 10 year old girl anymore. It was too much brain stimulation on a Saturday. Plus, this place is really expensive. Good thing my boyfriend and I still had our Student IDs (even though we're not students anymore hehe). It was still $48 for both of us. Pretty pricey for only spending 2.5 hours here! There were some cool things that I don't remember but don't think the price is worth it. If anything, I'd recommend doing it with CityPass. Also, had to pay $20 for a parking on a lot down the street. And then spent $80 at Hog Island Oyster Co. (DEFINITELY RECOMMENDED!) It was definitely a pricey Saturday afternoon! 

We also tried the Mexi Fries at the cafe. It wasn't bad. They have a nice patio where you can sit on outside to eat and there is a view of the Bay Bridge. If you are a childless adult and really looking for some brain stimulation with tons of kids running around, you might want to check it out. This place is great for kids but not so much adults.
author: Julie S.

description:
This place is awesome! It was my first time going and I highly recommend going to the adults only night. I had low expectations before I went, so I was pleasantly surprised to have such a great time!

The experiments are all hands-on and cool! There are different sections with different activities, such as nature, human body, color, etc.
author: Kayley W.

description: This museum is a national treasure and it keeps getting better.  The way they show scientific concepts simply and clearly in an engaging and indestructible small exhibit is truly incredible.  I've gone to science museums all around the world and this is the best one.
author: Lukas B.

description:
My son and I were down here early morning Aug 30, 2014, to attend a late 6:05pm Giants game (early to avoid late morning and afternoon traffic), so I purchased tickets online.  Get there right when they open (10am Saturdays), because it starts to get a bit crowded shortly after, being a weekend.

We parked just a couple of blocks away at Priority Parking (open lot) at 90 Broadway Street for $21 (good all day until 11:59pm), though I found out later that Exploratorium has their own open lot directly across the street from Pier 15 which costs $5/hour, so it may be a bit cheaper depending on how long you stay here or at nearby businesses.

Great new location and reportedly quite a bit larger than the old, though aesthetically more appealing Palace of Fine Arts that I had gone to when I was a young boy, and to which I had taken my now 18-year old son to when he was a young boy.  You can easily spend 3 hours here, and still not see everything this place has to offer.

As mentioned, great for ALL ages, young to adult to elders, and a great place to use up time before a later Giants ball game.

Note 1:  if you live in the number of "bay area" counties (check their website for specific mapped areas), admission tickets will be cheaper than it was for us coming out of Sacramento.  Next time I may call up an SF friend to purchase our online tickets, and just email them to us, but even without a discount, I would not hesitate to say the price was worth all that there is to do here at the Exploratorium.

Note 2:  It pays for you beforehand to bring some snacks and snack drinks (juice packs, etc.) to consume DURING your visit, to carry you over until a later meal, unless you are willing to spend on their pricey restaurant or café menu items.  We didn't, and were starving after 2-1/2 hours here (keep in mind, we drove 1-1/2 hrs from Sac also), but ended up having soup and sandwiches at Panera Bread just one long city block from AT&T park a few hours before the game.
author: Darrin K.

description:
So many amazing things to see at the Exploritorium, from sculptures, to live science projects, they even have a day camp for kids! If you are at all into science or art (hell even if your not) I can guarantee you that you find something of interest here. I took my youngest son and a few of his friends last weekend, and we all had a great time. I know I definitely had a better time than I thought I would. There is so much to see and to mention that I would never be able to fit it into this review, but I will say my son and I both had a lot of fun doing the activity where you make and fly paper planes. He did not want to leave! 

A lot of the art exhibits were very impressive as well, if it wasn't some amazing architecture or design, it was at least educational. Believe me I learned more than I thought I would have after a single trip here. My one piece of advice would be to bring comfortable shoes, you will be doing a lot of walking since this place is HUGE. Also make sure to keep your kids close, on a few occasions my son just darted off because he saw something really interesting and it's easy to lose them in the crowds.

Definitely an experience I would recommend and it's a good change of pace from always taking the kids to the movies.
author: Betty K.

description:
Amazing!

Came here with some young minions. It was my first time at this new location and it was amazing! It was spacious and organized. I am glad they kept some old exhibits and updated others. I loved the view of the bay and the history maps. 

I personally think I enjoyed it more than my minions :)

i will surely come back!
author: Jay B.

description: The new Exploratorium is a magnificent venue and certainly an upgrade from the one located next to the Palace of Arts.  So much to see, hear, and touch!  It's a tactile, sound, and visual overload in a good way.  But I feel you need like 2 days to truly enjoy and experience this magical place.  Until next time...
author: Henry C.

description: The perfect place for kids and adults. Not inexpensive but we ended up spending 2-3 hours and it could have easily been longer. Really great interactive exhibits on many subjects. About 5-10 min walk from the Ferry building. 100% recommend.
author: My O.

description:
Thank you for all of the fun hands on activities of just about every age. I brought my kids here for the first time and they had a ton of fun. They're favorite thing was the sand turntable! 

My only advice would be to have an employee at the Giant mirror to show people how to utilize it to get the best photos or imagination. 

Thank you
author: A D.

description:
I think the new location is gorgeous. We had a private work event here and the service AND the food were actually pretty good. 

I am a big fan of that "fox walking" silent room challenge. 

The location also allows you to walk outside after you are done with the Exploratorium and enjoy SF.

I will definitely be back :)
author: Jennifer T.

description:
We love it! Well worth the admission fees since my daughters spent the whole day till closing. They have 6 galleries all together and each galley exhibit is hand on experience. So lots of things to explore. 

Too bad we can't experience the outdoor weather exhibit due to the California draught! If you are in SF with kids, this is A MUST VISIT. My kids enjoyed this Exploratorium than the California Science Museum. They said this is the most fun thing than they have ever done in SF.
author: Doris D.

description:
Spectacular.  Can't miss.  Best museum of its kind I've ever been to and I've been to many of the best.  My kids and I spent 3 hours there and didn't get through all of it.  

There are adults-only hours in the evening and for good reason.  It is fascinating for adults and children alike.
author: John H.

description: Awesome place for kids, especially 5 years and up.  If you're local look for the discount online before you arrive.
author: MC C.

description: I grew up with the "old" Exploratorium (and actually worked there for a short while) and this "new" site was completely different from my childhood.  The museum has lot it's dark/gritty vibe and instead is gleaming and easy to navigate.  Much more spacious than I had expected, so I did not allocate enough time (5 hours) to properly go through the entire space with my kids.  The cashier selling tickets was very confused about how much to charge me, but that was a minor speed bump.
author: Terence L.

description: Went here on a field trip with my class, and four other 4th/5th grade classes. The kids loved it! There was so much for them to see and do, and it was all really hands-on. The staff was really accommodating, and it was extremely easy to get a reservation for all five of our classes. They also offer a free program for Title 1 schools, which is great because it provides access to all students, no matter circumstances. The only reason, I didn't give it 5 stars is because the bus parking is difficult-but c'mon, it is San Francisco, ya know?
author: Vanessa K.

description: Germs...germs everywhere! But germs are just the price you pay for some good ole hands on fun. This place is a never ending emporium of wonder and excitement. I love Exploratorium After Dark because you don't have to compete with the kids. Make sure you keep your hands away from your face after touching everything.
author: Amanda T.

description:
My tips if you're planning a visit to this fantastic, massive hands-on museum...

- For $25 (adult), this place delivers an unbelievable value, well worth price of admission

- Depending on when you go there can be a line out the door, but you can buy tix in advance online and skip the line...'city pass' also allows you to jump to the front.

- Make sure you ask for the locals discount ($5 off) if you live in the bay area (No ID required, at least when we went)

- If you're a germ-a-phobe, bring buckets of hand sanitizer as you'll be touching lots n lots of sticky items and there's none provided there.

- This place is chock o' block, so the later in the day you wait, the less crowded it'll be, especially if you're looking to deal with less kiddies

- Not recommended for the epileptic! Just saying, lots of strobe light action. But on the other hand, couldn't help but think this must be quite a trip for those partaking in hallucinogens!  
 
- Budget 4 hrs as the museum is quite massive. We spent about 5 hrs there and only saw about 60% (on a holiday).

- No coat check but they offer convenient lockers for only 50 cent!

- There is a restaurant, cafe and food carts on site but the Ferry Bldg is a 10 min walk down the Embarcadero for more tasty treats.
author: Jeff F.

description: Too big to see everything on one visit. Lots of fun hands on exhibits. Learned a lot!
author: Brittany N.

description: Lovely day at this museum. Beautiful location, easy to get to, easy to find parking. The museum is quite large and we ran out of time to see it all. There is a wide variety within the exhibits with plenty for everyone to see and do.
author: Sara O.

description: This is one of my new favorite places in San Francisco. I thought that this location would be more geared towards younger children, and maybe it is, but my entire family had a blast. There are various exhibits for all ages and a lot of different interactive experiments. The inside of the Exploratorium is huge and we spent about 2 hours just in the first section. I highly recommend this museum for anyone looking for a way to spend their day on the pier. You should be prepared, though, because it is expensive and for my family of four it cost about $101. If you stick around long enough and take your time you can definitely get your money's worth!
author: Katelyn R.

description:
Looking for an interactive museum? This is the place to be!
This museum is geared more towards kids, however, it is still adult friendly. I like the different interactive activities and informative information. i would say this museum is one of my favorite museums out there. If your in San Francisco, this museum is a must!
author: Mimi V.

description:
Love the new location. It is a lot more convenient than the other place. The place is very open and has one large floor and a smaller upstairs. They even added a newer area that wasn't in the old place. It is right by the water and it is gorgeous! It is great for children and adults. It'll be at least 2-3 hours to see everything. Bring comfortable shoes! 

If you are a local bring your ID you get a discount! Also bring your student ID! 

Please sanitize/wash your hands before you touch your face or eat after.
author: Sarah C.

description:
Went here on a free day with my husband. It's normally $29 for adults and that seems extremely steep given that this place is most definitely geared toward children. Founders Day is Oct 11 and it sounds like they may have free days every year on/around that day. We arrived at 10:45 AM (45 minutes after it opened), and while the line looked extremely long, it moved quickly and we only waited about 35-40 min in total.

My husband kept asking me what type of museum we were going to... Was it a science museum? An art museum? It's not technically any of these, but it's aptly named - "Exploratorium." Lots of little trinkets to tinker with.

This isn't really a place a young, childless couple would enjoy. It's definitely a place to bring the kids. There are lots of them. Bring your hand sanitizer.
author: Kendra N.

description:
I guess I would not recommend going on a weekend (I went Sunday). I paid $40 to have rude children hog up all of the exhibits and barge in while my girlfriend and I were interacting with the exhibits. It didn't anger us, just surprised us that people allow their kids to behave in such a way. 

I really can't knock the exploratorium for the behavior of children but I didn't feel too satisfied with my purchase. 

I'm considering going back on a weekday but not too sure yet.
author: Kevin E.

description:
This place is amazing.  There are just so many different things for you to do that you could get lost in here for an entire day if you wanted.  It was fun for me as an adult and I'm sure it's even moreso for little children.  I've been to similar places in Houston (Natural Science Museum) and Dallas (Perot Museum) and they can't hold a candle to this place.

Almost every exhibit is something interactive and of course, educational.  A lot of fascinating things if you read through everything, but of course it's also fun to just mess around in there and be wowed by science, lol.

I don't know about recommending this place to people who are visiting San Francisco for the first time as there are more interesting sites to see, but if you're in the area and looking for something fun to do and kill time with, then definitely check this place out.
author: Randy S.

description: Even if you're not really into science, this place is still a lot of fun. All the demonstrations of scientific principles were really neat, and the explanation were really helpful. We only stayed for a few hours, but you could definitely stay for a whole day and not get bored.
author: Jacquelyn M.

description:
So I was just telling Bryan R. that the Exploratorium totally exceeded my expectations. I wasn't too big on coming here, but the cousins convinced me to and I knew my girl would just go nuts in this place (she's giddy for science and all things nerdy).  I didn't think that I too would become so excited over such cool exhibits and concepts... this was a treat! 

Make sure you visit this place when you have time on your side, otherwise you'll be like me... Stuck on just a quarter of the museum, and miss out on all the other fun. There's just too much to do with so little time! Oh, and what's nice is they allow ins and outs.
author: Jo D.

description:
Not the Exploratorium of my kids' childhood.  It's a hundred times better.  We haven't visited since the days when it was located at the Palace of Fine Arts and we were not disappointed.  There are so many exhibits and tons of hands on for kids.
Now located at Pier 15, the place is spacious and doesn't feel crowded.  

The exhibits are so much better too.  They have office spaces, research areas and a development studio where you can see them build things, but not on Sundays.
There are 2 levels but the bulk of the exhibits are downstairs. 

The restaurant inside is overpriced.  $24 for a whole roast chicken?  A cheese sandwich is almost $10. I tried the Tcho chocolate ice cream bar and it was delicious.  Also tried the root beer which was good too (off brand).  The cafeteria dining area has great views of the bay - a million dollar view.  You can go out and walk around to see the back side and watch the boats, ferries zip by.  We even sat a boat with "pilot" on the side of the boat, speeding towards the GG Bridge, likely a bar pilot heading to a ship to pilot it into the bay.  

Pier 15 used to be where goods from Asia and Europe were delivered.  You can see the name of the company that used to be there and the various doors where the ships with berth with their deliveries.  

I highly recommend visiting the Exploratorium if you've not been there. The place is lovely.  Just make sure you wash your hands after you've been there.  All those knobs and stuff touched by people including the woman who was in the bathroom with me who left without washing her hands after using the toilet.
author: Ry T.

description:
We were here for a regular Thursday Night event where they open the museum just for 18+.  No DJ or party.  We spent 3 hours here and we only got to about half of the exhibits.  Its just that good.  We liked the environment a lot since there were no kids fighting over the exhibits or partiers boozing up the place.  It was mainly young couples and tech geeks walking around.  We never had to wait for any hands-on activity.  

We bought the tickets online and we got to skip all the lines (in our case, there were nobody in them to begin with).  At first, we were expecting hands-on exhibits geared to small children like the Tech Museum in San Jose.  But we were shocked on how intricate and complicated the activities were.  You need some math and physics chops to understand some of the stuff.  They had optical and physical illusions as well as visually showing properties of the universe in the craziest ways.  My party loved the huge inverted mirror.  I liked the fusion of steampunk tech and humanity in the hearbeat/lightbulb chandelier made specifically for the Thursday Night events.  It was probably the coolest hands-on museums of science and technology I've ever been in.  We will definitely come back to explore the place some more.
author: Jeff C.

description:
This is a really fun place for both kids and adults! They have really cool interactive displays that convey scientific principles in simple ways. My not-so-secret inner geek comes out whenever I'm here. They also have an area where you can see the employees making new displays. It's nice to be able to see which ones they're updating and how they put them all together. I'm taking advantage of the student discount while I'm still a grad student too! 

Their location on the Embarcadero also offers nice views of the bay with plenty to do at the surrounding piers. Plus they validate parking at the nearby parking garages so parking isn't quite as bad. I think this is a must visit place for anyone with some time to kill or just a fun afternoon!
author: Lina H.

description:
This place is and will ever will be super cool in my book. I love that they still have (and improved) a lot of the classic hands on exhibits from when I was a kid (the flash, wall picture thing) but have new things as well. 

We did go on a Tuesday of the Thanksgiving holiday so it was PACKED. And was a bit overwhelming at first but after a while, we eased into it and wished we could have stayed longer to try everything. We just didn't have time! So not to repeat what others have said but here's my pros and tips:

Pros:
-Dolby sound exhibits!
-One floor, with some nice outdoor things for kids to play with
-Ins and outs, lockers
-Totally kid and adult friendly. It's about science ya'll!
-Nice new location, with lot's of parking options BUT be careful where you park

Cons:
-Can get super, super packed
-Expensive parking if you don't park at the Exploratorium validated lot directly across the street (it's $5/hour for up to 4 hours there....$30 at the other lots!!!)

Tips:
-Purchase your tickets online, they can scan your barcode from your smart phone
-Bring a lunch - there's ins and outs and lots of places and pretty sights for a picnic
-We brought a 4 year old who no doubt ran amuck here but I think it'd be better suited for 6+ and up....
-One could EASILY spend the entire day here. We were here for only 3 hours and it wasn't enough time to do and see EVERYTHING. We totally missed the Cells side of the building =(
author: Elizabeth N.

description:
A place where you can become a kid and let your imagination roam.  For me, this is my worst nightmare, I'm a germaphobe, tons of children touching things.  Tip, don't put some exhibits that require up to your face/on your face, wash your hands super well before eating.  My worst flu was after visiting the old exploratorium location.

The new location is right off the Embarcadero, close to the Ferry Building.  If you want to avoid paying for parking.  Take the Bart to the Embarcadero stop.  Or you can take the train and hop on the muni rail across the street.  My point is you should take transit if your kids allow for you to.  Plus!  For tourists, download one of our transportation apps like: Sidecar or lyft, cheaper than a taxi.

Price, adults $29, youth $24, kids $19.  Is it worth the money?  I'd say yes, because you can spend hours here.  I wouldn't go all the time myself, but if you have kids, this is a great place to expand their minds.  If you live locally, a membership would be even better or just go to the zoo?  For us adults, they have "After Dark" at $15.  

Check out the Tactile Dome for $15.  It is all based on touch.  You're in the dark and make your way through a maze.  I did it once, pretty intense.  Now go explore.
author: Michelle M.

description:
So much fun!

We had a super fun day at the Exploratorium. Both the kids and us adults agreed that this was definitely worth a visit. We had bought the San Francisco City Pass and the Exploratorium is included in that.

We arrived quite early in the morning and there were hardly any queues at all. So in we went and immediately began playing, experimenting, testing. We were amazed that the museum was so large! And had so many things to do and see. We have visited these kinds of museum before, but never one like this, with so many different varieties of experiments. We constantly said: "come and try this!!" to each other. :)

As the day went by, many more visitors arrived to the museum, but it never felt crowded in any way.

This is a fabulous place to learn some physics as well!

The only thing we thought could be better was the lunch options. That I give 3 stars.

A PERFECT thing to do if you want to spend a super fun days with your kids!
author: Maria E.

description:
As a HUGE fan of science, this place definitely caught my eye! I came during my spring break and the place was packed! The numerous exhibits and experiments available could practically keep you there for hours on end just to find out how everything works! 

What really fascinated me was the San Francisco model made out of toothpicks that took around thirty five years or so to finish! It's still being worked on by the original artist, Scott Weaver. Right next to the sculpture is a video of a ping pong ball being released at the top of the sculpture which is originally entitled,"Rolling through the Bay" 

Interesting fact:
Each part of the sculpture is made of different toothpicks from various locations across the world! The heart inside the palace of fine arts in the sculpture is made up of toothpicks that people had thrown at Weaver's wedding! Symbolic of the fact that this sculpture shows importance, and encompasses a sort of passion he has for the art! How neat!

A few pluses to this place is that it's right by the Fishermans Wharf which is another tourist attraction, and has plenty of places to go nearby! In addition, the Alcatraz Island tours are right next door so you can book a ticket there if you're a history buff too! I absolutely loved coming to the Exploratorium, and I'm definitely sure anyone else would too!
author: Jimmy T.

description:
The new location is amazing, but I hope the Palace of Fine Arts doesn't fall into disrepair because of the new move.

-3 stars for the Tactile dome reservation system.  You can't do it online, and there's not flexibility in moving  it.  

A whole family trip here can easily cost over $100.  It's a great location, but it really hurts the wallet.
author: David W.

description:
This is fantastic hands on science museum. Founded by the brother of Robert Oppenheimer (of Manhattan Project fame) it differs from some of its famous brethren,  like the Museums of Science and Industry in Chicago and Oregon,  and the Pacific Science Center in Seattle, and any Natural History Museum, in that it is mostly physics, and mostly pure rather than applied concepts. No dinosaurs,  no submarines, no nanotechnology, no food science. Instead, they have exhibit after exhibit breaking down one aspect of light or color or sound or electro magnetism in hands on, pretty self-explanatory stations. BRAVO! 

Another thing that makes this museum unique is the stress level of the helicopter parents who bring their children here. Holy cow San Francisco! Pack some extra patience and love for humanity in your backpack (you can store it in a locker for 50 cents, the only bargain to be had here). 

Also pack lunch. The cafeteria prices trump those at many a ski resort. Decent food though, and an incredible view. Actually, this place would rock for a date.

There is a sensory dome in section one that you need to buy separate tickets for, if you wish to go, and the times sell out in a hurry. You don't need to do it, but you do need to decide from the start if it will be part of your day.

To get discounted admission,  consider a city pass which gives unlimited cable car rides, a cruise, and admission to the Monterey or San Fransisco Aquriums,  and another science museum. 

Happy exploring!
author: Jennifer S.

description:
I know this caters mostly to children, but it is still a lot of fun for grown ups!

They changed a bit since 2014, but I still enjoyed the exhibit. I still enjoy going onto a shadow image room, or the room where you shine light in a mostly colorless room to reveal a more vibrant color of the spot in the room you're pointing at.

They're also working on more exhibits, so I'll keep coming back to see what's new.
author: Vincent V.

description:
I went here for a scholarship meeting so I'm not sure of the price but it was really fun! I was really amused at all of the displays and was happy to see little kids exploring. Very educational with a perfect balance of fun and I love that its at the pier. You can easily walk on over to pier 39 for a bite to eat and come back. 

I would definitely come back to take my little brother or cousins. 

There is this super cool room that was monochromatic and there's a jelly bean machine in there. They should put the nasty flavors in and make you guess what you're eating...muahahaha

Physics lovers, say hello to your new playground.
author: Katherine L.

description:
Enjoyed a field trip with a 3rd grade class here. No plan or strategy.  Just walked around and touched everything.  Staff was friendly and helpful. 

Lockers available so you do not have to carry lunches with you. 

Walking distance to Embarcadero Bart Station. 10-15 min walk.
author: Anthony S.

description: This place is great for kids and adults. Very hands-on science museum. Admission was $29.95 and a locker rental is 50 cents. Getting there from the east bay is easy and a short walk from BART.
author: Annette W.

description:
The first time I came here was 1988 on a school trip. I was so pleased to see that the old Vanna White upside-down face that so fascinated me as a kid is still there! 

Tip: if you are a childless adult and you want to go just to experience wonder without having to battle screaming sticky-fingered children to explore the exhibits, 10:45 a.m. on a Thursday in late September is a perfect time for it. No school groups, no weekend crowds. 

Give yourself minimum two hours to explore.
author: Mandy H.

description:
Beautiful venue. We had our holiday party here. It's very unique for SF, and definitely worth a visit. They made it super special for our holiday party, although it got incredibly packed. For the after dark hours, it was also a blast, but got so packed that we weren't able to exhibit much.

Would love to visit on a normal day and really dive into exploring new concepts!
author: Albert K.

description:
This a awesome place. This was a hands-on museum, unlike other museums. The best part was the Bay Walk. Also at every hour, they dissected cow's eyeballs. Make sure eat a snack before because you are there for a long time.
Explainers will help you. This is very cool stuff. please come!
author: Noah G.

description:
If you plan on visiting San Francisco or the Bay Area, I highly recommend checking the Exploratorium out, along with the Golden Gate Bridge, the cable cars, Alamo Square, Blue Bottle Coffee, and Lombard Street, of course.

I'm from San Diego, so when I first set foot in this place, I was instantly reminded of the Reuben H. Fleet Science Center at Balboa Park..but much bigger and better!

I visited this place at the perfect time--a Thursday evening last October 2013. Apparently, only patrons 21 and up are allowed, so we didn't have to compete with kids to play with the cool gadgets.  I loved the black sand, musical lockers, toilet water fountain, the kaleidoscope, and basically everything I saw inside!  We even found a Google Glass demo exhibition, so it was neat to try it out for free.  The staff was helpful and friendly as they assisted us in operating the device.  The Exploratorium is so spacious that I would almost get lost in fun, and just when I thought I've seen enough, there was more to discover!

Thursday evening + no kids = great date night spot.  I saw couples left and right releasing their inner kid.

This place is no tourist trap, and I'd imagine locals enjoying this spot regularly.
author: Angel C.

description: What a wonderful place for kiddos. My boys are 4 and 8, and we arrived on a Saturday, right at opening. Parking was $5/hour right across the street, and a flat day rate of $20. I loved how hands-on all the exhibits were. The boys got to try EVERYTHING and we were out of there by 2. I'd recommend for anyone who has children ages 3 and up.
author: Yang S.

description:
The Exploratorium and Fort Point are my two favorite tourist attractions in San Francisco. Each are better than Fisherman's Wharf, Ghiradelli Square, Ferry Building, Twin Peaks, Coit Tower, Lombard Street, Palace of Fine Arts (the old Exploratorium location), Legion of Honor, DeYoung, SF MOMA, CA Academy of Sciences, or riding the cable cars.

Science museums are too frequently slanted towards children. After visiting a few, why bother going to any more because they are all so similar and geared toward people who never finished high school physics. Signs the Exploratorium is different? They don't have an IMAX theater or a laser show in the planetarium.

There are still plenty of things for kids to enjoy here, but this isn't just exploring for children. There are many huge and interesting interactive displays for adults. There is even a night designed just for adults. Basically, don't skip coming to the Exploratorium because you think it is just a kid's museum.

Allow three hours minimum to visit. We had a 15-minute wait in line to pay. There was no wait for a pre-printed, pre-paid ticket. Nearby lots know that tourists are going to park here, so the rates are high.
author: Brian U.

description:
This is the funnest place to learn or review nerdy facts, but make sure to either have patience for children (lots of it) or pick an off day. 

A very "hands-on" museum as there are many, many, many try-me, look-at-me, and touch-me stations. They appeal to grown ups and children alike. However... the children tend to hog them, thus, bring your patience.  

I want to say almost half of the stations require a partner. This makes it great for parents to bond, teach and learn with their kids. It also makes it simultaneously great for a date night.

They have a "Human Phenomenon" gallery that is focused on human interactions, emotions, evolution of mind and thought... etc. I found this gallery to be the most interesting and appealing, although I should confess that I'm a Neurobiology, Physiology, and Behavior graduate. 

With that being said, all of their Physics-related displays have already been seen and understood by me...Nevertheless, still enjoyed by me . My date is on the opposite end of the nerd scale, but he had fun at the Exploratorium too.

It's a truly interesting and amusing place.
author: Mimi N.

description:
Mr. M and I were saddened that the Exploratorium had relocated.  We felt the old location was perfect.

And it was.

But this new location is equally perfect.  Perhaps even more perfect.  

Easy to get to from the east bay taking the ferry.  Big bonus!
The space is enormous and the exhibits seem endless.  We spent several hours and still there was so much more that we didn't get a chance to see.  I love the layout.  There are several places where you can step outside, breathe some fresh air and enjoy the view from the pier, or experience some man made fog, or have a snack.  The staff is enthusiastic and helpful.  

Our favorite exhibits were in the Tinkering Studio.  We spent a lot of time exploring the experiments they offered us.  Truly, we could have spent all day tinkering.  I really, really want the stop motion animation station in my home.  I could sit there for hours making films with springs and dry pasta and computer keyboards.  It's super cool fun.  With only two stations, be prepared to wait for a turn.

Here are our films.  They took 5-10 minutes to make such short pieces, and they felt rushed due to others waiting.  But it was great fun.

Littlest M (couldn't keep her hand out of the picture), 9 seconds
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hz812EXSFBA

Tween M (used her hand as part of the film), 11 seconds
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iYkw84SBiRk

I went during the day with my kids, but I imagine if I wanted to come without children (and I do), that the 18+ evenings at the Exploratorium would be a great deal of fun.
author: Linda M.

description:
5 huge stars. I could have easily spent the whole day here.

Yes, technically, the place is for children but adults will likely enjoy about 85% of the exhibits, perhaps even more than the kiddies.

The "fog bridge" outside the entrance is simply terrific and there are other gems spread everywhere throughout the facility, probably too many for me to list here. In fact, you can visit the fog bridge without even paying admission.

Not cheap at all ($25 per adult, although the  super helpful counter gal saved us $2 per adult by asking if we had AAA cards) but completely worth it.

I have been to more than my fair share of children's science museums and many of them are tired, boring and have tons of broken machines. Not here. I would wager this is the best children's science museum in the country.
author: Craig W.

description: Love the location! My son love here, way more educational than Disneyland and cheaper! Haha.
author: Agatha Y.

description:
Loses one star because everyone I went with (aside from the guy who fell asleep when I asked for feedback) liked the old location.

Most of us missed the open spacious set-up.

And it also loses that same star because certain things weren't working properly.

But, I always loved learning and there is a lot to see, I didn't get to partake in every single thing, but it was great. 

With your ID and (also if you mention your a student on top of that), it's a bit cheaper.

**They're still adding new things, so I would suggest going later on, not right now!
author: Lilian L.

description:
I have been to the older exploratorium years ago. When I visited the new one, it still had that amazement factor. 

It's a place where your creativity and brain power can be put to use. There are many stations with interesting facts and tools to tinker with. Most of the stations give you the hands-on experience.  

The place is spacious, so it rarely feels crowded and there are many seats/benches just in case you need a little break from walking around. Great for kids to let their imagination run free or for adults that want to learn something new.
author: Joy L.

description:
My girlfriend has been asking to come here for a while now and we finally got a chance to visit  the new venue.  

First off, if youre a student, bring your student ID.  They give you a discount.  Even if you dont the price is well worth it.

There is a ton of different things to do in this place!  We spent all afternoon wondering around playing like we were kids.  You can build things, balance things, move things, throw things.  Basically a playground for developing minds! If you love to do different activities this is the place for you!

My personal favorite was the long booth with a decible-meter  where you try to walk over rocks as quietly as possible.  Of course, my girlfriend beat me.  =\.  

I would visit again!
author: Kirby C.

description:
The new location is quite impressive.  Housed at the port at Pier 15/17, it's massive. It juts out into the bay so you've got spectacular views of the Bay Bridge and the water.  

Even before you get to the ticket window, there's a long corridor. To the right, you can read about the beginnings of the piers and the longshoremen who worked along the waterfront.  To the left you can read about the Exploratorium's beginnings. 

As for the Exploratorium itself, I liked the layout.  Expect to spend many hours there if you're like Bill the science guy.  If you're like me, you can do a high level overview and be out of there within 1 1/2 hours.  The museum is broken out into categories, i.e. Light, water, sound, heat, etc.  The Tactile Dome is still there.  It's a separate ticket though.  But it looked like it was under construction. But the bubble area is gone.  That was my favorite.  

Yesterday it was free admission.  Hordes of families.  

As it's an interactive hands on science physics museum, bring plenty of antibacterial lotion.  Germs!!!

Plenty of restroom facilities. 

There's a nice restaurant in the back, Spyglass.  I'll have to check that out next time.
author: Shirley N.

description:
My friends took me here when I was visiting the city and I must say, it was a delight. As others have said, this place is packed with children. However... when coming to a place like this, you have to come prepared to deal with the families and their children - well behaved or otherwise. If this doesn't sound like your cup of tea, I will encourage you to come, but hopefully it's not too emotionally draining. 

With so many interactive exhibits and so many things that can make you and your friends laugh in the moment. Every few feet, there's a new engaging exhibit. It's just a great way to spend an afternoon and lose a few hours of your day (or the entire day altogether!). 

Pay the fee and see what this place is all about!
author: Daisy K.

description:
I'm not afraid to say it; generally, I don't like kids. The idea of meeting friends and their kids here on a Saturday made me twitchy, so I prepared to pretend to enjoy myself. 

The Exploratorium brings it, no pretending needed. I had such a fun time, I didn't really notice or care that the place was crawling with kids. We arrived early and when we left mid-afternoon, the place seemed quite crowded to me. Our friends said it was nothing, many times there are lines four deep at most displays, My advice is to go early and on a weekday if possible, it's more fun when you're not waiting in line or rushed to move along.

Being from Chicago, we have a lot of great museums, but nothing quite like this. Almost every feature at the Exploratorium is designed to be up close and hands on. It's the total opposite of museum trips I recall as child where my favorite part was the plasticy sculpture you could buy at a vending machine. Here, I was constantly engaged in different ways. We spent nearly four hours there and didn't see everything there was to offer.

Aside from the museum, I was hugely impressed with the restaurant - Sea Glass. I'm used to dull, depressing overpriced museum cafeterias with hot dogs, cheese burgers, vending machines and very few options for the non-meat eater. Sea Glass steps hit up a notch, a big notch; you can get entrees, sides, sushi and booze. My partner-in-crime and I split a generous side of roasted brussel sprouts and quinoa chili. The culinary staff tasted the dish before serving it and made a few tweaks to make sure it was up par. Prices aren't cheap, but compared to what I normally expect at a museum I didn't feel cheated.

If you're a local or a visitor, have kids, are a big kid, or have the slightest interest in science and discovery, I highly recommend a trip to to the Exploratorium.

TIP: The Tactile Dome books fast, call ahead and reserve your spot. Fun fact - according to the website, it was designed and built by Nicholas Cage's father.
author: Mary T.

description:
This place is awesome!!!! So much freaking fun running around learning and getting interactive.  Too bad when I went here there was a lot of kids so I had to fight for my turn.  

There is just so much to do here that it becomes very overwhelming.  I loved how they sectioned off the areas into different subjects.  Makes my mind focus on one thing.

My favorite areas?  Uhh...too many to tell you! 

I wanted so badly to do the Exploratorium After Dark.  It would be so cool especially with all the lights, sounds, and water.  It sounds amazing...

I would highly recommend coming here when visiting the city.
author: Jackie N.

description:
Gorgeous location. And bigger than ever. Granted I haven't been to the Exploratorium in maybe 15 years. The number of exhibits is mind-blowing. We spent an exhausting 2 hours there and maybe saw half of the exhibits? 

7.5 year old had a blast. 2.5 year old just ran around like crazy and didn't let my husband look at anything. I wouldn't recommend bringing the toddlers here. Exhibits really are more for school-aged children. 

Went on the Saturday after Thanksgiving and it was packed. Made the experience a little less enjoyable as you usually had to wait around to try anything. 

There is some fun free exhibits outside too, if you don't want to drop the money on tickets. It is expensive!  But it is definitely an improvement over the old Exploratorium. They did an awesome job with the exhibits.
author: Nora S.

description:
A museum filled with hands-on, interactive exhibits -- definitely not something you tend to hear about and experience. Geared towards sparking kids' curiosity and awareness, I can get behind the concept of experiential learning at an informal education site. However, this museum seems more like it's targeting (and attracts more) kids between the ages of 7-12, with maybe a few teens sprinkled here and there, and parents mostly there with their kids, either playing with them or sprawled [resting] on the many couches around.

It's pretty fun to get to play with all the things, so I see the appeal. I came here using the San Francisco City Pass, which I definitely recommend. For $86 (currently on sale), you can go to 4 different attractions, including the Exploratorium; compared to the $29 adult admission ticket, this is a steal especially if you want to go to the other attractions in the Pass as well.

Also, museum closes at 5pm SHARP and they don't let you use the restroom on your way out...
author: Judith C.

description:
I've been a huge fan of the Exploratorium ever since I was a wee little one - and I was pleasantly surprised by their revamped building on Pier 15 in San Francisco.  There are exhibits for the young and old alike and it's the perfect place to take your family, your significant other, your parents and your kids all at the same time.  We got here around 3pm and only gave ourselves 2 hours until it ended which was most definitely not enough!  Mark my words, next time I will be there from the second it opens til the minute it closes - the view of the Bay, the caliber of people you're surrounded by - you simply can't beat it.

Also, First Thursdays happens - you guessed it - the First Thursday of the month and gives us young adults time to enjoy the place at night with a few adult beverages in hand; I can't think of anything better!
author: Amanda G.

description:
Quite possibly my new favorite science center!  This was stop number one after checking into the hotel since it was within walking distance, and it's a good thing the husband and I went there first because we were there practically forever!  There is an amazing amount of stuff to do in this deceptively small-looking building.

We decided to tackle the Exploratorium in section number order, so after filling our water bottle from a toilet in the entranceway, we headed to section 1, a cool social area full of two-person exhibits.  Then we played in my favorite part of any science museum, the physics section (here sections 2 and 3), where we got to build things and play with neat contraptions.  I wasn't huge on the biology section (4) or the outdoor exhibits (5), which were notable mostly in how we couldn't figure out how to get to them, but the terrace (6) held our absolute favorite part of the museum, a giant pinhole camera that you could go inside to watch boats going by in the bay.  We spent a surprising amount of time just watching the boats, and then running inside for paper and pencils to trace the dockyards across the bay.

The camera may have been the best part also because that part of the museum was so quiet -- we came in at the same time as at least two different field trip groups and ended up missing out on a lot of the different exhibits on the main floor (even though we were there for hours!) because there was continually a line of small children ahead of us.  We will definitely have to come back next time we're in town and maybe be a little more pushy with those kids. :)
author: Alison M.

description:
I love it here! Being here makes me feel like a kid all over again, always so excited and looking at every exhibit. :p 

I think 4-5 hours would suffice for a thorough walk through every exhibit. If you decide to pay a visit, definitely go to the earthquake and the aquatic area. I'm pretty I spent about 2 hours in the aquatic area. 

p.s... students get a discount! even though it doesn't say state it at the door. Just show your school I.D and i believe you save $5 ?...
author: Lisa H.

description:
Whether you are a tourist, or a native San Franciscan, the Exploratorium is a must visit.  This museum/attraction is a place for children and adults alike.  This place offers hands on activities, as well as learning about different scientific phenomena that occur in everyday life.  You can learn a lot about sound, sight, space, animal and plant life, and much more.  

I have come here about a dozen times so far throughout my lifetime.  Many times as a child with classmates, and twice as an adult.  However, I have only come here once since they changed locations.  During my most recent visit, I came on Mother's Day.  They were offering free admission, and the line was huge.  But, we waited, and got let in within 30 minutes.  It is definitely nice to walk around and relive childhood memories, and to visit exhibits both old and new.  My favorite exhibit would have to be the one where you enter the room and make a pose against the wall.  Then a light flashes, and it leaves a print on the wall where your shadow is.  That, I think is pretty cool!
author: Victor L.
