description: thanks to our local library, we got to enjoy our first visit for FREE(saved us almost $50) after a quick walk from the Ferry Building. I grew up at the Palace of Fine Arts version and this new site is beautifully designed. It did feel somewhat overwhelming due to the number of exhibits but in a good way. There was a good mix of social, life, and physical science interactive exhibits; my 2nd grader was enthralled for the entirety of our three hour visit. Though it was crowded due to the holiday, it never felt packed. We had plenty of room to walk and never felt like we were being jostled by other patrons. The crowd was a mix of tourist  and local families, hipster couples on dates, and well-behaved crews of teens.
author: Julie C.

description: This place was actually kind of interesting. It has a lot of learning things for the kids. It is a very big place. It took us pretty much all day to explore the Exploratorium!
author: Hien B.

description:
Headed out here for their After Dark on Thursday night.  The place closes for an hour, sets up bars, and opens to the 21 and older crowd, much like the other museums in the area.  The theme of the night was Sexplorations, looking at the biology of sex, with many speakers set up around the Exploratorium to give mini lectures.  

This place is a great, hands on facility that needs far more time to explore than the four hours that an After Dark allows.  It seems like it'd be a great kid friendly place, if you have a child who enjoys learning or mental stimulation.  There are lots of fun, interactive exhibits, and having the after hours there is great to ensure you're not hogging the fun from a little kid.

I'll definitely have to go back to explore more; it seems worth the price.
author: Jes G.

description:
The Exploratorium is awesome. They have a bunch of cool experiments- like "space water", where the water flies off of the pipette upwards, a ball that you can hear people through if you are sitting on he same color, a sample of all the little organisms in one drop of water, and an echo tunnel outside. It was a very cool experience. I would definitely come back here. 

We stayed here for 4 hours and didn't want to leave when it closed at 5.
author: Olivia S.

description: This is a MUST see if you are in San Francisco! I was a little hesitant about coming here because I thought it would be similar to one of the discovery kids museums by boy was I wrong! We were here for two hours and that didn't seem like enough time to go through all of the exhibits. I would say 3/4 hours would be the sweet spot. I wish we would have done the after dark adult only time but we didn't know about it until we got there and we already had day time tickets. The reason I say this is because although the exhibits are all very adult friendly there are A LOT of kids at this place and they are always cutting in front of you etc. I would just have had more fun and been able to do a lot more of the exhibits if there weren't so many kids around. It is doable during the day though if you do have children in your group and you're and adult!
author: Taylor B.

description: It was all fun and games and it still is. They still have a lot of the same stuff from when I was in elementary so reliving the same experience was exciting. Lots to see. Took me about 3-4 hours to see everything and experiment with everything. On free days, the line is super long but it took about 30 minutes to get in. Worth the wait in line if you haven't been to this new location!
author: Benita M.

description:
Simply the best tactile museum in the Bay Area, possibly in all of California! 

The Exploratorium has countless exhibits that involve high-level tinkering, thinking, and questioning. If you want to try the Tactile Dome, it's an extra $15, but well worth it if it's your first time! You can get a discount if you're a student, teacher, or senior. If you're claustrophobic, don't do it... 

One of my favorite aspects of the Exploratorium is its strong support for teachers and students! Here, everyone is a learner, all the time.

The museum also offers weekly After Dark events, which is for 18 years old or over! You can buy drinks and snacks and tinker around! Great idea for a date! 

Parking anywhere in the city is quite pricey, so take BART and just get off on the Embarcadero. It's about a pleasant and flat 10-minute walk along the pier.
author: Nicki F.

description: This was my first time at the new location. What a gorgeous design and use of Pier 15. The layout of the galleries is much more spacious and organized. I am glad they kept some the old exhibits and updated some and added new.  I particularly liked the Fisher Bay Observatory Galley and Terrace.   I love the view of the water and the history and maps of San Francisco.  We arrived after 2:00pm and did not realize that it closes at 5:00pm on Sundays.  We did not get a chance to partake in the outdoor exhibits.  I think I also want to come back and go to the after dark event, I won't have to worry about the kids that cut you off to get to the exhibits.
author: Infodiva B.

description:
Short Story:
I came here on their free Sunday and it was packed!

Long Story:
I came here with a group of friends on their free Sunday at 1PM and it was packed!  There are plenty of exhibits to see, touch, hear, and interact with.  there are several employees stationed at a few major places so that you can ask for help and they show you what to do.  The place is mainly geared towards kids but even as adults it's still cool to go to.

Verdict:
I think it's a one time experience for me.  I like the place but once you go and see things...it's not as if you are dying to go back.
author: Michael W.

description: Amazing attractions, super over priced and very uncomfortable heat. This building will have you sweating through your shirt! Very uncomfortable.
author: Sean F.

description:
I loved this place in the old location and the new location at Pier 15 is even better. More stuff around it on the piers to do and see, and a better layout, even some outside things to play with for the kiddos.

I went on opening day and bought a ticket for a specific time. It wasn't too crowded and we really got to do everything that we wanted inside (me and my 6 1/2 year old son). He remembered a lot of the exhibits from the old place but there were definitely some new ones like the dry ice melting exhibit (super cool).

It looks like they have a lot of room to grow and some more planned exhibits coming in the existing space, and even long-term they can expand into Pier 17 next door.

Wish our science museum in Seattle was this cool.
author: Joshua B.

description:
Visited the Exploratorium as part of a short trip to SF from Seattle. In Seattle we have the Pacific Science Center which is similar to this, so I had a hard time not comparing my childhood memories there to my adult memories here. 

First off, there are a TON of exhibits here which was a little overwhelming because we didn't want to spend hours and hours there, but didn't want to miss anything cool! What I found was that a lot of the exhibits were really similar, or demonstrated very basic concepts (or sometimes nothing?). The science center in Seattle has fewer exhibits but seems like each one is a little more exciting. 

Also, we went on Friday, July 3rd and it was packed. Most exhibits had a line, and if you wait in line it was inevitable that a little kid would run up and use it before you (but who can say no to kids?). 

Overall it wasn't a bad experience, just not quite as good as I was expecting based on reviews and everything.
author: Troy C.

description:
Absolute fun all under one roof!

Trekked nearly two miles from the Caltrain station just to get here, and it was definitely worth it. The exhibits are numerous and nicely spaced out so there is enough space to comfortably play and explore.  

The exhibits seem endless and are all pretty much hands-on. The decor is modern and just crazy fun in here. Definitely allows the kid in you to come out. Shamelessly too. Just beware of the Adult-Kids who tend to hog some of the play things...they sometimes seem to grow oblivious to the fact there are children around who would also like to see what's going on. 

They're open 10am-5pm most days except Thursdays when they close at 10pm for us Grown Folk after hours events. Parking is usually along the streets or in areas surrounding where you'd have to pay. Take Bart or the Caltrain if you don't mind walking. 

You can purchase tickets online ahead of time.
author: Cat V.

description:
Decided last weekend to take the kids to the Exploratorium this weekend. Was thrilled to learn it was free admission day this weekend too, saved me almost $100.  But even if I had to pay I feel it's worth every penny.  

The place is HUGE and FULL of interesting interactive things for the kids of all ages to do to learn about science and mechanics.  The kids enjoyed it thoroughly, even my too-cool-for-school 6th grader who I had to literally drag out of bed and threaten to take away his tablet and skateboard to help him find the motivaton to go. Within 10 minutes of arriving he was running from experiment to experiment and kept saying "This is cool."  If he's impressed you should be too. :)

When arrived right when they opened the doors and were greeted with a loooong line...about 1/4 mile long, 3-4 people wide. That's alot of people! But, the line moved quickly and we were inside in less than 10 minutes. It was amazing.  Too bad the Fleet Week ships can't manage that kind of military precision and efficiency. That's another story.

Anyway, we were there 2-3 hours and only managed to see about 1/4 of the place.  By then it was really starting to fill up with people, even more so than earlier in the morning, and it was starting to get too crowded and difficult to keep tabs on where the kids were. 

The only downside was the restaurant. The prices were steep. The food was fantastic and lots of great variety, etc... no complaints there.  But pricey... plan on $20 a person for a plate and a drink. Idk, that's steep for lunch, imo.

We'll be back again for sure. Def worth the trip in from the Valley.
author: Brian E.

description: This place is so cool. My suggestion would be not to come on the weekend. The overcrowding proves to be difficult to deal with. You'll be waiting to 'take your turn'  on the different activities.  For your little ones, may be sensory overload!! I'd like to come with my husband to the adult night, sounds like fun.
author: Bianca V.

description:
This is the most amazing science museum we have ever been to! 
My kids loved every hands on experiment and learned so much. I wish that we would have had more time to explore, as you need an entire day to visit each section. We will visit the next time we are in the area. 
Awesome!
author: Toni L.

description: Fantastic!  Time well spent.  I knew nothing about the museum before we went and I admit when I walked up to buy the tickets I thought "how much for a museum?#%!"  But it was so worth it. We were there for a solid three hours and I feel like we only saw half of it. My kids were fascinated by the hands on exhibits and I loved the short movies that showed how cool and fun math is!!!  Who knew?  Plus they sell beer in the restaurant!
author: Kathleen S.

description: Interactive science museum with many hands on experiments ranging from physics, cognitive science, to botany, and geography. There are flower and cow eye dissections that you can partake in. There's a balcony that give you a great view of the bay bridge so for you photographers, I'd bring a tripod since they close at 10.
author: Kenny P.

description:
The new home of the Pi Shrine.

Happy 25th Pi Day Anniversary, and thanks for hosting us, Exploratorium! Welcome to your new home!
author: Lanie L.

description:
It it's super crowded on the weekends. The further you get from the main entrance the less crowded it is. Fun for kids of all ages, its also fun for adults. 

Some paranoid parents thought I was taking photos either their child or a child that was not my own. I was approached by a guy who didn't immediately identify himself as an employee. He told me they had received a complaint that I was taking photos. I responded that I was taking photos and I feel that people need to mind their own business. Good to know that the people at the Exploratorium are looking out for this sort of thing but I also feel like they should be more professional about it. 

I think one of the coolest things about this place is that they build the interactive displays themselves. I liked the old location but I am starting to get used to the new location. 

Membership gives you access to member only nights. No crowds at all and some fun additions, like free juice and book launch activities when they publish a new book.

Fun for children, fun for adults and fun for adults with children, the place is huge and you can hardly take part in all the displays and activities in a single day.
author: Ben M.

description:
If I could give this place 10 stars, I would. The Exploratorium was ahhhhhhh-maaazing. We were visiting San Francisco for a few days in August and decided to do the Exploratorium on adult night. It was bigger than we expected! We thought we would spend 2 hours at most doing the things but ended up there for the entire 4 hours! My boyfriend and I are science geeks and noticed a lot of the activities were Quantum Mechanics based and things you learn in high school/college physics so we didn't really learn anything new. However, the activities were fun and if we lived in San Francisco, we'd totally have a membership to the Exploratorium because of how much there is to do there. We went to the California Academy of Science and thought the Exploratorium was way better!

I highly recommend adults going to the adult night because you won't deal with bumping into little kids! Plus, they sell alcohol at adult night to make things fun (it is overpriced alcohol though).
author: Daphne L.

description: Great place to spend time with the family while visiting the city. Our kids love to tinker and this is our one stop shop for fun.
author: Dee R.

description:
Came here for a private event, and it was a lot of fun!  I do miss some of the "worn down" charm that they old location had, but I think that they have done a lot of cool things with this new location, and the views of the ocean are gorgeous.  I enjoyed all of their little exhibits and felt like a kid again running around and being fully immersed in the wonders of science.  I recommend checking this place out!  

They are also conveniently located right next to TCHO chocolate (which has a factory tour and chocolate tasting), so you should couple your visit if you decide to come here!
author: Alyx F.

description: I've been here twice already and both times I've been underwhelmed. Location is great. Been there for After Dark event. the Displays were okay, would have been nice it there were more people around to help explain things. The raining demo is gone. I like the old location better.
author: Tiff W.

description:
The location is beautiful. You can catch the stunning sunset setting behind the bridge and treasure island on the pier. 

Exploratorium contains MANY interactive and educational exhibits. If you want to catch everything, make sure to give yourself at least 4 hours. Maybe a little longer to give your brain a break from the science overload. They have a great cafe that even serves ramen! I tried their unique expresso drink (iced with an orange peel) and it was a refreshing pick me up. 

They also have hands on experiments and demonstrations. I deeply regret missing the cow eye dissection. Be prepared to wait your turn or even have the little kids cut in front you :p if you go on the weekend. Fun place if you want a hands on experience, complete with a gift shop that sells all kinds of knicks knacks. My boyfriend's personal favorite was the gun that shot puffs of air into people's faces....and I won't disclose how old he is either....
author: Caroline T.

description: Awesome place.  Bring your curiosity.  Great for kids and the kid at heart.  The admission is pricy so give yourself enough time to feel like you really got your money worth.  All kinds of exploratory, hands on learning.  Very fascinating displays.  Looking forward to a return trip.
author: Malia K.

description:
This is a review for Exploratorium After Dark - Every first Thursday of the month from 6PM-10PM - Adults only.   

I'm probably going to catch some flak for saying this, but I have to be honest...I was kind of bored by Exploratorium After Dark. I love tech, geeky things, and gadgets, and yes, the alcohol helped a bit, but I just didn't really find anything here that fascinating. I thought watching the special cow eye dissection would wake me up a bit, but it was still kind of a snooze fest.

Also, eat before you come. As nice as the Sea Glass "restaurant" looks, it pretty much tastes like cafeteria food. I would highly recommend going to Academy of Science After Dark over the Exploratorium. There's much more to look at and explore, and the exhibits over there are quite enjoyable with a glass of wine, in particular the aquarium.
author: Catherine C.

description:
This place is SO FUN! Just like CA Academy of Sciences, great place for a date, family outting, field trips, you name it! Super fun spot on the pier to take your kids and teach them about mechanics, science, environment, social sciences etc. 

Keep in mind it does get a little packed, especially during the weekends so you might want to plan your visit during off hours. Kids will swarm TF out of this place. But I love seeing little guys and girls run around and tinker with all the activities. 

My personal favorite exhibits were the social sciences and light ones. The giant mirror was a TRIP! Check out the water fountain (spray vs. sip) and the one exhibit that tests your scare reflexes with your significant other! It's hilarious. 

Not sure if the activities change with the seasons. I'll definitely be back to give the Exploratorium another go.
author: Jo L.

description:
This place was a success for my family. My 4 yr old son enjoyed himself to the fullest. There were so many exhibits that interest him that we could have been there all day. We arrived at 10:30am on a Sunday and there was already a lot of people. It was crowded but everyone was good about waiting their turn and not trying to cut. I was disappointed that we didn't get to participate in the drawing exhibit but it was cool to watch. I would have wanted my son to do it, but oh we'll there was so much other things to do. We left at 2:30 cuz out parking meter was almost up, otherwise we would have stayed longer. 

The view outside by the plant life exhibit is gorgeous. Def a good picture spot!! 

Entrance: FREE 5yrs and younger 
$20 for county residents
author: Chrissie G.

description:
A very busy place the day after Christmas. This is the first time we came to the new location on Pier 15. We decided to go right away to grab lunch at the restaurant and skip the very crowded middle of the building, so we walked around on the outside walkway, which had an hourly fog & mist "show" that we kept missing, so we'll have to come back. There was a climbing area and other science inspired activities. 

It's pretty nice and I wish we had the time to see everything before it closed down. Lots of hands-on activities and videos to watch. There's a lot more technology than I recall from the old location, so that was nice. We even got to see the machining area where they create parts for the exhibits. 

I wish I had known that this new location has a fantastic view of the Bay Bridge & Treasure Island so I could have brought my camera & taken photos of the setting sun on the buildings & bridge. 

Since parking is very expensive in this part of town, I'd suggest taking BART and getting in a 10-15 minute walk along the waterfront, maybe even stopping by the Ferry Building for some goodies.

Tip: My friend printed out coupons for out of town visitors. When I gave it to the ticket lady she asked where I was from and honestly told her, I got a bigger discount for being a local. :-D
author: Lisa T.

description:
So much fun!!! My husband and I had no idea what to expect and we were not expecting to be so entertained. 

We went for the "After Dark Night on Thursdays" for adults only (they serve wine and beer too) and roamed all the sections like kids in a candy store - there were so many things to do and loved that it was all hands on! Everyone there looked like they were having a great time and even though it was full of adults, it was truly filled with kids at heart :)

We were there for about 2 hours and we didn't get to even half of all the things there, we will be back for sure. What a great date night!!
author: S S.

description:
Came here on a Sunday afternoon.  I had not been to the new exploratorium since I was a kid.  It was nice to see that some of the old stuff was still there.  This place is a lot bigger than the old place, and what is nice is that you can Bart to the exploratorium and get off on Embarcadero.  

It was just okay for me because of the day that I went.  Soooo crowded with tons and tons of kids everywhere.  If you are a "germafob" you are not going to like this.  Almost  every thing you sit in and touch has been touched by 1000 or more people.  Very hands on museum.  You have to touch everything to experience everything.  

It was a bit too long of a wait for me, and way too many kids everywhere.  Maybe, I just went on a super busy weekend.  But I thought it was just okay.  

However, if you have kids this is a great place for kids because they like to touch everything.  Great for kids who are 7 to 13 years old.  

If I am babysitting one day or if I have little kids in town I would take them the exploratorium it was an okay experience.
author: Alice T.

description:
I came to the Exploratorium a few years ago when they were at their other location. I visited them again at my most recent SF trip in their new location by Pier 15 (I believe). 

You can easily access the Exploratorium via public transportation (I took the BART into the city plus took a streetcar a few blocks, which drops you right in front of the Exploratorium). Prices to get into this place is about $30. It's more on the pricey side, but well worth it! 

I spent about two hours here, but you can easily spend more than that here to really take in everything. I enjoyed it here and being able to play with their displays and act like a kid again. I learned a lot about science as well, more than I would ever know actually! This is a great place to take kids or teens as well and they would have a good time. 

There's a cafe attached here if you're in the mood for lunch/dinner or need a caffeine break. Plenty of seating inside and out to rest for a bit too. 

Next time I'm in the city, I'd come back here!!

Cheers!
author: Michelle M.

description:
Most museums post guards to make sure you don't touch anything; the public IS such a klutz. Cheerful helpers in the TINKERING STUDIO at the Exploratorium, however, helped this public build a lightweight vehicle with an eccentrically spinning motor that made repetitive patterns on paper as it moved. Felt proud of myself!

Then, while the 6-year-old public who was with me was methodically taking apart the marble race tracks other public had built on the peg wall, I was encouraged to use dangerously sharp instruments to make lightweight "drifters" that soared (or sank) in the updraft column of air in the flight cylinders. It was great fun and I didn't have to sign a liability waver. Other people were building elaborate circuits on a large table filled with circuit modules. It was shocking!

We said "No thanks" to watching a scientist dissect a cow's eyeball, but I marveled at the complexity and durability of the microscope stations for viewing microscopic life in the East Gallery. The specimens were all alive and my 6-year-old failed to take any of the apparatuses apart.

This public found the plate of (4) pulled pork tacos with beans to be the best deal in the more adult-oriented (meaning raw oysters & wine) Seaglass Restaurant. Then, in the Bay Observatory Gallery, empty of public, we sat transfixed in front of a huge NASA screen showing time lapse videos of ocean current temperatures, wind directions, and international dust drift across the world over 10 years. OSM!

On leaving, we ran through the clouds from the outdoor fog installation, got dizzy in the Camera Obscura Rickshaw and tried doing "ollies" in the skateboard trailer only spraining one ankle. After renewing our family membership, we boarded a beautiful old Italian streetcar and rode down the Embarcadero into the Fishermen's sunset for more exploring.

See our "Drinking from the toilet a perennial favorite" photo on the Exploratorium photo page.
author: William L.

description:
Likes: $19 for a student ticket.  The new location is at Pier 15/20 but it's definitely bigger than the previous place.  A neat way to spend a couple hours reliving being a kid.  My four favorite things were the magic card tricks table, the dark room where the screen captures your moving images in different designs and patterns, the giant chair, and the gift shop :)

Dislikes: Crowded with kids on a Saturday.  Get ready to wait for others to finish before you can try something.  I also noticed several things missing that used to be at the old Exploratorium.  Maybe it's because they are still working at putting everything together, I'm not sure, but I didn't see the giant bubbles or the wall of colored words or the color wheel :(  Plus the tactile dome was still under construction and wasn't ready for visitors yet, double bummer
author: Karen M.

description:
Nice to see this museum is in a more accessible area by the piers.  It's as fun as it was when I was growing up in the 70's.  It was amazing to see that some of the original exhibits were still in existence.  A great mix of old and new.


Support this amazing hands on museum.  We need more of these types of places in our country to enlighten our future generations.  I just read that they are having economical problems.  Silicon Valley folks, take note...donate some $$$ to this so it survives these tough times.
author: Stuart B.

description:
The Exploratorium made me want to move to San Francisco. And for someone who loves LA, this is a loaded statement. This museum is filled with so much adventure for kids and adults alike. I went with my 12 year old brother, my grandparents, my boyfriend and his niece and a full day was not long enough to enjoy everything the museum has to offer. If I lived in the Bay Area I would certainly (without question) have a membership. How can this museum not inspire children to want to learn about science? about nature? About the Universe? About how things work in the world? Starting with the musical Lockers, the fog bridge, the color-wash (reminiscent of James Turrell's perceptual cell), the plethora of activities to partake in, both alone and in groups, with friends and strangers, the outdoor playground, the Cafe with a small yet excellent selection of foods for the whole family; from fresh rolled sushi and mahi mahi fish tacos with mango salsa to creamy mac n' cheese and roasted chicken. 

So close to the Embarcadero you can stroll along the Piers and watch the sunset over the Bay. Exploratorium is the perfect name for this place, as it is most definitely a place of exploration through play.

The reason I give it four stars instead of five:
It is an experience that every child and adult should experience, and while I went on their website and saw that there are in fact free days for families who can't afford the steep $24 ticket price per person, there were certain class/social groups under-represented at the museum and having lower prices all year round, or offering more free days (than those shown on their website), would expose more groups of children from all diverse backgrounds to the wonders and magic of the Exploratorium.
author: Gabriela G.

description:
Wow this place is awesome! I have never seen so many interactive exhibits in my life.  Very cool place for both kids and adults. 
After walking in we noticed the bathrooms on the left with a couple of drinking fountains next to thier entrance.  One of the drinking fountains was made out of a toilet! Pretty crazy funny. 
The Human Phenomena gallery was cool.  Lots of hands on exhibits  to get your mind working. 
I really liked the Tinkering section. The were lots of cool hand made constructions made of metal. Here you will see toothpick city which is amazing. 
The Seeing and Listening gallery had one of my favorite exhibits, which was this giant mirror that gave a crazy mind blowing reflection. It was something you have to see for yourself to truly appreciate it's  awesomeness.  It inverts your reflection but with a 3 dimensional effect. 
The Bay Observatory was cool.  With the location on one of the piers, you get an awesome view of the bay bridge and surrounding areas. My 2 year old loved watching the variety of boats passing by.
This place was amazing,  and we can't wait to go again for another visit. A fun time was had by all.
author: Mike C.

description:
Attended the Member's Preview on Saturday, March 30th 2013.   Love the new new building.  You don't need a jacket inside to enjoy even if the location is on the water.  The staff has really goes out of the way to make the new (old)  digs feel as new as possible.   To move so much in such a short amount of time while creating a better INSIDE experience speaks well of the team.  The overall atmosphere matches the spirit of the Exploratorium.

While I like the Exploratorium itself, the loss of the park area surrounding the Exploratorium has sucked some soul out of the balance that was struck between tech, humanity, and life at the old location.  The inclusion of the outdoor area outside the rear eastern, and south sides of the new building does mitigate the problem somewhat. But only for those who love a cold concrete pier surface to go along with a water view.   But no ducks and swans for companions anymore.  Just gulls and air-rats ( pigeons).

Public transportation access has improved with the surface trains stopping right outside the building.  It's possible to reach the new building relatively quickly now via Muni + Caltrain / BART.  Definite improvement over the old site that was limited more or less to the Muni Busses for access.   Although I have to say i never took Muni to the old location. 

Parking just sucks.  Even the metered parking is $2.50 to $3.00 PER HOUR adding at least $7.50 to $15.00 to the cost of visiting the Exploratorium.  NO FREE PARKING anywhere near the site as there was in the old location.  Since the new location is on the Embarcadero  getting there, and leaving later, is going to be a chore no matter if you drive or take public transit.  Give yourself an extra 20 minutes or more on the summer weekends above what you would normally plan for your travel.

The Exploratorium is still one of the best outings for tech head in the SF Bay Area.  Just be prepared for a little less of a complete day trip experience of the Exploratorium + relaxing trip and you'll come out great.
author: Chris R.

description:
Oh man was that fun! Everyone (no matter the age) will revert to being a 7 year old on a field trip seven minutes in. All the cool stuff to see and do, plus a group of us went at night so they had drinks/ brews available for the scientist with a social life. 

HINT: Pay the extra $10 and do the 'tactile-dome'! It was awesome, you crawl through a blackened dome where there are a bunch of different sensory stuff going on. Really fun!
author: Austin P.

description: Went last night for the Exploratorium after dark. It's extremely interactive and a lot of fun to just go play.
author: Preet S.

description: Was the best experience my kids have had in a while. We always go to chuck e cheese or something but I can actually say they loved it more then going there! I have 2 kids and they love to touch things so this exhibit was the best thing for them! Everything hands on and all you can say is they where very satisfied and happy after they left
author: Anie G.

description:
My friends and I made the Exploratorium a day field trip and took the Muni there. We grabbed some coffee at the Ferry Building and headed there for some fun. 

We hit the fog bridge first since it was right at the entrance. Besides it ruining my hair, it was awesome! Try walking through there and imagine being attacked by Zombies. Scary!

There were kids running everywhere with smiles on their faces. I felt like a kid again and had to touch everything. There's a lot of space to explore and take pictures. 

I really enjoyed "The Changing Face of What is Normal: Mental Health." I spent some time in there reading the stories of patients who were institutionalized for most of their lives. For each patient there is a suitcase with personal items they brought with them when they first arrived at the hospital. It was interesting to see the comparisons between diagnoses then and now. You would be surprised. They also have interviews from the people who worked at that specific pychiatric center. At the end you are faced with the question: What is normal?. Young children will probably not understand the exhibit, but is definitely worth checking out.

I think I missed some of the galleries, like the outside one. I will have to come back to check them out.
author: Marilu R.

description: There was lots to do, but it was crowded. Saw some cool things. My favorite was this wall where you could do something with your body and it would take your picture. Then it would leave your shadow on the wall for 10 seconds or so. Plus they had a live chicken embryo, which was so neat. They offer discounts, you just have to look for them.
author: Alex W.

description:
Look, it's pretty simple. If you would rather learn by trial-and-error and love interacting with stuff, this is by far the best museum you will ever visit.

I may live in San Francisco, but I've visited many museums all around the US. I really believe I am not being biased when I say that the Exploratorium is by far my favorite of them all! No other place is such straight-up interactive! I honestly could spend an entire day here, the place is literally so big.

Bonus points if you come during the After Dark event, which is Thursday Nights. It's basically the same thing except they serve alcohol. It doesn't sound like much, but playing is always better a little drunk right? ;)

End of the day, I highly recommend the exploratorium one way or another. I don't know if it's the most "San Francisco" thing to do, but it is a TON of fun and I do not think there's anything quite like it in the world. Plus, the location is right near the rest of San Francisco's sights, so it's not that much out of the way!
author: Wynn C.

description: Plenty to enjoy for at least 2 hours. It's more hands on and less fine art. Maker Faire fans will enjoy the Exploratorium, great for kids. The exhibits (except the Tactile Dome which I wasn't able to try just yet) are catered to the young ones, I think pre-collegiate would enjoy this the most. Was surprised to see the OG paint table from the previous location by the golden gate bridge decades ago.  My favorite exhibit was the dead rat with beetles that covers the larvae and beetles getting into the body of the rat over a period of weeks. Very dynamic live and foul - life in a glass box! Bay Area Residents get a few dollars off and teachers get comp'd thanks to Genentech sponsorship, take advantage of that!
author: Wilson T.

description: This is an interesting place to visit if you are a science nerd.  The fire alarm went off when I visited and we had to leave the premises for safety purposes.
author: Marc A.

description: This is a great place to bring your kids if they are older (9yrs and up). I brought my two small kids  (1 & 3yrs) they liked interacting but got bored quickly with whatever piece they were playing with and ran to the next piece. My husband and I really enjoyed ourselves,  in would visit in a few years when my kids are older.
author: Veronica S.

description: This place is amazing. The nerd in me which is very little comes out in force. The kids absolutely love it and even with having a membership it doesnt seem to ever get boring. The membership is a hell of a deal since it's worth coming back. I would highly recommend for the family and adults alike.
author: Brent B.

description:
The last time I made my way to the Exploratorium was in the 4th grade on a class field trip; I have fond memories of that visit, including the novel astronaut ice cream sandwich I snagged from the gift shop :p 

On this visit at its new location at Pier 15, I channeled my inner excited 4th grader spirit and zigged zagged through the various science exhibits! After a bit of preplanning research, here are some tips for those with limited time: 

1. PARK AT THE EMBARCADERO CENTER (LOTS 1-4): If you're visiting from out of town and don't plan to take public transportation, finding parking can be tough in the city. We called ahead of time and learned that although the Exploratorium website advertises over 10 different parking lots, they will only validate for certain ones. We ended up parking at the Embarcadero Center and were able to get it validated by the museum;  with validation our parking was set at a $10 flat rate, which is pretty reasonable considering the outrageous parking prices in the area. The walk is roughly 10-15 minutes to the Exploratorium.

2. BUY YOUR TICKETS ONLINE:  My party purchased tickets on our smartphones and even went paperless; they will scan your e-tickets on your phone! We knew we made the right decision to purchase ahead of time when we passed by the hugeeeeeeeeee mile long line of families with rowdy kids. Also, if you're a local to SF you can get a $7 discount! (i.e. $22 vs $29) 

3. CARVE OUT A FEW HOURS TO EXPLORE: If you're lucky to snag one of the lockers once you first enter the museum, get ready to play, activate that cerebal cortex, and explore.  Even with the hundreds of parents, children, and other museum goers present, it was easy to be constantly entertained by a new exhibit. Some of my favorites include the toilet drinking fountain (ew!?), the toothpick artchitectural SF masterpiece by Scott Weaver, the Central Galley which explores light and sound, and so much more! 

Also on the second floor you'll find a beautiful Bay Observatory with glass windows and a great view of the newly remodeled Bay Bridge and water! 

My inner science geek loved every "ah-ha" moment I had at the Exploratorium- bring your childhood curiousity and appetite for learning, you won't be disappointed.
author: Leslie T.

description:
There is always something new to explore every time I visit. 

It is by the bay and Embarcadero. People can take the bus, car, streetcar, bike or walk. Bikeshare is very close.
The venue is huge. I could spend 2-4 hours inside. There are many activities to do.  
I like the musical section because there are so many instruments to play. I like the San Francisco Bay section, as well, since it has history, technology and science. 
There is a cafe for lunch or snacks by the entrance. 

Lockers are 50 cents, if you have a lot of things you don't want to carry. The free days and weekends can be crowded, especially in summer time. Downtown SF is not to far away.
author: Kristal C.

description: Came here 20 years ago on a field trip. Feels like yesterday but from what I remember this was (and probably still is) an amazing and educational museum.
author: Cameron H.

description:
This is a great place for kids and kids at heart (definitely us)!

It's been years and years since either of us have been to the Exploratorium. The new location at Pier 15 is just a few piers from the Ferry Building, and is easily walkable. There are a few exhibits outside the building along the pier that you can look at before you go inside. It's so great that it is situated right next to the water, offering beautiful views of the bay and the Bay Bridge.

There are countless exhibits, with almost all of them being hands-on in some way. For kids that love science, this is the place to take them to learn and explore! The topics the exhibits cover range from all sorts of physics, to the human body, and more! When we went, there was a really interesting exhibit on mental health that we both enjoyed. They also have a QWOP-equivalent exhibit with a bike. There is plenty to do that you can easily spend a large part of your day here and still have things you won't be able to get to. There is a really nice cafeteria area that overlooks the bay, and was a great place to finally sit down and take a break. There is also a small upstairs portion towards the back that has a terrace area which offers a great views and picture opportunities. 

If possible, try to come here on a weekday when it's likely to be far less crowded than on the weekends. Since the majority of the exhibits are hands-on, less people means a greater opportunity to try and play with everything!

One of these days we'll have to make it out on the first Thursday evening of the month for the After Dark event. Who wouldn't like to experience drinks AND science?!

Cons: It got exhausting about 3/4 of the way through the whole place. Reading each exhibit and the science behind them while trying to navigate around a forest of kids gets tiring. We ended up just walking through the last portion of it.


Pro-tip: Bring some hand sanitizer.
author: Vivian L.

description: This place is the shiznit.  EVERYTHING is interactive.  And they're still expanding.  Every museum everywhere should model themselves after this place.  Well done!!
author: Cindi R.

description:
Very fun and interesting place to spend 3 hours and get some good walking exercise after a great (and fatty) meal at the Farmer's Market by the Ferry Building.

If you are a parent to kids around 5-12 ... this is an EXCELLENT place to take them.

I really enjoyed the mix of science, nature, visuals, experimental, etc ...it's called an Exploratorium :)

My hosts told me they recently moved to "this" location, so everything is very new and very nice.
author: Dennis H.

description:
+ many, many exhibits. You can spend an entire day here. If you come with little kids, you should probably get an annual pass since it's easy to get stuck in one area.
+ interactive exhibits
+ reduced ticket prices for SF residents

- can get crowded
- you can't bring in coffee! I really needed it
- need more places just to sit and relax
author: Margaret R.

description: I haven't been to the Exploratorium since I was a kid and this place did not disappoint. My daughter was amazed at how many displays they had and the Tactile Dome is a must experience! It costs extra money on top of the ticket price and requires reservations, but it was totally worth it. You could spend hours here so plan ahead!
author: Emily M.

description:
Sweet views of the bay, and it's a vast expansion compared to the old Exploratorium in the Palace of Fine Arts. Devote a few hours to this at least!

The evening event for adults (Exploratorium After Dark) is a great chance to see the hundreds or exhibits without little kids running about, but be sure to get there early to beat the crowds. 

Great place for a second or third date since there's a lot of interaction and exploration. Art is mixed into a lot of the science exhibits, which works better in some situations than others.
author: Kevin L.

description: Quite possibility one of the greatest mistakes I made on our vacation.  This is NOT the place to bring a 1 1/2 year old.  Not to mention the hundreds of other summer camp kids running wild, knocking other kids over, being extremely rough on the exhibits.  If you have a child that is into science then this is probably a great place to go, however to charge $54 for 2 adults and a baby, is insane.  There was nothing that blew me out of the water and would have made the visit worth it.
author: Rob P.

description: This is the great place to take your kids to. They can play just about any item inside of it and learn.
author: Sam L.

description: We had to get a membership here this year as the kids totally love science and tinkering with things very educational obviously. Clean organized and would definitely make the most of our membership
author: Lissa Q.

description: The new location is HUGE!!! There were some repeats of exhibits from other sections, but for the most part the visit was fun because of how organized it was.  Each section focuses on one area of science and i enjoyed the new sections of social science and expansion on science of music! I highly recommend young and old to check it out.  Caution: there were a LOT of kids running around so come with patience and a coffee!!
author: Emily M.

description: All day fun for ppl with kids or not. Amazing scientific tricks and displays are sure to keep you and your child entertained all day.
author: Jay K.

description:
ton's of cool science exhibits for kids and adults alike
only thing missing are anti-bacterial dispensers scattered around as this place is riddled with germs from the sick kiddos touching EVERYTHING in sight
author: Lat H.

description:
More high tech and 5 times bigger than the old spot.  Although the old spot had more character and originality, Pier 15 gave us more space to walk and easier to explore.  

Probably takes 4 hours to see and do everything.
author: Kevin L.

description: I miss the old location, the new one does not have the same charm. The best thing about this museum I believe is that it is interactive for children. One of the hardest things about binging children to a museum is that they cannot touch anything. The opposite at the exploratorium. Great for a rainy day as you could spend the day here.
author: Roisin N.

description:
Highly recommended for all ages!  There is a variety of exhibits that anyone with an interest in science will love.  The building is enormous and we became tired after 3 hours and probably saw a third of the Exploratorium.  I could see why a membership makes sense if you live in the area.
The ticket price is a little on the high side if you pay full price.  We bought a package through smartdestinations.com and saved quite a bit.
The only low point of our visit is that we had parked in front of a school but didn't read the signs so ended up getting a parking ticket.  Make sure you don't make the same mistake!
author: Wesley N.

description:
Definitely hits the spot. I stopped at their little promo stand at the farmer's market a month prior, solved a puzzle and set the date to come to the opening night. Well worth it.

 Cute nerds, curious couples and a lot to do in such a big space! 

Their restaurant is a little pricey, so... yeah...
author: Ryan K.

description:
We parked at the Embarcadero and ended up paying $33 (all day/max). I believe theres a parking lot across from the museum, but I wanted to stop by the ferry building for snacks. The walk wasn't bad (10 mins) to the museum. We spent 3 hours there on a friday afternoon,  which really wasn't enough time to checkout all of the exhibits. My 2 yr old daughter's to young to understand the exhibits, however there were plenty of stations to keep her occupied. Since the exhibits are interactive, I would recommend bringing hand sanitizer/wipes.

If your up for the walk, pier 39 is about a 20-25 min walk from the exploratorium.
author: Gema F.

description: Family membership is worth it. Free metered parking on Sundays. The 4 year old has as much fun as the 12 year olds. Educational and physically stimulating.
author: Lauren R.

description:
This new location for the Exploratorium is great.  It's easier to drive to from East Bay (at least I don't have to cross the city to get there) and there are several options for parking.  I also like the option of being able to BART in.  The new location also offers many dining choices within walking distance.  The view is also fantastic.

A lot of the exhibits are the same, however the fact that there is more SPACE is nice.  In the old location on a full day, I felt like I was being bumped around by kids everywhere.  Here there is plenty of room.

The exhibits is less-so for young kids (my LO is about 3), but that's why they're free.  My husband and I got in using free passes that we "checked out" from our local library's Discover & Go program.  We played for about 3 hours and had plenty to do before eating lunch and heading out since it was my son's nap time.

My husband is a bit disappointed that they charge $15 for the Tactile Dome now (it used to be free), but I am ASSUMING that the charge and the location change means that the stuff inside is new now.  I used to wonder how old the interior of the Tactile Dome was!

This is a great stop for curious minds.  Now that it's more centrally located, you can come here and see other great things (the Ferry Building, Pier 39, Ghirradelli Square, downtown, etc).
author: Tracy L.

description: Here for my son's 7th birthday!  Everything is hands on,  educational,  and fun!  Great for the kids and adults!
author: Celeste K.

description:
Not for parents of toddlers.  We took our 3 year old and we soon realized this was not the right place for her.  While each exhibit is interactive and you can touch, jump, throw, bang or sign into something.  You need to read each exhibit to understand what it is trying to convey.  For a three year old, this got old quick.  She could not really gauge what we were trying to teach her. Also an attendant was passing out free tickets to a short film about food.  NOT something that would interest a three year old.  We were over this place in less than an hour.  We packed up and headed to the park instead.   
So For parents of toddlers, I'd say wait pass.
author: Jennifer V.

description: Every child should have the opportunity to come here. Sensational in so many ways. Beyond 5 stars.
author: OakPark M.

description: This new Exploratorium is fantastic! What a fun location and really great space. My daughter loved it! It's a perfect place to spend the day. The restaurant there is pretty good too - pretty good for museum food.. They also serve wine! yipeee
author: Monica S.

description: Great place to go with or without kids. Best to go when kids are 6+ but younger kids can have fun too. Tons of interactive exhibits. We went during pi day, where they had free entrance and pie. There were lots of crowds but it wasn't too bad. We were even able to pass to do the drawing board / swinging table.
author: Stacey L.

description: There's so much to touch! They have a plants section which is pretty cool that you can also touch because usually musesums wouldn't let you touch plants.
author: Hina W.

description:
This is one amazing place that everyone who visits San Francisco or lives in the Bay Area ought to visit. It is so much fun and filled with scientific learning experiences for kids and adults alike. Also, the experiments are very intelligent and exciting and not boring in any manner. 

They named it just aptly - Exploratorium - a place to explore! And all the stuff at this place makes the whole experience fun and enjoyable.
author: Sun B.

description: The happiest place in SF. So many fun things to do. It is kinda like the old exploratorium. We never have enough time to finish going around the whole place. I suggest going in right when it opens. Also, on discount days if you're a resident.
author: Lynn C.

description:
After going to the old Exploratorium since I was a kid, I never thought I'd fall in love with this "new" location... but they nailed it.

from the new exhibits, to maintaining some of my old favorites, to the layout, and the upper level and all the new high tech, this is a blast for kids and adults alike.
author: Mike V.

description:
I took my son here and I gotta say it was a great place. Very cool and interactive exhibits everywhere!!! It was packed with tons of people and kids. There are also great views of the bay, an outside part that has a unique playground and displays. 

I totally was having fun with the optical illusions area. 

I also think the toilet drinking fountain was funny!
author: Roger A.

description: The new location of the museum on the Embarcadero is huge. You can easily spend hours playing and exploring all manner of science. Light, sound, biology, physics, social cooperation - it's all here with great views of San Francisco Bay. There are a lot of families with little kids visiting, but it is definitely a good place for teens and adults - don't be intimidated from trying stuff out by all the pushy little kids and their equally pushy parents. Demo of the self-moving Strandbeest was absolutely fascinating. The restaurant in the back of the museum is quite good with fresh, made-to-order salads, sushi, vegetarian pozole, house-made cookies. Parking is a small fortune across the street from the museum - $5 for each hour, maximum $40. Admission is also expensive - $30 for adults, $20 for kids. At these prices, you should definitely plan to spend the entire day.
author: Wendy S.

description:
AWESOME new location.  Who doesn't love the Exploratorium?!  This place is HUGE and stuffed with all kinds of awesomely cool trinkets and learning stations.  I went with my team at work for a fun team building activity and to be honest, we all thoroughly enjoyed it.  There's so much to do and it really is meant for all ages. 

Not to mention it's right by the water so step outside and you got a perfectly beautiful view of the bay bridge. 

TIP: Since this is a learning type of facility, there are LOTS of kids and families and this can get BUSY. And like most things in the city, parking isn't great.  Since it's now at the embarcadero, you'll need to factor in traffic and parking issues! There are lots of parking lots and there are parking garages underneath the embarcadero center if you want covered parking! Not cheap - but at least it's covered haha
author: Steph S.

description:
This place is fun! I am really glad they moved to the pier because the views are amazing. I remember at the old location it felt like a warehouse of neat and fun gadgets and devices, but at this location it feels more breathable and spread out. And it looks great. There is a lot you can learn here, and even though there are loads of children running around, the information is described in a way an adult can understand without feeling stupid. Just go, and play around, literally. You will be like "oh snap I remember prisms from back in grade school!" You can really tap into the fun and be reminded of the neat science tidbits and projects you learned and did while growing up. 

If you go with children, I strongly suggest you take the time to teach and have them learn why and how things are the way they are. My nerdy side dies a little whenever I see kids run up to an exhibit and just pound and mess with it without learning about what it is and what it is trying to convey.
author: Tony C.

description:
The Future Home of the Exploratorium

Pier 15 / 17 will be the new home for the Exploratorium in 2013.  

Work / Construction has begun.  The Pier has been fenced off and construction workers are working to shore up the pier and giving it a new face lift.  Currently the work being done to Pier 15 is early so there are no signs of delays just yet.  Everything seems to be going smoothly.  

Pier 15 resides along the Embarcadero,  roughly a 10 minute walk from the Ferry Building.  Also a few piers furthers will be the home of the Future America Cup (Pier 27) and on going talks of the Future home of the Golden State Warriors (Pier 30).  

On the Waterfront:

King Street to the Embaracdero:

AT&T Park (Home of the San Francisco Giants)
Pier 30 (Possible Home of the Golden State Warriors 2017)
Ferry Building (Home of the Farmer's Market)
Pier 15 (Home of the Exploratorium in 2013)
Pier 27 / 29 (Home of America Cup and Cruise Ship Terminal) 
Pier 39 and Fisherman's Wharf

I sure hope they've figured out how to deal with the traffic and parking should a event occur at every location on the same day.

Currently The Future Home of the Exploratorium is on target and I can't wait to see the new facility when completed.  So far so good....

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/957M-K8oQdoFVPe8MxVjAA?userid=SRnOg-4Ya4g4dUQ1x0Tdkg#H4ymSOgTccxfWl65qwMmUg
author: Alan L.

description: THE surprise of the trip for us.  NOT cheap, but what a wonderful museum.  Our teenage boys were every bit as glued to this collection of amazing interactive pieces.  I've never seen anything quite like this, but am recommending it to all our friends that visit SF.  We spent 3.5 hours, and could have spent more.  Side tip: the cafe is nice, good food and drinks and decently prices.
author: Mike W.

description: Came here while visiting because we heard it was one of those "must see" places. We were a little concerned at first because we were a group of 20-something year olds on spring break and we saw kids everywhere. Came here on Pi day and found out it was free which was a cool little bonus. After exploring around, we soon were running around like little kids. This place is great for kids and adults. It makes learning interesting and fun. Definitely a must see!
author: Ryan N.

description:
Planned to be there for half of a day -- stayed all day for a full seven hours, breaking for lunch, and if we had the time, we would go back again before leaving San Francisco. Feels like they invented project-based learning. So many scientific knowns simply explained and demonstrated in a tactile setting that requires just enough brain power and elbow grease. Our kids, ages 12, 11 and 8, were engrossed and entertained the entire time. The adults were also thoughtful and amazed. (We all loved the Lego batman and penguin model. A lot.) Visit for sure if you're with kids. Once you get in, the cost will become evident in the work they do at the museum and in their surrounding educational community. 

PS. We ate at Seaglass Cafe, which allowed all of us to eat what we wanted and got us back on the museum floor in a snap. Food was pretty good, too.
author: M J.

description:
My husband and I had a blast here. Only thing we had an issue with was it closing at 5. I would have waited until another day if I knew it closed so soon after is buying a ticket. Yes it was our fault for not checking the time it closes but we only got through 3 of the sections and missed a large part of it. 

A bit expensive but you could spend a whole day in there exploring. Amazing Information and things to play with. Great for people of all ages!
author: Vanessa B.

description: Fans of dark matter rejoice! Here there is the opportunity to sit immersed in a full cinematic experience as a computer driven light show depicts what humans will never explore: though a black hole and beyond. HP money so well spent it is sumptuous and the screen three dimensional. Next to a resturant that serves great spring rolls do nosh before your viewing. The show concludes by reversal to Mother Earth at light speed with the Floyd tune dark side of the moon on their p.a. Very worthwhile to think expanded like that show forces so well.
author: Stefano B.

description:
Science is amazing, playing with expensive toys is amazing. Combine both of these things and you have an entire day of fun ahead of you. If you enjoy learning or even experiencing new things that don't tend to happen in your day-to-day life the Exploratorium has got you covered. Tornadoes, the human body and so much more! 

There are 5 different areas and showing up around 2, I ended up spending most of three hours in the first area alone. This may vary if you are with a younger group but there are so many exhibits with so much to learn I can't imagine taking less time because i would miss so much.

Another thing to note is that you will definitely want to go with another person. Many of the exhibits require a partner which I can imagine would be fun with a stranger but I didn't see many who were alone. Me and my group of friends participated in most of them together and it made it more enjoyable!

The only thing I was disappointed in was that they close at 5:30 and then an hour later you can pay again to enter of you are 18+. I didn't really feel like paying another $15 dollars just for an extension of my time there, despite my enjoyment. That being said I will definitely revisit so I can experience everything else here!
author: Kieffer W.

description:
What an amazing place. I wish I had places like this next to me while growing up. You need at least 3 hrs to check everything out. 

I could only imagine how much kids will love this place. I, a 20something woman couldn't get enough of it. Love the experiments and the interactions. Probably the best way to introduce and teach science to kids. Hands on teaching is the best kind. 

The experiments are laid around the place perfectly, lots of spacing so you don't feel overcrowded by the experiments and so everything is clear. 

Go and unleash that curious little kid still stuck inside of you!
author: Tamara S.

description: Wow...so much to see and do! Lots of stuff for kids to interact with and hands on learning! Wouldn't recommend it for children under 5. Want to plan on a few hours as its expensive ($30/pp)and you will want to make the most out of your money by visiting all the galleries!!
author: From C.

description: It's a good place to like science, good place to hang out as a kid or an adult. You like biology, physics, chemistry... Other activities . Fun interactive exhibits . I have visited and volunteered here and probably has been the most enriching experience of my life... Don't miss the geography exhibits! Totally worth the time and money
author: Aj J.

description:
I went to the Exploratorium solo because I'd been eager to go for a while. I knew it was mainly for kids, but I thought it would be interesting nonetheless. But I was pretty bored. I am interested in science and have been to the California Academy of Science and thoroughly enjoyed it. I also keep up with major scientific findings and have taken many astronomy and health related classes. I'm no stranger to science, but maybe that was why I didn't find the Exploratorium to be all that entertaining. Much of what was here I've already gotten exposure to or have background of knowledge about. 

The few things I did enjoy were the large displays different types of bacteria, explanation of why they look so different, and how they are able to flourish in different environments. I also liked much of the electromagnetic spectrum stuff and seeing live organisms under the microscopes. Much of the other stuff I'm sure is great for kids, but if you're a college educated person who keeps up with science related news, it's going to be a lot of repeat.
author: Victoria J.

description:
I was so unimpressed with the way I was treated today when I went into the Exploratorium to discuss membership options. 

First off my father was visiting from out of town and really was excited to show him the Exploratorium from what I experienced at the old location. I went online to review my options and was ready to happily give them my money after I decided to get the member + one guest of my choice membership... But wait there is a catch. Only I am able to use that membership with the guest of my choice. My wife frequents the Exploratorium and would love to take her friends when I'm not available, but she wouldn't be able to. She would have to buy a whole separate membership to take her own guest of choice. 

I'm baffled, disappointed because I really wanted to be in there today. The old lady managing ticket sales was very nice in explaining the situation to me but this needs to change whoever is in charge. Why wouldn't you make a family household card where anyone in the family could use it to take a guest of their choice? Have you not heard of people sharing Netflix, Amazon Prime and Hulu memberships, Exploratorium? The old lady working the desk response was they have many science seminars and teachers they have to pay. Really? $30 a ticket? $109 for a membership? Not to mention that you guys bought two piers on the Embarcadero for the new location? You're hurting for cash?
You lost my business and I did not walk in today. I won't be going back and will be telling many about my experience.
author: Cory S.

description: Best museum ever! I am a math teacher from Los Angeles and I wish I could.take.my kids here. We went on. Thursday night and this is the most engaging and interesting museum that I have ever been to. It has so.many hands on.wxpwriences that are science related and interactive.  I highly recommend for.any age over 5.
author: Dwight S.

description: It's made for older kids (those that can read) because there is a lot of good information everywhere. Extremely interactive exhibits for people to enjoy. It's $$$ but you can make a day of it and bring a lunch/snack.
author: Elaine Y.

description:
I highly recommend blocking off enough time to explore the whole place; it'll be so worth it! There is so much to do and see inside the Exploratorium, and the place can hold a lot more exhibits than I ever imagined. I spent an hour or so and felt so overwhelmed by the options -- I skipped so many things! Most of the activities are fun, educational, and easy to follow, so I'm definitely coming back and blocking off a day to really experience all the great things the Exploratorium has to offer.

Food and drinks aren't shabby either. My group asked for a bulk order from the Seaglass Restaurant, and it was probably 4 times the amount of food we were expecting to get! Obviously the prices are pretty good. There were also some pretty creative (not to mention tasty!) drinks.

Plus, it's in a beautiful location. Who doesn't love the Embarcadero and piers? I'll definitely be back.
author: Kimberly Y.

description: This was one of my favorite places to visit in San Francisco. It's exhibits were all mostly very hands on and interactive. I think it's a great place to visit for adults and children alike. If I had children of my own, I would definitely bring them to this museum. The exhibits are very educational while making it fun. The museum is quite big and there is a lot to see. I think the only downside is that it can be very crowded. There were so many children there on what I would assume is a field trip because there were a few large groups of children escorted by chaperones. Next time I will probably want to try the after dark event.
author: Pamela T.

description:
Had a lot of fun! Educational and interesting!
But avoid coming on the weekends. There are too many kids. 
And the Exploratorium is bigger than I thought!
author: Brenda Jiwon L.

description:
Having gone to the Exploratorium when it was still at the Palace of Fine Arts, and a few more times at this new location -- I would have to say this was a wise decision. It is now away from residential areas with better public transportation accessibility. And as a bonus, you get a nice view of the Bay Bridge!

Moreover, it is a great place to take your kids to explore; it has so many hands-on activities for you to learn kinetically and visually. It is also a great place to go with your 21+ friends for their After Dark nights to discover new things if you are tired of the normal bar/lounge scene. 

The staff is also veryyyyy nice and patient. I had one staff member seriously take 34897398 photos of me trying on all three of those small, medium and oversize chairs! (Thank you, kid. It was the best and cheapest photo opportunity I have ever had!)
author: Jen N.

description: Best hands-on science museum ever! Like how they update the exhibits periodically throughout the year, and the Tactile Dome is something everyone should try at least once. The After Dark events are also nifty, although can sometimes get crazy crowded, at least for the more interesting talks going on at the same time. Y'all should consider becoming a member, young or old!
author: Linus W.

description:
Holy crap, this place is amazing.

First of all, I'm not going to complain about the swarms of children that were buzzing all over the place screaming at the top of their lungs--I should've known that coming during spring break at mid-day would lead to such an experience. Even so, I was still able to wedge myself in to check out more than a few exhibits, and I had a great time doing so. The level of interactivity here is unsurpassed as far as museums go, and it's an enormous space, as well, so there's lots of stuff to check out, particularly if you can manage to get around.

If you're hungry, I would suggest trying the Seaglass Restaurant at the far end of the museum, but don't go during peak lunch hour. Otherwise you will wait for a while.

One note: If you park at the Embarcadero Center garage, GET YOUR PARKING TICKET VALIDATED. For the love of all that is good and holy, don't forget to do this. Otherwise you will be charged an ungodly amount upon exiting, as I did--$33?! I've paid less than that to park for multiple days in airport lots. Just... don't make that mistake.
author: Ryan E.

description: I went here on a sponsored Pi day entry. It was crowded as expected but I had a wonderful time trying interactive experiments and exhibits. Had so much fun on the photo ops, obviously! It definitely unleashed the inquisitive kid in me.
author: Liberty A.

description:
This place is a germaphobes worst nightmare but a lot fun for the kiddos. If Ebola broke out here the world is doomed. Seems like they could add a few hand sanitizer stations to address that. Definitely buy your tickets online to avoid the long line to get on.  Don't have to print the tickets either, they can scan from your phone. Somewhat pricey for what it is.

Parking across the street for $5/hour for the first 4 hours, not $5 total for the first 4 hours like we mistook.
author: S F.

description:
Dear God please bring hand sanitizer and wash your hands. 
Kids. Touch. EVERYTHING.
Free days are fun. Crowded as ever. Exhibitions are great, especially the ones that play with lights or physics.

Someone totally hot-boxed the flashing photobooth.
author: Jason S.

description:
This is such a fun place to spend your afternoon!

I was so happy to have stumbled upon the Exploratorium while walking along the Embarcadero. 

It's $24 for a student ticket, and only $19 if you live in the Bay Area. Definitely worth it since we came on a Tuesday afternoon and it wasn't too crowded.

There are so many fun, interactive science exhibits. This place is actually huge and I can't imagine anyone being able to go through all the exhibits in one day. My favorite part was the section on optical illusions, and the black magnetic sand! I played with that thing for 5 minutes. Also, the slinky treadmill is really cool :)

There was also a hands on area where you could build things and make your own stop-motion film. I wish I'd gotten to do that, but that section was jam-packed with kids, so we moved on.

I am so happy to have found the Exploratorium! My stay in San Francisco was definitely made better by it :)
author: Nancy X.

description:
Love the the new location of this place! I can spend hours here, and have spent hours here, on multiple occassions, and there's always something new and different to explore. My personal favorite is the Tactile Dome which requires separate reservations and an additional charge, but the experience is well worth it.

I got the dual explorer membership one year and it is defnitely worth the fees if you go at least twice in one year. Plus, with this membership, you can take one guest along with you for free, and you also get discounted parking at the Embarcadero center with validation ($10 flate rate)!

If you're looking for a day activity for groups, dates or family hang-outs, Exploratorium never disappoints.
author: Kristel S.

description: This is the most incredible place for both kids and adults alike. World class and proud that it's in SF. I didn't want to leave. Nor did the kids.
author: Matt T.

description: I remember going here for field trips when I was younger and it was located at Palace of Fine Arts. I have since moved to Southern California and came here with my family for a mini vacation. We took my daughter here and I was blown away with the amount of activity here. This definitely stimulated her young mind. You need to spend a few hours here. It's a wonderful learning experience!
author: Nina M.

description:
You need to eat before you get here.  The Seaglass Restaurant food selection was not appropriate for their customer base.  Come on people. I KNOW it's SF but they are kids!   The fish tacos made the adults sick (I mean REALLY sick). Bad fish?  
My 2 13 year olds decided there was nothing on the menu they wanted so they just passed (wise decision).
author: Jill B.

description:
I recently visited the Exploratorium on Pier 15.  It's an unbelievable, incredible, fun-filled place!  I really can't say who was having more fun, the grownups or the kids.  The hands-on exhibits here entice both the youngsters and the adults.  I found myself standing in line waiting for a particular exhibit so that I too could try it out!

The exhibits and displays at the Exploratorium are not only educational but they also encourage exploration and learning of science, the arts, and human beings.  The new site offers fantastic views of San Francisco and the surrounding bay.  Can't wait to go back and explore the exhibits I missed the first time as well as any new exhibits!
author: Lupe M.

description:
So apparently you can purchase tickets only for cheaper because if you'r ea local, you get a discount ($5 off). I bought an adult and student one, and when I got there they didn't even check IDs. Go figure right? 

The place is pretty big, and a lot cleaner than the old location. BEWARe..lot's of kids..all over the place! I suggest going really early if you want to try things out and beat the kids from getting to them first. 

There's also a restaurant inside, so if you're hungry you can get food. The gift shop is small, and nothing crazy, though there are two shops, one inside (the lamer one) and the one outside for anyone to go into (better stuff). 

The stuff there is neat, some are new, and some are old. There's a bunch of stuff that is being made still. If you're an adult, it probably takes 2 hours to finish up, if you have kids, o boy maybe the whole day? Overall not bad, great new location, the price is fair enough if it was like $15.
author: Minerva L.

description:
It's been a long while since i've been to the Exploratorium but I dig the new location! There's so much to do, and at first I didn't think that I could spend 4-5 hours there, but definitely proved myself wrong there. 

There are so many exhibits and fun hands-on activities that appease both kids and adults alike. Great for a date day, you really have a lot of fun learning with your significant other. If you are local, present your ID for a local's discount! Also if you're a student, be sure to let them know as well for a possible added discount. As stated, we spent a good four or so hours here, and with that being said, there is parking all around the pier. We ended up parking just across the street, in the meter parking. The cost for 4-5 hours wasn't bad at all, definitely worth it for a days worth of learning and fun.

Highly recommend taking the kids, coming with friends, or taking your special one out for a day full of fun and learning
author: Elliot K.

description: This place is so big! We walked and walked and walked I think for hours. unfortunately I was pretty sick so didn't enjoy it as much as I probably would. Still place has loads of stuff to see, touch and move. I personally loved smoke tornado and giant plate with smoke crawling on it, super cool. There are many things for every age, I saw grown ups having genuine fun while mixing their faces through fakey kind of mirrors and small odd trying this corridor thing where you have to beat your own score of being silent. Really good place to visit and price was more than fair.
author: Filip C.

description:
My wife and I went to the Exploratorium in its old location years ago to experience the tactile dome for a unique date. Margaret picked this date because she knows I'm kinesthetic. 

In the dome it is pitch dark, and you wind your way through a topsy-turvy maze in the dark through feeling your way. The darkness renders you blind, so you must rely on your tactile sensations. This is both interesting and a little nerve-wracking. This is definitely not an activity to do with people you don't trust!
author: Zander K.

description:
It takes me quite a while to pronounce this correctly -- Explora...torium. It is of a world of science, but more of a world of art. It's a beautiful combination of science and art. Every experiment is so ingeniously designed that it attracts you to play, think and admire.

I recommend multiple visits, since there are so many things to explore. I personally prefer the physics exhibitions.
author: Charles G.

description: WOOHOO! what can i say. from the layout and the new items/attractions? it is completely different from where it was before. I was so excited to come here but parking was so bad, i never did. i came here on saturday and boy did i feel like a kid again. i love museum especially the ones that are hands on. i can't wait to come back on a thursday night for adult night :D
author: Nancy W.

description:
A wonderful place to explore science... exhibits are hands on and interactive, designed for you to touch, feel and explore.  You could spend all day tinkering with one or two activities, or you could walk around and explore a bunch of exhibits.  There are tons of things to do, will keep you (and the kids) occupied for the better part of a day.  Great for kids and families.

The Embarcadero location is fantastic and allows you to soak in incredible views of the bay and bay bridge.  You can enjoy the inside as well as the fabulous views of the outside.  

We have had a membership for the past few years (expired this year) -- and loved the museum in it's older location - right by Chrissy field in the Palace of Fine Arts.  Sticker shock when they moved to their new location. A visit to the exploratorium used to be a low key and affordable day.  The museum in it's new location is more glamorous and high profile and the prices reflect this.  Sticker shock the first time we went back.  More crowded and expensive.  It was over $30 to park our car, and lunch for 3 in he cafe set us back $60.  It's probably not a big deal for tourists, but the parking and food add up quickly if you are a regular visitor (with kids).  


Tips to help with the day:

1. Take Public Transport if possible.....  If you drive and need to park, check out the parking lot across the street at Green and Embarcadero (the website will not direct you here).  The have good prices ($5 per hour), and always find you a spot.  Much more convenient than the lot in Levis Plaza that the exploratorium will suggest to you.

2. Local Discount: Tickets are cheaper if you are a resident of the bay area.  Ask for the local discount.
