3.  Plan to spend at least 3 hours here.  There is a lot to experience.

4. For tourists - keep in mind that this is a very popular destination for kids, and can get crowded.  It can get crowded, so get here early to avoid some of the kid traffic.

5. Wear comfortable footwear!

6.  Visit the tinkering center - the docents always have an interesting project to work on

7. The observation deck is a great place to take a break

8.  You don't need to do everything in one day!  Take time to experience and explore.

9.  The docents are very helpful!  Don't hesitate to ask for assistance.  

10. Lunch/ Food: The cafe is pretty, with a gourmet menu - organic, locally sourced food.   A little pricey, and no kid menu (they have PB sandwiches near the check out counter).  If you are on a budget (or have fussy kids) pack a lunch and eat on the benches outside the museum - the views are amazing.  They have lockers if you need to store your lunch while you explore.  Cafe gets really crowded from 12 - 1 - so eat before or after.  

11.  Take advantage of the location - ferry building has lots of great food stalls, TCHO next door has great chocolate (and chocolate tasting), the embarcadero is a great place to walk.  


Have fun!
author: Sunny C.

description: I've only ever been to the Exploratorium twice, and both times were for corporate events. I 100% recommend for corporate events as an attendee. You can always expect some kind of level of catering and music, however the Exploratorium offers a refreshing spin on a dressy night out. The new location had a great flow and setup for dinner, music, and dancing, and even more space for the fun hands on exhibits that set the Exploratorium apart from other venues.
author: Jennifer C.

description: Great place to get away and see a clear view of the Bay. The Exploratorium is a excellent choice to discover your inner scientific self. A must go see attraction if in the San Francisco area. Parking can be a hassle but well worth it.
author: Lajon T.

description:
A group of friends and I went to the after dark event on Thursday night. The entrance fee is $15 and that's probably all that it's worth. 

The place itself was large and spacious and there was plenty to do even though some of the exhibits were closed. It's different than the academy of science since it's more hands-on and it makes it more of a learning experience. 

There is one restaurant that is opened with a bar. They have limited drinks on their menu, but you can ask them to make things that aren't offered. 

It's good to go once in a while, but I definitely want to check it out when all the exhibits are opened.
author: Jenn L.

description: Be cautious with multiple children - large, open space, easy for them to get away. The Exploratorium is a wonderful museum with every display being interactive and engaging for the children. Of my 3, one tended to take longer on an experience than the next, leading to one child getting away 3 times, but thankfully I found him each time. We came on a rainy day and had a great experience. It is lots of fun, but more labor intensive than some museums in terms of kids attention being drawn in so many distractions (I take my kids to art museums a lot to avoid this at children museums, if you can relate to that statement you know why I mean). Highly recommend especially for older children or small groups
author: Oink A.

description: Coolest science museum around.  Captivates both young and old.  They make a lot of their own exhibits which are custom and Ahhhmazing.   I would love to come back but honestly too expensive for a family.  Very memorable.
author: Natalie E.

description:
The Exploratorium is great for all ages! I remember going on a field trip to the old location as a kid and this one is just as awesome if not better. This was our rainy day activity yesterday and it was a great idea. I admit I had some doubts about whether this place would be fun for 20-somethings since I hadn't been here since I was a kid, but this place ended up being just as cool as when I was 10! All of the exhibits were so cool and educational and the interactive ones were so fun! You could easily spend a whole day here without getting bored. Everything is so interesting! There is also a gorgeous view of the bay and the Bay Bridge since this new location is on the pier. Tickets for SF residents are $20 and regular adult admission is $25 and there's a parking lot across the street for $5/hr. It's also next door to Tcho so you could check that out too if you have time! 

Tip: rent a locker and don't bring any drinks in because you're going to want to have both of your hands available to play around with all the cool exhibits!
author: Stephanie G.

description: Better than the old location at Palace of Fine Arts now on pier15. Newer exhibits. Hands on for kids. Bring hand sanitizer due to the many germy hands on exhibits.
author: Clifford W.

description:
Definitely better for kids under 6. Nothing is really awesome. It's all just little stuff that is educational but disappointing to handle. I was so stressed out having to fight the crowds for 3 hours on every exhibit. 

I would skip it and go do something more relaxing outside.
author: Fareed T.

description:
The world would be a better place if there was more interactive museums--seriously. We learn better hands-on.

For a kid, this is probably the most amazing place ever (especially for a kid with some minute interest in Science). For an adult, it's okay--probably even an insult to your intelligence at times, but the fun for us is in watching our kids.

My only wish is that this place was opened longer. I got here at 3 and even with two hours and haste, we only managed to finish half the exhibit, which is sad considering how much you have to pay to get in (plus, how much you have to pay for parking... yikes). Even sadder considering I live in LA! In summary, get here early. Better yet, be here when it opens because you WILL spend all day here. How badly do you need to visit this place? Very. This is bucket list-worthy.

Things you should know...
- $19 for minors, and $29 for adults; Student ($24) and local resident discounts available
- $3/hr street parking; $5/hr lot parking. I managed to find street parking very quickly on a Sunday afternoon.
- SOME visitors are RUDE. They do not care if you're waiting for an exhibit, they will spend an hour on it if they want and bring all their family and friends to hog it with them. They will also cut you when you're mere centimeters away from an exhibit.
- And yes, you will wait. You will probably wait for 75% of the exhibits, with the 25% being lame exhibits.
- If you're not there at least 3-4 hours before closing, you probably shouldn't go at all because chances are.. you won't finish. Get your money's worth and get there as early as possible.
- And if you hear a bell ring, it means it's time to go.
Sure you can try to stay behind if you want, but they will cut the power to discourage laggers.
author: Anna C.

description: SOOO much fun!!! This is an amazing placed filled with so many awesome interactive exhibits! It is great for all ages and everyone will definitely learn about something new! Great to come with friends or family! Highly recommend!
author: J J.

description:
"Unleash the child in you!"

If you like a little science, a lot of science, this is the place. Hundreds of scientific projects with explanations of how things work. Electricity, physics, static, light, refraction, tact, symmetric and asymmetric divergence, the human body, biology, chemistry, history ... all taught in fun and surprising ways. Must do!
author: Matheus G.

description: Went to the exploratorium last night with some friends. We had fun and enjoyed ourself through out most of the night. We had fun exploring the dome. It is not until the end of the night when we decide to get a drink. We got 3 drinks $12 each for a total of $36. The drink was really water down and I'm a light weight and I didn't even get buzzed from that drink. I got a vodka cranberry and all I can taste is water and a hint of cranberry. The lady who made our drink was being kinda rude and told us we have to tip her since she provided us with service. I believe her exact words are "I make minimum wage..." and "provided you with excellent service and you need to reward me with something called T.I.P.S." I don't think that is right, you don't ask or expect tips from people. I work minimum wage as well and don't make much tips. Also the friends that I was with just graduated and don't have a job or also making minimum. Why should we have to give tips to to someone who gives us rude service? Especially since we're still in college or recently graduated with barely an income to support ourselves. The one night that we all want to go out and splurge and enjoy ourself we had to have our night ruin with this lady giving us a lecture about giving her a tip for 3 water down drinks. I hope management fixes this problem cuz if their employees going to do this to the customers I wouldn't want to go back there again.
author: C N.

description:
The Exploratorium is the best interactive and engaging museum I have visited. There are so many exhibits displaying fun and educational experiences like no other. I was very fortunate to receive free admission to explore whenever from a close friend that works there.  I learned that Exploratorium is so a non-profit organization functioned with the help of donors and research facilities.  I jumped at the opportunity to head to the wonderful relocation on New Years Eve with a couple of friends who visited! 

We were there for two hours and didn't get to finish looking at the plethora of exhibits (since the venue closed earlier on that day).  I hope to come back for the After Dark series that's hosted on selected Thursday nights with unique themes. The last time I went to one, it was a BLAST!  I hope they do a little more advertising with those special events. Anyways, I have nothing to complain about and would love to come back again! :]
author: Sally N.

description:
The new digs are beautiful.  Many of the exhibits are the same, but there's a totally different feel when they're on this side of town.  It's not as crowded as they expected it to be, and they laid off something ridiculous like 70 percent of the staff, including some people who had been with the Exploratorium for years, but it still feels crowded.  I guess it will always feel crowded when you're waiting your turn to turn the dials, spin the hoops, pull the switches, and on and on and on.

The clock near the entrance is really cool.  It probably garners an entire star.  Be sure to be around at the top of an hour, any hour.

The cool wooden play-structure cube/blob is outside, so it's free, but there's a height requirement.  Translation:  Some children are too short to climb the cool wooden play-structure cube/blob.  My little niece thought that was a complete injustice.  After having to help my nephew (her older brother) get down from the cool wooden play-structure cube/blob at least three times, I can understand the height requirement--it's actually slightly dangerous (and that's a good thing)!--but I'm starting to see things from my little niece's point of view now.  Why have a cool wooden play-structure cube/blob when not all kids can climb it?

I also like that winch that lowers and raises the stuff into the bay.  That's straight-up cool.  Oh, and the view is gorgeous.  That's what you're paying so much for.
author: John S.

description: Amazing museum! Thought it would be a day watching my kids play, but I was so wrong. Fascinating activities for kids and adults, with opportunities to learn something if you want to. You can really spend all day there and not even know 6 hours flew by. We did the tactile dome and it was a blast, even if it was an additional charge. Best museum we've visited in SF (read my review of the California Academy of Sciences - in short, it sucked).
author: Rick M.

description: The Exploratorium is fun by day and I have been many times as both an adult and a kid.  On my last trip to SFO, I experienced the Exploratorium at night for adults only.  Drinks, dinner, a great view of the Bay bridge at night; it was really neat. It was kind of like a fun house with liquor though.  The atmosphere is definitely chaotic.  Thursday nights from 6-10, $15 bucks each I think.
author: Gabrielle M.

description: Was here about 4 years ago. Loved it then, and the family loves it now. Kids 6 and 11 loved it  you gotta do the tactile dome. Special tickets on top of what you pay to get in, but this place is one of a kind and worth splurging on. Do it!
author: Jason B.

description:
Seriously, the Exploratorium is as much of a playground for adults as it is for children. One of my favorite places to explore. When a Groupon popped up that offered 50% off their annual membership, I jumped on it and have been there a handful of times since. This new location was so large (or maybe I was so enthralled by everything) that it took me two consecutive trips to see the entirety of the museum.

It's got a majority of the exhibits from the old location (the rainbow wall camera thing, the Tactile Dome, the spinning wheel, the dry ice exhibit, etc.), but there is a whole new arsenal of new exhibits to tickle your fancy and stretch your mind. One of my personal favorites was the slow motion camera. Create your own Pantene commercial! See the way your friends' faces move when you slap them. It's amazing.

There's a brand new (though temporary -- only on display until Spring 2014) exhibit on mental illness and the definition of normal that is heart-wrenching. This is the exhibit that stuck with me the most. It invites you to lay down in what looks like a cage that some mental institutions used to keep their patients isolated and theoretically calm. And the exhibits core is made up of personal belongings of past residents of the Willard Psychiatric Center in New York, found when the institution was closed. It's an exhibit that I would consider to be a little dark, compared to the other exhibits available, but definitely worth checking out.

There's also employees walking around, trying to engage people in more "organic" experiments. I had what looked like someone in an alien suit come up to me and make a series of gestures in front of me. Didn't speak, and I couldn't see their face, but after I mimicked their movements (because what else was I supposed to do?? I was so confused), they clapped and walked away. Not sure what the point was, but it was still a lot of fun and had me giggling really hard.

I wish I had spent more time at the outdoor exhibits they have. I constantly remind myself that I work down the street; I should just go walk around the outside exhibits on my lunch, but the cold recently has kept me away. Maybe when the weather warms up, I'll mosey on over for an intellectual break.
author: Anna W.

description:
This is one of the coolest museums i have been to. Its got a tons of things you can do, and most of them are related to science... so if you like that (and is curious like me)..then this is the place for you. 
Sure there were lots of kids, so it may take a while before you can experience some of the exhibits. But most likely it is because those are the cooler ones, so its worth the wait. I spent a while in there and walked through the whole first floor....but since I only had one full day in SF we were kind of in a hurry to ge somewhere else....but we did spend a longer then expected... because everytime we want to leave the place, something cool pops up....which is like all over the place....(and yah i played with almost everything...thats why we walked through the whole floor)
Once we walked outside...i noticed a big hole next to the ocean...so i walked over and looked down...nothing...so i was really curious of why it was there...i mean it cant be for nothing!! And then i saw the sign....its a hole with two microphones on two ends....that records what went on...and plays back 12 hours later from under....."a message for the future"...WOW...that's just so cool!! (Too bad i didnt snap a photo of it :( )
author: Wendy S.

description: Unbelievably amazing! If you are scientifically inclined or just curious about how things work you will love this place. There are tons of interactive experiments. It's an especially great place to take kids to get them interested in science. But it's great for adults too!
author: David H.

description:
I have been so cautious about new and improved facilities ever since they reopened the California Academy of Sciences. That place was meant for the donors and not the patrons. This place is meant for the people young and old, girls and boys, rich and poor, fish or fowl, fair or foul, so forth and so on.

Well, entering the place I was expecting to be not happy with the pricing, yet if you live in the Bay Area it is not so bad but if your are a tourist you are paying plenty. Screw the tourist anyway I say and let them pay for the place. Remember, folks in Las Vegas pay no income tax because us tourist lose in their casinos. So, this place in as large or larger than the old place, way cleaner and with better lighting. Really a wonderful space put so nicely together by the designers and staff. They seemed to have kept all the old exhibits and added so many new ones. There are also some nice outdoor spaces and views of the bay. and a nice but pricey restaurant. Now, the old place did have the biting swans, by which I am sure must folks don't miss them but I liked my toes bitten by these creatures.

So, this is a place for a great date. A place for the kids. A place to play with daisy, the fish and the rest of the fun things that are here to explore.
author: Rickey B.

description: Excellent place to take the kids. The exhibits are fun and engaging for both kids and adults. Very large space for the kids to run around, but keep your eyes on them so you don't loose them. There are a few dining options at the pier but lots of options a few blocks away around the city. Plan for a few hours to make it through the entire place. Go early when they open so it isn't as busy and wait time for exhibits are short or non existent.
author: M L.

description: They refused to give me a refund after the fire alarm went off and they kicked everyone out. Also, the food is really overpriced in the restaurant. Many of the exhibits are lame / broken.  I know everyone loves this place, but I think it's highly overrated.
author: Jackson W.

description:
It's fun for all ages! If you like museums but are constantly being told to keep your hands off the exhibits, this place is for you. You can literally touch everything in this museum. I've been several times and I always find new things to explore and play with. Most recently, I went into the tactile dome, which is basically as awesome as it is dark. 

Thursday nights at the Exploratorium are cool too if you are young and have a penchant for adventure. The view of the bay is an added perk. If your brain begins overheating from having your mind blown, a walk on the patio is a nice way to cool down. In conclusion, the Exploratorium is awesome and a must see for tourists and locals alike.

Itemized score:
Exhibits: 10
View: 10
Staff: They showed me a card trick so thats cool
Exploring: Lewis and Clark / 10
author: John D.

description:
There is so much to see and  experience over at the Exploratorium. The amount of exhibits they put on the floor is phenomenal. They have galleries dedicated for specific topics such as, east gallery for biology. They also have explainers that make it easier to absorb information, and these explainers hold demos. 
The demos range from magic tricks to cow eye dissections. Personally one of my favorites of the cow eye because it teaches so much about my eye and how it works. Every time I'm at the Exploratorium I always learn something new. Never a dull moment, except I might be having too much fun learning which I never knew was possible. Exploratorium always changes/adds new exhibit so it never gets old.
Definitely must come!!!
author: Wesley G.

description: I try to raise my son by giving him experiences that I would have enjoyed as a child, and this place perfectly captures the type of magic that sparks my son's imagination. No matter what age your child, I feel like there is something here for everyone. My entire family loves this place and we try to go at least once every six months to keep the kids interested in life's fantastic miracles.
author: Kenneth H.

description:
Yeah, I don't think this place is for young kids.  We brought a 4 yr old and 16-month old and we left in under an hour.  If you pay, it is rather expensive, $25 per adult, but 5 and under are free.  Luckily, we got in free through the Discover & Go program available at the library (check your library's website under "Museum Passes").  As far as I know, the libraries of Santa Clara, Milpitas, Palo Alto, and Sacramento currently participate in this program.  

We parked at the Golden Gateway Garage at 250 Clay St for a flat rate of $7 on Saturday.  The walk was not bad -- it is always a good sign when I am not huffing and puffing on a short walk.  The garage is located near the Embarcadero Center, which is $10 after the museum validation.  Otherwise, there are two open parking lots right across the street from the museum, one was a flat rate of $18, and the other was $5/hr for the first 4 hours.

We will definitely bring the kids back in a few years to give it another go.
author: C L.

description: Its so boring after you stay there for like 6 hours. It like I am going in circles. Also Seaglass it so expensive the food is so god damn expensive. The drink just for 1 bottle of soda is like $4 already.
author: Nq V.

description:
Exploratorium was open on New Year's Day, and it seemed like the perfect thing to do. The weather was gorgeous and the kids were ready to do some hands-on activities. We had never been to the old Exploratorium so we didn't have any idea what to expect. 

While overall, we enjoyed many of the concepts and experiments here, it felt chaotic. Maybe that's the point, but we wanted a little more organization to help guide and enrich the experience. We meandered from exhibit to exhibit for several hours but after awhile, everything felt kind of the same: spinning things, lights, and mirrors. I actually got a throbbing headache after an entire day here, even though we stepped out to the Ferry Terminal for lunch, a visceral break, and a bit of fresh air. 

Love the location though, central and convenient, on the beautiful waterfront. The Animation Studio near the Tinkering Studio was very cool, and the giant toothpick structure exhibit was amazing. 

Would highly recommend hand sanitizer, was very surprised they didn't have any  available there.
author: H D.

description: Expensive parking and the admission tickets are crazy expensive. The place is disgusting and dirty and full of greasy smelly children. We paid so much money for admission and they dont even clean the exhibits or have hand sanitizer anywhere? Wow
author: M A.

description: If you're visiting from out of town, you might have to pay the full price, which is expensive. But if you're local, check out the free Exploratorium pass from the library. It gives you two adult and four kid passes for free!
author: Ashley E.

description: A terrific full-day playground for any age/sex/race/nationality. If you can't find anything fun, interesting or educational - well, you're probably already dead.
author: Tim T.

description:
What's better than learning while having fun? Well, maybe having fun and not even realize that you are learning.  The geniuses at this science center have come up with a gazillion ways to get kids attention with the wonders of science. I walked through the center thinking, "I wonder how many science standards this place hits?" the answer? ALL OF THEM.  The spectrum of concepts one can witness here is truly endless.  

You can find helpful and friendly workers roaming the center answering questions and helping guests with the exhibits.  Coolest summer job ever.  There's a spot where the brains behind the program are working to bring you a new exhibit.  I thought it was pretty cool for the designers to see the impact of their work by locating their workspace out on the floor (sectioned off of course, safety first people).

But the best part of this place is sparking the interest of your child through science.  There's nothing more valuable than a curious kid who gets excited about discovering new things.  Nothing.
author: Denalee C.

description:
This place is a curious child's paradise, but it can be enjoyed by all ages. So many things to touch, play with, tinker around with, explore, learn, everything. It was actually a little overwhelming. There was something to do or learn every two feet and they were randomly scattered all over the whole museum.
I loved it, though, but I'm kind of a closet-science geek, even if I wasn't particularly good at it in school. Even if science isn't your thing, you'll most likely find at least a few exhibits that will blow your mind or leave you wondering and wanting to know more. The Exploratorium brings out the curiosity in all of us.
Fair warning: go on a weekday morning or afternoon (it's even advised by the museum website) and avoid weekends if you can, unless you don't mind being surrounded by hundreds of kids and toddlers and their parents. Me and my friend went on a free admission day and it was packed with little ones. Still enjoyable, but I imagine your experience would be better if you had more standing/walking room.
Have fun, to anyone that decides to go!
author: Hai H.

description:
I'm writing this review as a tourist who ended up at the Exploratorium because of a City Pass, so I can't attest to the retail price or value of a visit.  

I'm also writing this review as a science geek mother of three young children (4, 6, and 7.)

This place is amazing!  I really wish we had budgeted more time.  The place is huge!  There is so much to see and do.  The exhibits are presented in ways that really engage children and challenge adults too.  

Yes,  there are kids everywhere,  be prepared to deal with that.  (Although I do think I saw something about adults only from 6-10, but I'm not sure. If it's true it sounds like an excellent idea. Some kids really are hoggy brats.) 

While many museums offer a few interactive exhibits,  many times,  my kids just fight over who "pushes the button" and never even get the point of the lesson.  At the Exploratorium,  every exhibit is interactive and actually engaging.  They get to see science in everyday applications,  and Momma Nerd just loves that.
author: Juli D.

description:
Well this trip started off rough as Tom Tom sent me to the old location.

I'm glad they had a sign that directed me over to pier 15.

This trip I came with my son's 5th grade class.

I love seeing kids get to have fun with science and not have a phone, iPad, etc glued to their hands.

I really enjoyed getting them to try different things while having a blast and learning something at the same time.

The new location is really nice, but I really liked the old location. Maybe I'm just getting old and like my memories at the previous location.

If you want your kids to unplug and have some hands on experience this is a great place to go. Even if you don't have kids most adults seem to have as much fun as the kids.
author: Weston P.

description:
I love this place.  Actually, my nieces and nephews love this place -- they are between the ages of 7 and 11.  

We had allotted four (4) hours to roam around this lovely space and ended up rushing through most of the exhibits because there are simply way to much exhibits to explore -- I'd say allow a full day with frequent breaks in between.  

I was babysitting so I was watching the kids from five to six yards apart from each kids, which allowed them to explore on their own -- a very exhausting but fun duty.   My nieces and nephews were amazed and fully engaged by 90 percent of the exhibits they came across.

I went to the old space over 20 years ago and got bored after an hour.  I think I would be bored if I came to the new space with adults.  But if I had came when I was in my later years of elementary school, say between grades 3rd through 5th, I'd be engaged with the exhibits and be wowed by them.

I saw many parents with kids who seem like they were under 6 years old and those kids didn't seem too engaged except everyone found the toilet drinking water interesting.  

This is a great museum and I hope it will remain well funded and kept open and continue to provide a dynamic experience for school kids from the entire Bay Area -- great place to spend a day there as a science field trip.
author: Peace L.

description:
ABSOLUTELY AMAZING! 
Theeee best place ever! We didn't even know what to touch and play with when we entered. I had been wanting to bring my son here for a little while since he loves science so much. It was soooo much and the weather was perfect. They should open up a place like this here in Los Angeles. Each experiment had very detailed information about how to do the experiment. It was great, great great!
author: Rosy L.

description:
Awesome new location on the pier, but you'll have to pay for parking (unlike the old location)

The new place is much bigger than the old one. And the added new exhibits - I really like the mirror exhibit.

I joined membership and their customer service is sad as the guy couldn't spell my name from my id.  Then a lady near the entrance had to check IDs for both people on the card even though we are together.  Duh!

Still, this place is highly recommended.
author: Troy M.

description: We took our 3 kids ages 9, 11 and 12 expecting a few hours of entertainment.  Our older two enjoyed themselves, but were ready to move on after a few hours.  Our 9 year old, however, could have stayed all day.  He wanted to experience each and every experiment/exhibit.  It is a great value!
author: Sara W.

description:
About an hour in I realized I was going to have to shower immediately after the visit. And to wash hands thoroughly. And that I didn't bring hand sanitizer... the over stimulation helped me forget that this is The Capitol of The Non-Creepy Touchy-Feely. 

I've been to most of the major science / interactive tech "museums" in America, and this is the one to seek out. If I were five or nine, it would make me wonder how the universe is made, and thrilled that I get a hand's on experience to find just out how. Still at 31 there's plenty to enjoy without feeling like an out of place adult in a child's playpen (see: that dad who demands he gets in the bounce house at the party). 

If there's any sort of membership, it's worth it -- especially the outdoor patio area as it's an open space that's safe for kids to play in which would be a really good ol' fashioned place for a play date with kids without sacrificing integrity of what you're surrounded by (I'm looking at you, you strange parents who meet at McDonald's). 

I'd bring my child here annually as there's enough to go over & over to see them grow into the exploration of this place: from age three of thinking it's funny to create a tornado while running around it to age six when they begin to ask how and to age nine when they look to apply that knowledge into their own idea. Oh, and into age 31 when they consider making it an instragram video. But oph, no instagramming kids!
author: Jon A.

description:
As a Bay Area native, I've been visiting the exploratorium since the ripe age of 10. Every visit is a different experience, and you appreciate the exhibits in different ways every time. 

It's a place where we can all learn something new about what seem to be benign, every day occurrences. The Exploratorium is like a microscope with which we can all gain new perspective and appreciation for things like light, bubbles, film, optical illusions, and the physics of sound. My favorite exhibit is the Shadow Box, where a flash of light every 30 seconds or so projects your shadow onto a glow-in-the dark wall. 

This is a great venue (they used to be located near the Palace of Fine Arts) that is closer to public transportation and enjoyable for its proximity to the water. 

Make sure to check out parking options on their website (we paid $26 for almost 5 hours because we didn't plan ahead) and also be sure to note their discounts for students, teachers and seniors. Also, bring your lunch, and take breaks often, this requires a lot of walking around the venue. In any case, you're bound to have a great time!!
author: Angelica D.

description:
PI day! Free admission at the Exploratorium.  And because of that, the line was long.

You can park close by for $5/hr. There's other parking lots around for $35 max for day parking. 

I came here with my daughter's first grade class on a field trip. So much to do, see and explore. This surely is a rich fun way to learn. I must say tho that it's more age appropriate from children ages 10 and above. Children read instructions for the activities and theories behind it. 

Great location by the embarcadero!
author: Pam S.

description:
Went with a party of 3 (1 toddler)
*This is a hands-on museum for all ages.
*We went on a Saturday afternoon

*Place is great for the kids and of all ages.  There are lots of different activities and they are educational also.
*If you spend an entire day from morning till night you may be able to finish and go through the museum.
*The museum is clean
*The restaurant is a bit pricey ($9.95 for a quesdilla?!)
*Not much for variety of food and drinks
*It's pleasant outside and there's access to outside on the 2nd floor for great views
*You can get a stamp to get readmitted if you want to go outside and walk down the street for food or depending on time of day go to the farmers market
*Parking is across the street (public..as cheap as $10...that's SF for you)
*There is an outside playground for kids to climb.
*It's next to the body of water so nice to eat outside and just relax.
author: John B.

description: I LOVE the exploratorium. Makes me feel like a kid. I was a member at the previous one and finally got a chance to try the new location. Great space right by the water with the familiar exhibits and some new ones. Good option if you want to do a team building event...they offer a scavenger hunt which was a blast.
author: Sunil R.

description: My daughter wanted to visit all the exhibits. This place takes a full day to visit all the exhibits. My husband and I felt like kids. We loved all the hands on exhibits.
author: Michellea D.

description:
My husband and I really enjoyed our visit here, without kids! We thought each exhibit was interesting and the entire place is well put together. Anyone who is a visually person- no matter their age- should have a fun little adventure here! 

We sped through the place pretty quickly- mostly because we were in a rush to grab lunch. But the entire staff we encountered with were sweet. They made small talk and seemed sincere. We will for sure come back in the future with kids of our own. Awesome place for curious minds!
author: Tasha T.

description: Took the family here on a recent family trip.   Everyone had a great time.  I was surprised how much time we were all entertained considering that it's not as large as it would appear.   There are 6 years between my kids, so typically an outing is more appealing to one and the other is board, but this kept us all entertained for several hours.
author: T F.

description:
There is nowhere else quite like the Explo. 
I brought my kids to the original location, 
And now I'm here at Pier 15 with my grandkids. Energy, creativity, education all disguised as a huge colorful noisy indoor playground.
author: Gary F.

description:
Visited The Exploratorium in its brand new location on The Pier during my long Thanksgiving weekend and was extremely impressed. It was my first visit to the wildly inventive science museum since I was a kid, and the same sense of delight and wonder I used to feel while interacting with the tactile exhibits returned to me with a Proustian wallop. 

The Distorted Room, "invisible spring," the face-masher, and the many exhibits using lasers still show kids that science can be extremely and wickedly cool. I didn't grab tickets to experience The Tactile Dome, but got to see almost everything else. I even stuck around for one of their film programs, where they played a selection of short films to a delighted group... direct animation, experimental, and documentary shorts that the little kids gathered with their parents oohed and awwed at. Very, very cool.

The new location is huge, extending further back than you initially think upon entry (another distorted room effect?) and it's right on the water. A really beautiful upgrade to a place that was already wonderful, fun, and sciencey perfection.
author: Seth G.

description:
one of the best museums in the entire city, for kids of all ages, especially geeks and nerds, and science lovers. It is like a Hall of Science...an interactive musuem where you can learn about shadows, bubbles, air, wind, light, oceans, sand, the marine, fog, rain, the sun, and everything in between. This is a new museum so it's great because with science museums, things can get dated fast. The exhibits are beautiful and educational. The food at the cafe is delish too. I love the honeycomb with cheese and fruit and nuts. They also have sushi there and rotisserie chicken. 

This place also has night events for adults where you can learn about the science of making cocktails and do silly things as adults without having parents give you the evil eye for pushing their 2 yr old to play with shadow walls! Think it's on Thursday nights. Great thing is that afterwards, there are so many other places to check out along the Embarcadero or in North Beach!
author: Emm C.

description: Went here today I wish I would have read some of the yelp reviews before I planned my visit... I went with my little brother and for both of us paid $44 (expensive!) When we went in I noticed how packed it was inside. All the kids were all over the little experiments they have there and it was a pain to get my brother a chance to do something because of the kids bum rushing and not taking turns. I would never come back here with any kids maybe by myself after dark and that's it. I'm from san Diego and our museums in balboa park are nothing like this with kids. You have been warned!!!!!!! the price and quality don't add up
author: Jose G.

description:
Go to the gift store and ask for Jamin.

I wondered into the Exploratorium Gift Store, the goal find gifts  for my 2 nephews that will make me the coolest aunt ever.   Jamin to the rescue, I gave him the ages of the boys and he made several fun recommendations, book, toys, games etc... he was very knowledgeable, excited and made some great recommendations.  Big thanks to Jamin.
author: Dionne M.

description: We were looking for an indoor spot for kids because it was a rainy day. I think all the other families in the Bay had the same idea. Tip: Don't go on a rainy day if you don't like crowds. The exhibits were fantastic. However, it was a bit too pricey. The California Science Academy is superior and more affordable.
author: A P.

description:
The new Exploratorium seems to have a lot of what the old one did...plus a whole bunch more.  Super crowded with the elementary school set and younger in the summer.  Skip the big ticket buying line by pre-purchasing your tix online.  As usual, my middle schooler had fun pressing buttons, making things work and generally exploring.  Even pausing to hear from an "Explainer" about the inner workings of speakers...but skipping the cow eyeball dissection.  The rather large and depressing display of old suitcases and their contents found in a mental health facility just seems out of place.  IMO they could find something (or a lot of things) more sciency and fun for kids than that.  

Parking would be much more of a PITA than at the Palace of Fine Arts location, but the new Exploratorium is easily BARTable.  About a 10-15 minute walk from the Embarcadero Station, with the opportunity to explore the Ferry Building on the way to or from.  Also just two piers from the America's Cup display.  If you have any more walking in you after the Exploratorium, it's worth it to check that out, even if you just sit on a bench and marvel at Larry Ellison's 4 story yacht for a few minutes.  

The restaurant at the Exporatorium requires you to officially leave the museum and get your hand stamped to return.  I do like the trend of improved food options a la the Academy of Sciences.  Kid opted for the sushi bar, but didn't get much at $8 for two pieces of nigiri.  I went for the filling and tasty pork tacos and topped off the kiddo with tempura green beans.  Sushi bar line short.  Taco line long and slow.
author: Linda M.

description:
We came here as part of the City Pass and were pleasantly surprised.   The exhibits were educational as well as fun / interesting.   They were good for both adults and kids alike.  

btw.. bring a large bottle of hand sanitizer and wipes...  trust me, it will come in handy!
author: L L.

description:
Excellent for the big kid inside me and all the kids.  

Very interesting and kept me captivated for well over two hours.  Find the gallery on the roof and the 'shadow' view of the bridge was amazing.

Great place to visit if you are in San Fran.
author: John H.

description:
I have so many mixed emotions when writing this review. Is it true the new location is a lot bigger, cleaner, and more hip? Sure...but man..the old location was so nostalgic to me. Those of you who were 80's babies and older remember going to the old exploratorium and spending time outside at the beautiful landscape watching swans fly around and what not. Remembering their crappy cafeteria food and what not, but you didn't care because it was a heck a lot better than what mommy packed for lunch.

Those were the days! Sweet ol pre-puberty, hickies-infected, pokemon cards collecting, Tommy Hilfiger wearing days...

But I'm not going to knock the Exploratorium's hustle. Their lease was up and the show as they say it, must go on and Pier 15 was a great choice! The beautiful view of the water, the liveliness of the Embarcadero, and the polished architecture makes for a great step forward. 

The premise is still there. It's a place for you to explore and let science take you by the hand. I can spend the whole day there. Like literally. All of the old exhibits that i remembered were brought over from the old location and a lot more additions were...well.. added. I'm not going to list you my favorites...because really you don't want to hear me geek out. So I will leave you with some tips..

Tip 1: Eat breakfast the day you are going. Or you know...you should eat breakfast everyday.

Tip 2: Use public transportation. the Embarcadero Bart stop is only half a mile away and on weekends...there is a street market for you to squander around as you make your way there. You are not going to find parking, trust me. 

Tip 3: With Tip 2 being said, wear comfortable shoes! You are going to be on your feet most of the time, so treat your feet right. Ladies, don't wear heels or do..up to you. 

Tip 4: Don't rush, pace yourself. There's always next time. Spend time at each exhibit. Take something away from it. Learn something. That's what makes this place so magical. 

Unofficial Tip 5: If you are like me...and must have Blue Bottle coffee on the way to Pier 15, don't go to the ones at the ferry station. There is a location closer to the Exploratorium with about 95% less of the crowd. You are certainly welcome! 

Unofficial Tip 6: There's really no good/cheap places to eat around here, don't be afraid to hop on Bart or Metro to go to a different neighborhood to enjoy something scrumptious. 

That's it my breezies and brohans go out there and explore gosh darn it! 

Like Bill Nye said, "Science is the key to our future!"
author: Tung T.

description: Today was a good afternoon spent with Frankie and Jason. We enjoyed exploring the auditorium for free. We waited in a long line but it didn't take that long to get inside. It took about 30 minutes to get inside the auditorium. Don't ever go on the day it's free to many people take advantage of this day and it's crowed.
author: Joyce R.

description:
Excellent place for people of every age but especially kids to have fun and learn at the same time. You can easily spend a day there and you will not have discovered everything. So if you live in the area get a membership and come again!

Even on Black Friday when there were a lot of visitors it didn't seem so crowded once you got away from the entrance area.
author: Günter G.

description: The Exploratorium is one of the best children's imagination/science/exploring museums that I've ever been to. On a recent week-long visit to San Francisco, we ended up investing in a family membership so that we could go twice (we're planning another visit this summer). This place is huge and covers all aspects of the scientific world... biology, chemistry, physics, anatomy... By the end of our second visit (and several hours there), we realized there was an ENTIRE WING we still hadn't seen. Our family can't wait to go back and explore some more.
author: Deborah K.

description: There are a lot of interactive exhibits that are fun for kids and adults. The exterior and it's surroundings are as popular as the events going on indoors. A great place for a tourists and locals alike.
author: Christopher S.

description: The Exploratorium is one the best places to take kids and adults to experience technology and the different wonders of the world. For us adults it makes you feel like a kid to explore and find the joys of learning again.
author: Paul D.

description:
I will update this review once I've had a chance to go again on a different day but this review is specifically for the first Thursday After Dark experience.

First off, they need to NOT overbook this. 

There were well over a thousand people there. I could hardly walk down the center of the floor, it was literally shoulder-to-shoulder. Mind you, this was just for walking. Unfortunately there was someone on all the exhibits, so you had to also wait in line to even look at anything. They had 3 bars. We had to wait in line for a half an hour just to get ONE drink. They, of course, were insanely over priced for a tiny drink which was mostly ice. 

Lastly, on the first Thursdays they have live entertainment. They had 2 showing times. The theater that they did this in was completely filled up well over a half an hour before show time. They don't even have room for a 10th of the people who bought tickets to this thing. Absolutely ridiculous. Oh! But they told us we could listen outside through some speakers they had piping. Really? I could just listen to it on YouTube and stay warm. 

The one plus, which actually still has a con, is that the food in the restaurant was pretty tasty. They had a huge selection, oysters, sushi, ribs, tacos, dessert bar, plus a ton more. I was super happy about the quality of food. But, again, it was not worth $80 for 2 people.

Moral of the story, you need the full 4 hours this event runs just to wait in line for everything. I will not be coming back to the first Thursday event. It was such a waste of time and money. More than one person was asking for a refund from the staff as they had felt exactly as I do.
author: Annette D.

description:
Lets just preface this review by saying that this is for the second After Dark experience: the Zoe Keating show last night.

THE BOOKING OF THIS VENUE WAS ATROCIOUS. First off, there were two shows: one at 7PM and another at 9:30PM. When we first got to the Exploratorium at 6:50PM, we were horrified by the hundreds to thousands of people lined up to see the first show. 

Then, we were horrified even more to find that this line that extended into the first floor restaurant was the BACK of the line. The FRONT of the line was at the top on the second floor! And! these people got pushed back because the observation bay gallery, which the show was being held, was already packed and could only hold 150 people. These people who got pushed back started forming the new line for the second show at 7:00PM.  WHAT THE F@#$!!!. You charge the regular admission price and intentionally overbook the place for a very well-known performer who is a local. And because customers who cant see the first or second show are shut out, they're forced to get their money's worth by seeing the exhibits that weren't even  the planned attraction.

If we wanted to spend $15 per person to see the exhibits, then we would've....on a non-After Dark night.

 It was a ruined night.

After Dark is a scam

F____ this place
author: Christopher F.

description: My experience at the Exploratorium was extremely amazing - it gets you "2nd grade field trip"'excited. I got exhausted running around the place, pressing random buttons and testing out all the cool gadgets. I'm from SoCal so the closest thing we have to this is the Discovery science center by Main Place Mall and I used to think that was cool... But then I went to the exploratorium! Haha. Definitely a place you need to check out if you're around the area and have a couple hours to spare..
author: Nicole J.

description:
I must admit, I miss the free and easy parking at the old Exploratorium site. I know that's a petty complaint to some, but I have two kids under the age of four and I'm usually hauling a camper full of conveniences with me wherever we go. It's not for me as much as it is for the general public. Trust me, you don't want to see me without a diaper bag in an emergency. 

Although the Exploratorium was the aim of this review, the parking was so difficult and expensive, it has become the focus of everything I remember from my first visit to Pier 15.  And if you've ever tried to travel anywhere longer than a mile with kids, you understand the trouble with taking Muni anywhere in the city for the following reasons:

1) Stuff. Tons of stuff. Stuff for diaper blow outs. Stuff for soaked clothing caused by mysterious pools of water every child seems to easily find. Edible stuff for stuffing into hungry faces. Stuff for carrying the stuff.  Basically, all the stuff that doesn't fit neatly into a full Muni bus or train. 

2) People hate you on Muni. Yes, you with the adorable kids that do nothing wrong. All they need to do is take up space and breathe the same air as the passengers on Muni. They're deemed annoying without a fair trial. Anyone under the height of three feet is considered a possible threat to a peaceful transit ride in Muni world. Peter Dinklage barely sizes out of that category, and people LOVE Game of Thrones. 

3) It's gross. Muni is suffering from budget deficits, obviously, because they used to hose the busses out once in a while. Now, you're lucky if you get a bus that doesn't smell like a urinal. Your curious kid will be touching unknown ooze and then licking their fingers to see if it tastes like strawberry jam. Basically, it's the beginning of a terrifying, big budget movie about infectious monkeys. And by monkeys, I mean your kids. 

4) Getting children on and off a bus is not unlike wrestling crocodiles in a swamp full of Crisco while handcuffed to a chimpanzee in a roid rage. 

Other than the parking, it was a fun visit, albeit really confusing. We tried reading the signs but felt constantly lost. Larger signs or arrows on the floor might help people find their destinations. Trying to exit took ten minutes. We simply couldn't find the door easily because the signage was very hard to follow. And no, I'm not THAT sleep deprived and yes, I do have a college degree.

It's worth mentioning the food has vastly improved, but the high prices reflect the quality. One sushi roll was $8.00.  Delicious, but feeding two kids and two adults will set you back at least $40. I spent $53 because of drinks and side dishes. Ouch. 

It's their first week, and I have faith they will make their adjustments and be running smoothly in a few months. But at $19 for a ticket (resident prices) this definitely won't be our weekly destination. I have the distinct impression residents are not their target, however. In other words, tourists will love it.

P.S.  Dear Exploratorium,

Because I'm Korean and am required to taste test every non-Korean restaurant that serves it, I tried the "kimchee" in your food court.  Stop it.  Just stop.

Hugs,
Kristina
author: Kristina R.

description:
I LOVED the Exploratorium. I had no plans to visit but came across it while walking down the Embarcadero. I was a bit hesitant at first, but the ticket lady assured me that many adults go in by themselves and that I'd have a great time.

And a great time I had! This place is a science nerd's dream. It felt like there were endless exhibits and every single thing was interactive. I was able to do a lot in 2 hours, but I wish I could have spent days exploring.

The ticket price for adults was $25 which I thought was fine given the experience, but if I was just going to entertain children I'd probably be annoyed at the price. I went in the morning during the week and it was fairly packed with kids -- I can't even imagine what it's like during the weekend.

I'd definitely suggest going during the week, getting there early, and planning to spend a whole day!
author: Julie B.

description:
Came to the exploritorium and suddenly the inner science kid inside of me went crazy!  Literally, each gallery goes from various topics in physics ranging from light to the electricity to motion and more.  I loved how each exhibit was hands on and really explained the phenomenon in a simple way for everyone to enjoy.  Best of all, it suitable for both kids and adults.  The power of sciences never ceases to amaze me.

The exploritorium is right along the embarcadero so you can drive there (only $5 parking) or easily walk 5-10 minutes from the BART station.  The staff is extremely friendly and there are many tutorials or demonstrations happening for everyone to see.  Compared to other museums or science exhibits, I'd say the exploratorium is definitely one of the best as it has something for everyone and has a multitude of stations to keep everyone interested and engaged.  Best of all, you can enjoy the views of the bay.

**Pro tip: Keep an eye out for the FREE days that happen about 5 times a year.  I was lucky in that I fortuitously visited here on National Engineering Day (Yup, this day does exists) and was able to get in free (they did ask for a donation, but I was happy to donate).
author: Robert T.

description:
The new location is awesome.  Other people have some terrific reviews so I'll just add that you want to make sure that you walk around the outside of the building (which is free and open to the public) because there are at least 4-5 other hands on exhibits.  I really love the model of the Bay Bridge that sits in front the real Bay Bridge.  There is also an exhibit where you crank plastic rings down into the bay to see how murky the water is that day. (P.S. It's murky).

The gift shop is a great place to get unique, off beat gifts for adults and kids.  BEST part is that the shop is dog friendly!
author: Kim W.

description:
The Exploratorium is huge, and is of course a San Francisco icon. It is in a very beautiful part of the City with great locations outside in the nearby park to eat lunch by a lake with plentiful turtles.

The exhibits themselves are interesting but a bit old, and pretty basic, and you will find that they don't change them out as regularly as other science museums. All said and done, a great location for young kids, and it also has evening social nights at the museum which are great for the older crowd.
author: Spencer G.

description:
The exploratorium is awesome!! So much to do and learn!  We arrived early and with no little kids.  But there were so many kids around, so many!  It was fun watching the kids, but it was very busy.  About after lunch all the kids left and we got to play/learn all the different exhibits.  
The cafeteria wasn't that great.  I think they try to cook dishes that are really healthy or interesting.  For example, there was pulled pork on a cornmeal pancake, kale with pureed white bean sauce on pizza, i think a lamb sandwich.  They also had some more normal foods like sushi, margherita pizza, soup, salads.  Not sure if the kids like this food or not, but I would rate it as "ok."  
The guides were not that helpful.  We watched one of the demonstrations and they had no luck turning a cup, magnet, and wire into a speaker.   

So I would dock half a star for the cafe and a whole star for the guides, but in the end the exploratorium has so many wonderful exhibits it totally makes up for the things it lacks.  
Also, it has a pretty cool location on the pier.
author: Jenni C.

description: Love, love LOVE this place. Brought the family here and my children truly enjoyed themselves.  There is so much to learn.  The interactive stations made the experience so much better. Their restaurant had vegetarian options, which was a major plus. I highly recommend and will return soon.
author: Dee M.

description:
This place is phenomenal exciting the little kid in everyone! 

There are quarterly free days. Now, being a budget gal, saving 60 bucks makes me scream YES!  

We took the BART and I recommend that as parking looks to be a challenge and expensive.

There is so much to do and see! It's EXCELLENT! As you can imagine, it was quite full on a free day and the amount of children can be a challenge.  Thankfully, every Thursday from 6-10 is for adults only.

We had so much fun, I gifted a membership to my Beloved.

Make sure you have your walking shoes on, snacks, and  get ready to experience wonder and amazement.
author: Artemis X.

description:
Oh come on. What's not to love about the Exploratorium? I got to be a nerdy kid again!

My other half and I were engineers within minutes by connecting those light bulb + motor circuits. No additional schooling needed for us science nerds. Then again, we did take physics for engineers..

Well, I suppose you can say that we were in our niche. Made me miss being in school.

Anyways, one thing I miss about the previous location was the beautiful building and pond and scenic landscape. How do we take those pictures now?

$25 adult general admission
$20 adult general admission - bay area resident
$19 students
$15 students - bay area resident

Parked at the Levi Plaza Garage. $10 for up to 4 hours with validation from the Exploratorium and it was only a 5-10 minute walk. You can go check out my review for the garage.

PS Bring hand sanitizer. You never know what people touch before touching the exhibits! LOL
author: Bonnie L.

description:
On a day-trip to SF we decided to hit up the Exploratorium. I had my doubts because I'd always remembered it as a place for little kids (too many elementary school field trips here!) & wasn't sure as an adult I'd find it interesting. To make matters worse, we had spent too much time shopping in the Ferry Market Plaza building close by and  ended up getting there at 4pm, only to find out that the museum was to close in an hour!

We decided to do it anyway (they recommend at least 2-3 hours normally), and ran through the exhibits. This museum was so fun!!  Everything in this museum is hands-on and there are so many photo ops. As a group of 4 ladies  we loved this!!

Next time will have to try the Tactile experience.
author: Grace C.

description:
Saturday on Memorial day weekend is NOT the best time to visit. It wasn't the kids that bothered me so much, it was several of the other parents. It seems like some people think that their kid is the only one in the whole building. Of course a kid is going to want to keep playing when they find something cool. I moved my daughter along quickly so other kids (or adults) could get their turn without waiting too long. Unfortunately, very few parents showed the same courtesy and just let their kids camp out at some of the exhibits. A couple of them even barged their childREN in front of other people who were clearly waiting for their chILD to have a turn. It was an exercise in patience, and sadly, a validation of some negative cultural stereotypes.

The exhibits were great. My daughter had a fantastic time and learned a lot. It's nice having visual aids to help explain some of the important lessons I've been trying to drive into my six year old's skull, like why the cup always goes in the cup holder and never on the seat of the car while we're driving.
author: Paul L.

description: Amazingly awesome place before their move! Must be even better now!! Too bad they are closed on the ONE day I have off!!! :( wish they were open on Mondays. Tomorrow will be the second time I've not gotten to show off it's awesomeness to my sweetie!
author: Kat A.

description:
I'll mention the cons to get them out of the way: expensive and long lines. 

This museum is amazing and totally perfect for locals and tourists. Easily the most interesting science museum/discovery center/kids museum I have ever seen. Totally worth the price and the wait (note: local CC county residents get a discount and you can buy tix online and print out to save time). Also- we went right when they opened on a Tuesday at 10 and had virtually no wait and the entire museum to ourselves. Cool exhibits for both younger and older kids (and adults obv) and the docents were super helpful in showing us the best exhibits for our age group (18 months and 2.5). Would totally recommend!
author: Anna L.

description:
Twenty-five of us went on free museum day and it was a lot better than I'd expected in terms of long lines. 

There was so much to explore that I'd only wish that I wasn't one of the adults and had to keep an eye out for the kids!

When I go back next time though, I will be bringing hand sanitizer...just so I can explore with less worries!
author: Sylvia L.

description:
I had an amazing time on thursday night!
It's definitely an experience and I had sooooo much fun! 
Come with your friends, parents, kid, whoever, you will definitely enjoy it!
author: Carole P.

description:
One of my favorite spots in SF.  I can never get bored n i am always stuck in quiet meter and sand spinning tables. 

Above sentence is true for my 4yr old and also me (35yrs) !!! 

I have been fan from first time i have been there. Probably 8yrs ago. New location is bigger n better. Good food n amazing views. Nice indoor outdoor spaces to hang out.
author: chess t.

description:
Note to out-of-towners - if you're taking a taxi here from your hotel, make sure your taxi driver knows that you want to go to the Exploratorium at Pier 15.  Otherwise, you might end up clear across town like I did to the old location of the Exploratorium, and you might have to walk a mile or so before being able to hail a taxi.  And hopefully, you won't be like me - wearing heels, and you won't be on your way to the Exploratorium for a special event being hosted by your company (and find yourself more than 30 minutes late and $20 in the hole).

So, while it wasn't the best start, I eventually made my way to the correct Exploratorium at Pier 15, and despite the challenge in getting there, it was lots of fun.

Our organization held a private event here after hours and we had the whole place to ourselves.  I was staffing the event so didn't get much time to explore, but what I did see was enough for me to want to come back, definitely with my kids, and definitely on my own.

Lots of innovative and interesting exhibits, from space to the human body to geometry to music.  Several hands-on exhibits and activities and it's all educational.  The nerd in me was loving it, and judging by the success of our event, so were all my colleagues and our group.  We had open bar and a host of cold/hot appetizers and finger foods, and music playing throughout.  It was a great time, and there's just so much here to...explore.

Back home in the Chi, I/my fam are members of many of our own museums and children's museums, and Exploratorium rates right up to my faves at home.

...oh, and seems I wasn't the only one who ran into taxi troubles on my way to the Exploratorium.  I heard from a few others that they'd been dropped off in the wrong spot as well (which secretly made me feel better since I should have been paying more attention on the way over in the first place!).
author: Irene Z.

description: Love the new place can't wait to check out the after dark activities.
author: Eric C.

description:
This is for a review of their regular Thursday 6-10pm 18+ evening hours (not a "First Thursday") . I would recommend this for any adults who want to see the exhibits without the long lines/crowds.

I went with my coworkers for a light bite/cocktails and to play with the exhibits. This last Thrs was completely quiet...in fact, that would be my one recommendation to the staff: play some music to liven up the atmosphere! 

Maybe their "First Thursdays" are different based on the reviews/photos, but we went on a regular Thursday at 6pm.  There were a few organized meet-ups happening (folks walking around with nametags) but there were no lines at any exhibits.

In case you are considering this for a group event: in addition to the entry fees, we spent about $250 on food and drinks (for 6) - cocktails are about $9 and beer is $5 at the Seaglass Restaurant or you can get a beer/wine for $5 (cash only) in the exhibit area. You can even take your cocktails in a "to go" cup and walk around with them, which adds to the fun.
author: M J.

description:
My boyfriend and I had a NorCal trip and went to SanFran with a CityPass (which is totally worth it if you are exploring). We went to the Exploratorium on Sunday since they closed Monday and arrived an hour before closing.

What a shame! We thought it wasn't going to much, just a regular museum. Boy was I wrong! We were like kids all over again in there! If you plan a trip here, you'll need a couple hours to enjoy every exhibit. Too bad we didn't get that chance.

Whenever we return to the Bay area, will definitely visit again and bring others along!
author: Anna P.

description: Skeptical about the new location at first, but there's definitely more room with more exhibitions. Love the outside seats at the restaurant overlooking the bay. Easy parking. Fun and interactive for my toddler.
author: Jennifer V.

description:
The new location on Pier 15 is a lot nicer than the old location at the Palace of Fine Arts. There is a great view of the Bay Bridge light show and a partially visible view of the financial district from the upstairs outdoor balcony. 

 The night time ambiance is more like a kid themed night club. It has many attractions for children, while offering alcohol to people of age (at a pretty high price). 

There are most of the old exhibits are there. There are also new exhibits and activities, including "bacteria art" and a drawing pendulum. It's still fun even after 10 years. Try going on a day when you can play with all the exhibits!
author: Michael T.

description:
One of my favorite places in SF.  I've been to the old location near the Palace of Fine Arts years back so I was so excited to visit the new location.

Kinda pricey for tickets but it's worth it.  Everything is so awesome... and I always feel like a kid again :)  This is a great place to take your kids... very informative and fun at the same time.
author: Criselle O.

description: We were pretty disappointed by this museum on our trip.  It is so crowded and quite expensive.  Two of the things we wanted to do we couldn't - the painting/drawing thing and the touch cave thing.  We did get to see a cow eyeball dissection.  We liked the toilet water fountains and the telephone/safe activity the best.  Would not go back on future trips to SF.
author: Jasmine C.

description: Today, 3-14, is "Pi Day" & a FREE day at the Exploratorium on Pier 15 in SF! Where would our sciences and fellow geeks be without this profoundly elegant math constant? Filled w/ thought provoking interactive displays, the Exploratorium will stimulate the intellect from child to grandparent! Cheers!
author: Frank K.

description:
Exploratorium after dark is one of the best events in the city. I love it so much that I bought a pass for myself and several as gifts. 

Each after dark event is themed and while there are a few that are just boring, the majority of them have been well thought out and interesting enough to keep me there buying $10 cocktails until close. 

I am knocking off a star for the spam. Like I said, I purchased passes for myself and some as gifts  for friends. We all started receiving identical spam and couldn't figure out where it came until I realized a few of our names were misspelled the same way they are on our Exploratorium After Dark passes. I tweeted about it and they apologized via tweets, email and phone calls but the damage was done. Once your information is sold there's no stopping it.

As someone who values privacy I will more than happy to pay cash for passes in the future but they will not receive anymore of my personal information. I still agree with their mission but selling information that aggressively is not cool.
author: Amy L.

description:
Finally made it to the Exploratorium new location and I must say, I LOVE IT!  There is so much to see.  My sister and I didn't make upstairs, so I will have to come back.  Being a member definitely has it perks.  There is also a lot of natural light and a beautiful view of the bay.  I've always been a fan of the Exploratorium and the new location definitely is a bonus.  Yes I will be back indeed.

My only negative comment, is the Priority Parking across the street located on Front @ Green.  My sister and I were told by the guy that parking is $5.00 per hour and they close at 6pm.  My sister told the guy, we will be gone about 3hrs.  The man had no pulse, not friendly but we figured $15.00 for 3hrs isn't too bad.  WELL - when we went to pick up our car we were charged a flat rate of $35.00.  My sister argued with the man, ( a different man) assisting her.  All he did was point to the flat rate when it specifically says $5.00 per hr for up to 4hrs.  We got ripped off.  I would recommend double checking with these guys, cause my sister and I were gone about 3hrs and 15mins, not close to 4hrs and we were charged an extra $20.00.  Unfortunately I cannot Yelp this parking lot since they are not on the yelp site but looking at their other locations a lot of people have given them 1-2 stars.  So folks, my recommendation to you is to PLEASE double check with these guys on the rate and beware to get your car no later than 3hrs hours otherwise you'll be paying $35.00 flat fee.  I'm very, upset that we had to pay that much for parking when we could have saved $20.00 and parked over at the Levi's parking lot.  Someone from the Exploratorium needs to check on these guys as well.  I don't believe not much can be done, but on the Exploratorium site is states that you can park for $5.00 per hour for up to 4hrs and my sister and I were parked less than 4hrs.  We were ripped off.  I don't think it is right so I want others to be cautious.  If Priority Parking has changed their limit of parking, then the Exploratorium needs to update their site.  You are better off parking at the Embarcadero Center where you car is more secure or taking BART.  My sister had to meet a client later which is the only reason why we drove rather than taking BART.
author: Liz D.

description:
I like the new place. It has a lot of new exhibits, and quite a few from the old location.Sadly, I couldn't find the headphones with donkey ears, to prove that they can hear well. The view is nice, the outdoor climbing thing is cool.
My biggest complaint is that the prices went up 30% and trying to park near it is ridiculous and expensive, My 11 and 13 year olds had a great time. 
there is a lot to interact with. 
Every half hour, they set off "fog" on the bridge over the water. It varies from thin to pea soup thick. The fog was a big hit!
My advice is to pack a lunch (they have lockers) and allow at least 3 hours to play with everything there.
author: Tracy M.

description:
I am really impressed by the Exploratorium renovation and relocation.  It is back and better than ever!!  We brought our triple date group for Thursday's After Dark event ($15/ticket) and found parking ($10 for 4 hours until 11pm) at the Levi's Center Garage a few blocks down - no problem.

When we arrived, the line was incredibly long!  

Is this where San Francisco nerds congregate?  I guess I fit right in.

No more than 10 minutes later, with our prepaid tickets in hand, we entered the museum...along with over 1000 other people!! Fortunately, even with the crowds, we were able to get through a little over half the museum during the 3 hours we were there.

The exhibits:  100% interactive!  Touching is believing, guys.  Let your inner child roam.  The variety of exhibits ranged from simple to simply astounding.  You can always expect to learn (or relearn) something new whenever you come to the Exploratorium from electromagnets to emotions to mental health to optical illusions to art displays. There is something for everyone and I mean it.  You will probably find members of your group drawn to various exhibits and wandering off in different directions!  My fave exhibit - the shadow wall.  Hands down.

The space:  Perhaps on a less crowded day, you will be able to hit everything without waiting in line for an exhibit.  I really didn't mind though - we had good company and moved leisurely through the museum.  The Exploratorium is a treat inside and out (child's playground outside and fog simulator!) from floor to ceiling.  Loved it.

Overall, 3 hours in the museum left much to be desired esp because of the crowds.  We missed the concert and didn't check out the Bay viewing area or the restaurant or the gift store!  No time for drinks either...lines were really long.  I would still recommend the After Dark event to avoid overeager children during the day.  Adults at least know how to respect the concept of a line, you know?
author: Kathleen W.

description:
Came here with a group of 3 on a Thursday for After Dark. Tickets were $15 online, and we parked a block away in a lot across the street ($15 evening parking). There's cheaper Exploratorium parking directly across the street.

Pros:
-restaurant looked decent
-short line for prepaid tickets

Cons:
-way too many people. The entire place was packed, and we had to wait for a lot of exhibits
-boring exhibits. As an engineer and scientist by training, I didn't learn anything from any of the exhibits, and most of them were ones I had already seen before.
-Adler Dome closed for After Dark
-Zoe Keating special performance looked incredibly overbooked
author: David L.

description: I LOVE the Exploratorium. I remember going to the Exploratorium old location as part of a field trip when I was a kid and thought it was kind of cool but unfortunately I don't remember much about it. When I found out the Exploratorium offers night life for adults I figured it was time to go back with a group of friends. I went back and had a blast. I am a hands on kind of person and I love how the Exploratorium exhibits encourage you to touch, test and figure out what is going on. I especially loved playing on the distorted room taking pictures and sitting on the various size chairs. This place is big so go early and try to see as many exhibits as you can. It was nice going during night life because it was all adults having a good time granted some of them were too drink or tipsy to be polite and others did hog a certain exhibit for a while. Regardless, I had fun and I cant wait to go back.
author: Abigail L.

description: The Exploratorium rocks!  Not only it is a fun place to "play" and be a kid discovering science and nature, but is also a great venue for events with great views of the Bay.  They also have a great cafe (prices are a little high but food is good).  We came here for a film screening yesterday as part of the San Francisco Film Society - awesome screening room!  A very versatile place that is easy to get it on foot or by the F Muni line.
author: Maile N.

description: Came here on a free day so have no complaints.  The Exploratorium is not getting enough love!  Even though today was a free day there was no line and not as crowded as I expected it to be.  All exhibits are hands on, which is amazing for kids.  I certainly did not grow up with museums like this one!  Prices can be a bit steep, but it's a great place and in an even more beautiful environment.
author: Nancy C.

description: Came here for the first time yesterday for a company event.   What a fun place.   My kid adored it.  Fun for everyone.   Love all the interactive exhibits.    Can't wait to come again when there are a few fewer people. !!
author: Rick R.

description: The reason everyone give this place 4+ stars is that they have a pack of children they can take here & let them loose. Not that the kids here are terribly behaved but I felt that the place was a bit over crowded & it was difficult to see many of the exhibits. If I had kids & I visited San Fran with them, this would be my first stop. That being said, I obviously don't have kids & would recommend making a visit with a family members kids so that you can get the full experience. The exhibits really are great (but for kids).
author: Laura B.

description: I feel horrible writing this but hoping it helps others avoid our situation. We have two teens and came on a Tuesday during Spring Break. We spent $100 for the four of us and two hours was all we could stand. It was really crowded, with hundreds of little kids running wild with limited supervision by their parents.  Literally every time we tried to interact with an exhibit, a child would interfere.  If your kids are under 10, you might enjoy it more.  We had an amazing day yesterday riding bikes over the Golden Gate Bridge and doing the Alcatraz tour.  Wish we had skipped this and opted for another SF attraction that doesn't leave you with a migraine.
author: Vikki V.

description: I hadn't been to the Exploratorium since I was a kid, so when it moved to a more convenient location I was pleased to be able to check it out. I've been twice now and have enjoyed it both times. The only reason I don't give it five stars is because I wish it were a bit bigger. It sounds like a crazy thing to say, but I think that they could use the space a bit better. Now, I could be completely off, and maybe they need that space to accommodate the hordes of people that come in on a regular basis. Maybe it seemed bigger when I was a kid. Nonetheless, the exhibits are fun and a great way to get people of all ages engaged in the sciences. They even have some of the interactive exhibits I remember visiting more than 20 years ago.
author: Andrew L.

description:
Where to begin on the magic that is science. This place is so much fun and completely impossible to do all in one day. The restaurant is equally amazing with lots of yummy organic food options that are reasonably priced.
