The best part though - the customer service. Everyone clearly enjoys working there. My nephew lost his coat at the center and we went back to check the lost and found. They did not have it but they called the next day and shipped it to my sister (who lives in New York).

Thank you for making our family experience so positive. I'll be back!
author: Janet L.

description: Very fun place to visit with kids, or for curious adults. I used to love coming to the old location as a kid, and the new one is very similar, but a little larger. Many of the same exhibits/activities are still around from the old location. The Seaglass restaurant is pretty good, expensive as is any museum cafe but decent food and even a sushi bar (which was closed on the day I was there). I recommend you allow as much time as you can for this place, there is so much to do and see. There are some things you have to sign up for in advance, like the tactile dome and the drawing board, so ask someone when you arrive if you want to do those.
author: L J.

description: Was just refused entry and told that the museum is no longer doing ASTC reciprocity.  This is baloney.  Was at the museum several times before (less then a month ago), and haven't had an issue.  Out of town visitors beware, your pass will not work, get ready to fork over $100.00 for a small family.
author: Alec K.

description:
Bummer. I wanted to like this place when we went on the free day last Sunday. It was packed of course but was still bearable. The friendly staff helped too.

Inside, it was long hallway of various hands-on exhibits that were usually jammed with kids playing with them. I skimmed a few of the exhibits and wasn't really bowled over by them. Maybe I'm too jaded? 

Probably fun for kids or kid at heart but otherwise, spend your time/money elsewhere. Most of the food places around here are super touristy and expensive, not to mention crazy traffic and wallet damaging parking.

Good thing we got in on the free day as it would've sucked if we paid for that less than stellar experience.
author: Norman S.

description:
Crazy crowded but still fun for both adults and children. 

I came here with my boyfriend because I was dying to see the new and improved remodeled Exploratorium. The new location is larger and has a beautiful view of the bay. There were so many people there that we had to wait in line for many of the exhibits. All in all it was a fun experience but the one thing I was missing was the bubble area! That was probably one of my favorite things at the old Exploratorium. Also some of the exhibits felt cramped especially when there were so many people! If you love food you should also check out the gourmet food court at the end. This is a great place for kids to ease into science and understand why everyday things are the way they are.
author: Jacqueline C.

description:
Very impressed with my first visit - so much fun things to see and do.  With little ones, hard to see everything so the yearly membership is a must if you live in the area.  

It's a great space and there is a lot of room between the exhibits to not feel cramped.  

The restaurant/cafe is also very nice with a great selection of goodies for the kids.
author: Gina C.

description:
Great for kids and adults alike.  I had only been to the old location by Palace of Fine Arts and finally checked the new location out during a free admission day a few weeks ago --- had a blast despite the crowd.  Around that time, groupon had a deal for an annual membership which I could not pass up and got a few other families to enjoy the deal.  One can spend an entire day here and still not get to enjoy everything the place has to show.

Although the place is meant for children 5 years and older, the younger ones can still have a fun time exploring without really understanding what's really going on.  

If you're a healthy eater, I wouldn't suggest eating at the cafe near the entrance.  Almost everything is fried and heavily battered! =(
author: Michelle N.

description: The last time I visited the Exploratorium was when I was back in high school, so it was great to visit them at their new location. There was so much to see this time than at their previous location, you really need a good half of the day to see and experience everything. Their new location is great, right along the bay with plenty of parking nearby at the lots. Highly recommend visiting this place as you'll be entertained for hours and will learn something new at the same time.
author: Matthew L.

description: So this is the second year I've returned to the exploratorium and it's always such a fun time! But I also have noticed that the two years in a row I get the flu horribly and I just now but two and two together. Please be advised everyone and wash your hands/sanitize. I write this from my death bed (sarcasm). The funny thing is I work in the medical field and it didn't even occur to me. I mean to be fair I follow the 5 sec rule when it comes to dropping food, but a lot of people go through the exhibits/museum and especially young ones and the immune compromised should take caution. I wish the museum had sanitizer dispensers prompting people to use them through their visit. Anyways I loved the 18+ Thursday night thing, very fun and would make a good cheapish date.
author: Nelanne C.

description: One of my favorite museums ever. I love that everything is hands on! Also, the new location here by the pier is more spacious, and better because there's other places to wander off to after your visit. definitely a good spot to spend a day with the kids.
author: Jane C.

description: Been here a couple times now. Interactive museums are always the best. Get to have fun while learning! Good for kids, families, and even dates who want to have a good time.
author: Amar T.

description: This is the greatest place ever to bring your children. Tons of hand on interactive activities are everywhere,  it the whole point of coming. All of the kids I saw were having a great time and so were adults and teens . Rarely can a place appeal to all ages, but this place does just that. If you're going to come, I suggest you block off about 3 hours minimum to check everything out.
author: David P.

description:
Elton John said it best: "Oh, but they're weird and they're wonderful..."

That's the best way to describe The Exploratorium - and yes, it is now located on Pier 15, so make a note of that. 

We took our three sons this past weekend, we stayed for hours and we hardly scratched the surface of all of the cool things to touch, see, do and explore. With two spacious floors of interesting displays and interactive gizmos, my kids were in heaven. 

The staff was friendly and even helped me find my son who wondered off in search of "the next cool thing" and got himself lost for a few nail-bitey minutes. (PS: He DID find another "cool thing".)

From magnet displays and gyroscope demos to the fun with light and the EPIC foggy bridge, this is now a "must visit" San Francisco stop for families and curious adults alike.
author: Michael R.

description: WoW! Big improvement.  This place is huge compare to the old location.  This place bring back fun memories of being a kid. We spent a good 5 hours in here exploring and i believe we didn't get to touch everything.  I can say I need to go back and explore more.  The view of the bay bridge was great.  I cant wait to return on thursday night its open late for the adults.
author: Linda B.

description:
Such an amazing space, congrats to the staff on making the experience one to remember. The cafe/lunch space was calling to me- I'll be back to dine in such a lovely looking space with Bay side seating. Wow.

btw, this is ageless. Throw the demographic bent out the window. Most young families seemed happy to have a safe space to let toddlers roam.. a small feat for small feet in sf.
author: Christine T.

description:
This a great place to take your kids if your kids are over 5 or 6.  My oldest is 5 and he was able to enjoy a fair amount of the exhibits but I feel like if he was a year or two older, he would be able to appreciate more of it.  My middle son is 2.5 years old and I don't really feel like there was much he could understand.  There's a couple stations with blocks for him to play with but that's hardly worth the cost of admission.

This place is also very crowded.  If you go on the weekend, be prepared to be pushed around by all the other kids wanting to see each exhibit.  With younger kids, it was hard to let them get a good look at a lot of the exhibits because older kids would bump them out of the way or cut.

Finally, bring your own food.  They have their own cafeteria but it is over priced and the quality of the food isn't that good in my opinion.
author: Nicholas G.

description:
Yay for student discounts! Instead of the regular $25 (I think?), I paid $19 - which I think is a pretty awesome discount for what the museum offers. It's also conveniently close to a BART station - the Embarcadero. I think it was about a 15 minute walk from the station to the Exploratorium. 

The Exploratorium is like a giant playground! You can touch/play with almost everything inside and there is SO MUCH TO SEE! I wish my friends and I were able to spend more time there! But unfortunately, the place closes at 5PM :(. My advice is to spend at least 2-3 hours inside to get your money's worth! We spent ~2 hours inside, but I wouldn't have minded staying longer!
author: Polly H.

description:
Absolutely loved this place! So many interactive and fun things to do and see.

They have a few discounted ticket options: student tickets, AAA member discounts, and local residents discounts that i know of. Took advantage of the $15 Thursdays from 6p-10p for those 18+. Ten bucks off? Yes please! we ended up going around 7 and leaving at close. I'd say it was a good amount of time to check out everything. Luckily, it was not busy at all.

If you're in the area you should definitely check out the exploratorium!
author: Nikki C.

description:
Yay! Science everywhere! All kinds of science under one roof! So many memories from my younger days!

I got a $5 discount as a student and being a local of the nine-counties listed on the website. I paid $15. Yay for living in Solano County and being a UCD student!

One of my favorites was picking up the red telephone and opening the safe. The only way you can open the safe was if someone on the other end tells you. Pretty fun when you open it to see the camera and the video of the other person. haha

Being that this is the Exploratorium, kids are everywhere (especially on the weekends)! My friends and I came on a Saturday early afternoon and we stayed for a couple of hours. We wanted to kill some time before the Electric Run, and we decided to come back here after not being here since elementary school. I'm glad we did!

I kind of miss the other location because the Palace of Fine Arts is super nice! And parking is harder to get close by the pier.

Even though we only stayed a couple of hours (and didn't really get to see all of the fun stuff), I had fun and would love to bring my little sister. I don't think she ever got to go to the Exploratorium in elementary school (she's in 7th grade now). She definitely needs to come and check this place out!
author: Terri L.

description: This review is for the store only. The store features a wide collection of books, puzzles, and games that I found really interesting to check out. Everything is priced up, but that doesn't change the fact that there are plenty of interesting things to look at. I also got to ride the plasmacar around the store!
author: Elaine Y.

description:
These folks LOVE science, building, engineering, tinkering and all things exploration. We take homeschool classes there (Ken rocks!) and completely love and enjoy each class. This place is better than any science museum we've been (NY, Seattle). 

It does get a bit crowded at times with school kids on trips, so I'm on a quest to find out the down times. 

The food in the 2 available cafe/restaurants is pretty great.

We are also very grateful for the resources on their website and the experiments on Khan Academy. This is one generous museum that deserves all of our praise.
author: B D.

description:
Came here for one of the After Dark experiences. It wasn't that great. It is definitely a date night place. 

I don't think I enjoyed it that much because the atmosphere was so, adult? Idk. I enjoy the company and the environment of children. It was really quiet and empty and felt like it was missing something.

They had a few places for drinks. They were insanely overpriced and very tiny. Definitely not worth it. 

My bf was hoping the bubble making exhibit would be there but they said that it wasn't available because they weren't sure where they were going to put it yet. They also have a few new exhibits.

Although I did enjoy that it was a lot cheaper for After Dark, I think I will come back during the day time.
author: Cathie N.

description: Great, hands on place - so many things to "explore" and play with. My husband and I took our 6 year old daughter and we all had a great day! Definitely don't skip this - but, COME EARLY! It gets super crowded and was best when we got there when it opened.
author: K. L.

description: One of my professors calls this place the "high church of constructivism".
author: Gavin M.

description: Wish I had more than 90 minutes! So much to see and do! Also, wish I could have been there on a Thursday night for the adult hours. I went on a Saturday and it was packed with squealing kids careening in to me. Also better with a friend, lots of partner activities. A bit pricey, especially considering it doesn't include everything- wasn't about to pay another $15 for the tactile dome on top of the $25 already spent. Otherwise, great place to spend a rainy day.
author: Anna F.

description: Great place for kids and adults alike. My wife and I spent a day there visiting all the exhibitions and wish we stayed for longer!
author: Alex O.

description: I was in here with my friend who has a young son.  More for kids than anything else - lots of stimuli.  For an adult, it was marginally entertaining but exhausting with all the kids and I wanted to wash my hands after touching anything.
author: Arthur Y.

description:
Not so good since they changed locations.  

Might be good for the operation to be more crowded, but the crowd detracts from the experience.  Also, unless I am mistaken, they left behind some of the more interesting exhibits, such as the 

two seats, 50 feet apart, where you could hold a conversation back and forth due to the parabolic backs that focused the sound waves.

large ball filled with inert gas that also focused sound waves.

the water tornado.

and so on.  Well maybe they were in there somewhere, but after 45 minutes or so in the zoo of a place (like walking in a crowded Costco) I wanted to just get out.

Oh, they have this intricate carved sculpture made out of toothpicks.  That's for Ripley's!  I think they have lost their focus.
author: G. W.

description:
My husband and I were in San Francisco recently for the second half of our honeymoon and this was BY FAR the best thing we did there.

Every exhibit is hands on.  They had everything covered: sound, light, motion, biology, perception, psychology.  We got in around 3pm and it shut down at 5pm, but we easily could have taken another hour to finish wandering around.

One thing I want to point out is that the material and concepts the exploratorium covers are mature and assume you have more than just a basic understanding of the universe.  Kids will not understand or appreciate the exploratorium.  Unfortunately, when we were there the place was swarming with children.  In a children's museum this would be expected and fun but here it made it difficult to fully enjoy the experience.  Kids are curious, and all they want to do is touch things...great, but not when I'm sitting at an exhibit and a little boy comes up and starts playing with the tools provided at that exhibit.  So, parents...if you are planning on going, please, PLEASE leave your kids at home!

Highly recommend.  Maybe scheduling a trip during the 18 and older times would be more enjoyable.  Again, not for children!
author: Hillary H.

description: The Exploratorium is a wonderful place for old and young alike. It's filled with interactive exhibits that engage you with concepts that many overlook. It's a very creative introduction to science. The genuine smiles you see while walking around speak volumes of this place.  I found the view of the workshop to be interesting and imagine this would be a great place to work as a creative. If you go, give yourself the whole day to make the most of every exhibit.
author: Zoë B.

description: Had a great time exploring all the fun hands on exhibits.  It was really fun for children of all ages. Not bad for a weekend event in the city
author: Dr Fred D.

description: Bummer. This place has a lot of potential. I will totally echo what others have said about the Thursday nights here -- it was so packed that you literally couldn't do anything. A waste of time. If you wanna check it out on a Monday morning -- that may be the ideal time to come. Has a lot of potential, but not enjoyable bc of the crowds.
author: Mel G.

description: Great fun for the big kid I am!  I loved going to the old location as a kid.  The Exploratorium brought back fun memories of elementary school field trips.  It has somewhat of the same feel as the tech museum, just more touchy feely!  It's a little on the pricey side, but it comes with the territory.  It's definitely a great place to take my kids.  I could spend hours there just touching and looking at everything.
author: Michelle P.

description: This place is so awesome!! I didn't really want to go at first because I thought it was going to be filled with kids and geared toward children but it really wasn't. I learned a lot actually and it was really fun to play with all of the exhibits. The shops are filled with really interesting toys that make great gifts. I didn't get to see any of the live exhibits but I'm sure they only add to the experience. I loved how they also had partner exhibits where you got to interact with your friends and test them too! What a great place I would definitely go back!
author: Emily E.

description:
Much bigger space and better use of it than the original Exploratorium.

Great place for kids to learn some science in a fun way!
author: Michael W.

description: One of my most favorite museums. It's a museum that reawakens your curiosity and your urge to explore. The place is huge with hundreds if not thousands of interactive show piece. They even show you the production process of their showpieces! Be sure to come here early because otherwise you will not have time to explore the whole museum. My only complaint is not of the museum but of the nasty little drunk people (children) some parents should definitely do a better job at keeping their young ones in check as some of them are quite destructive to the show pieces. Overall 5 out of 5 stars. Would come back again!!
author: J D.

description: Not worth the 75 dollars we spent to come in here. Disappointing. I gave it 2 stars because of the nice guy that understood sound waves.
author: Victoria O.

description:
Writing from a tourist's perspective I have to say that while there was a lot of interesting things to see and do, it was so packed that we didn't get a chance to do much of anything. I don't know what was worse, the kids cutting in front of my six-year-old son or the adults pushing him out of the way. You would think that adults young and old would have more manners than their children, but you would be wrong. 

The traffic you have to sit through is also no joke. We sat for over an hour on the same street just to get to the parking complex a couple miles down the road. In reading others' reviews I think that if I were a local or knew all of the ins and outs of public transportation, it may have been a little better, but everywhere was just so jam packed that it really took away from the experience. 

All in all, if there was a time to go when there were not so many people, it would probably be much more enjoyable. Is there a time when there aren't so many people? Doubt it. The location and Exploratorium itself screams tourist trap.
author: Christina I.

description:
A very fun place to be if you're a geeky Dad. It's a cool way to interact with your kids and get them to think in different and imaginative ways. I was even able to take video the whole time I was there (see link below). Would love to go again and check out more.

http://vimeo.com/67579684
author: Mervin M.

description:
I initially thought this may be a child-centric science center (as many tend to be) but the boyfriend and I are both in our mid-late 20s and we had the time of our lives here! We easily spent 3 hours touching our way through all the exhibits. Interactive learning is the way to go! 

The only disappointment was that we were very much looking forward to checking out their tactile dome (http://www.exploratorium.edu/visit/west-gallery/tactile-dome). It was supposed to open this Summer 2013, but a sign at the exhibit indicated that  it would be postponed till Fall 2013.
author: Nikki W.

description: So many exhibits! Way cooler than other science museums. Make sure to bring a friend, and probably 3 hours or so worth of time.
author: Kj E.

description: Exploratorium, a smorgasbord for the senses. Don't let the science focus scare you away.  This place is filled with interactive and intriguing exhibits for all ages.  A visit will take at least 3-4 hours and at least 100 things to see and do and maybe more.  There is something for everyone to experience and learn about.  The new facility is quite nice and I liked the open layout.  A word of advice, bring lots of hand sanitizer and wipes.  You will definitely need it. A San Francisco attraction that shouldn't be missed.
author: Kali M.

description:
I don't think we've enjoyed this place so much, I think we came here unprepared. Hungry and crowded and too many kids who don't have manners and just cut you off in line. When your sugar is low, you don't have that patience. 

This place is very educational and you have to want to read the exhibits description otherwise you wouldn't have any clue what you are looking at unless you are a complete nerd. 

We came at the wrong time, Adult only start at 6PM.
author: Lora M.

description:
This place is the best place to just stroll around and explore.
Let me get my one complaint out of the way now. OMG the pricing, and what happened to the once a month FREE day? Disappointed on that aspect but lets move on.

Get there early if you really want to check out everything. We got there at least 30 mins before they opened the gates. Gosh we sound like some horses ready to race, LoL. Well we did have all the strollers right in front ready to stroll in.

Any how it took at least another 15 mins to get everything all paid for with our group of about 10. We had 2 toddlers with us as well.

Moving on again. Favorite exhibit hands down is always the toilet fountain. Not sure if the little ones realized much that they were drinking from a toilet. Oh wait did I see them in the toilet at home? o_O

The kids loved everything, we spent at least an hour in the tinkering station and ended up having to drag the kids away. Poor things wanted to spend all day there. But once we walked around and he saw the giant mirror that turned us upside down and the plants and lights we were good to go. 

This is seriously the best place to bring a kid. They have fun and learn at the same time. They have something for everybody. You should of seen some of the older folks in there, they were amazed at the fact that you could touch the leaf of a plant and it would curl up to defend itself. 
So many things to see touch and more. So many things that this is really at least a half day trip, plan to spend some time there. Bring a snack and change of diapers if needed for your group, LoL!
author: Theresia D.

description: This place is so much fun.  I spent about 3hrs here with my friends on Saturday and we didn't even get through everything.  Everything is pretty much hands on here and at some of the stations you need a partner to do it with so definitely great bonding time with your friends/significant other/or kid.  There's a $5 discount on admission if you're a student which is awesome.
author: Joyce L.

description:
GREAT place for active kids (or adults!)

LOTS of auditory, visual, tactile, and has both indoor and outdoor areas to go. It can be a bit overwhelming as there are lots of sounds and such going on, but for active people, it's a great place to literally spend the day going from one spot to another. We spent about two or three hours there and I'm sure there's still lots that we missed, but the kids (3 and 5yrs old) were worn out they had done so much. AND they had a ice cream stand outside, which was a perfect finish to the visit :-)
author: Ive M.

description: This place was really fun for my kids, as well as my husband and I!! Thankfully, we used CityPass and scored admission to Exploratorium. If you're in SF and you have kids, this is a must!
author: M K.

description:
I love science.  I can't possibly imagine giving my beloved Exploratorium anything less than 5 stars.  Please, everyone, bring your kids here.  This was one of my most favorite places to visit when I was a child.  Every kid should come here.  Why?  Because it shows that science and math are FUN!  Everything here is hands on.  Even if your little one is too little to understand, it's still fun to tinker around with the exhibits.  We started taking my son to the original location before he even turned 2 and since he is so interested in science, we decided to bring him today for his 6th birthday.  I wish all kids and adults alike would come visit this place to discover that science is awesome (especially to those people who think science is too hard to understand or that it isn't interesting).  

Now, I will say that the place was PACKED when we visited on a summer Wednesday afternoon, arriving around 12:30pm.  Packed to the gills!  We noticed that the place really cleared out quite a bit around 3:30ish.  Next time, I will go in the later afternoon, maybe after lunch time.  I had a bad experience with a server at the restaurant who wound up giving my pizzas to another family, but I got over it.  The food is good, but expensive (no kids' meals).  

Overall, I'm happy with the new location, especially since the biology area is way more interesting and inviting now.  Way to go, guys!  My kids especially enjoyed watching the termites eat wood.  :)  We will be back!
author: Wendy V.

description: Lots to interact with for kids and adults. Definitely worth getting here early to avoid a bit of the crowds.
author: Greg M.

description: Can I give six stars? Place is great. Was there all day. Lots of bathrooms. My son learned so much. Had a blast. I learned too. Very interactive.
author: chopp e.

description:
Returned to my favorite science museum for the first time since they re-opened at the pier and I was really impressed wit the layout. It definitely seemed bigger and was way more packed than the last time I visited the old location. 

I wish parking was easier, but they do validate at the Embarcadero Center garage, which isn't a terrible walk at all. I was just used to arriving early at the old location and getting decent street parking for free. 

All the favorite exhibits are still there along with some new ones and a fantastic outdoor terrace overlooking the bay. A little pricey but plenty to do and well worth it. Can't wait to bring our kids here when they're older.
author: Jimmy H.

description:
The Exploratorium is a really cool destination. We had this year's Yelp Company Offsite here and it was a fantastic venue for an event.

For us geeks, the Exploratorium is like Disney World. Experiments everywhere, cool projects showcasing a great combination of art and science. I highly recommend bringing kids to this place, as it was great to watch children run around and test out all the different exhibits. One great thing is the sheer size and amount of stuff to see here. No way a single trip suffices - you need at least 2-3 stops at the Exploratorium to get through all there is to see.
author: Justin O.

description:
This has to be the best 'membership purchase' we have made for our family with 2 kids - 4 and 7. The kids never tire of it and there are many installations that are fun and a learning experience for grown ups as well. 

Staff is friendly and available when you need but everything is hands on for kids and in the last year that we have been going here, almost everything has worked - as in not broken because of too much or mishandling so basically things are made solid.

Tried the restaurant and its average. Nothing to complain or compliment much there.

My one concern is that there is not enough rotation in the installations.
author: Rishi C.

description:
This weekend was my first trip since the move. We brought my 7 yr old niece. 
This is an amazing activity for adults and kids alike. There is so much to see it can be stimulation overload at times, but I think taking each exhibit for what it is is important. Do not worry about seeing and "getting" everything in one trip. It is next to impossible. 
I appreciate the introductory physics and bio concepts that are basic steps to taking hs and college physics classes. 
I appreciated that they still have exhibits from the old exploratorium from when i was a kid. My brother and I both remembered certain exhibits. 
If you are there with a child, i would encourage the inquisitive mind, ask questions, and help to explain the whys. Encourage them to try to play but figure out how and why at the same time. 
I can imagine how the exploratorium can be an absolute zoo on an overcrowded day, but I didn't feel that way at all this President's day monday. 
It was a lovely, nostalgic experience.
author: Lee C.

description: Touch it! Learn! Have fun! Repeat! Takes mystery and intimidation out of science. Great for kids of all ages.
author: E. W.

description:
I love this place so much that on my first visit I upgraded my ticket to a family membership. The inner science geek in me loves hands-on exhibits, and this place does not disappoint! I grew up going to the old Exploratorium, so I was more than excited to bring my own kids (2 toddlers) with me to the brand new museum. Although they're still young, they love to explore and there's plenty for them to enjoy. There's so much to see here, you need at least 2 hours to see or interact with everything. Some of my favorite exhibits are the shadow room (strike a pose, wait for the flash and bam your shadow is stuck!), cow's eye dissection, xylophone room, the microscopic imaging station, and the the sculpture of San Francisco made entirely of toothpicks. Don't forget to stop by their cafeteria for some fresh shucked oysters, sushi or all-organic burritos (pretty fancy!).  

When you're done inside, take a stroll around the pier and check out the Fog Bridge exhibit as well as the science of skateboarding trailer. Don't forget to get some hot cocoa and try the free samples at TCHO, the luxury chocolate factory next door at Pier 17!
author: Lorajean F.

description:
The new location at Pier 15 is fantastic.  I have fond, yet vague, memories of going to the smaller location near the Palace of Fine Arts as a youngster, so some friends and I made the trek to the new location.

Tons of interesting stuff, even as an adult!  I do agree with another reviewer in that there were far too many unsupervised children running around.  Of course I expected a lot of kids, after all it's primarily a kids attraction if you ask me, but adults need to look after their kids & not let them run loose in a VERY large and pretty confusing interactive museum.  Then again, when working with some of the group experiments, some of the adults were just as bad :(

I was worn out after a few hours and I KNOW there was so much more to see.  My interest started to wane the more tired I became after walking there from Pier 1 and walking around the museum, so I'd go back to see the vast array of exhibits I'm sure I missed.  If your child is at all inquisitive about science, I can't recommend this place enough.
author: Trisha F.

description:
Great for the young and young at heart. If you're the kind of person that likes to learn by touching, doing, and example, you'll be sure to have a blast at the Exploratorium. There's experiments to demonstrate math, psychology, and other fascinating scientific principles. My friends and I had a blast.
A nice tip to help with the parking situation would be to ride the light rail in-- there is a stop right in front of the museum!
author: Phil H.

description: My family including 2 teens went to this museum only because we had seen it in the City Pass, but were glad we went there. It was amazing for teens and adults alike. I am sure it is wonderful for kids as well. Plan on spending the whole day at this museum: It is very hands on and each exhibit is well thought out and you wouldn't want to skip it. I wish we had one in the northern VA area as well, where we come from. Please take your family here: You will love it. If you have to exit the museum and plan to come back, make sure to get your wrist stamped. Remember not to go there on a Monday, because it is closed (we made that mistake the first day). Thumbs up!
author: Ana T.

description: Went last saturday and it was CHAOS.. Way too many unsupervised (young) children, a group of kids on a field trip blatantly disregarding their chaperones instructions, a LOT of the exhibits flat out didnt work, rude pushy people who either took too long messing with the exhibits or made us feel like we were taking too long, and the restaurant seemed a little expensive for the offering ($13.95 for a fish and chip lunch).  Also, their website told us to get off at the Montgomery street BART station, when the Embarcadero BART station was blocks closer... Maybe we will drive in on one of the Adult Only nights and try again.
author: Dana N.

description: The new location is pretty awesome. We two adults had fun on their first free day (Latino Engineering day).. but I think kids make the experience better. This is perfect for children and families. Many many hands on exhibits to enjoy. It could fill a couple of hours or more I think.
author: Vol T.

description: Crowded.  Tons to do and see, even free stuff outside.  It's definitely a good place for the Chirrens.  Loads of learnifications goin' on down here.
author: Vanessa C.

description:
Alcohol + Science = perfect night out. Spent a week in San Fran and dragged my best friend there for the Exploratorium After Dark. 

Tip: Get there as soon as it opens at night! There's so much to explore and unfortunately we ran out of time. Will definitely go back next time I'm in town.
author: Jennifer R.

description:
avoid weekends and/or summer as it is packed with kids

expanded, larger than their old location, lots of the same old exhibits but plenty of new ones as well that take advantage of their waterfront locale. a neat and educational place to spend a few hours
author: Long C.

description: First time here with my 8yo and 5yo. We had such a great time. Lots to explore and learn. Will definitely go back since we didnt get to see everything yet. Good thing we got the 1yr membership.
author: Abby Dajano L.

description:
Oh yeah baby talk nerdy to me. I love this place!

PROS
- Tons of exhibits. I've been here twice (maybe a total of 5 hours) and I still haven't seen everything!
- All the exhibits are so fascinating! (FYI - Sometimes it does take some reading so younger kids may not understand the exhibit if they don't read the signs. Tell them how the exhibits work and make them fall in love with science!)
- Location location location. A nice spot on The Embarcadero with an indoor and outdoor area. 

CONS
- There are way too many kids. I don't mind if they are well-behaved but many are not. They jump in front of other patiently waiting kids and adults. Obviously this is not The Exploratorium's fault. 
- Parking. As with all of SF, parking can be difficult to find and expensive. If you're lucky you can get a meter on the street. Otherwise for convenient there are pricier lots across the street.
- Hours. They close so early on the weekends! And they aren't even open on Mondays!

Despite all these cons I will definitely go back. Got an annual pass! Whee!
author: Chantal T.

description:
Loved the new location! Great place to enjoy some of your old favorites and experience some new ones as well. We went for their adult only after dark first Thursdays of every month. So no kids competing, instead you get drinks and music. 

Quick tip: go to their after dark event, parking is doable and the ambiance is much better.
author: Johanna P.

description: The new location is very convenient and it's so much bigger than the old one! I've been to the old one a few times and although many of the exhibits are the same, there are tons of new ones. I feel like it is even more interactive than it was before. It's a great place to take kids, but you don't have to be a kid to enjoy it, and if you really want to spend time to see and try everything getting a membership wouldn't be a bad idea. The location is great because you can walk along the Embarcadero if you want to take a break and grab something to eat. It's not too far from the Ferry Building! Don't forget to get a stamp so you can get back in :)
author: Henna P.

description: Cool place, give yourself plenty of time to explore and come early before it gets crowded.
author: Irene L.

description:
The name says it all.  It is a good sign when upon entering a place, my kids already are intrigued with the first exhibit.  They are a couple gremlins full of energy and often low attention spans.  However, this place excited them, and I didn't have to worry about them getting their hands on things, because that was the whole purpose of it all!

Love the fact that there's a teacher discount and my kids are young enough to still go for free.  If we lived much closer, I would take them at least once a week.
author: Maricar M.

description:
This review is a couple months overdue, but it's never too late to share some tips that could be useful to somebody :)

I parked across the street because there had been a sign that said "Exploratorium Parking". Assuming it was their lot, I drove in appreciating how close/easy parking was & thinking that my ticket would get validated. I waited in a short line where a man with an Italian accent came up to me and told me to get out. I wasn't expecting valet parking since there were no signs indicating it was valet parking only... but when I asked if they validated, he said, "yes vallet." Uh.. By that time I felt like I couldn't change my mind since he had already taken my plates down w/o asking, but I was way too excited for the Exploratorium so I just got out of the car and walked away. When I paid for my entrance ticks, I asked about parking validation & the sweet lady who helped me told me the people across the street scam everybody! And that they don't even work with the Exploratorium... sketchy. She said they speak perfect English, but when anybody asks if they validate, they suddenly lose the ability to speak/understand you and just say, "yes... vallet." On point with what happened to me.

Anyway, 5 stars because the whole parking issue has nothing to do with this place and because it's awesomeeee. You'll definitely need to spend a good amount of time here if you want to go through all the exhibits. Also, beware: cute kids everywhere! It could be an educational date for you and your boo or a nice family day full of learning for the kiddies. I came with my boyfriend but I'd def come back with my baby nephew or cousins.
author: Justine V.

description: I came out of retirement to say lovely lovely lovely. For those of you who grew up with the old Exploratorium, you'll be pleasantly surprised at the space. The main reasons I'm writing this are because 1) if you're smart, you'll buy passes online and bypass the extremely long line just to buy tickets, 2) if you are going to eat at the restaurant, like all venues that have kids as a main customer, go before noon, and 3) there are bay area prices for visitors (this is more readily evident online than in person). You'll thank me later. Parking is plentiful if you know where to look and if you get there early.
author: Charlene L.

description:
My husband and I did a day trip to the city and we had a great time!!! This place is amazing! or even a little so overwhelming! There was so much to see! The place has 6 different exhibits area in total and each exhibit is about a scientific subject, such as, electrical, human body, biology, physics, sound, geography and botany, etc. It's so scientific! A lot of families with kids. We spent nearly 3 hours in there and still feel that we didn't try everything. 

A lot of reviews said there is a parking lot right across the exploratorium. It's $5/hour. But we found a cheaper alternative. There is this parking lot on 750 Front street and charge $10 FLAT RATE. It's about 5 minutes walking to the Exploratorium. Totally worth it. You can even make reservations through Exploratorium website and there is even discount offered. The reserve parking spaces are even more convenient and it's at the first level. We didn't reserve ahead of time because their phone number posted on website didn't work and we didn't want to risk it. But well, we talked to the guy working there today and the guy said we can make reservations online and use the more conveniently located reserved parking spaces. Oh well~ maybe people who read this message can take advantage of it next time. 

Also, there is this observation deck from where you can see the beautiful bay!!! A romantic spot for love birds. Good surprise we found today. This place is full of surprises and will leave you an unforgettable experience!!!
author: Bob H.

description:
SO MUCH FUN!!!!!!
Newly reopened on the 17th.
I came here on a Saturday because a friend from out of town wanted to check it out.

It was quite busy but I totally expected it. KIDS GALORE!

There is so much to do there I felt like I never waited that long to play with anything.

SCIENCE IS COOL KIDS!

You get a discount nextdoor at Tcho Chocolate with your entrance ticket :)
author: Anne-Mary P.

description:
We had a company offsite here, so my experience may be better than most. I'm unclear on whether they do this on a typical basis, but we had free alcohol and food. Granted it was finger food and not a sit-down dinner, but it was so damn good. I had an incredible time exploring this place - they have many interesting exhibits. My personal favorite (and what I thought was most hilarious) was a water fountain shaped like a toilet. It definitely gives you mixed feelings before drinking water. It's on the pier so if you get tired of being inside, you can always walk along pier 15/17 and enjoy the amazing view of the bay and bay bridge. 

Overall, wouldn't say the usual ~$20 entrance fee is worth it, but I mean, my admission was free so I thought entire experience was pretty great.
author: Gina T.

description: It was a lot of fun to explore around, but going during the day it was filled with way to many children for my taste( yes I know it's a children's museum). I wish I'd gotten to go to the thing after dark. But I still had a great time.
author: Victoria D.

description:
I really, really want to like this place, but it looks like my 3 year old and I went at the absolute wrong time. The place was overrun with marauding preteens on field trips. I agree this is a great place for excursions, but I wish the management would rethink the number of school groups they allow at a time. What we walked into felt like a Lord of the Flies situation--kids snatching control of exhibits from each other, running around without looking and then laughing when they bump into people...it was not a fun experience.

Also, their website says that the exhibits are entertaining to toddlers. I'd agree, except emphasize that this is only the case when the place isn't packed with big kids who are barely supervised.

And last, the restaurant and cafe are pretty ridiculous. The food was decent, but seriously: $8 for a hot dog in a foil sleeve?! I'd rather go next door to the ferry building and get real fancy food. I overheard kids on field trips standing in line behind me at the cafe worry about what they could eat because they hadn't brought enough money with them. One ordered a tiny blueberry bar for lunch because it was one of the cheapest things on the menu. Sad!
author: Ann R.

description: meh just meh. take physics class and all of the stuff there will be childs play
author: Keit K.

description: We went on FREE day (still made donations of course) but it was a ZOO of people- mostly small children and families. Since it was just my boyfriend and I, I think a weekday would have been a better choice. I'd say it's set-up for kids, but there were lots of really fascinating installments that anyone could enjoy. If you don't have kids, come prepared to give up your seat or whatever it is you're looking at to a little guy who waddles up and wants to take a look :)
author: Caroline C.

description: This place is huge! There are lots of fun things to do and see here, if you can squeeze through the crowd trying to do the same thing. Lots of cool exhibits, but lots of lame ones too. Might be worth taking the kids to once, but I don't think we will be coming back.
author: Jay B.

description:
Oh my gosh...I really LOVE the new location. I used to go to the Exploratorium when I was a kid. I loved the old location and was always thrilled to go...but I have to say that this location is totally awesome! Love the layout. Now I've taken my daughter and she absolutely loved it. We stayed FOUR hours!!! It was great. 

My daughter just loved drinking out of the toilet water fountain at the front. Hilarious. ;-)  Love the fog bridge outside. Loved watching teens show a dissection of a cow's eyeball. Totally cool.

We'll definitely be visiting again...
author: Colleen C.

description:
Exploratorium has a special place in my heart. I grew up going to the old place every so often during school field trips. I'm glad it finally upgraded to a new place that's easier place to get to. The new location has every old exhibit with some new ones. It's still a great place to be a geek at or to be amazed about things you have never thought of.

There are lockers now and a giant tree! I like the new Bay observatory wing they have here. It has old maps of San Francisco from the beginning. Seeing how San Francisco was planned and what it looks like right now is a bit mind blowing.

Weird thing in here is a restaurant. Last place I expect to find a restaurant. A couple of the exhibits or wings are still under construction.

Tip: There's a locals discount!
author: Steven B.

description:
I used to go to the Exploratorium as a kid when it used to be by the Palace of Fine Arts. Things have definitely changed since then. It is now located at pier 14 and has much much more exhibits to visit. I love how they still kept some of the old exhibits from when I was a kid! It was fun to come here, but it's definitely geared towards kids. It's a place I'd take my future kids to.

It was $25 for adult tickets. The employee asked us if we were visiting or residents. Being that I'm a resident and my bf is visiting, we somehow got a small discount. Not sure why, but I'm assuming the discount was for residents (but don't take my word for it).
author: Chris K.

description: This was an incredible venue for a multi-audience party.  While there were a few insurance and ordinance things that had to be addressed, once that was done, the party had begun (so to say).  This space is great for children of all ages and allowed our guests to spread out and truly experience everything and network with everyone.  I highly recommend this space and their preferred caterer McCalls.
author: Julie C.

description: If you get there early enough, you can park across the street on the street for $2/ hr. Otherwise the lot they recommend across the street is $5/ hr. The only down side to street parking is that you can only pay for 4 hours at a time. We were there from 10am - 5pm and didn't get to play with everything. The place is huge. It's a great place for kids. Although some parents just let the kids "go" and that can be annoying at times. I highly recommend it and if you're close I'd get the family membership.
author: Vince L.

description: Love the new location! Well, it's not quite so new anymore. There seem to be more toddler-friendly installations than I remember the old place having, and the space is a lot more separated and spread out, and not quite so loud anymore. I liked the old location better but this is a great building. We'll be back!
author: Brianna C.

description:
there isnt much to say about the exploratorium besides it rules, even as a young adult.
i do think its new location at pier 15 enhances your experience not only because it's a nicer area, but they added cool exhibits and lookouts where at night the Bay Bridge glimmers oh so nicely.
Negative, you probably wont ever get a slow day because the touristy children are abundant and.. um rude.
but hey theyre kids. 

you can easily spend 5 hours in the exploratorium and they even have super good food and Alchohal.. whaaa!?

every First Thursday of the month is Adult only, which will probably be when i next visit,
:)
author: Chelsea B.

description: This place Is really cool.   Definitely brings out the kid in you, but all the kids running and screaming around unparented will ware on you if you don't come mentally prepared....fun times though!
author: Mike L.

description:
Nerdy husband and kids just loved this place. It's all hands-on. I think that we were here for a total of 6 hours and it wasn't enough for them! 

The restaurant is overpriced and meh, so take advantage of the in/out stamp and go to pier 1's market for lunch. 

My only complaint is that even though the exhibits are clearly designed by scientists and educators, the staff doing the presentations and manning the stations were just high-school students taught to regurgitate from a script. When asked for additional explanations they just didn't know (and why would they? I couldn't explain science to inquisitive children/parents at that age). I don't see why a place like this wouldn't hire a professional teacher to give talks throughout the day.
author: Susanna S.

description:
Bought a 1 year dual explorer membership ($95). Figured as we live close by, and with a 22 month old - we can visit frequently, and I can bring along a friend for free. The museum isn't ideal for 22-month olds, really for older kids - I'd say elementary age and older, but my son finds some of the exhibits and running around entertaining. Given that he is so little and wants to run everywhere, I try and go on early weekday mornings and head straight to galleries that are a little walk away from the main entrance. The museum fills up very quickly with student groups in the summer and tourists on weekends, so it can get congested and hazardous for him to be sauntering around. 

I would love to come here on my own (when not on babysitting duty) and take some time to explore each gallery more closely. There is a lot to see and do - it is also a beautiful, well-kept space.
author: Wendy L.

description:
I love exploring! -and the new location?? Job well done, exploratorium! I haven't been to the previous exploratorium in years but the new place seems twice as large. A lot more to look at, and more interesting things to play with. 

One tip is not to go on a holiday because all the kiddos out of school are there and it is crowded. What's worse is that parents don't seem to teach their kids manners and the concept of waiting for your turn, which is especially important when it's crowded. And what's even worse than that?? When the parents are pushing and stepping in front of others, stepping on your toes and not saying sorry where I have to sass you and say "eXcuse Me!" C'mon, parents!

There's a parking lot right across the street but exploratorium doesn't validate the parking tickets from that lot. Stupid! 

I haven't eaten at the restaurants inside but I assume it's not great like any other dining at museums. Take a short walk to the ferry building and eat there!
author: Annissa H.

description: My favorite thing to do in the city! This is the best, especially on Thursday nights. Lots to do and not boring like most museums. A great place to go with a group, it has a super social aspect to it. I definitely recommend this place to everyone when they come to town.
author: Shawn B.

description: I went here as a kid for a class field trip and still vividly remember some of their exhibits. Fast forward severeal decades and those exhibits are still there. The dissecting of a Cows eye, the slanted floor room and even the tornado exhibit. I took my daughter here as a way to open her eyes to more science since she really doesn't care for the subject in school (even though I'm classified as a scientist by the state of California). I must say, she did rather enjoy the place since most of their exhibits are hands-on type. The price of admission isn't too bad since they give you discounts if you live near the area. Parking is horrible. You have to find a cheap parking lot that doesn't charge an arm and a leg. The location is beautiful since you're along the water. But try to avoid going on the weekends since this is considered a tourist attraction, it gets reallt busy
author: Carlo V.

description:
Very disappointing visit. Went during Christmas break and it was so crowded we barely got to "explore" anything. Given that it cost more than $50 for two of us, it was a real waste. A shame that they're so focused on revenue that they won't limit admission to ensure a good experience. 

Add to that the stations we did get to touch were pretty common science class experiments. Not a wow.
author: Anna M.

description: Great place for kids, families, and science lovers! Can get crowded on weekdays from school trips.
author: Sarah P.

description: A great museum of science and discovery for kids and adults.  Can spend a few days to see it all.  Great, original and fun exhibits.  Only problem can be when it's crowded.  We bought a 2 yr family membership that lets you write it off as a tax donation.  Go often, relax and enjoy.  (Keep an eye on Groupon for discounted annual membership for 1/2 off).
author: Michael W.

description: Not good for group/corporate offsite events, apparently. Although their website claims they offer guided tours, can arrange reservations for the tactile dome, and can provide lunch, they lady I just spoke with on the phone told me rather abruptly that they are no longer offering any of those services. An email request for more information went unanswered. If you're trying to plan a team-building event for a group at work, don't waste your time with the Exploratorium. They need to update their website instead of relying on the people staffing the reservations, because they are completely rude.
author: Kristen A.

description: You get to push buttons, pull levers and play with electricity??!?? And we aren't going to get yelled at?!?!? I've been to this museum a few times and it is always a good time for kids ages 1-100. There is something interesting there for everyone. You can even see the shops where they make/repair/grow the exhibits.
author: Gelacio V.

description:
Incredible. I took my 4 year old here as part of our CityPass and was expecting a fun little learning place with nifty science experiments but I was BLOWN AWAY! 

There are things for every age here. You and your children will explore the sciences of sound, smell, sight, touch, and all of the illusions and weird happenings in between! Im just a tourist, so i am sure they switch these activities out but here are some of my favorites from today: 

Blue half domes on either side of the room that you can sit in and talk, clear as day, with someone in the other. 

a manmade tornado. 

a giant game of pacman where the kids can choose a direction to control and they work together to play the game. 

tactile experiments that show how our bodies interpret temperature, feelings and touch, and smells vs colors. 

optical illusions with mirrors including one giant mirror that will make you think you are attacking yourself :)

perceptions and interpretations of things from another humans perspective. there were a few that really helped my son understand people and it really touched my heart. 

playing with air, current, wind. 

playing with magnets and sand!

lockers that, while you think just hold bags, actually have musical handles and you can create a melody.

plenty of "scientific" musical instruments. 

information on the human body and its components and functions. 

making a giant bubble. 

lots of buttons and levers that have reactions and actions. it was very fun to find out what operated what.

looking at the organisms and life coming from the Bay. 

and so many more I cant even remember them all.

it was a great place to take our 4 year old, and we didnt even get through all of it. its fantastic to challenge the mind and give them good clean interactive fun. Im so glad we found this place to take our children here. My 16 month old is not old enough to appreciate all it has to offer. but loved the wide open space and some of the fun tactile things and i know her brain was growing too! I absolutely wish there was one in my state; I'd get a membership in a heartbeat.
author: Rachel L.

description: Great new space. I got a membership for 2015. Although my daughter's favorite part of going was riding the street car on the embarcadero.
author: Zachary C.

description: Interactive. Fun. Educational. Been many times and still have not seen it all. The cafeteria at the end of the pier to watch boats go by. With an adult bar that is so fresh and modern. Great for a fun date. Endless hands on science experiments that are great for your little ones to learn so much while having fun.
author: Heather S.

description: Awesome sums up this place. Complete sensory overload with a building full of science experiments. Could take several days to fully enjoy the exhibits. Everything is hands on and explorable. Our 3 year old was just old enough to enjoy some of the exhibits, and the 5 year old had a great time. The older kids, of course, got into it all. No reciprocity with other science museums, which is a bummer. Buy your tickets online and have the email on your phone in order to bypass the line at ticketing. We went on a Friday during spring break but didn't have any trouble finding space to play.
author: Jared C.

description: This is one of those places where parents stop parenting and let their obnoxious kids run wild. There are neat science experiments for physics, math, science, etc but you probably won't get to play with them because kids will push in front of you. I wish there were more places to sit, we wandered forever just to get a chance to rest somewhere.
author: Mila G.

description: I visited the Exploratorium during Uniqlo's free day on Sunday, September 28th. When youre walking along embarcedo you don't really see a line until you see the corner and there was a super long line to get in. My friends and I waited in line for asbout 20 minutes and went in for free. Since it was a free day there were tons of children with their families everywhere. I think the Exploratorium is a great place to bring your kids and help them learn about different things. It was cool how the center was more focused on science and physics in a sense. However since I came on a free day it was quite overwhelming. There were so many kids that my friends and I who are adults couldn't enjoy the different stations. I was also afraid of catching the flu or something, so many kids were touching everything! Though this experience was not the best, my friends and I want to return on a less busy day. I think our experiences would be different then.
author: Tiffany T.

description: The new space and location along the Embarcadero provide views of the Bay and easy access to BART. The well-spaced exhibits made it crowd manageable. The Tactile Dome (separate admission price) was well organized by a staff member who was enthusiastic and gave pertinent information about what to see and expect without giving too much away. It was enjoyable and kids-friendly, with at least two opportunities to go through the dome. Food at the onsite cafeteria used locally sourced ingredients with a variety of tasty items, such as sushi and tacos.
author: Lana C.

description: My favorite exhibit was the one where you walked across gravel, trying to be really quiet before it got removed.  There are many exhibits that were cool, including all of the electricity and mechanical ones. Another one was the one where you balance blocks on a platform that tilts every which way, so you had to even it out.
author: L.B. M.

description:
I wasn't the hugest fan of the old location, so the new one is for sure an upgrade. It's right on the embarcadero, clean and spacious.

Unfortunately the layout is not much improved. We had a hard time finding the ticket window, which is along the side, (I guess we went in the wrong door?) and an equally difficult time finding the exit. There are doors everywhere, but they are all marked as alarmed and only for emergencies. For some reason you have to get your hand stamped when you go to the bathroom near the cafe. The bathroom was really cramped and the changing table awkwardly located if you have a stroller. The sinks are impossible to reach for a kid and there are no step stools or anything. We are used to the Academy of Sciences, which has thought of everything for kids. This new space seems to have been designed by a childless architect. Odd since it is supposed to be a kids science museum, no?

There's not a lot for young kids, mostly better for school age and up. We went on a weekday and it was not crowded, which was great. Go to the Ferry Building for lunch if you can.
author: Nicole M.

description:
The Exploratorium is spectacular and full of interactive, informative and visual stimuli!
A place where you can truly get in touch with your inner child and (I say this with warmth and amusement) be bombarded by children full of excitement and lack of spacial awareness, jamming though every exhibit. If you bring a young adult you are in for one hell of a ride - be prepared to be dragged around the entire place, bouncing from exhibit to exhibit like a pinball machine! Each exhibit draws you in quenching your curiosity and leaves you wanting to learn more.
I recommend this place for people of all ages! As for you sticklers out there that are easily annoyed by the buzzing of children and avoid the crowds - go early on a weekday.
author: M B.

description: Fun!  We actually went here by mistake (someone told us about the Academy of Science, which sounded wonderful, but I couldn't remember the name).  Lots of fun experiments.  Most of it was a little too advanced for my little 2-year-old, but she still liked it.  I especially enjoyed the psychology exhibit.
author: Tiffany J.

description: Avoid this place when school children might be present. It is over run by unsupervised masses. No one is learning anything. This is a simple example of inept management. After about 3pm it's great. The schools and the who ever supports the mass confusion in the morning (before 2pm) are getting ripped off. But if you can go in a quiet time, it's pretty interesting.
author: George H.

description:
Wow... this place is awesome !  We loved it, our 8 year old loved it !   Could not believe how many exhibits there are to play with & so cool to see the fab shop in the middle where they build them all. 4 hours flew by ! Probably best to visit on a weekday though as we were there on a Tuesday & it was still reasonably crowded. There are hundreds of exhibits though, so really no waiting.
Don't miss it if you are in SF !
author: Chris C.

description: Way too expensive for the overall experience with 3 kids and 3 adults. Tickets and parking alone will put you over $150. We were here on a Monday and there were schools on field trips, home school kids, and grandparents taking their grandchildren out. The place is bigger than it looks but it is dark inside. There are A LOT of hands on exhibits but the crowds will only allow you to appreciate only a few of them. CA Science center in LA is FREE with flat $10 parking and BTW it has the space shuttle. :)
author: King H.

description:
This is one of the best values in SF!  You can literally spend 4-5 hours here and not get bored.  Make sure you see the life science exhibits!!  The chicken egg with the beating heart was very cool.  

Tip... Go early and get a ticket for the large "Spirograph"  it is a free souvenir and looks very cool. 

Tip#2. Teachers get in free!!  Make sure you sign up online for this peek.
author: mike k.

description: Cool place for pre teens and adults, not really for kids in my opinion. Obviously it is a great location.
author: Jo M.

description:
What a great experience!!!  This place is huge with lots of different things to catch a variety of people's interest.  The restaurant is a bit pricey, but the view is fantastic of the bay. Oh yea, the food is good too.  The choices are more adult friendly vs. kids, aside the token grilled cheese sandwich.  I had Mahi Mahi with an Indian taste sauce along with the rest of their garnishes.  To me it was great.  Also, the staff were great at keeping the restaurant area really clean, which I really like.  

Parking tip (assuming you're going on a weekend): Park at the main garage next to the Embarcadero Center.  It's a short walk.  If you spend $3 item from any of the shops around that spot (say a coffee shop) or in China Town, get validated and it'll only cost you $3 ALL DAY....just plan to leave before 10 PM when the garage closes.
author: Greg O.

description: Adults without children: do not buy an annual pass.  It doesn't get you into the After Dark.
author: Katherine F.

description: We had a ton of fun spending the part of our first day and another day going through this interactive, attraction museum. (If it should even be called a museum; lots of fun). We did not go on Thursday night for the adult only time as many had recommended; the kids are not that bad. You just have to explain that it's your turn when they come up under you and start taking over. None of the parents paid attention to their children to explain to them that they had to wait for their turn. The "stations" or interactive pieces were very interesting some too adult for certain ages other were just right. The only disappointment we had was the Bosun's Whistle outside. A cone box hanging in the water with a bellows running a hose to a bicycle hanging over the water that was turned into an automated bosun's whistle. It never played. The museum explained that it was broken and they were attempting to get it repaired. Too bad. I would highly recommend this attraction for a day well spent for time and fun.
author: M T.

description: Cool place for science .just don't go on a weekend you'll find your self dealing with parents who don't teach there kids maners on how to take turns and selfish people not knowing when its time to let the next kid check out and enjoy the experiment.  Both times I went my kids couldn't even enjoy half of what tgey have to offer . Going to try  a weekday .othere than that this place is fun but I feel like the old location was better
author: Sal L.

description: I love the concept and spirit of this place, but the new location feels like a dingy warehouse (which it is). This place is still an important institution, but I can't forget how spectacular and magical the old location was.
author: Nicholas T.

description:
It was my first time coming to the new one. Parking was obviously much pricier. We took about 30 minutes on the street to find parking.  Once we were there, we liked the view of the bay!

We saw some of the old exhibits. We were happy with the new exhibits. My favorite part was when a cloud came out of the trampoline. A great place for kids to learn.

I didn't expect the amount of technologies in the exploratorium and not just focused on environmental exhibits. I would like to go back again very soon!
author: Demetri S.

description: This place is enjoyable no matter what age group you're in. My boyfriend and I came here a few weeks ago to just explore and we played with every element of the Exploratorium to the get most out of the experience. We had a good time but I felt like it would be best with grade school - high school kids. You definitely learn a little something here. :)
author: Tina H.

description:
I'm sure the exploratorium would have been a fantastic experience during my recent visit to San Francisco, however, I never got the chance to experience it. Having heard about their "After Dark" events, I was curious as to whether this option would be available on Thursday December 31, when my partner and I were visiting the city. I was excited to find that when I looked for tickets, the December 31st date was indeed available, and I booked our tickets right away. 
We arrived in San Francisco over a month later, and on New Year's Eve were looking forward to experiencing this unique event. We got dressed, made our way down to the pier, and looked for the museum entrance, only to find all the doors locked, and several other people wandering in confusion. A young lady emerged and informed us that the museum was closed. When we (and several other individuals) informed her that we had tickets to the after dark event, she expressed her apologies, and told us there was no event that evening. My partner and I were left with no other choice than to head back to our hotel, which resulted in us wasting nearly an hour of commuting for nothing.
I am frustrated and disappointed that 1) we were able to purchase tickets at all for this event, and 2) that the error wasn't recognized well before December 31. The fact that the tickets were errantly available for purchase is one thing, but the fact that the museum seemingly wasn't aware of these purchases, resulting in several individuals arriving to the museum with paid tickets for a non-existent event is inexcusable. We made phone calls to the museum regarding this error, and they still expressed surprise at our purchase, indicating that, had we not called, they would have kept our money, never aware of the error they had made. While they refunded our purchase price, the experience we had with the museum (or lack thereof), indicates a lack of professionalism and awareness of their own ticket-purchasing system. Should you choose to buy a ticket in advance to this museum, I recommend calling and explicitly verifying that they are indeed open during the time that you plan to visit,
author: Kristin J.

description: I took my 16 year old sister on a bonding day and headed over to the new location of The Exploratorium.  This place is huge so it's definitely worth it to visit....especially if you're a hands on type of person.  I don't know if it would consume my entire day, but it can certainly keep me busy for half a day.  Keep in mind, there's tons of parking along the embarcadero although it can get pretty pricey.  The space is huge and there are tons of mind bogglig exhibits.  You don't even realize you're learning while you're exploring and playing.  All of a sudden science is cool.
author: Christine D.

description:
I took my 9 year old and 2 of her friends to celebrate the end of school/beginning of summer. I used Parking Panda to reserve an all day spot at 90 Broadway. Regular cost is $21 all day, with new customer promo code I paid $13. Lot was super convenient and easy walk to the Exploratorium.

We purchased tickets to the Tactile Dome which was the highlight of the trip.  17 tickets are sold for each tour and you are allowed to go through 4 times per session. In complete darkness, you have to feel your way through the dome. The groups are staggered to avoid running into one another. A monitor sits watching infra-red cameras and keeping an eye and ear open on those inside.

The girls were skittish at first, but by the time they exited the first tour, they couldn't wait to go back through! They zoomed through three more times and hated to leave. The other exhibits were interesting and very hands on. We did not have much additional time before we left for lunch, but used the ticket purchase price as credit towards a membership, in order to come back for free!
author: Mrs P.

description:
The other reviews covered most of it, but here are my tips:

1. Restaurant will be crowded. Cafe will be crowded. You are better off eating somewhere else.

2. Ghosts In Your Eyes actually scared me. I went in with a friend who decided to make a really creepy face at me for some reason. I would not take small kids, fine for preteens-adults that don't get scared easily. 

3. Fun photos:
-drinking from the toilet (not real, just an exhibit!)
-the "ultica crate" in the mental health section
-sticking your fingers through the huge bubble

4. You really can't see it all in one, two, or even three days spent there. Take your time, and don't expect to see everything in one sitting.
author: Margeaux W.

description: New location is not so great. Hard to get there, parking hassle, and wild tourist spot. My kids grew up with weekly trips to the old Exploratorium but this is not a family place anymore. We miss it.
author: Baer B.

description: What a fantastic experience for all ages!  I loved this place before, but the new space at Piers 15/17 is amazing.  Science, art, things to look at and touch, new ways to think about and see the world... it's a great way to spend the day and I highly recommend a visit if you're in town or a local.  I loved the giant clock, the dry ice and fog stations, the giant and tiny chairs, the sharing exhibition.  There's definitely too much to see in one visit, so we'll be back for sure.
author: Ellen S.

description: This would have been 5 stars, if on the day California School for the Deaf came for a field trip the interpreter at check in, who said she would explain the bovine eye dissection to the students showed up when it was time for that! But instead the kids and a bunch of adults were left wondering what was being said about each cut and this crazy cow eye. And if when we asked for subtitles to be turned on in the theater we weren't given the run around and then told, "we don't have Spanish or Chinese subtitles, either." This is completely different than speaking a foreign language. This is about the ADA, and making information accessible for everyone. Foreign language speakers can learn English. Deaf people can't learn to hear. Every new tv, no matter how fancy, automatically has subtitles. Come on Exploratorium! Step it up. This is discrimination.
author: Shaston T.

description: Mind-blowing. Delightful. Fun. Mentally exhausting.
author: Inigo M.

description: OMG Best museum i've ever been to! My bf and i went (we're both 25) and LOVED IT. a place where you learn the science behind things and you get to touch anything and everything. There was so much to do that we didn't even make it half way before we getting tired. If anything this place might be too overwhelming. Definitely was wroth the entry. a must go if your visiting SF!
author: Sophiie W.

description: I brought a date here on a Sunday afternoon, and the place was really crowded. The line for the tickets stretched out the door! Luckily, we had a corporate pass and were able to skip the line. The museum is filled to the brim with little bite-sized exhibits, each demonstrating a strange and wonderful scientific phenomenon ranging from physics to psychology. I wish I could have come as a kid and looked upon each exhibit as a new mystery. However, even as an educated adult who was very familiar with majority of the phenomena, I had a lot of fun getting hands-on with each exhibit. Unfortunately, I didn't have enough time to check out the entire museum despite spending two hours there.
author: Sean W.

description: Twas a few days before Christmas to the Explorium I did go, I thought surely that during a week day the place would be slow. But from all directions I was surrounded. Where did they all come from? I was confounded. It was children, all sizes from big ones to small, all running and skipping, and some starting to crawl. They screamed, and they hollered, and shouted with glee. And at least half of them bumped into me. Their laughter got louder with each passing hour, their parents soon realizing they were beyond their power. At first I thought this was all too outrageous, till I found that their laughter was quite contagious. I really enjoyed it, but I have some advice. If you're one of those who thinks quiet is nice. Come here on Thursday nights 6pm-10pm Truly a place for all ages. New location is nice, but I kinda miss the old location.
author: Ron W.

description:
I thought I would miss the old location at the Palace of Fine Arts, but the new Exploratorium at Pier 15 is bigger and better than ever. 
Their exhibits are changing constantly, so there is always something new to discover. You don't have to be a science buff to enjoy the Exploratorium either, there really is something for everyone. 
Employees are friendly and helpful. They all seem to enjoy working there and it shows. 
Love the location. Amazing views of the city and the Bay Bridge is a bonus.
author: Annie G.

description:
Congrats on the new digs. Very nice.
Very many cool and explanatory scientific exhibits. Most if not all are hands on. Great.

Upon arrival I was asked where I was visiting from. I truthfully answered from southern California. I was then charged more than I expected. Upon question to the polite and charming clerk I was informed that the lower price I knew about was for "local residents only".

I then asked, "Was I just PUNISHED, charged more, for answering your question honestly" to which she responded "yes sir, I am sorry, I do not make the rules, but that is the case".

Hey readers, if you visit from out of town, you MUST LIE to get the correct admission prices.

Shame on the Exploratorium for charging me more because I drove 413 miles to see their exhibits. Predatory pricing gets a 1 star review. Punishing patrons for where they live deserves ZERO STARS.

Shame on you.
author: Scott S.

description:
EXQUISITE. EXCITING. AMAZEBALLZ. NERDY. ARTISTIC. FUN. MATHEMATICAL!! I wish I can say 5 hours worth of compliments about the place, but I only had 3 hours of intense fun there!

I've been to the Exploratorium many many times at the Palace of Fine Arts, but this is my first time being at the new location. I came here on a date so I'm writing in the POV of a young adult and not a parent. I got a student discount for $19. General Admission is $25.
