A great deal either way, but saving $6 was just the cherry on top for a fantastic day of exploration!

EXHIBITS:
There are cool ones, scary ones, trippy ones, learning ones, interesting ones, boring ones, exciting ones, magical ones, unexpected ones, beautiful ones, amazing ones, fun ones, all under one roof! There will be kids (even older folks) that just take forever on an exhibit. Be patient, linger onto close-by ones and swoop in right after them. There are kids that straight up cut you while you are trying to figure out an exhibit. This would normally be fine because I am an adult and sure, I'll let you kids go. But it's still incredibly RUDE! Kids are only going to learn that it's ok to just cut people. And the parents that just let it happen, SHAME ON YOU. Teach your kids please! If they really want to play on it NOW, teach them to ask nicely. I've seen a mix of parents that will keep reminding their kids to wait and ones that let their kids just be a*holes. Sorry but not sorry. It's not like I'm gonna spend longer than a minute if there's a kid waiting on me. Some parents let the kids stay on one exhibit for an hour and just sleep on a nearby bench. Come on... I'm no parent, but I was never taught to just cut people in line. (ok, enough with my anger at horrible parenting)

The great thing about the exhibits are that they have some of the old ones that I remember so fondly from my childhood, and they also have a lot of great new ones! The exhibits are separated well into their scientific categories, so you kind of know the gist of the areas (better to make your choice of which ones to skip because of time constraints). Eg, pendulum area, I skipping half of them, after like 
7 pendulum exhibits, I just thought to myself, "Ok, I get it..."


TIME:
It took me 3 hours, and I feel like I didn't even see half the exhibits. I skipped A LOT of them due to overcrowding and the fact that time was of the essence. Make sure you have enough time to really EXPLORE! Not just look at the exhibits, but really understand and learn it. So don't go in 30 mins before closing! :]

FOOD: 
Thank goodness I ate beforehand because food was EXPENSIVEEE

PARKING:
Parking will be a pain. I found a parking meter 2 blocks away and it cost $15 for 3 hours. Usually a horrible price, but not bad for this tourist area. Exploratorium also has a parking lot across the street but parking is $20.
author: Azn B.

description: OMG this place is amazing! Not just for kids and great for groups. There are so many displays and activities, you will need an entire day here to see everything. Loved it!
author: Tiffany M.

description: I'm stunned at the high rating for this place. If you're under 10 yeah maybe it's educational but I kept thinking the touted "fun for all ages" advertising was highly dubious. Maybe if you take your kids there it would be fun watching them learn but the science is definitely geared to kids, it's very basic and I'm someone who was bad at science at school and haven't progressed much since then. I saw adults wowing over fruit fly experiments we did at school at age 12. If adults without kids really get anything out of this place then I worry about the US education system. I'm not convinced that kids learn much either, mostly they ran from one piece to another pulling levers and making more noise than you'd expect in some war zones but didn't see many of them reading the "why/what/how" explanations. They were just banging things and inducing migraines. If you have kids take them but also take earplugs and plenty of aspirin and lots of money (the restaurant is super exy and my stomach still hasn't settled from the dodgy pulled pork), you'd be looking at $100 for a family and you'll likely wonder how many of the kids in there are being raised by wolves, lots of screaming little brats.
author: Ginny A.

description:
Boo!  I was so excited for this, but what a disappointment.  I arrived at 10:30am on a Tuesday with the two 20 month old children I nanny for.  We were stopped by a guest services lady out front and I told her I needed to get my membership that I bought on Groupon.  She sent me to a line outside.  5 minutes later she told me to go inside to a different line.  I go inside and wait 15 more minutes in a line that 1 person is helping while two other employees sit doing nothing because they are on the side of the counter that says business guest or private guests or something to that extent.  I saw 1 food delivery guy approach them in 15 minutes and the 2 idiots couldn't even figure out where to send the guy to deliver the food!  I mean, they really couldn't lift a finger to help out with the line?!  Your employees should be trained in all guest service related matters.  There were also tons of people asking where to go to buy tickets, which was in a different area.  Everyone just looked confused when entering.

We finally got in and I was beyond disappointed at the exhibits.  I mean we live in SF....impress me!  These exhibits are geared toward 5-15 year olds.  Why are you charging adults so much more than children when there is nothing for them!  To top it all off I paid $8 for a cheese quesadilla (the only real kid friendly option) for the kids.  You have children's ticket prices...get a real children's menu.  

Lastly, I had to change a diaper in the restroom and there was no real changing table!  Just a vanity counter at the entrance to the restroom that everyone (men and women) could view.  The little girl I was changing freaked out when I tried to lay her on this counter, because she is used to the universal Koala changing tables, so I had to change her standing up.  If I want to change my child without male strangers walking by and seeing her I should be able to!  Inappropriate.  They have tons of work to do to make this place match the ticket prices.  I will not be back.
author: Crystal I.

description: The museum is ok. It's a little over priced ($25) for adults. Some of the exhibits were out of order. I though a lot of the exhibits were rather simple and not very remarkable. I think the Tech Museum in San Jose is better for the price, with its Earthquake simulator and roller coaster machine.  Some of the Exploratorium's exhibits seemed like Facebook memes posted on a person wall, especially the perception exhibits.
author: Richard G.

description: This is the second time visiting with my 2 year old.  It is nice that they offer a local discount.  This brings it down to $22.  Still a lot.  They don't give you any map of how things are laid out or any information.  I am all for discovering things on your own, but it would be nice to look at a master list, just so you don't miss an area you may want to focus on.  I bought a couple of items at the gift shop and the total was $10.15.  The guy ringing me up asked if I would like to round up to $11 and make a donation to the museum.  I didn't appreciate being asked to donate while I am buying a couple of over priced items to begin with. The meters in SF now charge 27cents extra if you use a credit or debit card.  Would you like to round down to $10 and make a donation to my parking meter surcharge?
author: B N.

description: I loved the Palace of Fine Arts location, and had gone there as a child, so I was saddened to see that they had moved.  Saddened until I saw what they moved into, that is.  Pier 15 provides more space, and allows for a more logical layout of exhibits/experiments.  No trip to Baghdad by the Bay would be complete without taking your children to turbocharged jumpstart their brains at the Exploratorium for a day.  Convenient to BART or Muni.  There simply is nothing like it anywhere else.
author: David S.

description:
I just took my family to the new location for the first time. It was Sunday, 11 to 4-ish. 
Loved it! 
First, the outside space is amazing. There are gorgeous views all around, interactive things, the fog bridge, and rocking chairs. Plus, with a hand stamp you can go in and out very easily. The outside space really makes this place so much better than the last one.
Second, the experiments are still so freaking cool. Some are from the old museum, but the laws of physics haven't changed so of course the experiments still work and teach. But there are are so many more new ones. It definitely feels fresh. If you walk around and notice the crowd, you'll see about 90% of the adults actively engaged in some way or another. The games, experiments, puzzles, etc. are great for all ages. My four year lasted nearly 4 hours there, I could have stayed longer. Oh and the cow eye dissection is still fantastic.
Third, price. It's not free? Of course not, yes it cost money but if you think of it as a amusement park, it's way cheaper than anything else. Plus when you spend $9 per person for lunch the food is way higher in quality, not the junk served at places like amusement parks. Every piece of equipment in this building is CUSTOM. And these things take a beating. I'm surprised anything lasts more than a day without breaking. It takes a lot of skilled people to keep that place going. Kudos to the great staff.
Parking can be as cheap as $10 if you pick the right garage. They valid parking for specific garages. Call to get details. My family took BART and did the 10-15 min walk, easy.

If you go and plan to spend the day, pace yourself, take breaks (you can leave to walk the pier and come back), get focused on the activities, do the little tours they offer to get more depth out of the activities, and just have fun. There's plenty to laugh about and be amazed by.
author: Bob M.

description:
I'd give it zero stars if I could mostly for the total arrogance of assuming that moms with multiple kids in tow with all their gear would be comfortable going somewhere with NO parking.  Well, there are some expensive metered spots across the way, but that means crossing a very busy street while trying to corral the kids.  The only other choice is to haul the kids, strollers, and all their stuff onto public transportation.  There's also no good, safe place for all the school buses to unload and then park while they wait for the kiddies, so expect lots more traffic problems and accidents on an already crowded street.

I don't think any real parents were on the planning committee for this travesty, just a bunch of politically correct, theoretical planners who designed a space that looks good in pictures without any regard for how it works in real life and without any reasonable access for real families with real kids.  Shame!
author: Chai K.

description:
So very, very sad. And disappointed. And sad.

I was really excited to visit the new Exploratorium location on Piers 15/17 and finally had the chance to do so today! However, I do not think I will be returning for at least several years. In my opinion, the old location was SO MUCH better.

While I realize this museum is probably intended for older children and adults, it used to be a place that even small children could enjoy. My husband and I took our 2 year old son a couple of years ago, and I have taken more than one kindergarten class on field trips. All trips were thoroughly enjoyable experiences, even with heavier crowds (like the ones on free days). 

Today we took my son (almost 5), and my daughter (2). The kids enjoyed the exhibits they could access.The outdoor spaces are very fun, and probably the highlight of our day. Overall, I think they had a good time, but it was just so crowded that it was difficult to access the exhibits and be able to spend any time "playing" with them, as there were people waiting and cutting in. As parents having to look after little ones, I will say it was a bit of a nightmare. VERY easy to lose a kid. I don't know what it is about the new location, but the feeling was different. Dark, low ceilings, just a weird ambiance. I just didn't like it. The old place felt friendlier, somehow. Because of the new location in a much more tourist-y area, I'm sure they will get much better attendance, but I think that is what took away from the overall experience. Just too many people. 

And the restaurants. Not impressed. At all. Expensive, few choices, crowded, and not very tasty. What's wrong with offering a place where you can get a simple turkey sandwich? Or PB & J for the kids. I'm all for offering more "cultured" options, but why throw out the "old standards" too? 

Add to this paying $20 to park, and it's just not worth it for us to go back until our kids are much, much older. And for that, I'm pretty bummed. The Exploratorium used to be one of my favorite places. Kicking myself for not taking one last trip before the old place closed. :(
author: Amy R.

description:
As outlined in my review of the California Academy of Sciences, my fiancee and I are very big science geeks. So when we looked at the what the CityPass included and noticed that there was an attraction right on the Embarcadero, we figured it was a no-brainer to buy and pay the Exploratorium a visit. 

Our original plan was to go on Monday, but when we arrived to purchase our CityPass we found out it was closed. No worries- we just spent the day in the area and rescheduled the visit. A few days later, we decided to head down to Pier 15 one more time to check out the Exploratorium. 

Like the CAS, the Exploratorium has exhibits from physics, geography and life sciences. I would say the biggest difference between the two is that the Exploratorium is MUCH more hands on. I loved how you could physically try out an attraction, then receive a brief but informative explanation as to what actually happened. This isn't your normal museum where you take in information. The Exploratorium is so much more, allowing you to actually experience the science for yourself, then learn the theory behind it. 

The building itself is huge. There are 6 sections (I believe), and each one has a particular theme. They also have an upstairs section dedicated to weather, with an observation deck overlooking the bay. Even though it was a Wednesday afternoon, the place was absolutely packed, which meant a lot of patience was required to not only wait for exhibits to free up, but also kids running around and bumping into you accidentally. I'm fine with the latter, but if you're not particularly fond of children I suspect you need to visit right at opening, or on a weekday when school's back in session.

Overall, my fiancee and I had a blast. We took our time (4 hours or so), and still missed out or sped through some of the really busy attractions.  My last comment is for the mainly volunteer workers scattered in the different sections offering more insight to the exhibits. I thought they were really engaging for both kids and adults, and they really looked and sounded like they loved being there. You could see the wonder and amazement in the childrens' faces when having something explained, and that sort of reaction is priceless for a place like the Exploratorium. Even the enthusiasm oozed in the gift shop. My one example was the following: as my fiancee and I were trying out an exhibit beside the gift shop, I suddenly heard a BOOM, followed by a rush of air. When I looked over, it was the cashier at the gift shop using an air cannon. He waved, then proceeded to shoot at my fiancee, who was startled to say the least. When I told her to look over, she laughed and we all waved at each other to say hello. 

It's places like these that help develop a child's curiosity in the sciences which hopefully keeps them engaged when learning the dry material served up in schools nowadays. Along with the CAS, the Exploratorium is a must-visit if you have children in grade school. Even if they aren't terribly interested in the sciences, I guarantee that they will leave the place with a better appreciation for the world around them.
author: Vincent A.

description: I really liked the new place. They kept some of the old stuff , but also created a lot of the new exhibits. Kids really enjoyed it. Could not cover everything in 3 hours that we spent there. Cafeteria/restaurant that they have their serves a wide variety of food and the food tastes good. A few creative surprises outside of the building, like a steam throwing bridge and a cool climbing structure for kids, make a nice conclusion to your visit to Exploratorium. Great addition to San Francisco's landmarks.
author: Jeff M.

description: Loved it. Perfect for me and my seven year old son. We spent about three hours in the museum and could easily have spent more, but we were I satisfied and eager to get outside. They do have some outside exhibits that are great, as well! Well priced for what they have. You should bring your own snacks and drinks as options are limited. Really fun!
author: Kristen B.

description: Love the new location: it doesn't feel crowded like it did at the palace.  Displays are well spaced and well lighted.  Everyone who works there wants to take the time to make sure you have a fun, interesting, educational time.  Bang it, push it, move it...just experience it! Ahem...anyway, the new location makes it so convenient that this little family can get there easily from the ferry building?  Working our two year family plus membership!  My only complaint: though I appreciate the huge upscale effort to improve the food options, it is very expensive and not very tasty.  Everything looks and sounds delicious, but has fallen short every time.
author: Heather L.

description:
My 11 year old son and I decided to go visit the new Exploratorium.  It had been a while since we had gone, and we wanted to see the new place, so off we went.

Traffic for the new location?  Miserable.  Embarcadero had one lane cut off for bicycle traffic, and the jam up ran all the way back to ATT park.  I had to use side streets in order to move at all.  That was pretty awful.

We finally got a place to park, very close to the museum.  It was $30 to park on a Sunday.  OK, fine.  I coughed up the money, and we walked over to the museum.

Once inside, since we were locals, it was $35 for the two of us to enter.  Wasn't this place free at one time?  Anyway, the people at the front desk were very very nice, all the employees were very nice.  

The exhibits were what they always have been, but I guess in the years of seeing the same sorts of things a few times now, they weren't all that exciting.  We pretty much buzzed through them and were done with the place in about 2.5 hours.  We tried to see a lecture on lasers, but the pace of the presentation was so slow and over-detailed that we left after about half an hour of droning.

We ended up back at the restaurant that faces the bay for lunch.  the food was very good, but everything cost about $9, so it was also pricey, making for another $30 for the two of us to eat.  I suppose there might have been lower cost options tucked away someplace there, but they were not obvious.

Given all this, it was not too surprising that the museum was not very crowded at all.  That was quite pleasant for us, but probably not too good for the museum itself.  We could walk up to everything with no wait, and I think that helped contribute to us being able to get through the whole place so quickly.

I think if you want to go to a science museum, you should go to the California Academy of Sciences in Golden Gate Park.  That is a much better experience at a much more reasonable price point for what it is.  

I can't really recommend the Exploratorium, unfortunately.  It's in a beautiful location, but it was difficult to get to, and over $100 for just two people for just a couple of hours.  They just recently had a layoff there due to crowds not being what they had hoped they'd be.  There's good reason for that.  It's just not worth the money or effort.
author: Jon N.

description: I Have been going to this place since I was a kid, before it moved. I loved going here then and I enjoy  it even more now that I can take my daughter here . This is just a great place for the family or friends to go spend the day. From my own experiences I find the light rooms to be the best.VERY PSYCHEDELIC!
author: Isaiah H.

description: Awesome place...especially if you have kids! The exhibits never get old. We have a family pass so come back often. Great that there are lockers for rent (cheap). The food is also good at the place near the entrance. I recommend the clam chowder. Definitely get the family pass if you plan on going more than once!
author: Steven E.

description:
This place isn't just for kids! On our trip to San Francisco, my boyfriend was excited to checkout the Exploratorium. We arrived on a Tuesday at 3PM. The place was a bit crowded at first but as it reached closing time at 5PM, there didn't seem to be too many groups left inside.

We purchased student tickets for $18 each. I showed them my student ID, however my boyfriend had left his at home. The cashier was very nice though and said she would still give him the student discount (:

The Exploratorium is essentially a very long room. You enter from the middle and can either go down to the right or left. There were so many different exhibits. Some were really cool, and though others weren't as interesting, everything was very informational and FUN. It can get a bit hectic with so many children running around. I bet this place can turn into a zoo on the weekends! But for a weekday, there were just enough people so that we never really had to wait to check out one of the displays.

My favorite exhibits were located on the lefthand side.

- The Lego Batman strobelight show!
You might miss it because it's tucked away behind a corner so be on the lookout. A scene of lego toys is set up to appear as though they are moving with the help of a strobelight and spinning platform.

- Camera + waterdrop
A highspeed DSLR is positioned at a cup that contains water. The observer controls at what point a water droplet will fall as the camera takes a photo. You end up with really interesting shots of the droplet suspended in the air to the point where it makes a splash in the water. Very neat, especially if you love photography!

- The very end of the lefthandside featured plantlife and information about the ocean, which was one of my favorite parts.

As I mentioned above, this is not just a place for kids to have fun! I saw young couples on dates and even elderly people on vacation enjoying all the fun the Exploratorium has to offer.
author: Courtney C.

description: Visited during one of the preview nights and "meh" pretty much sums it up. Seriously, there's nothing new or inspiring about the new location. An Academy of Science "ohhh awww".. it definitely wasn't. It was more like they packed up their rickety old toys and moved them into a warehouse with a view. Fortunately, the view is already free without reaching for your wallet. The $10 half cup of wine didn't help matters, either. While wandering around the soulless cavern, tripping over the "hidden" cords, each step was just a further reminder of how awkward the entire thing felt. Tourists will love it. Yay!
author: Michael A.

description:
Not as sweet and homey as the old Exploratorium, but there are lots of new exhibits and it never felt crowded. The three teenage boys who were with us absolutely loved it.

I gave three stars instead of five because the eating options displayed a callous disregard of the needs of families who don't have unlimited amounts of money to spend.  If you're visiting with kids, bring your own lunch, unless you're prepared to spend about $60 for lunch for a family of four. Not only was the food expensive, but there was little geared toward kids at either of the museum's two restaurants.
author: Carol R.

description: To hell with all the other negative reviews from snobby people,  this place is awesome. .. we stayed at a few other 4 star hotels in the city a few months back and this place beats all by far.  SUPER CLEAN SUPER FRIENDLY SUPER NICE... and its the hook up KINGS!! we got a standard on a 3rd party site,  I checked in in less than 2 minutes and was in my Deluxe Suite in less than 5 minutes... we ate staying here from now on!
author: Miles L.

description: An amazing museum for both kids and adults. It could even be a good place for a fun first date, really! My husband totally fit in with all the other kids and had a blast with all of the hands on experiments. It's a pretty large museum with lots to see and do, and I felt we got our money's worth.
author: Kaleena J.

description: Love the great new location! :) not too difficult to get to and crazy fun when you are here :) Price is reasonable considering all the exciting things you can do here to entertain your kids, students, and yourself haha. Highly recommend this place! :) explore everything from cool science to optical illusions to simply weird facts and things.
author: Olivia W.

description: As a 24 year old adult, visiting the Exploratorium with another 25 year old adult, we stayed here for five hours. Needless to say, this place is awesome. All the exhibits are just fun to let loose and experiment with like a kid again, and the price is a bargain for how long you can end up staying. We didn't even get to see every exhibit before closing time!
author: Laurie B.

description: I recently came to the Exploratorium with my kids and they loved it. Everything is hands on and you get to learn how things work. I recommend you have at least 2-3 hrs to explore because it's such a big place.
author: Inara A.

description: Amazing exhibits and great location on the pier. The exploratorium is both fun and educational and I really like that the exhibits are hands-on
author: Deanna L.

description: This new location seems much bigger and brighter than the previous one.  It is a great place to take the kids and learn some interactive science!   You can now find explantations in English, Chinese, and Spanish!
author: Tiffany H.

description:
It has been years since I'd been to the Exploratorium when it was located near the Palace of Fine Arts. I'd been home for the opening weekend and thought ok, when we come up for Memorial Day weekend I'd pass the tradition onto  my little one.  
Well I must say that the tradition stopped at the ticket line counter. Seriously almost $70 just for entry for the three of us??  Guess someone has to pay for the prime real estate, but given it's an educational and nonprofit, rather expensive to teach your kids about physics, and such.... oh but that's right someone has to pay for what our public education system stopped funding... but moving on...
Like many other said, there were quite a few of the old, same old exhibits. Although the toilet bowl fountain was rather cool. 
It certainly is huge. I did like the cool workshop with all the machinery that is now all replaced by automatics stuff in the the real world of factories.
We were there for about 3 hours. I didn't see the any advertisement for the cow eye dissecting exhibited and the big orange cone with the ball suspending in air.
Surprisingly we went on the Saturday of Memorial weekend. The place itself was not crowded, but getting there was. As Bay Area native, we took the train over from the East Bay, and took the F trolley (ok so we had to wait for 4 since they were so packed)
Did like the microscope exhibits, but how do you explain the bull sperm cell sample to the 6 year old. 
There was a cool lab exhibit with a huge baleen piece.
We ended up a the Skybar for a light lunch.. Light it was, but not one the wallet.
Sushi bar was great because it was made to order.
The gyrojungle gym was the biggest hit.
Please be prepared, that now that it on the toursity section of SF, i,e on the way to Pier 39, Fishermans' Wharf, that the visitors aren't always the most polite folks, or teach their kids the etiquette of manners, ie not cutting in line to the exhibit, not hogging the exhibit, etc.
But it is a cool nostalgia for those of us who grew up in the Bay Area during that time of field trips, as well as getting to kids to stop xboxing, ipading, etc for a few hours.
author: N L.

description: This would be a 5 star review but it's not really set up to entertain toddlers.  I hope to return one day when my son is a little older and really able to appreciate and explore the space and exhibits more fully.
author: Lisa I.

description: So much fun! A little over-stimulating but totally worth it! My husband and I came here and had just as much fun as all the kids running around. They also had lots of seating all over the place which was nice when my brain was on overload and needed a minute to chill. Also was nice to give my feet a rest. We spent quite a few hours here. Definitely worth the price to get in.
author: Katie W.

description: I love the new location it's huge ! If you're going, try to get there early so you can try out all the exhibits. Also, buy your tickets online so you don't have to wait in the long lines.
author: M G.

description: Great place!  We took our 7 yr old daughter, and she loved the hands on exhibits (of which thee are plenty). It's enjoyable for the adults too!
author: Justin S.

description: It's the bomb.  It will EASILY take an entre day to enjoy the whole place.  YOU will enjoy it so much.  Your kids will enjoy it.  Grand parents will enjoy it.  There may not be another place like it in the whole world.  And now it has re-located to its new phenomenally wonderful space at the Embarcadero which, by itself, is one of the most delightful places to be, stroll, eat, shop.  Go.  Do not have second thoughts.  This is so much fun.  Go and enjoy!
author: John H.

description: This is a great place to learn the afternoon away for all ages. When you take your time and experience all they have to offer its overwhelming. 99% of the employees are fun and helpful. It a great new location that offers room for additional exhibits.  Its a little pricey, but what isnt nowadays.  Its worth the money. Relax spend the day and open your mind. You'll love it.
author: Blake N.

description: This place is really really fun and I like fun. Not to mention very educational. I enjoy the ways the Exploratorium stretches the mind. There are so many interactive and fun different things to do and the variety of ages of people is really wide. I would recommend it for anyone over 10! I went with a big group and it was super comfortable doing your own thing or interacting with the activities with groups of people. I really enjoyed the way in which they interact with standardized thought.
author: Silas F.

description: Adult night is wonderfully fun. We went here for a date night and with drinks in tow, we had so much fun learning and playing. Seriously -- we probably didn't need the drinks to have that much fun but it was nice to just enjoy everything. It reminds me quite a bit of the New York Hall of Science or the Children's Discovery Museum of San Jose (but way more hands on activities).
author: Shauna S.

description: My boyfriend and I are full grown adults and we couldn't get enough of the west side of the Exploratorium.  In fact, we closed the place down after only enjoying a quarter of what this place has to offer in 3 hours.  It was an amazing nerd date and we plan to return.
author: Ashley W.

description: By far the coolest interactive mind blowing museum on the planet. No matter your age you'll be fascinated.
author: James C.

description: If you're a science geek that happens to be in San Francisco you must stop by this spot. It reminds me of the childrens museum I went to when I was a kid in DTLA. Admission for adults is $20. It has a lot science projects that adults and kids can try out. However I find this place to be more geared towards the science aficionados and kids. Though the experiments are very interesting and fun, I eventually got bored and tired out after walking around and trying out all the projects. So if you have time to kill or have kids, definitely drop by this place.
author: Casey P.

description:
We attended the Thursday night adults only session and it was fantastic. An absolute highlight of our San Francisco experience. I would advise to buy tickets online rather than get them at the door to avoid the massive queue. 
If we had gone during the day, it would have been filled with kids and hard interact with the exhibits, so it was great.
A perfect date activity!!!
author: Luke S.

description: Thoroughly enjoyed this.  Best  place around for kids.  So many things to explore, touch and do.  Very fun.  Highly recommended.
author: Aerin L.

description:
Wow, new place is truly awesome! Loads of new exhibits. I was a fan of the old place, but there is so much MORE to do & play with at the new location. Gorgeous setting on water, cleaner & lighter--but still the hands-on, "play til you drop" atmosphere. 

Parking was easy at the lot across the street (tho SF prices$$).  
No waiting, no lines to get in--Exploratorium has figured out great processes to manage crowd/demand. Very glad we didn't wait for a few weeks after opening as a friend had suggested.  The place is so huge inside and out, it didn't feel crowded, even on opening weekend.

What a great spot to spend a lunch hour during the week & recharge batteries.
Aslo great date night spot, esp Thursday nights for adults only (they sell alcohol).

Have to mention the FOOD--I actually would not eat or let my kids eat the food at the old location. The new restaurant, Sea Glass, at the water end and the small cafe right  near the street both have AMAZING food, locally sourced, organic, lots of fresh seafood, a full bar.  The Sea Glass is a SF caliber eatery.  So plan to eat when you  visit.
author: Mary A.

description:
The new exploratorium is to the old one like New York is to Cleveland. 

The main concept remains the same, the old exhibits your kids grew up with are still there, but much is added, and the cave feeling is gone.  Being on a pier, there are breathtaking views of the water  (not just the oyster bar) and feeling of endless space.

The place is so large that it seem impossible to see it completely filled with people.  Yet it will be.

Unlike the pretty Academy of Sciences where one can look at fish, sure, but has not much to *do*, there is so much to do here that at the end of the day you will wonder where the time went and it will be impossible to drag the kids out by the ankles.  

And speaking of kids, don't even bring them. That is, they are not the main reason to go. I brought mine and they had a great time, but really there is so much to do and learn for  anyone.  If anything there are many more exhibits geared towards a kid of advanced age, and, at times one feels more like participating in some crazy conceptual art at MOMA.

The place stays true to it's original vision of not dumbing anything down, and really leaving the exhibits speak for itself, so you might actually need your 5 year old demonstrate how stuff works. 

There will be some that will miss the village feel of the old Exploratorium, but that's like missing the Embarcadero Freeway.
author: Lucy Z.

description: Wow! Something for everyone - interesting and innovative. Our company party took place here - perfect venue for our large group.
author: Vicki L.

description:
Wow!!!

We got there just after opening, left at closing and Didn't get to see the whole place, way too much fun for kids and the big kid at heart!!!

Science was Never this much fun at school!! 

Totally recommend for all ages!!! I need to go again to finish the tour. Went in middle of Summer break, place was packed with people, but didn't feel too crowded. Reasonable entry fee, great day out...
author: Michael L.

description: Great place for kids. Even better deal on site when you visit first time. Can convert the first visiting fee to annual membership. Now even have on-site $125 promotion for a family one year membership .
author: Kyle T.

description: What a fantastic place!  So many hands-on exhibits.  It's too bad we didn't have more time to play around with the exhibits, but still a 5-star experience nonetheless.
author: Kent I.

description: So much to do that I don't mind going again next time I'm in the city. If I lived in san fran or Oakland I would totally look into the yearly pass. I hear the Exploratorium after dark is 21 and over. you must pay a visit if you're from out of town!
author: Bernard K.

description: I was so excited to check out the new Exploratorium on the free day. Well I got there late had an hour to walk through, it was crowded and not as exciting as I remembered when it was at the old location. I would think it would be fun for kids but not for me. I like the Academy of Science a million times better.
author: Karen T.

description:
As a two year member, I went with my family for the member's preview on Saturday, March 31st.  The new Exploratorium is amazing.  The new space is slick and very well done.  All your favorite hands-on exhibits are back with a large number of new ones.

It does look like parking will be much more of a challenge than it use to be at the Palace of Fine Arts.  However, it is nice being able to walk to the ferry building or Pier 39 with the kids.  A definite must do for families in or visiting S.F.
author: William N.

description: The best museum in San Francisco for exploring science and art. The new location on the waterfront (Pier 15) is spectacular.
author: Jeff H.

description: Awesome place to bring kids! My wife had read to go in the afternoon, after all of the school field trips had left, which turned out to be wise advice. Best kids museum we've been to! My son loved this place! He's under 10, but over 5. He liked it so much, we went two days!
author: Chris P.

description: Very cool and loads of fun. Go alone or with a friend and play. Love the pier home, fits right in!
author: Traci H.

description: My kids spent hours tryin every experiment this place has!   Great buy definite go back place in fact the season pass is totally worth it!
author: R C.

description: Finished up our 2 day visit today. There is simply an overwhelming amount of cool things to do here so we split it up into 2 partial days. You could probably do it in one, but after a while you start to suffer from sensory overload. It's in a great location on Pier 15 with stunning views of the Bay, Treasure Island and the Bay Bridge. It's a must for locals and tourists alike.
author: Scott G.

description: The Exploratorium is a fantastic hands-on science museum. Really cool for kids and grown ups. If you are in San Fran don't miss it. Be prepared to sown some cash... It's not cheap. $77 for two adults + 8 yr old. Probably could get discount tkts at AAA but we didn't. Plan to spend a good 2-3 hours here.
author: Mary A.

description:
After a very long time in its planning and construction period, and few event parties and some other private affairs, "The Exploratorium" is finally open to the public.  

I was surprised that while there has been some existing exhibits that they had carried from the previous location, there are quite a lot of new exhibits.  Even better, is that they organized their display into general themed areas and every single of the descriptions are clearly marked, easy to read, and well described.   If you can read basic English you will be able to fully follow the listed experiments, know what to expect and likely apply to something  in your day to day life.  
Physics (light, waves and forces) are well covered.  Sciences are wonderfully covered and even Social Psychology is also very well covered and super interesting.   Sound, waves, perspectives, all were also covered along with biology, chemistry and similar sciences.  I felt like I walked away learning a bunch of new stuff that even though I might not use on an everyday basis, I could apply it to various applications.   

Hungry, thirsty or just want to snack on a little bit lunch?. No problem... simply go to the cafe for a great selection of foods.         Rather pack a lunch and enjoy eating along side the pier with million dollar views of San Francisco Bay.

I want to mention that "The Exploratorium" is within what I would call an award winning building.  Architecturally it is amazing.   Even better, the spaces are perfectly defined as so are the ways people can interact in the provided space.   There is a perfect balance flights and the flooring selection has great resiliency that doesn't cause you walk around and get too tired.  When you do come to visit, be sure to give yourself lots of time when coming over, the various experiments are very interesting and fun for both adults and kids.
author: Tito Y.

description: One of the most impressive place that I enjoyed together with my children, which we revisited many times over several years, and continued making new discoveries as ell as just were having fun.
author: Vadim D.

description: Excellent museum with many fun, interactive exhibits. Best to go on a weekday when it won't be as crowded
author: Kevin S.

description: My first review on an event space/local attraction.  Growing up I've always remembered the iconic Exploratorium located in the Marina, next to the Palace of Fine Arts.  Since its move, the location is even more beautiful: located right near the bay, and public transit is very convenient.  The Exploratorium has its popular, crowd favorites (ex: shadow box, pillar illusion with the man silhouette in between pillars, bike wheel chair, mirror looking like you're cut off, cow's eye dissection presentation, etc.) and added many more "experiments" since its move.  One new crowd favorite is the toilet water fountain in which one looks like you're drinking "toilet water"; another is that in the shadow box visitors can use their flashlight apps on their smartphones to trace their own silhouette or draw something after their "shadow" has been taken.   There are many activities for all ages, though I'd probably take them at youngest 6 - 7 years. when they're old enough to understand at least how basic science works.  After your visit, take a casual walk or exercise along the Embarcadero, stop by a restaurant for coffee or a meal, or visit the Ferry Building's shops and eateries.  Would like to return to experience the Night Life sights and sounds.
author: Jessica S.

description: Tons of fun! And it was educational. This is what I think every museum should aspire. Not to hit you over the head with facts, but inspire you to want to learn and spark an interest. So many great exhibits. Highly recommended with friends or a date on the Thursday adult times.
author: Ali B.

description: This place is amazing! I love that they have so many things to do for kids. Well, not just the little ones, but also the big kids. I'd say if you failed physics in high school, this place has some great gadgets and set-ups to tinker with and help you understand the idea behind them. We walked here from the Fisherman's Wharf where we stayed at the Sheraton and it was no more than 30 mins by the Embarcadero. You can walk or take the F line cable car for less than 15 minutes.  Highly recommended for families with more than a couple of Hildren to entertain. It takes a couple of hours to check everything and it will surely keep them busy.
author: Barbara H.

description: So much fun! Too much to do. We went after lunchtime, and an escape from the rain, and felt like we could have spent the whole day there! We were with our 10 month old, who slept the whole time we were there, but me and my husband had a blast anyways! There was a safe-ish place to leave our stroller outside, but still lots of room to navigate the stroller inside.  Check out the LIVE chicken embryos....also, the ticket guy hooked us up, deals for locals and finally a discount for TEACHERS! Looking forward to more visits with our daughter as she grows up.
author: Mallory R.

description: Nice place for the kids.  Try and go on an unpopular day and time. It can be quite busy.  Adults may just have a little fun as well.  Tons of hands on!
author: Chuck B.

description: My family always stops by this place when we are in San Francisco. All the hands-on exhibits are fun for the whole family. When I have been here on the weekends it is super full so be prepared to encounter a bunch of kids running around. Their new location (at the Embarcadero) is a nice change because you can always catch a cab without a problem. So be ready to get your thinking caps on and learn new science facts.
author: Miriam Z.

description: My husband, son and I along with our 3 grandsons visited the new exploratorium recently. I was quite a fan of the old Exploratorium and definitely resistent to the move. I must say, it was a good move. The displays are plentiful, including most of the ones from the old venue, with quite a few new ones. The building is well designed and I was impressed to read that it is almost as earthquake resistant as hospitals. The back (or front?) of the building is a deck on the water with gorgeous views of the bay. And the restaurant is outstanding. We all had a great time. The exhibit where you look into some kind of 3d mirror shows you upside down, a really cool treat of a trick to experience. Consider this a rave review.
author: Barbara S.

description: When I first stepped into this place, the first thing I thought of was how much it reminded me of the Discovery Center back at home in Orange County. If you have children, this would be an awesome place to bring them. I just felt a little out of place because I am older... All in all, the staff here is friendly. There's a lot you can do. One of my favorite was playing with the plants that bloomed/wilted when you touch it. I definitely need to come back here when I have children of my own.
author: Jennifer N.

description: Not impressed. Way too many dirty little kids running around. The exhibits... not intelligent at all. California academy of science is probably better.
author: Ryan H.

description:
Overrated.

Fun, but if limited time, many more options in the city.  This was our most expensive event as a family and we should have just wondered the city.  We only had a day and a half, maybe if we had 5 days in SF, Exploratorium would have been worth half a day.
author: Mike M.

description: I don't think I've ever been to a place quite like the Exploratorium. I am now happy to say that I've been. What a great time for kids, young and old. Anyone who enjoys experiencing things hands on, will love it. I think we were there for under 2 hours, and could've stayed for 4 more. Really, there are a ton of exhibits for a variety of interests. My 2 year old was thrilled from start to finish. Your kids will go home happy.
author: Matthew H.

description: Amazing place and absolutely beautiful. There is always something new to see or discover here at the exploratorium. There are neat tricks with some exhibits and cool demonstrations from explainers going on all the time. This place is not just a science museum, there are many wonderful art exhibits as well. The view of the bay bridge lights on Thursday nights are amazing from the new observatory. Fun for kids and adults, it is definitely up there as one of my favorite places to be in the city!
author: Wells Y.

description: Crowded but FUN, FUN, FUN! I LOVED my visit! Go early, because there's lots to see and do. Me & my sweetie didn't get to complete our visit because there just wasn't enough time! Minus one star for closing so early--5pm on a Saturday? Really? I can't wait to go back!
author: Rox M.

description: This new location is incredible!!  I hadn't been to the exploratorium in years, and well here you go in this awesome new location.  Two stories, spread out, great veiws at night time when it's clear, and a really good cafe, the food is kind of pricey, when I was there at the cafe, I just grabbed a soda. Going here brought back memories of when I was younger.
author: Peter J.

description: I came here for the after dark experience. It's a great deal because prices to get in is slightly cheaper than a normal admission day. You get access to the whole museum and all the exhibits. I guess wherethey make their money is with the drinks and food. They are overpriced, but that's to be expected. They dont check bags, sooooooo you could potentially bring a bit of something something. I brought a sandwich I bought close to work. I've been to the academy of sciences nightlife and personally I like that the academy of sciences is nature concentrated. The exploritorium is more hands on with their exhibits and physics orientated. That is only one aspect that sets them a part from the academy of sciences. Overall I'm glad I came to experience after dark. I wish I went to more of their talks and if they were more frequent or even on a different day. It's a great place to go to right after work to hang out with friends. Learn a bit here and there with a drink or two in hand or in your bag. Makes learning fun and interesting.
author: Christina L.

description: We visited on a special members' admittance day to the museum which remains uncompleted. But I can tell it's going to be terrific. The Official Grand Opening is in two weeks and I'll be back. It's just across the street from my condo! It's a beautiful addition to the waterfront. Especially love the Explainers Program.
author: Paula H.

description: Great place but gets way too crowded for my liking
author: Max P.

description: This place is the BEST. Seriously I've been there 7 times (I'm an adult) and I've seen something new every time. Thursday nights are adults only and there's beer and wine. Great staff. Fabulous exhibits. Never fails to totally amaze.
author: Sophie G.

description: cool place I went here and they let me explore a lot of things. my favorite thing to explore was the pin thing bc u can put ur hand on it and the pins look like ur hand so it looks cool. also there is this part with a big bubble and bubbles are round
author: Charles Y.

description: Love this place, great location and ample to do for everyone. Whether you have kids or not, this place will def. amuse you.  Be warned that you cannot see ALL the exhibits there in one day, the place is massive.  I take my kid there at least once a month.  If you have time, make sure to check this place out.
author: C L.

description: Went here today and had a awesome time. Perfect for all ages.
author: Cassie M.

description: We used our SF citypass and chose this one instead of the De Young Museum. BIG MISTAKE! It was full of kids and very few exhibits were available. This is very good for kids and parents, but not a couple esp. non science people like us. We have experienced such museums before so nothing new. The cafe was only half operating so had to go outside to get something to eat.
author: S B.

description: One of the best places for kids of all ages to spend a whole day learning using ALL the senses! I have been going since I was a kid, taken my kids and now my grandkids.  Now I am a donor.
author: Kathy P.

description: Best views of the Bay Bridge from the outside cafe seating.  Secret spot for a tasty lunch.
author: Truth Mama B.

description: Granted we are grown ups, and this place is full of little kids butting in on my fun like they run the place, we still had a good time!  I would really like to try out the Thursday night 18+ events... Maybe next trip.
author: Roofy T.

description: Ha this place is great! I went on a Wednesday night at 8pm and left at 10pm because they were closing but had no idea I would need atleast 4-5 hours to explore the entire place completely! Was rushing through with my best friend. Paid the student price cant remember how much but it seemed a little expensive ha but paying for cool fun. Thank goodness we went on a night though when there werent a bunch of little kids running around. I cant even imagine that place during the day it would be a mad house with kids running everywhere. But it is really worth a visit
author: Kyle R.

description: What a fantastic Sunday morning spent at the Exploratorium. Plenty to keep the 3 nephews (10 -15 yo) busy and happy. Place gets crazy by noon, but still fun to interact with the other kids.
author: Monster B.

description: Fun Fun Fun. Even for not-kids. I went with my friend (we're both 20+) and we stayed for hours.
author: Lilian K.

description: So much fun! My husband and I spent a Tuesday afternoon here and had a blast. Everything is hands on and it's a great place to learn and nerd out. Yes, there are ton of kids running around but it's def worth a visit.
author: Kelly T.

description: I am definitely a fan here! There is so much to do here and you feel like you just want to hop from one activity to another, there is just so much to learn. The prices do vary if you are a local or out of town so let them know you're from the area and if you're going there with kids then kids under 5 is free I believe. Need a place to take the kids while babysitting? Here would probably be a good choice. I had so much fun here and will come back again. Everything was very hands on and it is great for all ages. I want to try out their night life on Thursday too. Only con about this place is that there is validation for a smaller fee at certain location, BUT it has to be AFTER 4pm I believe. If you do get there early then parking across the street with valet (required for that lot) is $5 an hour for the first 4 hours before a certain time. Basically parking is the most challenging thing you'll have to go through once you get here. Also check out the view from their dock, you can see the new I-80 bridge!
author: Kathy T.

description: There is sooo much to do here, you would have to get there really early to do it all and you need a lot of energy to deal with how much your kids are going to run around, trying everything. Definitely consider your children's ability to read because without understanding what you're doing and supposed to be producing, the exhibits could be confusing and a bore. But when you understand what the exhibit is for and is supposed to teach, it will definitely restore your wonder in the science world. The restaurant has a long line most of the time and the nicer food is down the road about a half mile of a walk (really not much compared to all the walking you'll do in the Exploratorium) and there's a little mall of specialty shops nearby too. You'll have a great time exploring all the fun exhibits.
author: Manda H.

description: Best museum in the world? Fantastic exhibits. I never leave myself enough time for the Exploratorium. Can't wait to go to one of their After Dark events.
author: Gina C.

description: This place is really well designed.  But it is not for the 5 and under set in my opinion.  While there's lots of things to "play" with, the concepts were far too advanced for them to understand and they ended up being bored even though that's the last thing they should have been.
author: Laura E.

description: Was here two consecutive days. Yesterday, with my son, and today with 2 mite kids in tow. We love this place! So much bigger and better than the old location at Palace of Fine Arts. With all those adults and kids touching the exhibits, I wish they would place antibacterial dispensers throughout the place though...hence the lack of 1 star.
author: November C.

description: Go there Thursday night! It's the perfect combination of science and fun and alcohol without a bunch of kids running around and screaming. If you plan to come here on Thursday night with your friends, and they say no. GET NEW FRIENDS. Thats how good this place is.
author: Duo C.

description: I love it here! I feel like a kid again when I come in here. They have many of the same exhibits from the old location, and also a bunch of new exhibits. My kids loved it and had a blast running around exploring everything. The location is beautiful and is just a 15 min. walk from BART. I would really like to go to their After Dark hours on Thursday just so I can look around without the kiddos. I bought the year membership and will be putting it to good use this year.
author: Liz P.

description: Price is about right - if you live in the Bay Area, don't forget you can get $5 off tickets with your ID.  Clearly it's a fun place for people of all ages but it does attract more kids or families with kids.  I would imagine they have "adults only" times or dates which would have probably been a bit more fun for me as I get overwhelmed with the running around, screeching and general gooeiness of kids...but that's because I'm old and grumpy!
author: Shannon L.

description:
I took my niece and nephew here today. It was quite packed for a Tuesday, but then again it is summer. Though I was born and raised here in SF, I never got to visit the old Exploratorium @ Palace of Fine Arts (I know, what a shame!) so I wasn't too sure of what to expect. It was pretty overwhelming as there are sooo many things to do and see! Like we got there maybe 3 hours before closing and still didn't get to see everything even after skipping some parts of the exhibits due to things being occupied and such. I think I took the kids here at too young of an age (4 and 6) because there wasn't too many things they could do, things they didn't know what to do with or understand but they still had fun with all the buttons, levers, lights and all that. Definitely recommended for older elementary kids and up. 

I assume that it's less packed during the non-summer months but based on my experience -if you're planning to come out during the summer, plan to be in there for at least 4 hours if you'd like to see everything and take some quick breaks. And please parents, have your kids behave and/or beware if I'm in there because I almost went to whoop this one kid for purposely pushing the table where my niece and nephew were building towers. Mm hmm. Don't think I wont!!!!

Totally looking forward to coming back here [on a much less crowded time if that will ever exist] to see what I've missed -without the kids ..and then later on when the kids are old enough :) Fun experience.
author: Mila B.

description: This place would be a great place for kids.  For adults, it's just OK.  A word of advice, get there early or else you will have to wait in a long line to get in.  I think it was $25 for adults?  Well luckily, the cashier only charged us for 1 ticket, and either she was too lazy to change it or was too nice to charge us again, so she gave us 2 tickets for the price of 1!  You go in and it's what you'd expect... A lot of exhibits and things to touch and look at and play with, but nothing crazy cool.  Most of it's common sense stuff, but other things are kind of cool.  Kids running everywhere, but none of them were crazy.  Everything you touch is covered in dirt and germs so you feel like you want to shower right after.
author: Easter E.

description: We had a great time here! We bought San Francisco's citypass and it included this museum. There's so much to see. Everything's interactive and it'll keep you entertained. After 2.5 hrs, we were pretty much done. We just browsed thru the rest. We didn't have any kids with us so we managed to go thru the museum within 3 hrs. Definitely fun for all ages. We visited on a Sunday and the museum didn't feel overly crowded.
author: Jenn R.

description: This place is pretty cool. There are many hands on things for kids of all ages. They showcase a lot of different areas of since and technology which is very educational. There is so much that u will wanna allow at least a whole day to check out all 6 galleries of activities
author: Nate C.

description:
Wow, what an incredible place.  Our kids learn so much.  We became members because it is SO awesome, especially in the new location.  My daughter was riveted listening to the cow eye dissection lecture and demonstration.  Two highly knowledgeable young women did the demonstration and it was fantastic!  My kids wanted to stay there all day.  We only get through a small part of the place on each visit the kids are so engaged and learn so much.  

We went on a weekend and it wasn't that crowded.  Taking the ferry from the East Bay is the way to go--then walk from the Ferry Building.  Or we've parked on the street over by the Embarcadero and then walked over, it's a pleasant walk.  
Thanks Exploratorium!
author: Alicia M.

description: This is a great place to take little guys for a variety of hands on fun and learning.
author: Josh B.

description: Bigger, larger, new exihibits.  Great for kids and adults.  Great easy to get to location by car, Muni and BART.  Easy street parkiing if you get there first thing in the morning, take BART, get off at Embarcadero and walk 5 minutes or take F train and stop right in front.  Holler.
author: Chris R.

description: Finally, the Exploratorium is super convenient to get to! Easy to take BART in from the East Bay and walk from Embarcadero. Great place for nerdy little kids (as mine are) to explore and learn. My son's favorite is the toilet water fountain (he is 4). The attached restaurant is also amazing. Worth going just to eat at that place (and you can access the restaurant without needing to get into the Exploratorium). Go for the annual pass if you think you will want to come more than twice in a year (and you will).
author: Bill J.

description:
Exploratorium, I missed you when you were gone. Now that you're back, I miss the old you. The new Exploratorium is dysfunctional and chaotic. 

I am a firm believer that form follows function. The new Exploratorium had a great opportunity to create the best experience in a great location in one of the best cities in the world. They used the best architects, project managers and consultants. They had access to great customer feedback. But they blew it! The museum succeeded merely at proving how poor design, drives customers away (and conversely, how great design is good for business).

The new Exploratorium looks nice from the outside but enter the doors and welcome to chaos. Once passing through the admission line you enter the exhibit area. The exhibit guide/map identifies distinct areas focusing on well-selected science and technology topics. But, as you wander through the museum, identifying which area you are in is impossible. The signage is very subtle and hardly existent and the boundaries between areas are ill-defined. There are lots of twists and turns in order to navigate the exhibits; a perfect way to lose your child. Although the museum claims to be bigger than the old museum near the Palace of Fine Arts, the ceilings are lower and the noise level is much higher. The result is a feeling of being closed in. Now add a mass of people, mostly kids of course, and you end up chasing your kids through crowds of other adults and kids equally trying to keep track of each other. I went to the museum with my wife, our 12 year old son, my brother, his three 11 year olds (yes, triplets) and my father (grandpa). We took the strategy of each adult being assigned to keep track of one kid. The crowds, the noise, the twists and turns made tracking just one kid feel like an endurance sport. I can't imagine having to keep track of two or more.

Again, the aesthetic is very nice but I am shocked that the fire department approved the design. From the western part of the exhibit floor you see a great big wall of glass between you and the entrance from the Embarcadero. The catch is that there is no door in the glass wall and the nearest exit is subtly placed off to the side. Imagine a frantic crowd in the face of emergency running toward the exit only to be blocked by a thick sheet of glass with no clear way out. This is yet another great example of form preceding function and a perfect formula for more chaos in the face of an emergency.

So, after 1-1/2 hours my son and his three cousin couldn't take any more of the crowds, the noise and the waiting to use the exhibits. The kids wanted to leave! My son used to spend 3-6 hours in the old Exploratorium at least a half dozen days each year. After his first visit to the new museum he stated that he is not interested in coming back; unfortunately, I am fine with his request.

Now for the good things: 
- Individually, the exhibits are great; both the new and the old.
- Enabling the visitors to see the machine shop in action was very smart. 
- Creating a net zero energy building is great. 
- Updating another SF pier is nice to see.

My dad is a scientist, my brother an engineer and program manager, my wife a designer and I'm a project manager and industrial designer. We all love great, thoughtful design, science and technology. I can't express how excited we were to explore the new museum and how disappointed we were after visiting. So good luck Exploratorium, my old friend. I wish you the best.
author: Phil A.

description:
I visited the Exploratorium this week as I knew my visiting grandsons, ages 7 and 9, would enjoy it.  They certainly did, until they just got tired. It is certainly a place that for children requires repeated, and probably shorter visits (not all day). As my grandsons and their family are moving overseas, I am sad that their repeat visits are not possible.

BUT - FAMILIES - PLAN TO BROWN BAG  and eat outside on the Pier deck.  As the primary audience is for children, we were startled and dismayed by the menus offered by the Exploratorium partner-eateries on site, the Seaglass restaurant and Sonic Joint Cafe. They are run by the same business. Neither offered a child menu i.e. all offerings and prices are adult size. Also the food selections, while no doubt tasty, simply were not healthy, quick-meal, family-oriented.  We finally went outside and found one cart at the Pier that produced grilled cheese sandwiches but nothing else.  Those sandwiches were good but the predominant Exploratorium visitor base needs easy access to family-friendly eateries. 

I agree with a prior commenter that there is much here for adults of any age but don't expect to enjoy those exhibits if you have children with you.  It is good too that entry prices are discounted for Bay Area resisdents and are reasonable and appropriate to encourage repeat visits.
author: Eileen M.

description: I give it a 4 star mainly because they should have kept the exploratorium back at the palace of fine arts. It would have saved tourists time and gas going back to view the gorgeous palace. Anyways this place you need a good 4 hours to view and experiment with most of the physical experiments. Idk about taking children 5 and under to this place mainly because its more about learning reading and doing and also understanding the purpose of the experiment. I recommend taking hand sanitizer as everyone touches every experiment. There is children running everywhere and cutting in front of you while you do or see the experiment which sucks because your looking into it and whoosh comes a child and so rudely cuts you off. Where are the parents at? Geez. There is two shops where they sell souvenirs.  I recommend the shop on the outside of the museum since it contains more adult souvenir items.  My experience overall was a 4 star.
author: Steph_b00 B.

description:
We went on PI day which is 3/14, and it was a free museum admission day.  My kids had the day off from school as it was a staff planing day so it made sense to do some fun interactive learning on their day off in the city.  We spent 5 hours there and sadly learned more about how crazy some people are than from their science exhibits.  I guess it was a lesson in social dynamics and how important crowd control could be if utilized effectively.  When we got in line to get our free tickets, they asked for a donation which we were happy to support them with.  However, now when I look back at today's experience, I think we should have gone on a regular admission day to pay the regular admission fee or better yet to become a member at the museum to avoid the hordes associated with "free days."  Everyone and their mama's mama's mama come on these days and then some so a lot of waiting around to be skipped and pushed out of the way.  We had a few bad experiences with the ruckus crowd so we just chilled at the outside cafeteria and kid's play area for most of the day.  We'll wait for a less crowded day (hence not a free day), and when the kids are older to come back.

One much older girl felt the need to come from behind and push all the buttons on a display my daughter was trying to use.  It's like my little five year old girl had four arms working the four button controls.  Then when I politely asked the girl if she could wait her turn.  Honey Boo Boo's Mama yelled "You idiot, don't talk to her.  She's just a child" from another station.  She was not even at the same station we were at watching her child.  She was one of those long distance mamas.

Oh excuse me for telling someone to mind their manners.  So I just took my little girl to a different station not knowingly and unfortunately meeting Honey Boo Boo's other relative (a grown man) who was in the process of snatching a piece from my son's hand to make a lever contraption.  Again, I can not repeat how annoying it was to watch a grown man taking a piece of plastic block from my seven year old son's hand.  A lack of patience is served everywhere here so I recommend an older child who may be able to handle the disappointment of not being able to learn the science behind the exhibits due to rude and disrespectful kids and adults alike.

By this time, I just stood silent because I have ESP, and I just knew this was that type of hill billy moment when another hill billy would cause some ruckus.  Yes, these hill billies were all starting to stand out, and my bad that I bumped into the first hill billy's relatives or close friends/neighbors.

Soon after Mama June #2 started yelling "Oh this Mama hits kids" repeatedly while staring at me.  I'm thinking "WTF?!  Who are these people?  Do I know you?  Am I getting punked for the Hee Haw series at the Exploratorium?"

Later on I realized that the two Mama Junes knew each other as they were waddling together with a trailer park full of kids.  Gosh this free day at the museum let me down and these hill billies almost ruined it for us.  I really wanted to speed dial my buddy Roscoe P. Coltrane to sort this nonsense out, but I kept my cool.

We did see some friends and their kids.  We marched in the PI parade and got some delicious pie to eat to celebrate Albert Einstein's birthday.  We looked out for hill billies for the rest of the day by hiding outside in the sun and we survived.  Thank goodness we have some color to us so we didn't burn on that sunny day.

Anyway, another Dad (who I shared this story with because he told some older kids not to skip his younger kids and my child) told me that he was surprised that I didn't hit one of those crazy LSD acid mushroom eating tripping mamas that day as they were so full of imagination.  I'm sure if those two mamas talked to another one of their mama friends then the story would have been translated into something like I had killed a kid and stuffed him/her in an exhibit at the Exploratorium.  Yeah, their telephone skills were not that great with their story changing along the way each time. Anyway, the other Dad (who I shared my story with) made me laugh when he jokingly said he would have hit somebody for all that nonsense.  Nice to know that not everyone has forgotten their manners or their voice to speak out for their younger kids.

Yes, we were the bigger persons for just ignoring the crazies, and I'm thinking somebody must have woken up on the wrong side of the barn or ate some day old plus roadkill or something.  A bad case of telephone or faulty mental reception from the 1st dopey mama reporting a fire to the 2nd loopy mama when it was just a firefly.

So you're welcome, you've been warned about these free museum days.  Go at your own and your kid(s) risk, but be forewarned that it's better to pay upfront or else you'll end up paying later.  So yeah, Happy Birthday Albert Einstein, but we'll be celebrating your birthday at home and not at the Exploratorium in the future.
author: Maggie L.

description: Expensive admission and a dull, non-involving, self guided tour of science. Let me preface this review by stating that I'm an adult and I went alone... So I know I'm not the prime audience. However, if I had a child I would have a hard time interesting them in the values of science and the world if wonder with the various trinket-lesson stations. At a whopping $29 for adults I was expecting captivating, visually stunning, and complex machines. Instead, I got a tour through a tinkerer's garage at what amounts to a small bag of science related tricks. Where's the Bill Nye type personable scientist blowing up things and talking about what made that happen? Where is the 3d printing machine and live demo and exhibition? Where is the well rounded guide through each theory? There is plenty to learn about science basics for a 8 yr old but you'd do better to set up experiments in your backyard from YouTube and save your family $100 for 4. If this place wants to truly define science exploration it needs bigger, badder exhibits that fully explore the past and future of technology. Otherwise the price needs to be $8... Because that's the roof of what this was worth.
author: Curtis M.

description: Cleaner and smells better than the original location. Lots of new exhibits mixed in with the classics so there is much to do and see. Have been here twice, today with just my niece and once in June on a field trip with 300 middle school students. I am/was amazed that though so many people are in the Exploratorium, it does not feel overcrowded.  I am concerned that some parents do not supervise their children and allow them to run across the halls or on the stairs almost knocking over younger and older people alike. Kids will be kids, but why does a parent stand there and do/say nothing when their child shoves others out of their way because they cannot wait their turn? I also do not feel that it is staffed enough to provide supervision and safety for its guests. I see a lot of staff cleaning, but not many circulating encouraging children to interact with exhibits or to re-focus those disorderly children into more positive interaction. This is a great place for children to come and explore and get interested in science. Unfortunately, people should remember that it is also a shared space and should be respectful of all and their right to enjoy all the Exploratorium has to offer...we need to remember to take turns and not push others out of the way. Please, Thank You, and I'm Sorry goes a long way when so many diverse groups of people all converge into one venue.
author: Carrie W.

description:
We hadn't been to the Exploratorium since it moved from The Palace of Fine Arts to Pier 15, so we were eager and looking forward to the visit. We arrived at 11:15, found parking at Broadway & Embarcadero for $25 for the day ($20 if we had arrived before 11am), and walked the 2 minutes to the Exploratorium. Definitely like this location better. We saw a *long* line at the entrance for buying the tickets. We did a quick math and figured it works out cheaper to buy the family membership if we'd visit more than once next year, which we would, and took the shorter line to buy membership and enter. We got a cool messenger bag as a sign up gift - score!

The layout is lengthwise and not circular, and we immediately noticed that there was much more space around each exhibit, allowing us to watch better while waiting, which adds to the fun. There were many familiar exhibits and many new ones too. Though there were a lot of visitors today, we didn't have to wait at most exhibits. Somehow, even the familiar exhibits seemed a lot bigger, must be the new design. I won't go into the exhibits, but suffice to say that they were interesting to elementary school kids, high schoolers and adults. We were usually in the same area, but we each did what interested us the most, and grouped up whenever we ran into each other at an exhibit. We grossly underestimated the time we would need to visit all 600 exhibits. In the 5 hours we spent there, I doubt we even covered 25% between the four of us. We were really glad we bought the family membership, and realized we need more than 2 trips next year just to make sure we visited each exhibit at least once. 

It closed at 5 sharp, wish it stayed open longer. We walked to the ferry building, got ourselves something warm (coffee, hot chocolate), and walked around sampling olive oil & variety cheese. We bought some bread to go with the oil and cheese we bought, pulled up some chairs and a table, and had a simple but satisfying dinner before walking back to our car. Again - love the new location! We'll be back before not too long!!!
author: Vidhya H.

description:
Never have so many with so much done so little. 

The quality of the Exploratorium concept far outpaces the quality of it's implementation, and the new setting simply highlights this contrast. 

It used to be an aging homey setting with aging homey and generally fun but un-educational quasi-scientific toys; fun for kids, very slightly educational for adults (but you had to try really hard to a learn anything). The old setting was pleasant if ugly, but quite appropriate to the level of quality of the educational "technology" deployed, which was always fairly poor, and these days is downright terrible. I'm an STEM informal science ed researcher, and have been going to the Exploratorium for 30 years, and it pretty much hasn't changed in all that time. I just assumed that they were too poor to create good teaching technologies, and were just stuck with what they could get starving artists to do. That would have been fine, and I support that. (It's also a science teacher training center, which is great, bcs I'm sure that their "demos" work must much better in a classroom guided discovery setting!)

Well, apparently poor they aren't! But you'd think that being in the world center of science and technology, with some money, they'd have tracked the field, at least a little! But 30 years of advancement in informal science education research seems to have passed them by. All they did was add windows, and move to a high traffic, expensive parking zone. The new place seems FAR more claustrophobic than the old one did, and darker, mostly, I think, because it has low ceilings and tons of walls whereas the old place was essentially one huge room. At least the old one was enjoyable to walk around in. The new one you just want to get out of asap. So the "pleasant" part is completely gone!

So whereas it used to be a fun bad science museum in a pleasant setting, now it's just a bad science museum that you want to get out of asap (and feel bad for having wasted the time in traffic and all day parking price to just hate the experience). 

(I'm a member, and not planning to renew.)
author: Jeff S.

description: Loved this place. Came during Thursday night when it's adults only. It was so much fun to run around and try all the little experiments and interactive activities. They were well explained too. The four hours was almost too short and there was still plenty to do.
author: E E.

description: It is totally cool. My kids are both big science buffs so they did love it. My complaint is not with the content, just the price and enormity of the place. It seems impossible to hit every station in one day, plus after 3-4 hours you are just totally worn out and so are the kids. Would be cool if they could sell tickets based on area at a discounted price.
