So you could spend a few hours in the section you choose for that day and decide if and when you want to come back for the other areas. This would also make it affordable to those that may not have $48 for entrance for one adult and one child. Plus we spent $25 for parking for the day.
author: Joy G.

description: This place is fabulous!  Tons of exhibits, nearly all working! Could spend days here. Much better than any other science museum I have been to. Well worth it.
author: Rich U.

description: Touch all the things! If you dislike kids, stay away from this place. Also arm yourself with an ample amount of antibacterial. I went here for three hours and only got through 1/3 of the place I suspect. It sucks that they're closed on Mondays. All the staff I talked to were super nice and accommodating. I bought an annual pass so I will definitely go back.
author: k h.

description: Was there today with a toddler & preschooler among the hordes. It is definitely not geared for that age group (see also: Chabot Space & Science Center) but my 4 y.o. enjoyed flitting around touching stuff. The 2 y.o. was overstimulated literally within minutes (not to mentioned trampled); would not bring that age if I could do it over again. The outside exhibits (most or all of which are free?) were just as cool and not as mobbed as inside. As another parent said, "There's almost TOO MUCH stuff here." Amen - the jam-packed set-up (hardly room to move between exhibits in some areas) and massive crowds lend themselves to a frenetic atmosphere that my little ones instantly hummed in frequency with (look at me, I'm all sciencey-metaphors now). Try not to bring a stroller inside, it's just too crowded to maneuver it. No kid-sized potties or sinks, and no quiet corners for nursing (or calming down an upset toddler... sigh). Bring your zen and snacks. I don't plan to return until my children can read and comprehend the signage, and even then I wouldn't advise less than a 1:1 parent-child ratio. On the plus side - THANK YOU for making inside bathrooms available before the place opens at 10. My 4 y.o. was not going to make it otherwise! P.S. The bike racks were full at 11:30 on a Sat.
author: Amalia C.

description: Exhibits and stations are 5 stars and the staff as well.  It is terribly crowded and the hours of 10am - 5pm on Saturday...really?  Traffic, parking and crowds makes this a place we won't be back anytime soon unless it is a mid-weekday at 10am.
author: D S.

description: A long fan of the old exploratorium, i was wary of he move and expansion.  I was wrong to doubt!  The new space is fabulous.  It retained the feel of the old space, but with more room and more exhibits.  Well done Exploratorium!  I highly recommend everyone head down and check it out.
author: Julianne r.

description: Cool place, wish they were open later. I arrived around 3, and they told me my tickets were still good for the next day. Makes sense as you need way more than 2 hours (close at 5) to get thru everything. Had fun tho. Would go again.
author: Charlie S.

description: Cool spot right on the pier. They should just call it the Childrens Science Museum of SF because that is what it felt like. At any given time there are hundreds of little kids running around touching every little thing. As an adult I would like to read and enjoy the science exhibits but the mass of little kids just gets in the way. 3 stars because it is being overrun by youngsters.
author: Ryan L.

description: Took my kids here recently.  Wow, it is such a cool place.  We all had a great time with the hands on nature of this museum.  There were a couple of things that were out of order.  But that didn't seem to be a hindrance.  It was pretty crowded and we had to wait for a few things.  But there was so much there that we were able to jump around.  The only negative is that it can be a pretty overwhelming sensory overload.  All in all, we left happy.
author: Robert C.

description: Wow, this place is big! My family of four (ranging in age from 8 to 67), arrived at Exploratorium 1.5 hours before closing time, and saw maybe 1/6 of what they had to offer. Our CityPass tickets still made this a good deal, and we enjoyed everything we got to do. The only disappointment was the additional fee for the Tactile Dome (which we opted not to pay). Plan to stay all day, and know that you still won't have time to do it all!
author: Michelle L.

description: The best museum in San Francisco.  It is entirely hand-on and incredibly inventive.  The Cal Academy is great, but too much video.  I had a great time with the kids, but would have loved it on my own.  The new location is fantastic and beautiful.  It is great fun for kids - even young ones.  There is way too much to see and do for one visit, so just pick a few things that seem fun and enjoy them, too much to try to see everything.
author: Anne F.

description: We went to the exploratorium on a free admission day. As expected, it was very crowded. I think we would have had a lot more fun if we had kids to go with, but just as a couple, a lot of the exhibits were a little too immature for us. We also went as a big group wanting to have fun, so that may have been a fault in our planning. From what I could see though, lots of kids were having fun testing out the exhibits and figuring out what was going on. The fact that it's a hands-on museum was definitely a plus. Because we went on a free day, we didn't feel the pinch of it or feel like the trip wasn't worth it, but otherwise, we might have. Tickets are $25/adult, and parking ends up being about $20 if you plan to spend the 4+ hours you need there to cover everything.
author: Patti M.

description: We went using our City Passes. We used the Light Rail and got there around 9:30. The cafe was open so we bought some muffins. The kids looked at an exhibit outside while we waited. We went in and the kids loved it. They took their time at each exhibit. Then we ate lunch at the restaurant (very pricey) and had to rush through the rest of the exhbits because we knew we wouldnt have enough time. The kids got tickets at 2pm to come back and do art later in the day. They really enjoyed that too. We ended up staying til closing and felt like we didn't have enough time. It would have been nice to have more than one day here. If we lived nearby, it would be a nice place to have passes for.
author: May P.

description: The kids enjoy the different displays, especially the hands on mechanical stuff.  The new location is in a more crowded area and it is a way for them to add high parking fees to your visit.  Also they want to have your car keys, but we didn't let them have ours.  The food is new age, yuppie selections that are high priced and completely unappealing to kids, in a exhibit that is setup for kids that seems pretty stupid.  We actually had to give our daughter a chocolate chip cookie to tide her over because they had nothing that a normal kid would like.  Our son isn't as picky of an eater, but there was nothing that he liked either.  For that matter we were hard pressed to find something we would want.  I also don't appreciate the PC propaganda exhibits that have been added according to San Francisco sensibilities, which are for the mentally deranged.  I also hate San Francisco and preferred the other location so that I could skirt as much of the city as possible and avoid as much of it as possible.
author: S. M.

description: This is a great place for kids and grown ups alike! The new building is amazing and right on the water. Even though it is always crowded I feel like there's enough to do that there's room for everyone. The cafe is very upscale and has gorgeous water views, however it is expensive. It would be nice if there was a less expensive place to eat there.
author: Caroline B.

description: The exploratorium is the kind of place that will bring out the curious kid in you and make you gasp in awe and wonder at the magical world of science. Although as an adult you pretty much know the mechanics behind most of the science-experimenty stuff in the exploratorium, yet, looking at them, tinkering around with them, brings a child-like smile to your face. The place has a bunch of sciency awesomeness with magnets, gyroscopes, mirrors, pendulums, electrostatics, microscopic bacteria and even an live almost-born chicken embryo (it was really awesome to see the little embryo's heart beating through the microscope!). Situated at Pier 17, it's location is also pretty awesome. There is this small patio area that gives you some of the most stunning views of the city skyline and the bay bridge. The reason I give it 4 stars instead of 5 is because I've been to better science exploratory museums in the country (like say the Museum of Science and Industry in Chicago). There is definitely scope for improvement, the ginormous size of the place allows for expansion...so let's see if the exhibits continue to get better over time!
author: Srivatsan S.

description: My first time here and I couldn't do it all in one day!  I parked in Embarcadero 4 parking lot and brought my ticket in for validation, and it ended up only costing $10 for the day.  It is an short walk to the Exploratorium, passed about 2 play structures on the way, breaking it up and having something to look forward to after leaving the museum.  Bring your own hand sanitizer, they don't have dispensers out and the displays are awesome, but hands on.  They hand stamp for for you leave and come back.  We ended up leaving for lunch and did a short walk to Pier 23 Cafe.  It is a lot bigger than it looks.  Wasn't fast and there was a wait for a table, but we dined outside on the patio with a beautiful view and the food was surprisingly good!  They did have a kids menu (hamburger, grilled, cheese, chicken stripes, etc for $8).  Thanks to the previous yelper that mentioned the AAA discount, and they also have a better one (maybe $5 off) for SF Bay Area resident (San Jose was accepted) and she said their teacher or adult student discount was even better (and she did not ask for school ID or any verifying proof).  Next time I will pack a backpack with water, snacks and maybe lunch that we can eat outside.  Glad we brought our jackets, the temperature changed a lot, depending on the sun/shade and wind.  There are lockers there and some of them required you to bring your own lock (or perhaps maybe those are for employees/volunteers?).    It was crowded on a Saturday (not a free day), but most displays we only had to wait after one child for our turn.  Some annoying families there that didn't supervise their kids or ignored the lines and let their kids play endlessly, but probably run into that everywhere.  My GPS was confused, it is not the address on Lyon St, but they moved to Pier 15.  Amazing displays, what a fun day!
author: S. E.

description: It was a fun museum. My husband and I had a great time walking around and exploring science. However- $25 per person seems lost on the venue.
author: Stephanie C.

description: So happy we went to the exploratorium during our time in San Francisco. We went early and thank god we did because there is so much to look at and do. Sure kids would love it, but so do the adults! Had a great time. One con was the food, pricey and quite tasteless. Don't let that take away from this great place though.
author: JJ B.

description: My husband and I came here for our first day on our honeymoon as he and I have never been to San Francisco before. We first tried to go on the Alcatraz Tour but it was sold out until the end of August, but on our way our cab driver had pointed out the Exploratorium. At first I was very hesitant because all I saw were a bunch of schools on field trips, all kids! But once we got inside everything was very trippy and cool. There are a ton of need gagets and gizmos that even as adults my husband and I had a freaking blast. There are neat things like a big bulb that you place over your head lights up with a different color and it can affect your mood, you can drink water out of a toilet bowl (its actually a water fountain), and you can sit this half oval circle square box item and across the room your partner sits in the other half and about 75 feet away from each other you can have a conversation. This place is very cool and it was just renovated. Great place to take the family, kids, or to just even have a great day. It is very close to Pier 39 were more excited things take place. We had a great time and would definitely come back!
author: Victoria C.

description: If you are an engineer or science student or have a generally inquisitive personality, this is the place for you! There are few activities out there which are so engaging. Near the end of four hours here my head felt a bit numb from all the stimulation! The exhibits all seem really well thought out, and you can see them constantly putting out new ones. More over, the new location on the pier is gorgeous, with beautiful views of the Bay.
author: Darren P.

description: We loved it!  We happened upon it on one of the free days and it was amazing.  Kids were able to touch and play with everything and it kept their interest for a long time (ages 3-10 years).  We would highly recommend it, and really wasn't that crowded on the free day.
author: J V.

description: Fantastic interactive museum at its new Pier 15 spot!  Definitely a great spot for kids or a day date with lots of interesting hands-on science exhibits.  Do check out the feature made of toothpicks, featuring scenes of San Francisco.  It took 30+ years to build and is really impressive.  It's perfect for a Saturday morning followed by a visit to the Ferry Building Farmer's Market.  Also, be sure to mention you're a local for a discount.
author: Alice Y.

description: good fun for kids not for 13 and up it tels them about siens
author: Eric Q.

description: Awesome!  My kids (ages 5, 8, 10) loved it (so did I). Wish we had planned more than a couple hours for this. It is loud and crowded so keep track of your kids! As of my visit in June '13 there was no reciprocal program with other science museums around the country, but i was told they were hoping to join soon.
author: Beth S.

description: ok for the price, try not to go when a bunch of school trips there, took away from the experience for my toddler.
author: Jason O.
